Major Lazer's image has always been a bit slippery. Having gone through a number of member and affiliate changes since UK producer Switch—one half of the founding production team
column3: along with Diplo—jumped ship in 2011
column4: their ever-evolving mission has been confusing
column5: sloppy
column6: and not entirely easy to nail down. Their debut album Guns Don't Kill People... Lazers Do was a singular artifact of Diplo's fascination with global dance music
column7: for lack of a better catchall
column8: for which he is often called out as an appropriator. Despite the fact that he and Switch worked on the album in Kingston and recruited dancehall bona fides for every track
column9: from icons like Vybz Kartel and Mr. Vegas to up-and-comers like Brooklyn bashment luminary Ricky Blaze
column10: it was still sticky with an undercurrent of tourism.

column1: But with all of the pitfalls Major Lazer has faced since its inception—solo Diplo's hypeman Skerrit Bwoy's departure for religious pursuits; mismatched guests like Dirty Projectors' Amber Coffman and Ezra Koenig of Vampire Weekend for sophomore album Free the Universe—Peace Is the Mission finds the group finally emerging from their cocoon. What helped to pierce them out of a murky
column2: genre-blurring funk
column3: it turns out
column4: was the confidence (and perhaps the notoriety and resources) to cash in and go full pop.

column1: Even though Diplo already had work with major pop stars on his CV (namely
column2: Beyoncé's ""Pon De Floor""-sampling ""Run the World (Girls)"" and on Madonna's recent Rebel Heart)
column3: it was Major Lazer's inclusion on the Lorde-curated soundtrack for The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 that truly marked this sea change. Their contribution
column4: ""All My Love"" featuring Ariana Grande
column5: maintained their penchant for dancehall-inflected festival dubstep and worked in a winky interpolation of ""Lollipop (Candyman)"" by Aqua (yes
column6: the ""Barbie Girl"" group)
column7: all with a much slicker sheen. The song could have been just another paycheck
column8: a chance to go for polish on a non-album project while staying esoteric with their own work
column9: but lead single ""Lean On""
column10: a collaboration with Danish upstart MØ and DJ Snake of ""Turn Down for What"" fame
column11: indicated that they were sticking to this new refinement.

column1: These tracks also illustrate what Major Lazer excel at: crafting intricate
column2: innovative EDM for honey-voiced singers that pushes boundaries people like David Guetta and Calvin Harris seemingly refuse to touch. Album opener ""Be Together"" with Chicago sibling duo Wild Belle combines breathless yearning and skittering percussion in a way that sounds new
column3: while the warbled soul of ""Powerful""
column4: featuring vocals from Ellie Goulding and reggae artist Tarrus Riley
column5: swoons in a way we don't expect from the production trio. With his performance
column6: stripped of patois and giving every Top 40 pretty boy a run for his money
column7: Riley offers the album's best example of Major Lazer's ability to synthesize their influences. Where the previous two full-lengths tried to mesh opposing forces
column8: here
column9: they are finessed into no-nonsense stadium rattlers. Riley can master an EDM power-ballad
column10: while the menace of a rapper like Pusha T meets its match with dancehall vet Mad Cobra on ""Night Riders"". Even a refreshed ""All My Love"" benefits from additional vocals from soca singer Machel Montano.

column1: ""Lean On"" and ""Powerful"" will likely end up the big hits of Peace
column2: but tracks like ""Too Original"" with Jovi Rockwell and Swedish singer Elliphant
column3: ""Light It Up"" featuring a guest appearance from R&B-reggae duo Brick and Lace's Nyla
column4: and Chronixx-featuring ""Blaze Up the Fire"" also show a group locating its footing. They accomplish the
column5: well
column6: mission the group has trained its sights on since its genesis—and it's because they've linked with artists who also deal in fusion. They're not forcing it. There is no doubt Peace Is the Mission will suffer some criticism from dancehall purists
column7: those exhausted by EDM and people who hate Diplo (a hate that he has certainly worked overtime to earn)
column8: but their maturation is palpable across the album's nine tracks. In the process
column9:
they've made a great pop record through uniting some of the globe's most exciting and celebrated pop artists.

If you pay close attention to the Baton Rouge rapper Kevin Gates’ volatile Instagram feed
column2: you may start to note some similarities between his videos there and his music. The focal point in the IG clips is Gates’ oversized personality
column3: up close and personal (these videos are usually 90% his face in closeup) but somehow inscrutable: You never really see exactly where he is
column4: or what he’s doing
column5: or fully understand the things he’s getting worked up about. In Gates’ rapping
column6: there is the same strange dichotomy of intimacy and mysteriousness: Often
column7: we get a window into an extremely specific and personal story without seeing its full arc. Gates refuses to hold our hand as he zigzags between talking points and styles
column8: which is why we hang on his every word and gesture—we search for context
column9: closure
column10: and understanding
column11: but it's constantly withheld. The video monologues begin and end mid-thought
column12: suggesting a faucet being turned on and off
column13: and his flow
column14: too
column15: is like a source that just has to be been tapped into
column16: rather than started up and wound down.

column1: Increasingly
column2: these days
column3: Gates’ music sounds like an unfiltered representation of his id. It’s less carefully fashioned than on his unerringly catchy Luca Brasi Story or the street-rap style primer By Any Means. On his latest
column4: mini-mixtape Murder for Hire
column5: especially
column6: his emotions and points of inspiration seem to rush in at once
column7: like potential energy suddenly unleashed. Musically and structurally
column8: there are easy comparisons to be made between this release and Atlanta rapper Future’s darkly comic 56 Nights: the scorched-earth
column9: stream-of-consciousness flows
column10: the paranoid atmosphere
column11: the less immediate hooks. The street-rap-Drake-like overtones which surprised on Gates’ 2013 work are barely there; the hooks are chant-based
column12: sometimes pallid rather than craggily soulful.

column1: But unlike Future’s album
column2: there is the lingering impression of Murder for Hire being a follow-up EP of outtakes rather than a carefully streamlined statement (notably
column3: ""Rican Johnny"" shares its primary melody with Luca Brasi 2’s leadoff banger ""John Gotti""
column4: and comes across like another draft of the same song). As on Brasi 2 (released in December)
column5: there are some career highs on Murder for Hire
column6: but it is dramatically less consistent than his previous 2013-14 work. Unlike Brasi 2
column7: however
column8: the lows here are more nondescript than far-flung and strange. This is a rarity for Gates
column9: since one of his strengths has always been transforming near-stock beats and relatively unassuming trap hooks into colossal
column10: immutable rap songs. Still
column11: on forgettable tracks like ""Thuggin Hard in the Trap House"" and ""Her""
column12: the lack of melody and a lynchpin of a primary line undoes him.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: however
column3: he’s busy doing the exact opposite—eerie Autotune d-boy anthem ""Chico"" hinges on the drawn-out cry of ""My Jamaican bring the reefer iiiiinn
column4: a small gesture which elevates a potentially forgettable post-Luger anthem into a standout. The two most impressive tracks on the tape
column5: though
column6: are ""Khaza"" and ""Mexico""
column7: two newfangled trap records on which nothing seems to stay consistent except for that dry
column8: wood-shaving of a snare on beats two and four. ""Mexico"" is restrained
column9: driven by some synth take on an eerie Celtic harp
column10: and features Gates’ sharpest lyrics on the album (""So-and-So broke my jaw with the flash light/ All because I wouldn’t make my pockets look like bunny ears/ Killed a nigga
column11: broke and ran
column12: piss running down my leg/ Went and hid the gun behind the counting house""). ""Khaza""
column13: on the other hand
column14: is one of Gates’ fiercest songs to date
column15: a great hookless wonder full of free-association both hilarious and frightening. A sneering Gucci Mane-like emphasis is built appealingly into his flow throughout (""Free the ‘wop
column16: that’s Gucci
column17: nigga
column18: he cries at the end of the song) and his rapping feels more measured and expressive than anywhere else on the tape.

column1: This is by no means an essential Gates release
column2: but still serves as an interesting document of where he is artistically. Whether future releases will move further away from the warm and inviting hooks of his earlier records (those which helped him
column3: initially
column4: set up a major-label partnership and become a nationally vital act) toward more freeform structure and experimentation remains to be seen. However
column5: Murder for Hire demonstrates that the results will doubtless be unpredictable
column6: full of flights of inspiration and
column7: unfortunately
column8:
some moments when Gates seems to be not all there.

There is no shame in not knowing who In Camera were. Like a few zillion other bands
column2: they formed in the summer of 1978
column3: just as punk rock was turning into post-punk. By the time they recorded their first single
column4: 1980's ""Die Laughing""
column5: they'd clearly had their minds blown by a couple of their contemporaries—especially Bauhaus (for whom they were opening when 4AD's Ivo Watts-Russell first heard them)
column6: Joy Division
column7: and Public Image Ltd. They immediately mastered the tone of that moment's music: echoing minor-key drones
column8: a wailing singer with an unpretty voice
column9: rhythms modified from disco to evoke faltering inhuman mechanisms rather than motion and delight
column10: words that suggested imminent disaster.

column1: But they weren't quite there. Singer/keyboardist David Steiner didn't have the vocal charisma of a John Lydon or Ian Curtis; their songs announced their intent right up front
column2: and then didn't offer any surprises. Listen to In Camera's ""Fragments of Fear"" on its own
column3: and it sounds like a fine example of its time and genre
column4: with guitarist Andrew Gray's dissonant
column5: trebly riff settling over the recording like a clammy fog. Compare it to
column6: say
column7: Bauhaus's superficially similar ""Terror Couple Kill Colonel""
column8: released on the same label a few months earlier
column9: and you hear what's missing. Bauhaus's song offers the dry wit of its tabloid-headline title
column10: Peter Murphy's out-of-nowhere grunting and panting
column11: and details of intonation that refine its repetitions into hooks. In Camera's song just kind of sounds eerie for four-and-a-half minutes.

column1: ""Fragments of Fear"" appeared on In Camera's accurately titled IV Songs EP in late 1980. Around the same time
column2: they recorded three new songs for John Peel's radio show (subsequently released as another EP
column3: Fin)
column4: then broke up before they ever made an album. Guitarist Andrew Gray joined their 4AD labelmates the Wolfgang Press; the whole band reconvened briefly in 1991 to finish off four incomplete songs for a retrospective
column5: 13 (Lucky for Some).

column1: Era
column2: true to its title
column3: doesn't include those four tracks. Instead
column4: it augments the nine songs of In Camera's original discography with a couple of demos
column5: some indistinct live recordings
column6: and a five-song rehearsal tape. For enthusiasts of the goth/post-punk nexus
column7: it absolutely has its moments: ""The Attic"" is carried by sour
column8: hammering chords from Pete Moore's bass guitar
column9: and ""The Fatal Day""—an 11-minute-plus doom-disco jam from their Peel session—hints at the expanses they might have explored if they stuck around a while. It also has some unintentionally funny flashes of insight into the band: the parts of ""Legion"" that aren't a slower knockoff of Gang of Four's ""Anthrax"" mostly seem to be derived from ""Bela Lugosi's Dead"".

column1: But that's fine. Every scene has its geniuses and its hangers-on; pioneers need somebody to follow them. For every band that creates something magnificent and enduring
column2: there are five more who catch on early to their innovations
column3: maybe come up with a couple of good songs
column4: and end up really only being of interest to listeners who are very curious about their great contemporaries' historical context. In Camera were one of those
column5: and there's no shame in that
column6:
either.

André Bratten explores the same depopulated yet emotive spans of synths
column2: drums
column3: and bass as his Norwegian post-disco peers. But he also distinguishes himself with a sound you might peg as Teutonic before Scandinavian. While the likes of Prins Thomas and diskJokke range over earth and space
column4: none cover precisely the furrowed
column5: cratered landscape Bratten claims. Featuring dark hues and rough crags
column6: it inspires visions of low
column7: ore-spined mountains. In an Oslo-producer family portrait

column1: At six tracks
column2: Math Ilium Ion looks like an EP
column3: but its half-hour length and lack of filler makes it feel like an LP. Bratten consistently cultivates ominous tension
column4: even as he instills a certain measure of stubborn optimism
column5: pressing corroded frequenices into diamond-hard melodies. He avoids clear-cut builds and releases
column6: laying parts with their own internal tension in rows and letting their ripple mete out catharsis. This is especially clear on ""Trommer & Bass""

column8: with relentless assassin-like accuracy

column1: Bratten's music has a monstrous mechanical movement
column2: but his tuned toms and chattering patterns are offset with live-feeling accents that rattle in the grid
column3: giving the sense of someone striking a head in real space. The music feels wonderfully self-generative
column4: as if willing itself into being. With its controlled speaker fry and choked-out melody
column5: album highlight ""Yours Sincerely
column6: Andre Bratten"" ingeniously un-crumbles together. Bratten's sounds don't just lurch in; they take shape before our ears. You can picture him slowly turning knobs to tame each wild tone into the groove
column7: which is never far away
column8: even when it decays into textured abstractions that keep alertly pushing it forward.

column1: Though many passages of Math Ilium Ion are highly kinetic
column2: only ""Trommer & Bass"" is ready for the floor. The record's games with time are clearly built with the listener in mind. ""The Little Things
column3: Fools and Kings"" opens with a terrific little near-catastrophe. Many tiny elements seem to accelerate in at different rates but arrive simultaneously at the same place
column4: to be promptly drawn taut with one oozing lump of saw waves. By the time we get to the two ""Misconception"" tracks
column5: mutated rave overtones have subsided into something more like ambient house
column6: deep and broad and full of subtle activity. Since we are fully immersed

column1: The only thing even slightly bothersome about Bratten is that sometimes he doesn’t quite nail the landings
column2: which is strange since he takes so much care until then. The abrupt endings of several tracks are startling after all the subtle permutation we've been through
column3: and a little unsatisfying. But that minor complaint really means that
column4: when so much similar music is available
column5: it's easy to stay invested in these long tracks all the way to the end. When the next groove is always one antsy keystroke away
column6:
that's saying something for Bratten.

column1: She makes a pretty good case for that

column6: bleating vibrato. And the arrangements on How Big are this big: lush and ornate

column1: What really binds How Big together

Josh Martin seems more stunned by the success of Daughn Gibson than most anyone else. In 2012
column2: Martin—the former drummer of a knotty blues-metal band and a big-rig driver to boot—released All Hell
column3: his debut LP under a name just one fancy vowel sound removed from revered country crooner Don Gibson. All Hell arrived as an uncanny wonder
column4: with Martin’s gorgeous and mysterious baritone presiding over an ad hoc band built of soul
column5: country
column6: and soundtrack samples he’d snipped from thrift-store finds. Martin bellowed elliptical tales where lovers discovered the worst in one another
column7: smooth talkers seduced damsels

column1: A daring juxtaposition of disparate forms
column2: it was issued in a tiny domestic edition of only 400 copies
column3: marking it a curio meant for the few weirdos who might catch on. But a lot of people actually caught on—the press
column4: a booking agent
column5: slowly growing audiences
column6: and the label Sub Pop
column7: which signed Daughn Gibson just as All Hell’s dark gospel began to spread. Martin found himself fronting a band expected to tour and record. On 2013’s Me Moan and the uneasy new Carnation

column9: Akron/Family) and a cast of Dunn standbys
column10: including string arranger Eyvind Kang and former Earth multi-instrumentalist Steve Moore. Only Elkington returns. The performances and the production at large are impeccable. The band is as assured with the slinking poses of ""It Wants Everything"" as they are the sashaying cool of ""For Every Bite"" or the string-backed slowness of ""Runaway and the Pyro"".

column1: But that variety—or
column2: less generously
column3: Martin’s halting stylistic indecision—plagues Carnation. For 38 minutes
column4: he seems like an accidental bandleader who has no idea where he’s leading his band
column5: let alone how to get them there. The rudiments of All Hell
column6: from the country touches to the sampler obsession
column7: survive only in the crevices—the baritone guitar echoing around the light new wave pulse of ""Shatter You Through""
column8: the vocal loops bouncing beneath and around it. Martin loosens his grip on that once-dominant baritone
column9: too
column10: sometimes affecting a foppish British accent and occasionally slipping into lounge-singer softness. The indecision starts in the center and spreads
column11: as Martin and crew work through homages to early Soft Machine and depressive Depeche Mode
column12: coruscated Tangerine Dream and languid David Bowie. During ""I Let Him Deal""
column13: he launches into a chorus that could be cut straight from the National’s catalog; for its chaser
column14: ""Shine of the Night""
column15: he nods to LCD Soundsystem and indulges a saxophone solo
column16: even as he sings about staying alive on Iraq’s infamous Highway of Death. The first half of closer ""Back with the Family"" sounds like a Scott Walker fantasy
column17: the second like a Tom Waitsnightmare. There are some bright spots here
column18: especially in the grand attempts at pop
column19: but Martin’s presiding confusion mitigates their album-length impact.

column1: Worst of all
column2: though
column3: is the way these shifts hamper his songwriting. All Hell built big
column4: poignant scenes out of tiny
column5: perfect details. And for all its transitional woes
column6: Me Moan showed Martin to be a vivid
column7: sharp storyteller in the making. He loaded his lyrics with references and sly turns of phrase—the romantic at ""the corner lobo solo … dreamin’ with the TV lit"" or the widower trying to find nostalgic comfort in surrounding sounds and sights. But these lyrics are thin
column8: limpid
column9: and loose. The writing gathers a smattering of soft-focus snapshots
column10: twisted aphorisms
column11: and dimensionless characters. Martin gives us the teenager who’d rather hang himself than turn into a hideous man during ""A Rope Ain’t Enough"" and a young patient who's left a mental hospital during ""Daddy I Cut My Hair"". But we learn so little about each of them
column12: their circumstances or their motives. They seem like mere verbal stand-ins for jams by the Daughn Gibson Big Band. If every Daughn Gibson song used to prompt a mental short film
column13: Carnation is a collage of bad watercolors and corrupted Polaroids.

column1: Gibson’s voice has always echoed another era
column2: but his approach has seemed deliberately contemporary
column3: too
column4: eager to step over stylistic borders and bend the past against the present. Beyond his baritone or assorted honky-tonk accents
column5: that quality is the essential link from All Hell to Me Moan to Carnation. But I like to imagine Daughn Gibson’s trajectory had All Hell been recorded and released in another epoch of the music industry
column6: one where so many strange and stunning private-press records languished in obscurity until being rediscovered decades later. All Hell collected but 10 short songs
column7: some of which seemed like sketches of a nebulous idea
column8: with space for elaboration and edges for refinement. Without the need to meet public expectation or record label demands
column9: what might that aesthetic have become in seclusion?

column1: Perhaps he would have enriched the language and stretched the sounds
column2: as he did on Me Moan. But it seems unlikely that being cloistered would have yielded a record like Carnation
column3: a set of songs that discard almost all sense of Martin’s singularity in favor of a search for anything new that might work. Martin’s uniqueness was the very element that turned him from a tall dude with a deep voice making odd records on a tiny imprint to a troubadour enlisted in an indie empire. But some slight attention has spoiled his significant idiosyncrasy. On Carnation
column4:
he tries and fails to be something other than himself.

'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2015-06-02 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:10:18.347441|"

Shangaan Electro is the sort of genre that you’d assume cultural imperialism would have long ago rendered obsolete: a quirky
column3: hyperlocal sound that’s nothing much like anything else around it or before it. You can attribute its singular nature to the fact it’s
column4: in large part
column5: the creation of one man—Richard Mthethwa
column6: aka Nozinja. A large
column7: avuncular businessman who formerly ran a successful mobile phone repair store in South Africa’s poor
column8: rural Limpopo province
column9: as the story goes
column10: Nozinja heard the music being made by his peers and spied an opportunity.

column1: An electronic
column2: MIDI-powered take on local Shangaan folk traditions
column3: kwaito
column4: and South African house
column5: Nozinja’s productions—which have been the engine of a number of artists and groups
column6: including Tshetsha Boys
column7: B.B.C.
column8: and Zinja Hlungwani—sit somewhere between the naïve and the visionary: catchy constructions of synthesized flute and marimba
column9: dotty drum machine
column10: and soulful romantic entreaties dialed up to the speed of an agitated hummingbird. Even in South Africa
column11: Shangaan Electro appears to have been relatively obscure
column12: a localized sound made for communities
column13: not clubs. But thanks to the support of the Brooklyn documentarian Wills Glasspiegel
column14: Shangaan Electro found its way out of South Africa in 2010
column15: with releases on the London-based Honest Jon's label
column16: remixes from respected producers such as DJ Rashad and Ricardo Villalobos
column17: and Nozinja helming a travelling Shangaan Electro roadshow
column18: performing with Shangaan dancers: men in clown masks and bright orange jumpsuits
column19: women shaking their rumps in big floaty dresses.

column1: Nozinja’s leap to a label such as Warp Records feels significant
column2: to see how Nozinja Lodge might advance its maker’s vision. The sound is slightly more polished—although that might largely be the consequence of a good mastering job—while keyboards add a bit of body
column3: lending a reggae skank to ""Baby Do U Feel Me""
column4: and lacing plaintive descending melodies amongst the freeform snare eruptions of ""Xihukwani"".

column1: If Nozinja Lodge proves anything
column2: it’s that Shangaan Electro’s sense of twitchy acceleration remains fundamental. Playing live
column3: Nozinja gradually tweaks his music faster and faster
column4: introducing each lift in tempo with the booming gusto of a carnival master. Much like footwork
column5: you get the impression his music evolved to cater to the demands of athletic dancing bodies. Consequently
column6: it makes a certain sense that attempts here to temper Shangaan Electro’s frenetic pace don’t always come off. ""Mitshetsho We Zindaba""
column7: a 120BPM bounce
column8: holds its own thanks to a bright palette of bendy keyboards and the hearty call-and-response of a female Shangaan choir. By contrast
column9: album closer ""Wo Va Jaha""
column10: plodding along at ballad tempo
column11: feels somewhat ordinary by comparison. Broadly
column12: Nozinja Lodge’s finest moments—the spry
column13: insistent ""Tsekeleke""
column14: the frenetic pointillism of ""N'wanga I Jesu""—adhere pretty closely to their maker’s celebrated original 180BPM template.

column1: That Shangaan Electro has made waves outside of South Africa feels to be a lot to do with its weird collision of signifiers: lo-fi electronic sounds that Western listeners might consider tacky or tinpot
column2: fused to an African singing style that speaks of love
column3: yearning
column4: and other matters of the heart with earnest sincerity. Post-Diplo
column5: the modern DJ set can feel like a finger smeared across borders
column6: cultural forms dissolved into beige global mulch. But unlike
column7: say
column8: footwork
column9: Nozinja’s music defies such easy assimilation. Almost devoid of low-end
column10: and presented with a sunny spirit generally incompatible with gangsta posturing
column11: it’s a sound that—in unremixed form
column12: at least—amiably refuses to be absorbed.

column1: Consequently
column2: it remains hard to determine Shangaan Electro’s significance to dance music at large. Who could copy it
column3: without sounding absurd? Of course
column4: in the context of Nozinja Lodge as a self-contained ""artist"" album
column5: all that hardly matters. Instead
column6:
it serves as a reminder we should treasure these rare outliers wherever we find them.

Deonte Hoard. Giovanni Matos. Savon Davis. Jennifer Ponton. Amari Sutton. Nicole M. Towns. Javante Linson. Terrell Campbell. Anthony Diaz. Uchenna Agina.
These are a few of the 150-plus people killed by gun violence in Chicago so far in 2015. All of these names (and the ones I don’t have the space to list) are important
column2: but for 22-year-old Durk ""Lil Durk"" Banks the last name hits incredibly close to home. Agina (better known as OTF Chino) was Durk’s manager
column3: a confidante who was
column4: in a cruel sense of irony
column5: murdered after meeting with Bulls player Joakim Noah in an attempt to partner Durk with the latter’s anti-violence organization. It’s doubly frustrating given Durk’s affiliation with French Montana’s Coke Boys imprint
column6: which recently suffered the loss of rising member Chinx Drugz. Durk’s first studio album (he’s released 5 mixtapes overall) since signing to Def Jam back during the Great Chicago Rap Gold Rush a few years back
column7: <i>Remember My Name
column8: is a project that has the spectre of death looming over it at all times.

column1: A common criticism of Durk’s music revolves around his near-total dependency on Auto-Tune. He’s aware of the charge
column2: addressing it on ""What Your Life Like"". The software is Durk’s friend when he adopts a singing delivery
column3: like on single ""Like Me"". The tune showcases Durk (and featured crooner/fellow Chicagoan Jeremih) in his lane fully
column4: producing a smooth entry into the pantheon of Sensitive Thug jams. Other times
column5: like on the absolutely grating ""Tryna' Tryna'"" or when he tries to feebly hit high notes during the chorus on
column6: uh
column7: ""Higher"" it can be his worst enemy. Luckily
column8: the highs outweigh the lows. It’s apparent after a few listens that Durk is only getting better
column9: from both a rapping and writing perspective. He’s definitely grown from his earlier mixtapes (he sounds like a different person entirely than the one who once rapped <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MntLMkF1z2c"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Yo' bitch know she doin' dick
column10: we call that ho double D."" Growth! Progression! Artist Development!).

column1: It’s apparent that Durk has a solid ear for production and a nascent ability to craft songs that get caught in your ear. The C-Sick-produced opener ""500 Homicides"" is a thunderous intro that finds Durk viciously addressing enemies
column2: shouting out his affiliates and reminding folks that there are repercussions of your online actions. ""What’s up with this Twitter beef?/ Thought we was keeping in the streets?.../ Hell yeah
column3: you can die over a retweet!""

column1: Remember My Name as an album isn’t going to change lives. It is
column2: however
column3: a view into the psyche of those who reframe the concept of death as a way of life
column4: a cost of doing business
column5: or even a source of motivation to create a better life for yourself and those you care about. On the album standout ""What Your Life Like""
column6: Durk laments
column7: ""They say the murder started after L’s/ Now my phone got shit to tell... /Got that call
column8: they cancelled 20 shows/ That's money down the drain/ I got kids
column9: don't take it wrong.""

column1: The moment underlines a curious tension for Durk and the other artists in his orbit. The culture of the neighborhoods that produced Durk
column2: his OTF (Only The Family) affiliates and the rest of the various artists who find their sounds lazily lumped together under the name ""drill music"" find themselves in a weird catch-22. You rap about the stuff you’re seeing (and participating in
column3: for some) and you’re rewarded with money
column4: fame and the opportunity to make your life better. At the same time
column5: you’re branded as ""trouble"" by promoters
column6: your profile is raised among the police and old enemies
column7: and you’re forced to go on the defensive. The thing that might make your life better might be the same thing that ends up killing you. What in the hell are you supposed to do? On Remember My Name
column8:
Durk chooses to keep on keepin’ on.

Amir Alexander is 42 years old
column2: and Love & Fear is his debut album. A former Army brat who eventually settled in Chicago
column3: Alexander has been DJing since 1993 and making music for nearly as long
column4: but he only began releasing records around 2008. In that light
column5: the cover image of a mountain climber scaling a snowy peak at a 45-degree angle has a slight autobiographical tinge: In electronic music
column6: full-lengths always tend to constitute milestones
column7: but for an artist like Alexander
column8: who has made his name later than many
column9: there's a palpable sense of raised stakes.

column1: Appropriate for someone with such a deep and abiding investment in a scene
column2: Alexander uses Love & Fear to contend with the legacy of American techno. Any attempt to extend that legacy raises questions: How do you evoke a classic sound when innovation was central to that tradition? Can you pay tribute to your roots without the music withering on the vine? Making do with the same sorts of synthesizers and drum machines that have dominated dance music for the past quarter-century
column3: his response is to worry less about novel sound design and focus on his machines'—and his own—expressive capabilities.

column1: One way he does that is to explore a far wider range of tempos than most. ""A Virtuous Woman!"" treads a strange
column2: slow-motion path
column3: stepping and strutting
column4: as a scaly bassline ties itself up in writhing knots
column5: and atonal bleeps suggest the ghost of Kraftwerk's ""Numbers"". The title track is even slower
column6: with a stately synthesizer melody that braids itself around snapping
column7: deliberate hi-hats and rimshots. Even sitting in your chair
column8: you can tell that it's a track made for dancers
column9: an invitation to move the body in different ways. ""The Blues (Never Had)""
column10: even slower
column11: offers the opportunity to get horizontal: smeared in jazzy chords
column12: pitch-bent keyboard solos
column13: and meandering vocals
column14: it's a narcotic funk number
column15: while ""Tranquility Base!"" dials up the tempo to footwork's high-flying range. It's woozier than most footwork
column16: though
column17: with tightly syncopated rimshots banging like a screen door in a storm
column18: and hi-hats spinning like a wheel that can't get traction. ""That's how I feel inside
column19: sings a doleful voice
column20: as chilly Juno pads voice even chillier chords
column21: buzzing and bracing as an ice-cream headache. The only tranquility here is an overarching sense of numbness.

column1: He also experiments with instrumentation—""A Child Is Born"" pairs the chimes of '90s electronica with the fat
column2: rich tones of a church organ—and with themes not often represented in techno. In ""Nordisk Saga!""
column3: he looks north for inspiration and overlays his moody synths and sparse drums with a dramatic reading of a Nordic saga written by Cecilia Bruun Hansen
column4: all crisp consonants and alien-sounding vowels and rolled ""R""s
column5: and references to Freyja and Ragnarok. He presumably got the idea from his time in Malmö
column6: where he lives for part of the year. But given how often white European producers have appropriated African-Americans' voices—all those tracks made with Martin Luther King Jr.'s ""I Have a Dream"" speech
column7: for instance—Alexander's Scandinavian gambit also amounts to a clever turning of the tables.

column1: But at the root of Alexander's music is a simple knack for what makes sounds come alive
column2: both on the dance floor and off. The three relatively straight-down-the-middle techno/house cuts here are among the most immediate
column3: attention-grabbing work he's produced yet
column4: although none of them quite nail the spooky transcendence of 2013's ""Don't Go"". In ""Tight Situations""
column5: carefully deployed dissonance sends chills down the spine
column6: and he shows off his arranger's chops with counterpoints that sneakily keep evolving. ""Moist Flesh!"" is a warm bath of swelling pads and playful plucked leads. And the crowning glory of it all is ""Komm
column7: süßer Tod
column8: komm selge Ruh!""
column9: which takes its title from one of Bach's 69 Sacred Songs and Arias. The bassline takes the form of a gnarled
column10: shape-shifting throb; the background swirls with metallic chirps; and as the track patiently unfolds
column11: it gives way to a wild
column12: psychedelic cadenza reminiscent of one of Prince's guitar solos. ""Come sweet death
column13: come blessed rest
column14: is the translation of the title
column15: and the song's graceful chord changes echo the sentiment
column16: faintly. But that solo tells another story; there's too much struggle in Alexander to stop here. That peak on the album cover will be scaled
column17:
come hell or high water.

The sampler is a memory machine. This is true in both the literal sense—memory is one of the device’s key specs
column2: measuring how much sonic information it can hold in its ""mind"" at once—but also as a metaphor. When you capture and play back a sound
column3: transposing it to a new context
column4: you are ""playing"" the memories that have attached themselves to the original piece of music as much as you are playing a particular piece of sound. The producer Jamie Smith
column5: better known to the world as Jamie xx
column6: is a sampling artist and a memory artist. He does things with the music he's absorbed and with the associations that are embedded within it. So when we listen to his music
column7: we aren’t just listening to music played by people in a room. We’re listening to his listening and hearing his hearing; he senses memories in certain sounds—some of which he was there to experience the first time
column8: some of which have been handed down to him—and transforms them into something new and personal.

column1: In Colour
column2: Jamie xx’s full-length solo debut
column3: has been a rumor for a few years now. In 2011
column4: he followed his remix collaboration with Gil Scott-Heron
column5: We’re New Here
column6: with his debut single ""Far Nearer"". It was strikingly different from his work with the xx and hearing it
column7: it was possible to triangulate and imagine the broader and more varied sensibility that served as an umbrella over both. The emergence of Jamie xx as a producer’s voice is part of what made the xx’s follow-up
column8: Coexist
column9: disappointing. It’s a decent record
column10: but once we had a better sense of Jamie xx’s range
column11: it was hard to square that knowledge with the narrow aesthetic parameters of his main band
column12: lovely as their music could be. All along
column13: this one was coming together. One of the great things about him is he works slow and gets everything just so
column14: treating each project as the one chance to get it right. In Colour gets there: it’s the dazzling culmination of Jamie xx’s last six years of work
column15: gathering up elements of everything he’s done—moody ballads
column16: floor-filling bangers
column17: expansive and off-kilter collaborations with vocalists—and packing them tightly into a glittering ball that reflects spinning fragments of feeling back at us.

column1: A key idea embedded in the notion of rave is it had something for everyone. Though rave was at one point very fashionable
column2: it was also
column3: early on and at its best
column4: egalitarian. The platonic ideal of the dancefloor
column5: which is obviously never quite fulfilled
column6: is that the dancers meet as equals. Everyone is on their own journey and there is no judgement
column7: and the right drugs at the right time have helped to bring this starry-eyed vision to life. Jamie xx’s music captures some of this spirit by being terribly hip and of-the-moment but also deeply emotional. It’s ""cool"" music designed to make you feel
column8: and the mechanism is vulnerability.

column1: There are passages on In Colour where the music is huge and anthemic while being simultaneously open and intimate. Opening track ""Gosh"" is the table-setter. It builds
column2: one loop upon the next
column3: each new brick of groove slotting into place
column4: until it becomes a sky-scraping edifice whose call-to-motion is impossible to resist. And then
column5: just as the last tightly-bound fixture is put into place
column6: there comes a squelchy
column7: slightly awkward synthesizer solo that sounds like it was knocked off in one hurried take by someone who approaches the instrument with the excitement of a newcomer. When the keyboard falls in
column8: which is still exciting and surprising after many dozens of plays
column9: it’s as if our tower of sound is suddenly crowned by a massive cluster of balloons that lifts it into the sky
column10: Up style.

column1: The view from this vantage point never flags. ""Sleep Sound"" takes a sample of the Four Freshmen’s ""It’s a Blue World"" and gently cuts it into pieces
column2: the voice tumbling through time in a manner not unlike what the Field’s Axel Willner did to the Flamingos' ""I Only Have Eyes for You""
column3: but the whole thing is filtered and submerged
column4: a dream of water that’s soothing even as it hints of drowning. ""I Know There's Gonna Be (Good Times)"" features rapper Young Thug and dancehall vocalist Popcaan and while the combination of the three was iffy on paper
column5: they wind up clicking. Thug is bursting with joy as he delivers profane couplets in his sing-song cadence
column6: and Popcaan grounds the music and forms a bridge to the ragga of Jamie xx’s jungle heroes. As the album moves on
column7: Jamie xx moves through styles and textures
column8: everything unified by his highly attuned ear.

column1: Three tunes find Jamie xx collaborating with his bandmates
column2: and
column3: like ""Good Times""
column4: they show how well he straddles the line between ""song"" and ""track."" ""Stranger in a Room""
column5: featuring Oliver Sim
column6: could be a (very good) xx song and is the only thing here that seems like it could have come from the band. Romy’s melody on ""SeeSaw"" is all hushed confession mixed with longing
column7: but instead of spare guitar and drums
column8: Jamie xx surrounds it with breakbeats and a pulsing synth that suggests the cosmos
column9: merging the closest possible feelings with the vastness of the infinite. ""Loud Places""
column10: making brilliant use of a sample of jazz drummer Idris Muhammad’s ""Could Heaven Ever Be Like This""
column11: is a song of contrast in the manner of ""SeeSaw"". But the sample on ""Loud Places"" is warmer and more inclusive
column12: and it’s followed by a brilliantly simple lyric about club-going loneliness and desire that might make Morrissey jealous: ""I go to loud places/ To search for someone/ To be quiet with.""

column1: That clash of feeling
column2: of being overwhelmed by everything at once while also wanting to zoom in on and live inside the tiniest detail
column3: is the animating force of In Colour. Late in the album
column4: the rush comes to a head on ""The Rest Is Noise""
column5: a track that functions as the flipside to ""Gosh""
column6: the party turned inside out
column7: as shouting abandon gives way to a huge wash of yearning. There’s even a small nod to ""Gosh""’s synth break as the album seems to return from where it started. It makes me think of a comment from Jamie xx regarding one of the record’s most modest tracks
column8: ""Obvs""
column9: which is is driven by a steel drum lead. Jamie xx is fascinated by the instrument and has returned to it regularly
column10: describing its appeal like this: ""You can make it sound quite melancholy…but at the same time
column11:
it reminds me of paradise."" It’s not a bad description of how In Colour works. It’s the album as raucous party where the thrill of the moment never quite obliterates the wistful sadness that comes from knowing it will all end too soon.

"|20458.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20458-in-colour/|9.3|Mark Richardson

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21679/homepage_large.e5bcb308.jpg|Algiers|32840.0|Algiers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2015-06-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:10:20.993794|"

Algiers are a heavy band
column2: though not so much in sound as in effect—they’re getting shit off their chest and piling it directly onto yours. Raised in the American South
column3: they personify the foot-stomped physicality
column4: call-and-response communiques
column5: and outsized oration of the church
column6: but their music is the anti-gospel. Rather than promote uplift
column7: out-of-body ecstasy
column8: and communion with the heavens
column9: Algiers weigh you down with the burden of American history
column10: a despair born of centuries of systemic oppression
column11: and the soul-crushing futility of hoping for a change that never comes. Though they project the righteous indignation required of all great protest music
column12: their music doesn’t so much represent a raised fist as a shoulder aching from the stress of trying to keep it aloft.

column1: On their website
column2: Algiers present a crazy quilt of musical and philosophical touchstones
column3: which include everyone from Malcolm X and Angela Davis to Alejandro Jodorowsky and Basquiat to Public Enemy and Ian Svenonius. Their music is likewise a pastiche of transgressive rock signifiers: the soul-powered activism of early '70s Motown
column4: the proto-punk fury of the MC5
column5: the synth primitivism of Suicide
column6: the biblically charged drama of the Bad Seeds. But if the 11 songs on Algiers’ self-titled debut draw from familiar record-collector reference points
column7: they’re radicalized by the context in which they’re being presented. Algiers are hardly the first biracial band to emerge from the indie-rock industrial complex
column8: however
column9: they are distinguished by their eagerness to make discussions of race the foundation of their ideological agenda
column10: the gasoline-soaked fuse that sets their songs alight. For Algiers
column11: signing to Matador isn’t just a means to reach more people; it’s an opportunity to thrust the modern African-American experience in the faces of an audience who rarely have to grapple with it.

column1: Though steeped in Southern tradition
column2: Algiers could not exist without all mod cons: with frontman Franklin James Fisher now based in New York
column3: and guitarist Lee Tesche and bassist Ryan Mahan situated in London
column4: the trio pieced the album together through transatlantic file swaps
column5: atop bed tracks built through programmed beats or their own hyperactive hands and feet. But while the band have taken the somewhat inevitable step of recruiting a proper drummer—Bloc Party’s Matt Tong—for their current North American tour
column6: the songs on Algiers hardly feel like rough sketches begging for full-band embellishment. The brittle beats are crucial to establishing the album’s often suffocating atmosphere: on the mournful opener ""Remains""
column7: a chain-gang stomp provides a none-too-subtle evocation of America’s slave-trading past
column8: while Fisher’s anti-television invective highlights the modern form of captivity that’s replaced it; the we-shan’t-overcome dejection of ""Blood"" is chillingly framed by a tambourine rattle and handclap that feel like lashes from a whip. ""Four hundred years of torture
column9: four hundred years a slave
column10: Fisher seethes on the latter song
column11: as Tesche’s spasmodic guitar squeals emit sparks. But the noise ultimately relents
column12: and the beat goes on
column13: all while Fisher ruefully repeats the line ""all my blood’s in vain.""

column1: Though Algiers’ debut is dropping in the midst of a flashpoint in American race relations
column2: Fisher’s lyrics avoid ripped-from-the-headlines reportage for a more existential angst. These songs were written before Ferguson and Baltimore
column3: but they ultimately exist to remind us that such flare-ups aren’t the shocking aberrations that news networks make them out to be
column4: but the inevitable
column5: recurring spillover of a frustration that’s been simmering for centuries and will continue to in perpetuity. Accordingly
column6: the savvily sequenced Algiers ebbs and flows between moments of gritted-teeth tension and furious release
column7: its solemn
column8: confession-booth ruminations offset by heart-racing
column9: steeple-toppling rave-ups—like ""And When You Fall""
column10: ""Old Girl""
column11: and the planet-rockin’ ""Irony. Utility. Pretext.""—that fulfill the prophecy of a power-music electric revival anticipated by some fellow Atlantans 15 years ago. While their messaging can sometimes be overshadowed by pulpit-thrashing theatrics (see: the provocatively titled but erratic ""Black Eunuch"")
column12: Algiers can also harness their jittery energy to sublime effect: the piano-powered dub strut ""But She Was Not Flying"" contrasts the album’s most relaxed
column13: easy-going rhythm with Fisher’s most incendiary
column14: exasperated vocal performance
column15: representing the mid-album peak where Algiers truly find their groove.

column1: Despite their gravely serious demeanor and fierce intellect—this band doesn’t so much give interviews as present thesis defenses—Algiers ultimately value accessibility: from the participatory hand-clapped hysterics to their callback-ready refrains to their conflation of church congregations and circle pits
column2: these songs beg for audience engagement and strength-in-numbers support. And if the album proves unrelentingly pessimistic in its worldview

column4: disorienting ambient fog

column6: as if to chase away the album’s dense
column7: dark cloud cover with a ray of light. Algiers are never so naive as to assure us that a change is gonna come but
column8: as that brief denouement suggests
column9: in their hardened hearts
column10:
they haven’t completely given up on the possibility.

Monds-Watson writes like she's ready to fall in love and get her heart broken a hundred times over—like she's hungry to feel everything the way a lot of 18-year-olds are hungry to feel everything. ""When you're young and reckless/ You should not be stopped

The music of now-defunct Canadian trio AIDS Wolf was as bold and confrontational as their name. It was a blare of frenetic energy and rhythmic bludgeoning. Beneath all the prog-punk brutality lurked actual song structures
column2: the kind that could easily hypnotize anyone with the patience to uncover them. But no matter how long you stuck with them
column3: AIDS Wolf always managed to incite dizziness through chaos.

column1: In his solo project Drainolith
column2: AIDS Wolf guitarist Alexander Moskos has a similar goal
column3: but comes at it from an opposite side. Where his former band built an in-your-face wall
column4: Moskos’ sound is all skeleton. The moving parts and overlapping shapes that motor his songs are in clear view. He’s not afraid to get dense and noisy too
column5: but you can always hear a Drainolith tune being built
column6: each element working to find its place. Beats fall down and get back up; shards of guitar riffs build into loops; somnambulant moans glide by
column7: then dive into the music’s crevices.

column1: On Hysteria
column2: the follow-up to Drainolith’s 2012 debut Fighting!
column3: everything emerges in semi-slow motion. It’s as if there's a faster
column4: tighter version of these songs out there somewhere that Moskos could catch up to if he felt like it. But he’s more interested in wrestling the ghosts of those imagined tunes than inhabiting their bodies. The effect is disorienting but intoxicating—music designed to sneak up rather than overwhelm.

column1: Especially mesmerizing is the way Moskos fuses together melodies while simultaneously wrenching them apart. It feels like you should be able to hum along to these songs—and in places you can—but it's all skewed enough to dodge predictability. Moskos grafts together parts that don’t naturally fit in a way that recalls Captain Beefheart’s misshapen anti-songs
column2: but his aura is much woozier
column3: almost lethargic. Yet Hysteria rarely settles into grooves that allow passive listening. Moskos may sound like a stoner
column4: but that's because he wants you to feel foggy and confused rather than comfortable.

column1: This smoky haze comes across in Moskos’ words
column2: too. During ""Inside and Outside (Bog’s Blues)""
column3: he sounds like he’s not even sure he’s awake: ""The structure of my sleep/ Is different this time
column4: he slurs
column5: practically drooling onto the pillow. In the drifting
column6: beat-less ""Joy Road""
column7: he whispers that ""Sometimes it seems like everything’s/ Moving too damn fast.../ Slow it down/ Move the ground/ Watch it shake."" Moskos’ zombified delivery recalls the sleep-walk of Excepter’s John Fell Ryan. But where that band often sounds like deconstructed disco
column8: Drainolith is more like fractured rock—rock whose muscles have been stretched so much its bones dislodge and rattle against each other.

column1: There’s also a hint of broken blues to Hysteria that recalls the more drug-addled side of Royal Trux. That’s not surprising
column2: since Neil Michael Hagerty produced this session
column3: which also resulted in the excellent Dan’l Boone record featuring Hagerty
column4: Moskos
column5: and Wolf Eyes’ Nate Young. But such comparisons just reveal Moskos’ very particular take on rock
column6: an approach that resolutely eschews expected patterns. The result is a kind of blissful cognitive dissonance
column7:
making Hysteria’s 25 minutes feel wonderfully longer.

Tanner Anderson barely has time to end his guarantee of our collective mortality—or that ""the same fate comes for us all
column2: as he roars halfway through ""Anlace and Heart""—before his guitar begins to exalt the proclamation. His squealing solo takes a simple riff for a short
column3: jubilant ride
column4: as if he’s a glam-metal headliner leaning back with his eyes closed. He pushes notes together and pulls them apart
column5: the carousel-like movement of the melody suggesting delight in the face of death. Like most of Aria of Vernal Tombs
column6: the captivating second album by Anderson’s metal-and-medieval-music amalgam Obsequiae
column7: ""Anlace and Heart"" explores cycles of birth
column8: death
column9: and rebirth. Greek gods battle with nervous mortals. Seasons shift
column10: so that needles drop from tired tamarack branches. People weep as once-happy homes succumb to senescence. Jumping between black metal and doom
column11: death metal and delicate interludes played on a medieval harp
column12: the music animates all of these ideas
column13: turning centuries of dark thoughts into 44 bright
column14: momentous minutes.

column1: Anderson appears to be invested in intersections
column2: or what the lessons of the past can say about the present and what seemingly disconnected forms of music (metal and otherwise) can afford one another. He has clocked nearly two decades in the metal underground
column3: that time split between the grim doom act Celestiial and Obsequiae precursor Autumnal Winds. Recently
column4: he’s been playing harp and assorted acoustic instruments in Hiraeth Eschar
column5: the eerie soundscape project of Agalloch bassist Jason William Walton. At last
column6: Aria of Vernal Tombs aggregates and unifies all those experiences
column7: synthesizing them into songs that fold Anderson’s passions into singular sweeping motions. Obsequiae’s previous album
column8: Suspended in the Brume of Eos
column9: aimed for a similar end
column10: but it often felt self-conscious and separated
column11: its rigid parts coexisting on a record rather than cooperating. (It’s symptomatic of that record’s try-hard approach that Anderson and the band’s former drummer took the names of prominent 12th-century musicians in the credits.) But on Aria
column12: where most tracks interlock with their neighbors
column13: the vivid black metal of ""Wilweorthunga"" flows perfectly from the triumphant solo that closes ""In the Absence of Light"" and into a pensive
column14: dense instrumental meditation. That sequence captures the sprawl of Anderson’s interests in less than 10 minutes.

column1: Metal has a dirty habit of embracing bygone eras and appropriating historic symbols and stories without actually incorporating how those times might have sounded or felt into the music. It’s easy and alluring to slap a painting of a Viking feast or an ancient battle scene on a record cover or a name in a song title
column2: more sophisticated and subtle to make those elements a dynamic and vital component of the finished product. Obsequiae plunders the past
column3: of course. The cover of their debut featured a detail of a 15th-century fresco
column4: where a regal woman posed among unicorns and other strange
column5: smiling beasts. Likewise
column6: Aria of Vernal Tombs offers a gorgeous scene of ruins at the gloaming. And a third of Aria’s tracks are atmospheric harp solos
column7: augmented only by the glow of echo.

column1: But the real power of Aria of Vernal Tombs stems from how deliberately and diligently Obsequiae integrate these elements into the main event—that is
column2: the metal. Anderson’s methodical grammar
column3: antiquated vocabulary
column4: and rich reference library offer the impression that you’re opening an ancient
column5: sealed text. It’s no coincidence that the liner notes come printed on stained paper that appears to be centuries old. Sure
column6: that sounds pretentious
column7: but the same principle actually makes the music thrilling. The guitar solos
column8: for instance
column9: often mirror the action of the harp
column10: and vice versa. At the opening of ""Anlace and Heart""
column11: Anderson’s pace and polyphony suggest the interlocking melodies of Vincent la Camera Mariño’s harp interludes. The album opens with a harp piece
column12: the notes piling into thickets and then spreading into thin strings. When a bell tolls after three minutes and the grand anthem ""Autumnal Pyre"" begins
column13: it seems less like a new song and more like Anderson and drummer Andrew Della Cagna have simply replaced Mariño. Anderson sings through refracted black metal shrieks. The drums swing between blast beats and an unwavering march. Topped with arching
column14: heroic guitars
column15: however
column16: the music is of a piece with its instrumental predecessor
column17: a modern update of several classic obsessions. The past becomes more than a sales pitch.

column1: Despite Anderson’s longevity
column2: he and his bands have existed in relative obscurity to date. But Aria of Vernal Tombs should help change that. Its deft reach across multiple metal aisles and resplendent
column3: refined sense of presentation and production recall the recent successes of Agalloch and Chris Black’s assorted projects. Such gradual movement and improvement dovetail well with Anderson’s philosophy of slow
column4: almost ecclesiastic change. Obsequiae have matured into a great band
column5:
Anderson a brilliant leader. It’s as though being very aware of an inevitable end helped him make Aria of Vernal Tombs count.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21812/homepage_large.0a40eea0.jpg|Frankie Knuckles: House Masters|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Defected']|2015-05-29 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:10:25.030881|"

Frankie Knuckles died last year at the age of 59; here is a retrospective which seeks to bring his art to life in the wake of his passing. Or an aspect of it: at the core of Frankie's music was his work as a DJ
column2: and it's heartbreaking that future generations will be denied the experience of his dancefloors. Much like the genre he forged in parties at the Warehouse in the late 1970s and early 1980s
column3: his work as a producer was an extension of the singular sensibility of a man behind turntables. Frankie Knuckles' credits as a producer will secure his legacy in his absence
column4: even as they remain bronzed touchpoints in a grander journey.

column1: Although it's not the first compilation of Frankie's production work
column2: House Masters is by some distance the most ambitious. Earlier summations focused on his groundbreaking material of the 1980s
column3: when songs like ""Baby Wants to Ride"" (which also appears here) and ""It's a Cold World"" (which does not) were part of house music's big bang; when each new record contained the DNA of thousands to follow. But the Defected label's House Masters—the profits from which benefit the Frankie Knuckles Fund/Elton John AIDS Foundation—looks at the bigger picture of Knuckles' recording career
column4: spanning from early records like ""Your Love"" (originally heard during Frankie's sets at the Power Plant in the mid-1980s) all the way to 2011's shimmering
column5: quivering ""I'll Take You There"".

column1: Those two records
column2: both of which feature the yearning vocals of Jamie Principle
column3: bookend this compilation
column4: an argument for the continuity of Knuckles' vision across four different decades—five if we consider the groundwork he laid as a DJ at the Warehouse in the late 1970s. Rather than pay lip service to his longevity while highlighting a narrow fraction of it
column5: House Masters treats his formative years as first steps in a lifelong journey as a recording artist. House music may have de-emphasized artist-driven careers in favor of democratic dancefloors
column6: but taking a focused look at Frankie Knuckles as an auteur with a lengthy résumé not only unearths forgotten singles deserving of more attention
column7: but refracts back upon his earliest
column8: most well known material
column9: pulling new insights from well-worn releases.

column1: That is
column2: if you purchase the CD version. Due to licensing restrictions
column3: the version of House Masters available digitally in the United States switches out certain records in favor of others
column4: and appends two bonus tracks. This alternate tracklist doesn't feature any bad songs
column5: but it's a much less cohesive listen. The success of this compilation
column6: appropriately for an artist who was a DJ first and foremost
column7: is as much about its meta-narrative—the deliberate shape of the project as a whole
column8: and what it says about Frankie's career. Defected has said as much in the press around the project
column9: which suggests Frankie was responsible for ""hand-selecting"" the records that made the cut. He passed away a month after planning began
column10: and while the label isn't specific about his contributions to its final state
column11: whoever did sign off built the original tracklist with care. The alternate version
column12: despite adding two additional songs
column13: has moments of incoherence: the emotional punch of Rufus and Chaka Khan's house dub ""Ain't Nobody (Hallucinogenic Version)"" feels like a lynchpin of the original
column14: and hearing Quentin Harris and Ultra Naté's ""Give It 2 U (Frankie Knuckles' Gagatha Christie Mix)"" in its place is disorienting.

column1: Whether you're a house novice or a dance music savant
column2: House Masters (in its original form) inscribes a new and invigorating story about who Frankie Knuckles was
column3: and who he will be for the future. If one quality connects the disparate sounds of his work from every era
column4: snaking its way through the full range of his discography
column5: it is a sensation of expressive confidence. Too often confused with the self-serious theater of masculinity
column6: for Frankie
column7: confidence was about muscular vulnerability
column8: both as an m.o. and the texture of his art. Take
column9: for example
column10: 1983's driving edit of First Choice's 1977 disco classic ""Let No Man Put Asunder""
column11: a stand-in here for his earliest days as a disco DJ. Although he wasn't the first to extend the 4 minute 30 second record into dancefloor-friendly shape (Walter Gibbons remixed it several years earlier)
column12: Frankie's had the more forceful groove
column13: pointing to the direction Chicago would soon shift the country.

column1: The self-assuredness of his early work helps explain how a New York DJ who'd moved to a far-flung flyover like Chicago dramatically reoriented the sound of dance music nationally. In the city of broad shoulders
column2: where the streets are wide and even Chicago's classical trumpet players are known for their large-bore
column3: powerful ""Chicago sound""
column4: Frankie Knuckles spread his wings as a DJ
column5: and as this collection suggests
column6: as a producer as well. As a compilation of mainly 6-8 minute house records

column8: as peak time anthems for the party's emotional climax

column1: Perhaps the best example is the grandeur of Sounds of Blackness' 1991 single ""The Pressure (Frankie Knuckles Classic Mix)"". Knuckles doesn't merely dare the audience to adjust to its slow

in full bloom.

Dub is a way of tunneling through space-time. Like hanging two mirrors opposite one another in a small room
column2: it opens a window upon the infinite. Dub burrows an endlessly regenerating maze through the otherwise finite confines of the mixing desk. Paul Dickow's Noise Tape Self goes one step further: it tries to wring infinity out of a single cassette tape.

column1: Dickow
column2: who lives in Portland
column3: Ore.
column4: has made a lot of different kinds of music over the years. His debut LP
column5: 2003's Strut
column6: was a homebrewed response to the blippy
column7: squirrelly sounds then coming from UK labels like Planet Mu and Rephlex. His '00s releases for Kranky veered into dubby ambient music indebted to Pole and Arthur Russell. He's no stranger to the dance floor—disco and Afrobeat often linger at the edges of his music
column8: beckoning—but he seems most at home in pursuit of headier ideals. On this year's Seeds of Paradise
column9: for the Bristol bass-music label Idle Hands
column10: and Pods of Punishment
column11: for the experimentally inclined Entr'acte
column12: he has ventured ever deeper into a sound of his own making

column14: ambient
column15: and DIY electronics.

column1: Noise Tape Self is the most focused thing he's done
column2: and it's also the most experimental. Its six tracks date from between 2008 and 2010
column3: and all of them were made using an arcane system of Dickow's own devising. At the risk of getting too technical
column4: it's worth explaining his process in some detail
column5: simply because it's so inventive—and also because it's hard to fathom how such strict limitations could yield music this enveloping.

column1: Using a technique developed by David Chandler
column2: aka Solenoid
column3: Dickow first created his own looping cassettes by disassembling the plastic housings of cassette tapes
column4: extracting the tape
column5: cutting it
column6: and re-threading it in a loop configuration. (These images help explain the technique.) Those then became
column7: in a sense
column8: both his canvas and
column9: when he recycled the contents of the tapes (many of which were often found on the street or given to him by friends)
column10: his raw material. Plugging those into a 4-track recorder
column11: he recorded his own sounds and also utilized the existing material on the tapes
column12: all of which he ran out
column13: via separate outputs for each track
column14: through a handful of effects: analog delay
column15: high-pass filter
column16: spring reverb
column17: a broken loop pedal
column18: and a tube overdrive built by Not Breathing's Dave Wright. (He diagrams his process here.)

column1: Why does any of this matter? You can listen to all six of Noise Tape Self's tracks on Bandcamp right now
column2: so you tell me: Would you have guessed that any of these were the product of a single set of loops
column3: all running in parallel? I doubt it. They move like water—not in circles but in long
column4: winding streams
column5: a muted rainbow of intermingled currents
column6: some faster and some slower. Four parallel eight-second loops become
column7: in effect
column8: a series of garden stakes drowned in vines—overgrown
column9: unruly
column10: uncontainable.

column1: ""Awesome Piano"" is a sawtoothed raga suffused in mist
column2: a gentle call-and-response between gravelly synthesizer and watery keys. ""Cassette Loop"" recalls both Seefeel's spectral ambient dub and Grouper's drain-circling drones; a rhythmic clacking suggests the movement of a train
column3: while the glassy sway might be buoys far out at sea. That's as lonely as the album gets: ""Ominous Lovely Piano"" plays with whimsical
column4: daydreamy loops—major-key
column5: frayed around the edges—and something that sounds almost like a dog sighing in its sleep. ""Lovely Loop""
column6: cooler and more distant
column7: wouldn't be out of place on Kompakt's Pop Ambient series. It also has something of the aquatic to it
column8: complete with the rustle of what might be waves and seagulls: If ""Cassette Loop"" is a fogged-in bay at night
column9: then ""Lovely Loop"" is the same scene by the light of day
column10: sun-baked and ringed by green pines. ""Hobgoblin"" employs the 4-track's variable-speed feature to create a spooky gliding melody
column11: and the closing ""Rhen's Loop"" settles into nine minutes of resonant drones that glisten like a pit full of beetles.

column1: None of these tracks deals explicitly in reggae—not its bass lines
column2: not its backbeats—but the album's commitment to dub as a process
column3: an ethos
column4: is total. And it shows that dub

column7: catching sounds and propelling them out toward the limit of our perception; they wrest time from the rails and send it flying off into space. ""The studio must be like a living thing
column8: Lee ""Scratch"" Perry told David Toop
column9: and Tape Noise Self implants dub's DNA in a whole new host. As studios go
column10: Dickow's couldn't be more modest
column11:
but there is no doubt that it is alive.

column5: which finds Shibata’s voice nearly cracking during the final stretch. Save for Trust In Love’s feature

Gucci Mane takes the restrictions of prison sentences as a challenge. He smuggles out music like contraband. It has become less about whether or not he’ll be able to produce while incarcerated and more about just how much music he can muster. Since his conviction on felony weapons charges in 2013

column3: all while serving a sentence that won't see him released until early 2017. At times
column4: his release schedule feels like a personal affront to the penal system

column1: It seems during this current stint

column3: Gucci is releasing music more aimlessly than ever. Projects are compiled of old throwaways from long-forgotten hard drives. Mixtapes arrive one after the next or in packs with no consideration for consumer consumption. There is often little to no method to his madness. He releases new projects en masse simply for the sake of it. These days
column4: it’s less about the music itself and more about how he rolls it out. But he’s been playing a game of diminishing returns: the more music a mercurial Gucci releases

column11: Trap House 5 (The Final Chapter)

column13: Gucci is slowly becoming a caricature.

column2: a sentiment that resonates even louder now. On the title track from his newest mixtape

column4: he hears those murmurs echoing: ""Some people say Guwop ain’t Gucci/ They say Bricksquad ain’t So Icy…/ What?!"" It’s a shot at any suggestion that he’s self-saturated to the point of being washed up or that he’s become a parody of his former self. There’s more disbelief in his voice than menace
column5: as if to render the notion unthinkable. To that end
column6: King Gucci feels like an attempt to reaffirm Gucci’s identity and re-establish his place in trap’s mixtape hierarchy with a measured dose of what he built his trap house on: a wild mixture of slurry phonetic gaffes
column7: lumbering wordplay

column3: but there are flashes of it everywhere (""Cash smell like cocaina/ Got Febreze for all my cheese"" on ""Still Selling Dope""; the combo of ""My pops wasn’t ‘round but least he gave me good looks"" and ""Tattoos on my face card ‘cause I don’t want no job"" on ""I’m Too Much""). You still have to parse through his sometimes clumsy phrasing and garbled speech
column4: but the flows are trickier here and the wordplay niftier than on a lot of his other recent releases. The woozy Tarentino production on the title track allows Gucci enough space to stretch and mash vowel sounds like putty. On ""Real Dope Boy"" he again implies a return to form: ""I’m back making old school trap boy music."" The tape’s highlight is the Chief Keef-produced ""Smart Mouth""

and TM88 have all built respectable careers with Gucci’s help and their presence here feels like another boast. King Gucci is a valiant but limited attempt to re-establish Gucci Mane’s foothold on trap from behind bars with old tropes and familiar faces.

column4: Mo-Dettes
column5: and Lucrate Milk

column5: releasing a number of EPs on labels like Ecstasy and Mexican Summer. However
column6: following the birth of their first child in 2013
column7: the pair felt compelled to temporarily step away from club sounds. Rather than release the resulting mellower guitar-driven music as Miracles Club
column8: Owens decided to resurrect Valet
column9: only this time as a group
column10: featuring Fauria and multi-instrumentalist Mark Burden. The result is Nature
column11: Valet’s first record in seven years.

column1: A lot has changed. Previous Valet albums were song-driven
column2: but much more abstract in their execution. The music was centered on Owens’ voice
column3: but also readily wandered into extended space-outs—abstract doodles
column4: warped guitar leads
column5: and repetitive psychedelic loops. The music was gentle
column6: but the improvisational disorder conveyed a certain amount of menace and discomfort.

column1: Nature is more focused and more serene. Both the melodic content and production style suggest that Owens and Fauria have been revisiting '90s psych and space-rock staples like Slowdive
column2: Spiritualized
column3: and the Verve (A Storm in Heaven-era Verve
column4: at least). Those bands relied heavily on studio time and technology to generate a distinctively gauzy vibe—leaning heavily on reverb
column5: delay
column6: and lots of guitar overdubs. On <i>Nature
column7: Valet turns to similar sounds
column8: but on a stricter budget. Much like Kranky-era Deerhunter and Atlas Sound (Owens was a touring member of that band)
column9: the group uses readily available resources—foot pedals
column10: computer-based recording software
column11: digital plug-ins—to dial in otherworldly ambience. It sounds DIY
column12: but in a way that strengthens the record’s character and allows some distance from its influences.

column1: What really separates this most recent incarnation of Valet from the shoegaze records of yesteryear
column2: though
column3: is the songwriting. Old-school space rock bands were very concerned with transcending or escaping one’s physical self—revisit Ride’s ""Leave Them All Behind""
column4: the Verve’s ""Slide Away""
column5: or just about any Spiritualized song. On Nature
column6: Owens’ lyrics tend to involve memory and personal upheaval
column7: rather than altered states. ""Twelve different ways to put up a fight/ Upside down police cars under fire bridges
column8: she sings on the record’s title track
column9: which alternately recalls experiences with civil unrest
column11: and LSD. For such a trippy
column12: reverb-drenched
column13: and ethereal set of songs
column14: Nature is surprisingly intimate and reflective.

column1: Nature does deliver the psych-rock goods
column2: though. The trio’s songs impart a feeling of ascension—with murky atmosphere giving way to nodding repetition and guitar-driven uplift. Like their peers and forebears
column3: Valet create simple music that feels expansive. Only here
column4: the swirl of fuzz and echo isn't an exit from terrestrial woes
column5:
just a comfortable place to take stock for a moment.

Two-and-a-half minutes into ""Udder Dust""

column5: her violent voice slowing toward the back half of the sentence as the beat breaks in two. The 17 songs on Qliphoth

column7: portray characters often trampled under society’s heaviest feet—inner-city outcasts and sexual deviants
column8: drug addicts and civil servants

column10: Marshall
column11: one of metal’s best new bandleaders
column12: unapologetically offers those characters a megaphone. Qliphoth feels like a series of prepared rebellions
column13: then
column14: simply waiting to start.

column1: It’s always been easiest to talk about Cloud Rat as a grindcore band. Their self-titled 2010 LP ripped through 11 numbers in just less than 18 minutes
column2: while 2013’s Moksha crammed its first 12 songs into about 22 minutes. But the latter’s closing title track made it clear there was more to Cloud Rat than sprinting and stammering. Throbbing bass and groaning guitar drifted around an eerie piano theme
column3: Marshall’s wordless vocals webbing around the instruments like the ghosts of her wrath. Coupled with the album’s occasional nods to D-beat

column6: riff-driven rock'n'roll

column8: Brutal Truth

column10: one DJ Lethal turntable solo away from Limp Bizkit’s ""Faith""
column11: would have dispatched any lingering doubt.) On Qliphoth
column12: they doggedly power around those predecessors once and for all.

column1: Aside from their respective finales

column3: evidence of the band’s decision and ability to do more here than plow ahead with vitriol
column4: velocity
column5: and volume. ""Udder Distance""
column6: for instance
column7: climbs from an arching riff and a low tempo to a tremolo-and-blast-beat bristle
column8: touching on death metal and post-punk along the way. ""Raccoon"" unfurls as steadily escalating doom
column9: the drums pulling backward even as Marshall’s voice arrows ahead. Previously a trio
column10: Cloud Rat expanded into a quartet for Qliphoth
column11: adding Brandon Hill and his abrasive electronics to the guitar
column12: drums
column13: and screams. His impact is immediate
column14: as album opener ""Seken"" begins with a static roar
column15: a droning guitar
column16: and Marshall’s momentarily seraphic vocals
column17: refracted as if by a prism. On ""Thin Vein""
column18: the first half of a two-part suite

column20: Neurosis-sized coda.

column1: All of these influences wind around a grindcore framework
column2: now five years in the making for Cloud Rat. They are cold and efficient when it comes to the basics
column3: as on the 96-second tirade ""Live Wake"" or the prurient
column4: punctuation-free ""Bloated Goat"". Marshall is thrilling and telling on these brow beaters
column5: as she’s able to control her voice without mitigating its barbaric effect. With the band racing behind during ""Botched""
column6: she manages to deliver commands like ""Get on your feet

column8: too.

column1: Even within metal
column2: grindcore is often regarded as a relatively impenetrable niche
column3: where lots of words and riffs come crammed in very little spaces. Sometimes
column4: the pugnacious effect of it all gets more attention than the particulars. But on Qliphoth
column5: Cloud Rat take the time and risks necessary to make sure their points are clear
column6: that all their rage is not for naught. ""The end goal is really just for cathartic therapy
column7: as it’s hard to express yourself in public
