column9: you can’t stop the clock
column10: etc. So we need this outlet to survive at this point."" To that end
column11: Qliphoth invokes both folk and punk rock
column12: idioms where form and function commingle rather than compete. Cloud Rat’s misgivings with the world both power and mutate the music they make
column13: rendering a rebellious vision of liberation and existence. During ""Rusting Belt""
column14: the band loops a sample of Brenna Sanchez
column15: the co-director of a documentary about Detroit’s recent seizure by fire. ""Arson is a form of self-expression in a place where you can’t express yourself
column16: she says. On Qliphoth
column17: Cloud Rat extend tempestuous expressions for troubled times—proof of life
column18:
offered with utter conviction.

Karen Dalton is one of the tragic ciphers
column2: an Oklahoma-born folksinger who played a long-neck banjo and a 12-string guitar and sang weary
column3: welling songs about bad and broken loves. For decades
column4: late-arriving fans were told she died of AIDS
column5: penniless and displaced
column6: curled up on a New York City street corner. That particular bit of apocrypha has since been debunked (she was in the care of her friend
column7: the guitarist Peter Walker
column8: when she passed away in 1993)
column9: but it pervades her memory anyhow: Karen Dalton
column10: lost soul. The saddest
column11: sorriest voice of the '60s.

column1: Dalton only recorded two LPs in her lifetime
column2: 1969’s Its So Hard to Tell Who’s Going to Love You the Best and 1971’s In My Own Time
column3: both of which have since been reissued and lionized as lost folk classics—held up
column4: decades later
column5: as examples of how
column6: sometimes
column7: the culture falters
column8: fails
column9: picks the wrong heroes. Dalton wasn’t known as a songwriter—neither record contains a single original composition—but Walker
column10: who oversees her estate

column12: snippets
column13: poems) that she never got around to recording

column15: maybe

column1: Dalton’s words were distributed to a handful of contemporary singers

column4: 2000’s <i>Mermaid Avenue

column1: Bob Dylan said Dalton had a voice like Billie Holiday’s (lots of people thought so)
column2: but Holiday sublimated her suffering—there are the tiniest suggestions of it in her control
column3: in the way she judiciously deployed vibrato
column4: the way she pulled back
column5: raised her chin—whereas Dalton let it bubble up
column6: get ugly. There’s a comparable shrillness to vocals from Kurt Cobain
column7: Axl Rose
column8: all the great American sufferers; it’s there when Skip James sings
column9: viciously
column10: ""I'm so tired
column11: and I am tired; I am tired."" It’s there when Dalton sings ""You haven't got a thing to say
column12: you feel you want to run away
column13: in ""Something’s on Your Mind""
column14: and it reaches an apotheosis in that song’s devastating coda: ""Well
column15: you know
column16: you can’t make it without ever even trying."" That quality is what allowed her to take other people’s material and make it feel personal—in her voice
column17: everything seems singular
column18: a site-specific wound. The best tracks on Remembering Mountains do the same.

column1: Sharon Van Etten opens the record with the title track
column2: the only song for which Dalton receives a non-lyrical credit (""words and chords by Karen Dalton""). Van Etten
column3: joined by the Walkmen’s Hamilton Leithauser
column4: has a particular knack for writing big
column5: sweeping laments—the kinds of aching melodies that make your breath catch—and she manages to match or at least meet the deep melancholy that haunts so much of Dalton’s output. Van Etten sings here
column6: as Dalton often did
column7: of wanting her lover to be better
column8: stronger: ""I’m believing/ You’ll find tomorrow.""

column1: Marissa Nadler’s take on ""So Long Ago and Far Away"" is brutal in its ghostliness
column2: like a memory you can’t quite access
column3: a memory that registers only as a loss. ""Friends and lovers all become/ So long ago and far away
column4: Nadler intones
column5: her voice breathy
column6: bare.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: songwriters build structures around Dalton’s words that feel more anachronistic (Diane Cluck’s beguiling ""This Is Our Love"" could be the lone ballad on any number of million-selling pop records)
column3: but few find anything particularly joyful in her lyrics; folks hungry for an alternate narrative about Dalton—something sweeter
column4: more balanced—will have to look elsewhere. Lucinda Williams comes closest to at least finding some toughness in Dalton’s found language: ""He asked me if I needed help/ I told him to go help himself
column5: she sings on ""Met an Old Friend"". A few peals of blues guitar act as a kind of confirmation—the look you give after you tell someone to back off.

column1: Remembering Mountains is maybe the closest we’ll ever get to hearing Dalton’s own articulations of heartache
column2: although plenty was communicated on her first two records
column3: regardless of whether the words there were her own. Still
column4: there’s a palpable narrative here
column5: a sense of loss and stillness
column6: and it reanimates Dalton
column7:
if only for a moment. It’s good to have her back.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21820/homepage_large.2de5e5e5.jpg|What You Hear (Is What You Hear)|559.0|Thomas Brinkmann|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Editions Mego']|2015-05-27 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:10:31.258544|"

Spend too much time listening closely to music and you may find yourself obsessed with tones
column2: ignoring the melody and rhythm that give songs meaning to most people. It’s a common affliction in recording studios
column3: where one minute you can be doing something relatively mundane like figuring out the right placement for a hi-hat in the mix and the next thing you know you’re hours deep into microscopically tweaking an array of equalizers and compressors
column4: feverishly searching for some sort of tonal nirvana.

column1: Usually this is a sign of studio madness
column2: but some musicians and producers have made it a viable way of working. On What You Hear (Is What You Hear)
column3: German minimalist techno producer Thomas Brinkmann has gone deliriously over that particular edge.

column1: Minimal techno
column2: a genre that revolves around compulsive sonic fastidiousness
column3: is a breeding ground for tonal obsession—the picky ears of its makers and audience have played a major role in keeping pure analog synthesis alive and evolving during the periods when it wasn’t in style. Even within this context
column4: Brinkmann stands out as an especially exacting engineer
column5: and his recordings offer a sense of painstaking sumptuousness that stand apart from the rest of the minimal techno crowd.

column1: What You Hear (Is What You Hear) is minimalist
column2: but it’s not techno. Each track consists of a single tone held for anywhere between two and 11 minutes
column3: with minimal modulation and no significant changes in dynamics or pitch. Rhythm is only occasionally a factor
column4: and only emerges as a byproduct of the sustained sound’s internal pulses
column5: never as a separate track. Ambient’s not the right word for it either
column6: because the songs are too alien-sounding to settle into the scenery.

column1: The static quality of the compositions don’t make for what’s traditionally considered an exciting listen
column2: but anyone who enjoys dissecting what comes into their ears will find a lot of pleasure in What You Hear. It rewards listeners who take an active role in the listening
column3: those willing to dig deeper
column4: analyzing the elements in the sounds one at a time and teasing apart their structures.

column1: But the record’s not just for obsessive audio freaks. If you engage with the songs on their own terms they’re fascinatingly evocative. ""Ziegelrot"" (which means ""brick-red"") is a recursive
column2: juddering howl that sounds like the first feedback-saturated seconds of a cheaply recorded hardcore song extended to the length of an entire 7"" side. ""Mitisgrün"" begins as something like the comforting white-noise pulse of a distant air conditioner unit and ramps up to a throbbing grind so slowly and subtly you’re likely to miss the point where it tips over from soothing to anxiety-inducing.

column1: Brinkmann’s experiment in pure tonality is the inverse of the works where he’s effectively removed it from his compositions entirely
column2: producing music that’s pure rhythm. In the incredible video of a performance at Tokyo’s Taico Club
column3:
he skillfully etches lines in blank vinyl on eight turntables and constructs a fully rave-able techno song out of the staticky pops the gashes produce. The only apparent direction he has left is to make a record that doesn’t have any musical elements at all. It’ll probably sound great.

Assembling is a thoroughly suburban record. Not in the conceptual sense of Real Estate or The Suburb. Rather
column2: Two Sheds’ sophomore LP is suburban in how it prefers to maintain a distance from the bustle
column3: turnover
column4: and excitement that's so close in a city. When I listen to the Los Angeles quintet
column5: I’m reminded of how quickly their home city can look like Anytown
column6: USA if you drive 30 minutes in any direction—neat little plots
column7: calm
column8: manicured lawns
column9: with the palm trees and sunshine making it look just a little more Californian.

column1: Appropriately enough
column2: the CVs of everyone involved are heavy on supporting roles and side projects. After Two Sheds quietly released their debut Strange Ammunition in 2006
column3: singer Caitlin Gutenberger moonlit in Rogue Wave offshoot Release the Sunbird. There
column4: she met new Two Sheds drummer Josh Barnhart
column5: who had once manned the skins for Rogue Wave-ish Port O’Brien. Barnhart replaced Rusty Miller
column6: a collaborator of Cali power-pop mainstay Kelley Stoltz and Grandaddy’s Jason Lytle. The credits of engineer Eli Thomson include Everest and Delta Spirit
column7: both of which are the kind of secretly very popular alt-roots bands you never read about in major publications. And it’s mastered by TW Walsh
column8: a guy name-dropped as David Bazan’s trusted van driver in Pedro the Lion’s ""Bands With Managers"". Bassist Johnny Gutenberger is the outlier
column9: having played for late-'90s alt-rock almosts Far

column2: that overstates their range. None of Far’s quasi-emo alt-metal seeps into Assembling
column3: but it would’ve been a welcome jolt on a record that seems to revel in its lack of urgency. Gutenberger's lyrics tend to express passing concern about things not really worth getting worked up about. ""It’s Okay"" shares a common heartsickness with Rogue Wave’s ""Chicago x12""
column4: of trying to stay enthusiastic while playing to empty rooms. But it’s nowhere close to touching the latter’s devastation and demoralization
column5: the implication being that if no one comes out to see Two Sheds
column6: at least they’ve got each other.

column1: Gutenberger's voice is suited for lower stakes
column2: appealing and capable of blending in and reminiscing about the instability or novelty of her '90s influences rather than embodying them. ""Choose"" and ""Nighttime"" are earnest Mazzy Star homage
column3: ""It’s Okay"" is Neko Case after being hit with a noise ordinance
column4: the hints of Liz Phair are from her Whitechocolatespaceegg phase. And those are the edgier parts of Assembling. The core is the kind of clap-happy folk-pop that picks up right where Strange Ammunition left off
column5: which is Los Angeles in 2006. On any given night at the erstwhile Spaceland back then
column6: you might see Elvis Perkins or the Little Ones or the Parson Redheads or any number of Midlake-esque acts and be told in all seriousness that this was everything exciting about indie rock.

column1: I found out after the fact that Assembling was the result of a dare where Gutenberger was challenged to write 20 songs per day
column2: and she did so for three days. Accounting for sleep
column3: bathroom breaks
column4: checking Twitter
column5: and milling about the house
column6: that rounds out to a new song every 45 minutes or so. In their words
column7: the 14 resultant songs (and a pitch-shifted conversation about a drum set tagged as the closer) were considered ""solid"" enough to be included here. They are indeed sturdy and uniform in structure
column8: with choruses arriving with the pleasant regularity of the mailman or street sweepers. The breeziness ensures that everything passes by like neighborly small talk
column9: getting on before anything gets too invested or deep. Ultimately
column10: it’s suburban in that there’s nothing wrong with it
column11: it’s certainly a nice place to not have to worry about much. But if you’re feeling even slightly weird or craving adventure
column12: Assembling can remind you just how suffocating Anytown
column13:
USA can be.

column1: As a whole
column2: Have a Nice Life stands as a decent collection of songs that
column3: while palatable

but he's still searching for that complete statement.

Holly Herndon’s songs play new tricks on you with each listen. The Bay Area composer and singer’s work percolates in the mind first

column4: Movement
column5: but her range broadened and deepened across a slow but steady stream of intoxicatingly dense singles; Platform is the most complete representation of her music yet.

column1: Herndon constructs synth patches from the sound of her voice
column2: whether she’s murmuring
column3: singing tunefully
column4: or on the verge of shrieking. But she also processes and sequences acoustic sounds derived from movement and disorder (what could be shattering glass
column5: a bucket being poured out
column6: the tapping of a keyboard
column7: the swish of a dancer’s legs)
column8: molding samples until they no longer reference the action that produced them. Even with the processing
column9: her tracks retain an organic quality

column1: In interviews

column4: Herndon spells out her themes and methods. She seems to consider her art as
column5: by design

column9: and our relationship with them is less fraught. Herndon doesn’t believe that her work exists in a vacuum; it signifies in all directions
column10: and is tied to and defined by everything around it. By explaining her music
column11: she seeks to set up a more direct relationship with her audience. Clarifying the experiment is
column12: to some extent

column1: There’s always the danger that channeling our listening according to an artist’s directives means we’ll miss out on engaging with the music in more personally significant ways. But though Herndon unifies her pieces with clear conceptual frameworks
column2: the moment-to-moment experience stokes our subjective impressions. The best of Herndon’s compositions function something like the age-old visual illusion of the young woman with the big hat
column3: who could just as easily be
column4: on second look
column5: a babushka-wearing grandmother. You might focus on the cold digital debris or the human voice crying out one minute and a melody or a meaningful lyric the next. At transcendent moments—busier
column6: murkier work like ""Interference"" or ""Home""—Herndon offers an unclassifiable combination of the two.

column1: The previously released single ""Chorus"" provides the album's sonic template. It builds and settles expertly
column2: as if catered toward the energy of a dancefloor in real time
column3: and packs an earwormy wordless chorus. But it breaks through the wall of techno-informed percussion and synth pulsations only sporadically
column4: like a lament filtered through a bad cell connection

column6: Herndon’s Internet chatter is like a primordial ooze the song emerges out of and back into.

column1: Those who loved the pop acuity of ""Chorus"" won’t find much else on Platform as persuasive in that vein. In fact
column2: the record’s only weak moments come when Herndon adopts pop song structures instead of self-generated ones. ""Morning Sun""
column3: in particular

column5: unembellished melody which doesn’t develop anywhere in particular

column16:
with a lot of room for further development and expansion.

of sublime rhythmic focus and freaked-out guitar violence.

In the summer of 2012

column1: The result of the triple-distillation process is Welcome Back to Milk

column4: and Wurlitzer are all out

column12: ""Isn’t It Wild"" waltzes dreamily to the stars

column3: Sparks-like riff as Houghton yells and trills theatrically. Third track ""Raw Honey"" simmers

column6: polish their egos (""After the Show"") and mansplain your ""issues"" (""Hard to Please""). On ""Young Entertainment""
column7: a shimmering noir-punk number

column9: ""What is it like to fuck your mistress with her hands tied?""

column1: Welcome Back to Milk scans as an overhaul of its protagonist’s romantic history
column2: a poised reassessment of domestic situations that seemed okay at the time
column3: but maybe weren’t the best
column4: after all. Wherever her gaze turns

and your present will look after itself.

In the age of social media and perpetual feed refreshing
column2: releasing new music has become akin to issuing a status update—something that should be done quickly and often
column3: if only to remind everyone you’re still alive. Sure
column4: savvy
column5: big-name artists can use long delays between albums to their promotional advantage
column6: parlaying pent-up anticipation into a major cultural event. But for the typical
column7: blog-buzzed indie-level artist touring the same 200-cap rooms as all the other typical
column8: blog-buzzed indie-level artists
column9: even taking the once-standard 18-month break between releases can be a huge gamble at a time when trends and attention spans seemingly shift overnight.

column1: The story of Holly Miranda
column2: however
column3: betrays the benefits of just letting things happen in due time. The Magician’s Private Library
column4: the Kanye-approved 2010 album that first introduced the Michigan-born
column5: bicoastal-based singer to the world at large
column6: technically wasn’t her debut—she self-released an album in 2004
column7: back when she was an acoustic-strumming open-mic aspirant
column8: and went on to make two records as the singer-guitarist for one-time Brooklyn indie-pop hopes the Jealous Girlfriends. Magician’s
column9: however
column10: clearly marked a major turning point in Miranda’s trajectory
column11: its fantastical fusion of southern '60s soul and hazy '80s dream-pop perfectly timed for a moment when acts like Cults and Girls were putting similarly modernist spins on classic pop-song conventions. And in producer Dave Sitek
column12: Miranda had found the perfect conduit between left-field experimentation and MOR accessibility
column13: his maximally minimalist aesthetic so prevalent on the record
column14: you’d think the album was named after his studio. (Alas
column15: it was not.)

column1: But whatever momentum Miranda had acquired with Magician’s would slowly peter out
column2: along with the indie-zeitgeist moment that supported her ascent. In the five years that have passed since the album’s release
column3: all those aforementioned bands have either broken up or drifted to the edges of the cultural conversation; Miranda's XL contract gave way to crowd-funding pitches; and even her most famous cheerleader’s blog has gone offline. Miranda didn't exactly disappear
column4: a seeming impossibility when you’ve been romantically involved with everyone’s favorite ""L Word"" star and joined ScarJo’s supergroup. But her musical output slowed to a trickle
column5: as a crippling bout of writer’s block sent her fleeing from her L.A. home in 2012 to a place that has come to signify rock'n'roll canonization and immortalization: Joshua Tree. Not one to ignore the spiritual significance of such sacred ground
column6: Miranda used the opportunity to get born again. When she sings
column7: ""I’ve been tripping so long"" on her new album’s opening
column8: new-day-rising anthem ""Mark My Words""
column9: she’s not referring to the usual mode of desert-based therapy so much as the protracted process of regaining her proper footing after an extended creative drought.

column1: Like its predecessor
column2: Miranda’s first album in a half decade seeks to balance the earthy with the ethereal. But in contrast to the insular
column3: hermetic environs of The Magician’s Private Library
column4: this new one—produced by Miranda and Florent Barbier
column5: with a one-song assist from Sitek—is all open road
column6: both in its vastness of sound and fresh-start philosophies. (""I know this town could be the death of me
column7: goes the chorus of ""Come On""
column8: its Edge-inspired gallop pushing the L.A. skyline further into the rear view mirror.) It’s a self-titled release
column9: traditional artist shorthand for ""this is the real me""—accordingly
column10: throughout these 11 songs
column11: Miranda projects a greater sense of confidence and candor
column12: dispensing with the fantasy imagery of her previous record to cut straight to the heart of the matter by openly addressing matters of the heart.

column1: Miranda was raised in a strict evangelical household
column2: before rejecting the religious dogma that effectively rejected queer kids like herself; she originally wrote the bittersweet
column3: drum-machined lullaby ""Pelican Rapids"" for the It Gets Better campaign
column4: as a retroactive note of assurance to her teenage closeted self. But when it comes to expressing her distrust of ecclesiastical institutions
column5: Miranda doesn't feel the need to belabor the point; she'd rather appropriate religion's fundamental tenet—the belief in and yearning for something greater than yourself—for secular songs of devotion
column6: and infuse them with the gravitas of modern-day hymns. (The omnipresent baritone-sax hum of Maria Eisen—this album’s star player—inches them toward Spiritualized’s brand of celestial soul.) And while the tumble-in-the-grass romp ""All I Want Is to Be Your Girl"" and the urgent synth-pop of ""Whatever You Want"" respectively document the idyllic beginnings and bitter end of a relationship between two women
column7: Miranda is more liable to write transcendence-seeking songs—like wedding first-dance candidates ""Everlasting"" and ""The Only One""—that can be applied to all sexualities and identities
column8: implicitly promoting the sort of inclusiveness that religious orthodoxy so often denies.

column1: The result is an album that feels both disarmingly intimate and broadly universal
column2: and Miranda's voice—fragile and fearless in equal measure—mesmerizes even when the lyrics veer toward non-descript platitudes. But she is occasionally guilty of forcing her hand. The moonlit elegy ""Desert Call""—an elaborate reworking of a stripped-down 2013 single recorded with Sitek—boasts the album’s most dramatic
column3: chandelier-rattling performance
column4: but the extended closing chorus of ""hallelujah"" oversells the weightiness of a song that’s already done much to establish itself as this album’s epic centerpiece. (It also feels like an overly on-the-nose evocation of a song re-popularized by one of Miranda’s biggest influences.) A better measure of Miranda’s re-stoked bravado comes with ""Until Now""
column5: slotted into the climactic penultimate-track position
column6: but stripped down to just guitar and piano. Like the nocturnal serenades that fill up the back half of Big Star’s Third/Sister Lovers
column7: it’s a song that gently guides an emotional roller coaster of an album towards its peaceful conclusion. ""I never opened my eyes till now
column8: Miranda sings
column9: before pledging herself to a long-time crush. ""You’ve got some kind of sweetness/ Tied up in that string I’ve been tugging on/ But I’m pulling now."" For a lapsed church-goer like her
column10:
it’s a moment of spiritual awakening that no preacher could inspire.

""Let's fuck shit up
column2: suggests Alexis Taylor on a bonus track from Hot Chip’s sixth album. ""Let's go for a rollercoaster ride—even a shit rollercoaster ride."" The lines are pure punk while everything around them is anything but: Taylor sounds like the universe's loneliest astronaut as synth pulses blink in blackness behind him. The song is called ""Burning Up"" and it's vintage Hot Chip: funny where it might be wistful; wistful where it might be funny. It also serves as a mini-history of the London quintet
column3: who first formed 15 years ago. As the song moves along
column4: youthful abandon gives way to consequence
column5: weight
column6: blame. Co-leader Joe Goddard arrives to split the difference in the final verse. ""My age says I'm an adult but some days my heart will not be told
column7: he hums as the track evaporates behind him. ""Hearing teenage symphonies dancing through my head.""

column1: With Why Make Sense?
column2: Hot Chip continue to capture pure joy while acknowledging the limits of such a quest. It's an adult album made by a group of guys in their mid-thirties who know all of the trappings of an ""adult album."" These ahead-of-their-time pop omnivores—remember the bewilderment that surrounded the bedroom Prince and Stevie-isms of their debut album in 2004?—are now
column3: remarkably
column4: something of an institution
column5: their eclecticism the new normal. They used to be LCD Soundsystem’s brainy British counterparts (the two bands even shared a member in guitarist Al Doyle)
column6: but now LCD are gone
column7: and James Murphy is opening wine bars
column8: and Hot Chip are still here
column9: still looking for spontaneity
column10: still hopelessly bittersweet
column11: still trying to get better
column12: still romantic
column13: still funkier than a bunch of pasty dudes from Putney have any right to be
column14: still making it cool to dance even if you can’t dance for shit.

column1: This is the smoothest Hot Chip album
column2: and they’ve never sounded more professional. It's a mixed blessing: For a band healthily obsessed with not making sense
column3: the refined sound can seem a bit commonplace after more than a decade of spikes
column4: jump-cuts
column5: and curveballs. Then again
column6: Hot Chip have always been traditionalists at heart
column7: making pop songs that utilize the vocabularies of house
column8: R&B
column9: and hip-hop rather than the other way around. They've stacked up plenty of bridges worthy of the Brill Building
column10: a phenomenon that continues on the lovingly nostalgic ""Need You Now""
column11: which is about as close as they've come to matching the melancholy perfection of ""Boy from School"". The wafting ""White Wine and Fried Chicken"" takes the band's high/low culture expertise into the realm of gastronomy
column12: and feels like a soul standard for our century. The three-minute song sounds about as straightforward as anything Hot Chip have made
column13: though there are big knots in Taylor's words; whereas much of the band's last two albums dealt with the wonders of stability and contentment
column14: Why Make Sense? seems more conflicted. Existential crises abound
column15: creating discord with the album's glossy finish.

column1: Taylor and Goddard ask themselves questions that many almost-middle-aged musicians—especially in the pop and dance worlds—are too scared to broach. They try to find some clarity within the ambiguities of committed relationships (romantic or musical)
column2: exposing vulnerabilities in the name of emotional honesty. ""Out of happiness can come a bitterness
column3: admits Taylor—the son of a Shakespeare scholar and psychoanalyst—on the booming title track
column4: before mixing in confrontational politics that spin around ideas of personal freedom: ""Why be tough when strength is just for losers/ Be what you are ­at the mercy of your rulers."" Meanwhile
column5: the mildly anti-machine-music ""Huarache Lights"" has Taylor trying to find a heartbeat between ones and zeroes
column6: but he’s too savvy (or neurotic) to construct any bold lines. ""Am I so truthful
column7: or in truth
column8: is the youth just getting old?"" he sings
column9: putting his own perspective into question. On a self-critical bonus track
column10: Goddard suggests
column11: ""I need to separate the head from the body
column12: but he knows that can be hard to do—a fact that this album
column13: with its bulbous grooves and anxious themes
column14: makes clear again and again.

column1: Why Make Sense? is probably the fourth-best Hot Chip album. But that’s not necessarily a knock
column2: because their fourth-best album is still a very good album. At this point
column3: they seem too smart and talented to really fail. They will always be underdogs that you root for to make songs that highlight the complexity of human experience while also helping you to put those complexities in the back of your mind for a minute. They are confident in their abilities
column4:
even when those abilities are aimed at throwing their own confidence into doubt. They are beloved. They are trustworthy. Their senselessness now makes a lot of sense to a lot of people.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21834/homepage_large.0988e0f7.jpg|Tundra|32037.0|Lakker|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['R&S']|2015-05-20 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:10:44.151859|"

A curious thing about the human voice is that it’s a shortcut to the eerie fascination that drives techno music and science fiction alike. Lakker’s Tundra
column2: the Dublin duo's second album in a decade
column3: delves into the uncanny valley of treated vocals
column4: ground up and looped in with all kinds of noise. Lakker weave voices in the style of sacred music into contexts where they wouldn't normally be heard. The resulting effect is spit-shined patches of perfect sonority that make the noise sound brighter
column5: like there’s something alive inside it.

column1: Lakker is the project of Ian McDonnell and Dara Smith
column2: two producers who started out as overheated noise-blast collagists on their first album
column3: 2007's Ruido
column4: and then spent a few years producing straight-ahead techno 12”s for labels like Blueprint and their current home
column5: R&S.

column1: Tundra falls somewhere outside of both of those approaches. It has the same restless spirit as Ruido—but while that LP was a frantic pastiche of frenetically stitched-together ideas
column2: Tundra’s oddball details are all in the service of larger structures
column3: like glyphs carved into the surface of stone blocks. Its range is too expansive and colorful to fit under the umbrella of club music. Like fellow noise artists Fuck Buttons
column4: whose dizzying fractal scaling on Slow Focus echoes through Tundra’s biggest and boldest tracks
column5: Smith and McDonnell have a loose compositional template here; they tease ideas into play with one another
column6: elaborating but never quite releasing the tension between them. ""Mountain Divide""
column7: the dizzying third track (and first introduction of hostile noise) buries a muffled choral fragment in chaotic whining and sawing—an ""O Fortuna"" for sparking machinery—and stays naggingly dissonant.

column1: There’s a narrative quality in the sequencing that brings to mind massive planes swept clear by a destructive force
column2: but Tundra is also touchingly reverent towards humanity. ""Mountain Divide"" is the beginning of a powerful three song segment that includes the luminous ""Three Songs""
column3: and ""Ton’neru""
column4: a wispy ambient piece reminiscent of Julianna Barwick. One of Lakker’s claimed influences is the Estonian composer Arvo Pärt
column5: an explorer of sacred music and Gregorian chant whose dramatically charged compositions have proved enduringly popular in film and television. Smith and McDonnell share a similar flair for concentrating emotion into refined detail.

column1: Only one track here sounds like an exercise rather than a finished composition: ""Halite""
column2: a steady stalactite drip of a melody that never coalesces into something more interesting
column3: despite its near seven minutes
column4: and slows the momentum of the album’s back half down to a sluggish chug. Given the proliferation of disaffected-sounding techno on the Internet these days
column5: it’s easy to imagine this as a tune-out moment for listener
column6: though nothing that follows sounds remotely like it.

column1: In fact
column2: the closing four tracks on the album are its purest examples of industrial-strength noise—the title track
column3: which starts out with a good-natured
column4: ear-wormy beat that’s vaguely familiar
column5: slides into a positively romantic-sounding mix of delicately ticking percussion and sonorous humming
column6: only to double back into an apocalyptic
column7: buzzing cloud of noise. Then there’s the final ""Herald""
column8: a burbling
column9: melodic composition that makes for a disarmingly sensitive come-down from the album’s often ominous landscape. That alone indicates that Tundra is a bid for the kind of album-based respectability that’s so difficult for techno crossover artists to achieve
column10: and its accessibility may give momentum to R&S’s own mission to revive their catalog with forward-thinking techno acts that can replicate their late '90s golden age of left-of-center psychedelic dance LPs. As with any piece of music that ebbs and flows this forcefully
column11: you should listen to it loudly
column12:
and try to get swept away by it.

"|20570.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20570-lakker-tundra/|7.8|Abigail Garnett

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21867/homepage_large.d125cf21.jpg|The Desired Effect|12459.0|Brandon Flowers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Island']|2015-05-20 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:10:44.741813|"

Brandon Flowers is hard to pin down as a pop star
column2: in part because he's still playing at being a pop star. After he stepped into the limelight on the Killers’ still-terrific debut at 22-years-old
column3: he made three more records with his band full of bona fide arena anthems as well as cheap knock-offs that substitute as arena anthems. The latter is why it's advisable to skip over most of his 2010 solo debut Flamingos
column4: if only because the beige
column5: desert-tinged production says and adds very little to his songwriting. The album is clunky and rote even by the Flowers metric.

column1: But with the help of Grammy-winning producer Ariel Rechtshaid
column2: The Desired Effect gives Flowers new backdrops to play around in. Rechtshaid doesn’t mine the '80s and '90s for inspiration like he's done for Haim
column3: Taylor Swift
column4: Carly Rae Jepsen
column5: and many others recently. Instead
column6: he straight up jacks that sound
column7: aiming directly at those fond of the calmer side of Duran Duran
column8: Pet Shop Boys
column9: or Peter Gabriel. Electric guitars are swapped out for chugging piano lines
column10: hand-clap snares
column11: and melismas sung by anonymous background singers; never mind the inclusion of special guest Bruce Hornsby
column12: a song that samples Bronski Beat's ""Smalltown Boy"" and features Neil Tennant on vocals
column13: and floppy disc after floppy disc worth of synth patches. Credit to Rechtshaid
column14: the album’s big and luxe sound fits Flowers' big and luxe voice. When they sync up in this milieu
column15: against all odds
column16: it works really well.

column1: Above these glossy textures
column2: Flowers doubles down on his earnest goobery
column3: which actually brings him closer to this ideal pop star image he's been chasing. Not since Sam’s Town has Flowers sounded so at home in song. ""Can’t Deny My Love"" is a masterclass in '80s production tricks (wooden pan flutes! pitch-wavering synth pads! orchestra hits!) with one of those famous
column4: powerful hooks that made him so likable to begin with. It’s cheesy
column5: but the cluster-bomb of ideas is ultimately what makes you want to go back for repeat listens. Likewise
column6: on the mid-tempo ballad ""Never Get You Right"" Flowers finds the perfect equation for his sincerity and hyperbole. Again
column7: it’s the hook and his voice that do most of the heavy lifting
column8: but the song works because of a simple idea. You look at someone you know and love (who in Flowers' case is possibly a sex worker) and think how ""They’ll turn you into something whether you are it or not/ But they’ll never get you right.""

column1: There are more huge Killers-ready songs to fill stadiums or casinos (""Dreams Come True"" and ""Untangled Love"") and hoary love songs (""Still Want You"")
column2: but Flowers can’t help but trip over himself as he’s writing. He’s just so daffy. He sings ""Friday nights
column3: football stands"" and you just pray the sports imagery stops there
column4: but sure enough
column5: he follows it up with ""been fumbled by so many hands."" It’s always just one move too many. Sometimes he reaches for the cliché like ""ship of fools"" or ""casting...stones"" and sometimes he does some gangly inversion of one
column6: like
column7: ""She wasn't having anything
column8: no birds or any bees/ Girl
column9: don't go shootin' all the dogs down just cause one's got fleas."" At best
column10: Flowers is too wordy and obvious. At worst
column11: he is BruceSpringsteen_ebooks
column12: cobbling together blue-collar American signifiers in odd arrays that appear to have meaning but are really just empty gestures.

This quote is great because it says everything you need to know about Flowers as a songwriter: He believes deeply in himself by way of absurd and often extra-grammatical reasons. At his essence

like being tackled by 20 puppies. Flowers gives off charm and stupidity in the same breath and it is as comforting as it is disposable. It’s the mark of a pretty good pop star.

Hardcore is a genre that revels in certain clichés—the ultimate of which is making a record that renounces your ties to hardcore. Despite its commonality
column2: it’s still a risky maneuver: perhaps playing in such a stylistic straitjacket has made a band incapable of doing anything else. Even if it’s an artistically successful record
column3: it can alienate old fans without attracting new ones. Most relevant to Ceremony
column4: it’s a card you only get to play once. Six years after they could be accurately described as ""powerviolence
column5: the Bay Area group released their John Goodmanson-produced Matador debut Zoo—a slog through boggy
column6: primordial punk
column7: interesting for the sole fact that it was made by a former powerviolence band. Ceremony undergoes another drastic change on The L-Shaped Man
column8: but it cannot be leniently judged relative to Violence Violence. They’re now just one of the thousands of indie rock bands that really want to sound like Joy Division
column9: and sounding no more engaged with their source material than the average dude plucking an Unknown Pleasures graphic T off the rack at Hot Topic.

column1: Mind you
column2: Ceremony are on their fifth record and are named after a Joy Division song. But at the very least
column3: the veritable return to their roots makes sense within the context of The L-Shaped Man. Ceremony are also one of the thousands of indie rock bands making a conceptual breakup record; and in these situations
column4: such a breakup is assumed to be so catastrophic that it totally dismantles one’s self-construct and leaves nothing but foundation. Joy Division lyrics
column5: advice from your father
column6: bumper stickers that read ""all things pass""—everything you’ve been led to think is trite once you’re out of your teens might actually reveal themselves to be the truth.

column1: There’s no way to judge the authenticity of Ross Farrar’s emotions on The L-Shaped Man. But how can he can be exempt on an album where everything feels like facade? In particular
column2: the facade inherent in Ceremony’s own name
column3: as they grab at the most obvious signifiers of their idols and pass them off as their own. For one thing
column4: Farrar’s vocals are now unrecognizable
column5: or only recognizable as Ian Curtis karaoke. To be fair
column6: Curtis is a natural touchstone for a punk rock carny barker
column7: as his enduring qualities—the militaristic cadences
column8: the claustrophobic melodies—can be approximated without much technical ability.

column1: But you can’t fake his command or intensity or sonorousness
column2: though Farrar tries. Or maybe he doesn’t try hard enough. The lyrics are delivered with honesty and presumed urgency. They are also proof that those qualities can be less important than thinking before you talk. The dishwater-gray ambience of ""Exit Fears"" implies sleepless nights filled with lingering regret
column3: while Farrar moans
column4: ""The pain will leave in the night/ Memories return in the light""—which seems to express the exact opposite of what he means. ""The root of the world is in the red heart
column5: ""you saw yourself walking with no one else and it scared you""—they all aspire to be aphorisms and fade upon impact like a tweet never to be favorited. The album title itself is indicative of Farrar making observations without any insight—men are generally L-shaped
column6: but...so?

column1: The lack of resonance is even more obvious in Farrar’s newfound tone
column2: a monster mash of alternating cartoonish bellow and honk which doesn’t sound like Curtis or Paul Banks so much as the dude from Editors drunkenly imitating Paul Banks trying to sing like Ian Curtis. Of all Farrar’s means of cheating towards cogency—repetition of lyrics that just can’t bear the attempts at establishing portent
column3: lending numerous song titles a definitive article to import significance—the most absurd is his Jay McInerney-like tendency to speak almost entirely in the second person. Call it Turn on the Bright Lights
column4: Big City.

column1: As a working unit
column2: Ceremony still play with customary
column3: clumsy enthusiasm. The terse drumrolls
column4: plangent guitar fills
column5: and basslines that are all thumbs—it’s all here and played with the expected looseness of a former hardcore band that moved onto garage rock and is now learning post-punk on the fly. It occasionally coalesces into a surf-goth hybrid that at least justifies John Reis being roped into this. Who knows what Ceremony expected of the former Hot Snakes/Rocket From the Crypt frontman
column6: but his production might be more overmatched than mismatched: the confused melodies Farrar strews over the piano plunking of ""Hibernation"" and the wayward guitar leads in ""Root of the World"" can generously be heard as an experiment in avant-garde atonality. Ceremony would’ve been better off phoning a different guy from Drive Like Jehu—put Mark Trombino behind the drums or the boards and he could provide a high-velocity
column7: low-viscosity sleekness that would make relatively hooky outliers like ""The Separation"" and ""Bleeder"" go incognito on satellite radio as enjoyably derivative post-pop-punk.

column1: The L-Shaped Man does have an advantage over Zoo
column2: in that it’s interesting in the way any true debacle is
column3: where a band’s conviction is either impervious to any kind of outside intervention or just not subject to it. Just look at the album cover: almost immediately after Ceremony revealed The L-Shaped Man
column4: fans noticed its too-hilarious-to-be-intentional similarity to a gag from the ""A Millhouse Divided"" episode of ""The Simpsons."" This is better known as the ""Can I Borrow a Feeling"" episode
column5: an unfortunate coincidence seeing as how we’re talking about a record whose entire aesthetic is on loan. It’s even more serendipitous in light of the exact scene with the offending Pictionary attempt—there we have Kirk Van Houten
column6: on the verge of a calamitous divorce
column7: yelling at a dinner party crowd who reacts to his inept visual rendering of ""dignity"" with embarrassed silence. Maybe it's good for a laugh
column8:
but only as a defense mechanism against the cringe-inducing experience of watching artistic expression abandon a heartbroken man at his lowest moment.

To debut her new album

column4: ""wearing a green dress and ill fitting heels
column5: and throws ""a flaming boulder straight into our servers."" In another article she starts a Twitter war with Ziggy Stardust. In every photo Ray wears an ape mask that has become her avatar on Last Year’s Savage—the equivalent of Bowie’s alien costume from the 1970s or Bono’s MacPhisto get-up from the '90s. The disguise itself is visually striking
column6: albeit obscure; Savage Times
column7: on the other hand

column9: pointed cultural satire
column10: meta humor
column11: and good old-fashioned punsmithery.

column1: Ray brings that same sophisticated
column2: intensely derisive sense of humor to the songs on Last Year’s Savage. ""Johnny Thunder Fantasy Space Camp"" skewers the constant romanticizing of doomed rock stars—male rock stars
column3: although that goes without saying. Over a '50s pop piano line and an insistent snare drum snap

column6: as she recounts her own dreams of gender-blurred virility over a tense rhythm section and rumbling guitar riffs: ""My dick’s bigger
column7: my breasts are thicker
column8: whatever power means."" Ray buys into the same overinflated rock myths she’s puncturing
column9: perhaps because each one represents a way to transcend the limitations of the body and live a bit longer
column10: a bit better. As she cautions on ""Nocturnal Emissions""
column11: ""Don’t ever wake me up
column12: bitch!""

column2: Shilpa Ray and Her Happy Hookers
column3: just Shilpa Ray) and toured with Nick Cave
column4: Ray delivers these songs in a voice that shapeshifts constantly

column1: Especially on the album’s second side

column3: a bit too impressed with their own cleverness. She sings ""Sanitary iPad"" from the point of view of a high-tech gadget that’s obsolete before it even hits stores. ""I’ve got a short shelf life
column4: who’s gonna throw me out?"" she sings

or perhaps that monkey-avatar flinging its own poop at not-so-innocent bystanders.

""There’s a lot of stupid things that happen in the world that you can’t control
column3: ” Faith No More bassist Billy Gould told Pitchfork. ""It’s funny
column4: but it’s not funny. It’s there. But it’s great to have enough of a connection with that mentality where you can interact with it and poke your finger in it a little."" That joker’s soul
column5: that urge to poke
column6: can be traced through all of Faith No More's biggest moments
column7: from their stunning hit ""Epic"" to their genre-defying
column8: commercially unsuccessful (and critically acclaimed) 1992 opus Angel Dust. From the early 1980s through 1997
column9: Faith No More were the reputable carneys
column10: sporting an array of influences and oddities: everything from Madame Butterfly and Nirvana
column11: to Nietzsche and Miles Davis
column12: and even a not-yet-dead fish. And then they went away.

column1: For the past 18 years
column2: fans have waited patiently for Faith No More to wrap up a disappearing act that was the inevitable result of exhaustion
column3: creative differences
column4: and branching paths. Since that time
column5: frontman Mike Patton started his Ipecac label and pursued numerous solo projects
column6: from the poppy Peeping Tom to the experimental supergroup Fantômas to the style-swapping Tomahawk. Keyboardist Roddy Bottum
column7: the group's musical brain
column8: started the bubblegum band Imperial Teen
column9: scored films
column10: and penned an opera about Bigfoot; meanwhile
column11: bassist Billy Gould started Koolarrow Records
column12: and drummer Mike Bordin manned the kit for Ozzy Osbourne. In 2009
column13: the group stirred from its slumber and began performing again. And now
column14: at long last
column15: we’ve arrived at the confrontational Sol Invictus
column16: the follow-up to 1997’s Album of the Year.

column1: Distance and time do not make the heart grow fonder
column2: and two decades haven't softened Patton’s coal-black heart. He’s pissed off and proud of it
column3: picking fights with just about anyone and anything. ""Superhero"" sees him spewing taunts at beloved authority figures
column4: each syllable hitting with the percussive force of a slug to the jaw. ""Leader of man
column5: get back in your cage
column6: he sneers from atop Bottum’s majestic piano strata
column7: a fool cracking his whip at a lowered God. The humiliations continue with ""Cone of Shame""
column8: which imagines a wrongful lover in a state of depersonalization and animality
column9: while ""Black Friday"" mocks anyone who’s set foot in a Target at 4 a.m. This commentary is far from subtle
column10: but the ridiculousness is part of the experience
column11: and you can’t help but smile at the return of one of rock’s great contrarians.

column1: The success of Faith No More’s theatrical approach depends on their ability to organize motifs
column2: riffs
column3: shouts
column4: and whimpers into cathartic musical structures. Most of the album’s songs follow a similar dramatic pattern
column5: with the band bookending their frantic (and typically brief) climaxes with unsettlingly calm passages and plodding tempos. The unassumingly simple melodies in ""Sunny Side Up"" and ""Rise of the Fall"" are set-ups for the carefully-orchestrated rage that lay in wait
column6: and when it hits right the contrast makes for a fascinating listen
column7: especially on the venomous ""Cone of Shame"". But over the course of the album
column8: especially during later songs like ""Black Friday""
column9: ""Motherfucker""
column10: and ""Matador""
column11: the recycled dynamics begin to lose their force.

column1: Set aside the negligible opening and closing tracks
column2: and Sol Invictus has just eight tracks spanning 34 minutes
column3: an underwhelming running time considering how long Faith No More have been away. Such brevity could be overlooked if Sol Invictus was accompanied by a significant shift in the band’s sound
column4: but many of these songs feel like retreads. ""Superhero"" and ""Separation Anxiety""
column5: while enjoyable
column6: bear the signatures of ""Epic"" and ""Midlife Crisis""
column7: with their loping piano lines and bloodthirsty rap incantations. Meanwhile
column8: ""Black Friday"" and ""Sunny Side Up"" conjure up déjà vu of Patton’s side projects; ""Motherfucker"" could be a pumped up version of Tomahawk’s ""I.O.U"".

column1: There’s nothing necessarily wrong with a band repeating itself. But because Faith No More have such a long history
column2: and their members are responsible for music in a staggering array of styles
column3: it's hard not to expect more
column4: to wish that they might in some way top themselves
column5: or at least change direction. Towards the end of ""Cone of Shame""
column6: Patton admits
column7: ""I’m only happy when I’m pissing you off."" Considering Faith No More’s history of confounding and confronting the listening public and the systems of order which influence it
column8: such a statement could serve as the band’s motto. In that sense
column9: maybe holding something back was the plan all along
column10:
and a future Faith No More record (one is said to be on the way) will have something more.

On their 2013 debut Weird Sister
column4: Joanna Gruesome rubbed sugar up against sandpaper until both started to melt. Clean leads and light
column5: melodic vocals trickled into oceans of fuzz under song titles like ""Wussy Void"" and ""Anti-Parent Cowboy Killers"". Two years later and they haven't evened out. Peanut Butter could have smoothed the Cardiff band's sound
column6: finding the happy middle between their rough edges and sticky-sweet center. Instead
column7: it pushes the group's music further out toward both extremes.

column1: Weird Sister flung a few deliberate curveballs
column2: like the ""wrong"" chords that rocked ""Madison"" off its equilibrium. Peanut Butter is a tornado full of curveballs. At a slight 22 minutes
column3: it bursts and buzzes
column4: locking into patterns and then exploding out of them once you think you've figured them out. Joanna Gruesome is still partial to melody—the pop syrup flows freely after a quick hardcore fake-out at the beginning of ""Last Year""—but the hooks have lost their primacy inside the band's rough collage. The most interesting parts are now the serrated edges
column5: the way textures brush up against textures
column6: and how unstable the whole freewheeling machine can get.

column1: On ""Last Year"" and the aggro-peppy ""Honestly Do Yr Worst""
column2: singer Alanna McArdle snaps out of her light
column3: breathy melodies to find a rhythmic kinship with Perfect Pussy's Meredith Graves. Those choking
column4: biting yelps reveal exhausted phrases here and there
column5: snippets of language like ""I am running on empty."" A song called ""I Don't Wanna Relax"" opens with 12 seconds of blast beats and dilapidated guitar chords. When guitarist and lead songwriter Owen Williams slashes ""There Is No Function Stacy"" sideways with noise-punk breakdowns
column6: it's as if we're getting a glimpse of what exactly McArdle is trying to outrun.

column1: Between the bright riffs and the squalls of feedback
column2: a deep instability rests at Joanna Gruesome's core. There's more than just anger in their screams and the quick slams of the bass drum; there's a nervousness too
column3: a sense that anything you could ever hold on to is always on the verge of slipping away. ""I know that life would be alright if I hadn't met you
column4: Williams and McArdle sing on ""Separate Bedrooms""
column5: as if seeing into a parallel universe and preemptively trying to reconcile the loss. Even the sub-two-minute tracks
column6: like ""Jerome (Liar)""
column7: seem to argue with themselves
column8: switching modes from ""everything is fine"" to ""nothing will ever be okay again"" in the blink of an eye.

column1: Joanna Gruesome combust to keep the world from freezing shut around them. Peanut Butter is a chaotic listen
column2: powerful in parts and fragile in others
column3: and often both at the same time. No matter where it goes
column4:
it's always running away from itself.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21770/homepage_large.29d0ca3f.jpg|The Complete Cecil Taylor in Berlin '88|11694.0|Cecil Taylor|['Jazz']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Destination: OUT']|2015-05-19 00:00:00|1989|2016-06-11 16:10:49.342771|"

One of the more famous descriptions of Cecil Taylor’s piano playing compares his sound to someone playing ""88 tuned drums
column2: and it’s true—his all-over-the-instrument dexterity is a physical marvel. You have to recalibrate your imagination when listening to Taylor performing at top speed
column3: the better to make sense of how much music can be made by one person in a single moment. That those note-rich passages routinely add up to unbroken hour-long performances is what makes Taylor seem like the Everest of American music.

column1: Precisely because his technique is so potent
column2: critical reaction to Taylor's music usually breaks down into two camps: those who feel the big climb is worth it
column3: and those who don’t. Miles Davis famously walked out of an early Taylor gig in New York. When asked by a 1990s PBS documentary crew about Taylor’s suggestion that audiences should ""prepare"" for his concerts
column4: saxophonist Branford Marsalis dismissed the concept out of hand. But elite opinion has shifted in recent years. A rising vanguard of pianists
column5: led by the likes of Vijay Iyer and Craig Taborn
column6: is not shy about praising Taylor’s extreme
column7: often atonal style as a crucial part of the jazz tradition. This advocacy harkens back to the '60s work of African-American poet-critics like Amiri Baraka and A. B. Spellman
column8: both of whom wrote about Taylor’s abstracted connection to the blues as much as they emphasized the pianist’s classical
column9: conservatory training.

column1: This recent shift in perception of Taylor's work has been helped along by two significant reissue projects. The first is a fresh and deeply clarifying remaster of Taylor’s seminal 1966 group album Unit Structures (reissued on vinyl and in a ""mastered for iTunes"" edition as part of the Blue Note label’s ongoing 75th anniversary celebration). With this title
column2: Taylor made explicit his idiosyncratic break with previous jazz practices. Instead of charts written out in standard notation
column3: the structure of these compositions was based on sequences of themes
column4: many of which were communicated and rehearsed orally. (Other bits of Taylor’s music might be notated in small snatches
column5: or else delivered to the band live
column6: during Taylor’s feverish piano improvisations.) That Taylor was working with an exploded conception of ""ensemble togetherness"" was indicated by one excerpt from a lengthy bit of free-verse poetry that served as the original LP’s liner notes: ""Time seen not as beats to be measured after academy’s podium angle."" In other words: buckle up.

column1: After Unit Structures
column2: Taylor cut one more LP for Blue Note
column3: Conquistador! (also reissued by Blue Note this year). Then the pianist fell into a seven-year recording hiatus. During this period
column4: it was possible for fans to look back at the ""we’re concerned for Cecil’s future"" tone of those '60s music-journalism pieces by Baraka and Spellman and concede that these writers had correctly foreseen a challenging period ahead. When Taylor popped back up
column5: in the '70s
column6: it was often as a solo artist touring in Europe. And
column7: over the ensuing decades
column8: it has been the interest (and respect) that Taylor has received from foreign promoters
column9: crowds
column10: and artists which has contributed mightily to the cause of keeping him afloat
column11: and at work on his art.

column1: The most lavish European tribute Taylor has ever received came in the form of a month-long residency in West Berlin
column3: which afforded him time to perform in all of his guises—as a solo visionary
column4: as a telepathic improviser playing next to a wide variety of top-shelf duo partners
column5: and also as a big-band and orchestra leader. The results were recorded
column6: and released as In Berlin '88
column7: an 11-CD box set from the Free Music Production label. Longtime Village Voice critic Gary Giddins wrote that ""Cecil Taylor’s Berlin adventure represents his finest achievement."" Then the set promptly went out of print.

column1: Thanks to Destination: OUT
column2: the mp3 blog turned Bandcamp reissue-label
column3: the whole set is now available as a high-quality
column4: authorized download
column5: complete with two additional discs of solo works Taylor recorded on the other side of the Iron Curtain in '88. The whole package is now titled The Complete Cecil Taylor in Berlin ’88
column6: and while it’s an investment ($125 for over 14 hours of music)
column7: it’s the other iconic reissue event that makes 2015 a prime year for approaching Taylor.

column1: The first disc in this set
column2: Legba Crossing
column3: presents the Cecil Taylor Workshop Ensemble
column4: which the bandleader had time to instruct in his idiosyncratic compositional/rehearsal system. There are passages of collective squall here
column5: but in its best moments
column6: you can hear a sense of dawning discovery
column7: as subsections of the group try out Taylor’s serpentine motifs and steadily gain control over them before individual players dare to contribute fluttering improvisations. The takeaway here is that
column8: in contrast with his often lighting-fast pianist playing
column9: Taylor the chamber-music composer has a taste for long
column10: sustained tones
column11: which might entice fans of drone artists like David First (who actually spent some time playing in one of Taylor’s early '70s groups).

column1: The next five discs in the Berlin box are all piano-and-percussion duets (each with a different drummer). Here’s where you get several metric tons of Taylor at the piano. On these sets
column2: Taylor is by turns raging and lyrical
column3: though always confident. And the drummers bring out different aspects of his playing. He meets the shrapnel-distributing heaviness of Günter Sommer with similar intensity
column4: on the box’s second disc (Riobec). On Regalia
column5: the occasionally Latin-tinged work of Paul Lovens brings out an interesting restraint.

column1: Another attraction of the Berlin box is the double-album Alms / Tiergarten (Spree)
column2: recorded by the Cecil Taylor European Orchestra. It’s a major addition to Taylor’s in-print catalog. Behaving less like an orchestra and more like a big band outfitted with famous names from Europe’s avant-garde improv scene (such as Peter Brötzmann and Evan Parker)
column3: the group is capable of high-energy blowouts. But like Taylor’s Workshop Ensemble
column4: they play his quieter music with authority
column5: too. Album number nine in this set
column6: The Hearth
column7: takes the cellist Tristan Honsinger and saxophonist Parker
column8: both members of the European Orchestra
column9: and places them in an instrumental trio setting that I don’t believe is duplicated anywhere else in Taylor’s discography.

column1: The most divisive album from the original box set follows: Pleistozaen Mit Wasser
column2: which pairs Taylor up with the late British scrape-guitar pioneer Derek Bailey. The first half-hour track features very little piano playing from Taylor: He starts out by accompanying Bailey’s free-improv plucks with poetry (and then various inside-the-piano rubbings). It’s not a disaster
column3: but given the historic meeting between iconic experimenters
column4: it feels underwhelming. Things improve on the second half-hour cut: a stretch of quietly metallic avant-garde music that avoids sounding like well-behaved children sorting the recycling. The richness of the piano (even with Taylor pedaling the mute) contrasts winningly with the dry sound that Bailey coaxes from his electric guitar.

column1: The finale from the original box set
column2: Erzulie Maketh Scent
column3: is a solo marathon
column4: broadly similar to other such Taylor records from the '70s onward. And the double-album bonus release
column5: <i>In East Berlin
column6: is split between piano solos and another Taylor hookup with drummer Günter Sommer (who seems less intent on out-walloping Taylor
column7: this time around). Neither East Berlin set trumps the highlights from the original West Berlin box
column8: but hey—as long as you’re paying real money
column9: they’re nice to have.

column1: Speaking of consumer considerations
column2: there is the inevitable question as to whether this box set
column3: important as it is
column4: makes for a ""good place to start with Cecil."" The answer is no. You should start with some early Taylor albums first
column5: if only to get a clearer look at his connection to jazz’s past. (And if you elect to pick up Blue Note's new vinyl pressing of Unit Structures
column6: you’ll find a compelling value-add
column7: too
column8: as Taylor’s original poetry has been reproduced on the back jacket.) Though once you've got some grounding in Taylor's core approach

be advised that there's still a full lifetime of music waiting to be discovered.

At their best and worst
column2: solo acoustic guitar albums can feel like workshops

column1: Daniel Bachman has spent the bulk of the six albums he’s released during the last four years showing that
column2: even at the age of 25
column3: he can stretch. For 2013’s Jesus I’m a Sinner

column1: Though Bachman is now based in Durham

column3: where River was recorded
column4: he is a native of the northern Virginia city of Fredericksburg
column5: near where the Rappahannock River winds out of the Chesapeake Bay. A set of seven unaccompanied guitar instrumentals
column6: River reads like a private love letter to an old home
column7: written and sent from a new one. Named for another nearby town
column8: the short ""Farnham"" is nostalgic but sentimentally vague
column9: like a winsome feeling in search of the exact childhood memory that inspired it. The two-part
column10: 17-minute suite ""Song for the Setting Sun"" conjures an array of emotions in one fluid listen. In part one
column11: Bachman seems to express anxiety over the disappearing day in a place he loves but must leave; just before the three-minute mark
column12: you can hear him nervously shuffle in his chair
column13: perhaps even sigh. The nerves soon sublimate into contentment
column14: though
column15: as Bachman plays the sort of bright
column16: gentle melody that suggests a hand-me-down folk standard
column17: a musical home remedy meant to quell unease. At one point
column18: Bachman’s busy
column19: bustling strings imply he’s even throwing a backyard party. This material is like a survey of his experiences
column20: not an overview of his abilities.

column1: River runs so well as a unit that
column2: unless you’re able to spot the tunes or sleuth the liner notes
column3: you likely won’t detect that Bachman didn’t even write two of these numbers. Bachman undercuts the original sliver of menace in Jack Rose’s ""Levee""
column4: turning what sounds like an ominous threat into a hopeful promise. His chords glow
column5: and his pulse is quick
column6: as if he’s reflecting on a hard place from a safe
column7: removed distance. The same holds for his spry interpretation of <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MZDgMi2YGhA"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">William Moore’s patient
column8: playful 1928 delight
column9: ""Old Country Rock"". Bachman fills the spaces between Moore’s licks with brief notes and radiant overtones; he’s practically dancing with the source material. Though divided by nearly a century
column10: Rose and Moore both lived in the riverine area Bachman extols here; Rose grew up in Fredericksburg
column11: and Moore used to cross the Rappahannock for work. Bachman treats their tales with the same familiarity and fondness he treats the land and his own life there.

column1: The Rappahannock is Bachman’s thematic thread

column5: it’s unlikely he’ll return to the same geographical feature often. But maybe that’s not necessary now. During the 14-minute opener ""Won’t You Cross Over to that Other Shore""
column6: it’s clear something has shifted with Bachman’s composition and execution. There’s a little bit of raga and a little bit of ragtime
column7: some rock'n'roll gusto and some bluegrass spirit. But all these elements feel connected and cohesive
column8: like bits moving together with perfectly governed momentum. Even when the song swings from its darkest
column9: slowest drags to its shiniest
column10: fastest flourishes
column11: the results feel more personal than professional
column12:
a demonstration of experience rather than education.

column1: Most of it is drawn from the 1980s

There are plangent synthesizers and gently pealing guitars; there are chiming echoes of classical minimalism and even synthetic strings descended from the vernacular heritage of Charles Ives. ""Hollywood"" sounds every bit like the incidental music its title would suggest

column4: E-mu Proteus sound module

column6: at least in part
column7: their technology—long-since outmoded synthesizers
column8: unvarnished drum machines
column9: springy delay that wreathes the music with a hint of fizz—and their aesthetics
column10: a mixture of proto-ambient
column11: late-night television soundtracks
column12: and homebrewed avant-gardism. Both of those artists released electronic music that sounded completely otherworldly in the '80s
column13: and both
column14: like Ricci

column16: via reissues like this one.

column1: In that sense

column3: sounds that even five years ago might have seemed unfashionable suddenly sound fresh. That's not to take away from Ricci's accomplishments: much of I Was Crossing a Bridge is wonderful stuff

column9: an eight-and-a-half-minute fugue for shuddering percussion and chirping analog delay

column16: speaks to the uncanny timeliness of Ricci's work. It's as though gardens planted in vacant lots in the '80s

column18: were finally being harvested
column19: and their heirloom seeds put back into circulation.

column2: and they are

Plucked acoustic guitar cuts against coolly bowed lines and dissolves into a galaxy of delay and faint percussion; dissonant and arrhythmic

column16:

Calling music ""meditative"" often means it's mellow and soothing—a conduit for relaxation. But truly meditative music isn't so much sedative as it is transformative
column2: inducing a deliberately slower
column3: quieter mental state. That's the kind of meditation Haley Fohr encourages as Circuit Des Yeux
column4: and never more so than on In Plain Speech. The album is all long arcs and patient development. It's not laid-back; much of it is urgent and dramatically tense. Fohr's not here to placate
column5: but she does seem bent on getting you to step back
column6: to hear things calmly rather than in a rush.

column1: If that sounds more like a task than a pleasure
column2: don't worry: Fohr does most of the work for you. Her songs escort you toward stillness and awe rather than requiring you to get there first. The music is immediate and enveloping
column3: and because of her rich
column4: stirring voice
column5: it's sometimes even bracing. But once you're ensnared
column6: it becomes quietly mesmerizing. Part of that comes from the way she builds songs
column7: adding pieces and textures subtly over time. But much of In Plain Speech's meditative power is a product of the wholeness and commitment of Fohr's vision
column8: which communicates itself on a more intuitive level.

column1: Often her approach is refreshingly simple: to make you pause
column2: Fohr pauses herself. In ""Do the Dishes""
column3: after a stretched-out haiku moaned over a cycling sample
column4: she retreats into complete silence
column5: then re-emerges with long
column6: wordless tones. A similar full stop comes after the folk-rock climax of ""Fantasize the Scene""
column7: as Fohr appends a string-heavy epilogue that evokes the best dirges of Nico.

column1: Though it doesn't contain a literal pause
column2: ""A Story of This World"" is In Plain Speech's most stillness-inducing track
column3: and its best. On the surface
column4: it's a simple folk tune
column5: with acoustic strums
column6: gentle strings
column7: and Fohr's koans about how ""all the gold turns to rust."" But the tune's primal patience—its willingness to hang in space as it moves
column8: to stand rather than sprint—is so thorough it feels like nature. Here and in the slow-burning instrumental ""Dream of TV""
column9: Circuit Des Yeux recalls the Dirty Three
column10: the way they grow a tune so organically it feels more like weather than music—and the way they tease out powerful emotions without triggering easy sentimentality.

column1: Past Circuit Des Yeux albums flirted with the maudlin
column2: but In Plain Speech feels brighter and more optimistic; the music seems to be continually rising. Where she was once introspective
column3: Fohr is now interested in human connection
column4: using second and third person more than first. ""Do you roam for the end?/ Do you roam to transcend?"" she asks beatifically in ""Ride Blind"". Later
column5: ""Fantasize the Scene"" dreams of eternal companionship: ""I know a place where we could go/ Maybe I will meet you there/ In a world where we'll go all the way.""

column1: The optimism of In Plain Speech still comes with plenty of heavy drama
column2: especially in Fohr's harrowing singing. Dark
column3: thick
column4: and nearly scraping baritone
column5: her voice is so strikingly different —and so unafraid to skirt melodrama—that you can never quite get comfortable with it. But that uniqueness is part of what makes her music so compelling
column6: as is her willingness to drift into wordless sounds—perhaps her recent experience using her voice as an instrument in Mind Over Mirrors was an influence.

column1: Part of In Plain Speech's relative sunniness comes from Fohr's embrace of collaborators. She went it alone on previous albums
column2: and the music was accordingly intimate and confined. Here
column3: with the help of some Chicago neighbors—including Cooper Crain (Cave
column4: Bitchin Bajas)
column5: Rob Frye (Bitchin Bajas)
column6: and Kathleen Baird (Spires That in the Sunset Rise)—her music opens up and spreads out
column7: incorporating more percussion and strings. Fohr's voice remains central
column8: but these partnerships have added new verve to her music.

column1: That openness to collaboration dovetails with Fohr's framing of In Plain Speech as an outward-looking album. As she recently put it
column2: ""This record is me putting out my hand and asking the world to grab onto it."" That may seem to contradict the idea of this music as meditative
column3: but it actually fits quite well. Where previous records offered a portal into Fohr's own inner space
column4: In Plain Speech is about altering her listeners' perceptions
column5:
and taking them somewhere new.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21572/homepage_large.eb000efe.jpg|"Blues: The ""Dark Paintings"" of Mark Rothko"|15877.0|Loren Connors|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Family Vineyard']|2015-05-18 00:00:00|1990|2016-06-11 16:10:52.385585|"

For the last four decades
column2: Loren Connors' guitar miniatures have crept from mysterious and twilit corners
column3: places where bits of blues
column4: jazz
column5: rock
column6: and ambient abstraction formed messy assemblages. Thin little riffs stopped mid-phrase; chords splintered
column7: as if Connors had simply forgotten he was playing them. Background noise cycled through the recording. At first blush
column8: Connors' music can sound casual and even errant
column9: the practice reels of someone learning to play.

column1: But stay with it
column2: and the internal logic of Connors' work becomes evident. Rather than mimic the blues of his forebears and heroes
column3: he splits their style open and reorders the elements. In doing so
column4: he can weep with his guitar
column5: moan
column6: exclaim and even stare (almost silently) into the middle distance. To that end
column7: the newly resurrected Blues: The ""Dark Paintings"" of Mark Rothko is one of the more revelatory sets of Connors' career
column8: one that finds him vocalizing through six electrified strings and adds another emotional sphere to his repertoire.

column1: The restored and remastered edition from Family Vineyard—an imprint that's done essential work in both preserving and pushing Connors' legacy since its second release
column2: in 1999—almost doesn't qualify as a reissue. Sure
column3: it has all the trappings
column4: like a new cover (one of Rothko's ""dark paintings
column5: in fact)
column6: new liner notes
column7: and archival addendums that include the original liner notes. But Dark Paintings was barely issued
column8: anyway. Connors originally released it in 1990
column9: under the short-lived named ""Guitar Roberts"" and on his own label
column10: St. Joan Records
column11: in a hand-made edition of between 200 and 300. For years
column12: its seven tracks have existed mostly as a phantom
column13: something you pilfered from an MP3 blog or heard about rather than heard. At last
column14: however
column15: one of the best documents from an essential
column16: transitional phase of Connors' career is widely available. It's another chance to hear more of him and to understand his quiet intensity.

column1: ""Blues No. 4""
column2: for instance
column3: begins with a frail melody
column4: Connors stepping up and down across the neck. He applies the same pattern across the instrument's range
column5: high notes that nearly squeal countering low ones that sulk. He stretches some into rock'n'roll leads but mostly lets the notes circle around one another
column6: allowing for variations so slight you barely notice. The music's relative simplicity highlights his vibrato
column7: or the way that the whole piece seems to wobble in time. Using only an electric guitar and a four-track recorder
column8: Connors conjures the essence of a battered old 78
column9: a song spit out by the horn of a hulking Victrola. Connors sings these blues with his fingers.

column1: Likewise
column2: during ""No. 6""
column3: Connors sounds alternately like an opera singer and Bessie Smith
column4: with the soprano pleas of his guitar's upper register cutting against a blanket rumble of low notes. Dense tangles unwind into long threads for ""No. 2"". Each time
column5: it's as if you can hear him sigh beneath some heavy burden
column6: like Robert Johnson lamenting the last fair deal or Geeshie Wiley remembering those last kind words. These seven instrumentals represent Connors' responses to a posthumous exhibition of the ""Dark Paintings"" of Mark Rothko
column7: a major ideological and technical influence he's long acknowledged. Rothko finished these works just before committing suicide in 1970. Connors' responses
column8: then
column9: seem like an attempt to live among those same bleak grays and blacks but to not languish in them—that is
column10: to survive by singing about the sadness
column11: not drowning in it. The anguish so apparent in the hand-wringing chords of ""No. 1"" sublimate into a kind of contemplative beauty by the end of ""No. 7"".

column1: When I recently revisited Dark Paintings
column2: I heard in Connors' work an unintentional and contemporary connection I'd never imagined: These seven songs use instrumental guitar to produce the same immersive effect as recent electronic work by the likes of Andy Stott
column3: Demdike Stare
column4: and even Zomby. You yield to the feeling of it all as much as the technical form or finesse
column5: however accomplished that might be. And you depend on the glimpses of light—the gentle melodies
column6: the sudden shouts—that creep through the void. Though Dark Paintings lasts only 29 minutes
column7: it's work that's worth hearing on repeat for hours
column8: as if you live inside these sounds. The meticulous
column9: counterintuitive logic comes into slow focus
column10: and perseverance engrained in these reflections starts to become clear. Rather than succumb to the blues
column11:
Connors and his guitar get them out the best way they know how.

These days
