column2: Bryce Dessner co-designed something called a Chordstick with Aron Sanchez of freak-folk duo Buke and Gase. Their creation is a hammer dulcimer and electric guitar hybrid
column3: combining taut strings with sanded wood and metal fixtures. The instrument only plays two chords
column4: but it's written in a way that dense contrapuntal rhythms—two melodic lines dancing simultaneously without touching—can switch between eight different sets of strings. The resulting sound is complex. It’s thin and full
column5: sharp and malleable
column6: hazy and clear. Brooklyn quartet Sō Percussion employ four of these Chordsticks with remarkable precision in Dessner’s post-minimalism piece
column7: and the sound is the sonic equivalent of WALL·E and EVE dancing in space.

column1: Music for Wood and Strings uses repetition as its canvas. The open space between notes throughout the 10 ""tracks""—the tracklist sections off the piece by style
column2: but the album is continuous—encourages contemplation the same way post-rock bands do. It requires repeat listens
column3: which
column4: given the end ""song"" is a reprise of the 35-minute piece as a whole
column5: comes naturally. The use of mirrored inversions within chords and complex rhythms lends the piece an almost instructional quality
column6: as if it’s teaching you quietly how to listen to it. Like David Lang's The So-Called Laws of Nature
column7: it creates its own sound world.

column1: Dessner chooses a layering of rich tones inspired by the open chords of American folk songs
column2: a deliberate change from the intensity of his debut Aheym. It begins with elongated whole notes peppered by joyful sixteenths
column3: plucking their way through what sounds like a cave walled with blossoming wildflowers. Later
column4: one Chordstick impersonates a spa-like gong and the others tremor like bugs buzzing near the speaker. In ""Section 4"" and""Section 6""
column5: the bass string is plucked with the warmth of a cello. Occasionally a snare drum pops up
column6: but it stays muted in comparison to the strings.

column1: The true beauty of Music for Wood and Strings stems from the enrollment of percussionists
column2: not guitarists
column3: to play these four parts
column4: something that's a little lost in the translation here. Without visual aids
column5: much of the joyful physicality of the performance is gone. Visually
column6: the instruments look like two guitars laid flat beside each other. Sō Percussion don't use hammers to hit the strings. Instead
column7: the players use #2 pencils to tap them like a xylophone
column8: chipping the yellow paint off and creating indents that look like bite marks. Then
column9: of course
column10: come the bows
column11: stretched across the strings and quickly sawed against the highest frets for a trill. Occasionally
column12: the players stretch their thumbs flat against the bridge
column13: pushing down on the strings the way you gently squish an ant on the kitchen counter
column14: creating a muted note. It’s mesmerizing post-minimalism
column15: but in headphones it gets occasionally lost in its own hum. Between his orchestral
column16: chamber
column17: and vocal compositions
column18: this one is Bryce Dessner’s most adventurous work
column19:
but its own reverb masks the very complexities it should boast.

column12: when Welchez asks
column13: ""Hey
column14: boy! Why you gotta be so hard?"" he might as well be posing this question to himself
column15: as he takes off his leather jacket and begins to explore the emotions and rhythms of recording in Mexico City. It’s almost as if the first half of the album is comprised of songs that Crocodiles had finished writing by the time they got to the studio
column16:
and the second half is all of the stuff that they came up with while they were there. And this exploratory spirit is where Boys finds its strength.

All cool guy posturing is gone by the time they get to ""Blue""
column17: a wispy melody that recalls the Zombies. This might be the most honest thing Crocodiles have recorded yet
column18: with lyrics like
column19: ""Years chained up in shame
column20: nothing but family to blame/ Now when darkness arrives it swallows all that lived inside."" Also noteworthy is the interplay between the polished pop structure and the queasy guitar on ""Peroxide Hearts"". It's unclear what they are going for with the song ""Transylvania""
column21: which seems to broach themes of trans-identity. The spirit of the song is reverent and anthemic
column22: but lines like ""sometimes it's such a drag to be a man"" miss the mark
column23: unless the mark was groan-inducing puns. Incidentally
column24: the song's chorus may be the catchiest thing on <i>Boys
column26:
it shows us Crocodiles actively moving outside of their comfort zone.

The same goes for the syncopated rhythms they put under numbers like ""Kool TV"" and album closer ""Don’t Look Up"". Whether this was the influence of producer Martin Thulin
column27: the band soaking up their environs in Mexico City
column28: or a little bit of both
column29: it’s a winning combination. Crocodiles have referred to this new sound as salsa-punk and ""muy chingón!"" which
column31: means ""fucking awesome"" in Spanish. They don’t quite get the salsa part right
column32:
but that’s what makes this unique. Some of the most inventive music can come from people not quite understanding a different kind of music: The fact that this braver experimentalism rounds out an album that begins with old formulaic fuzz provides hope that the next Crocodiles release will actually be fucking awesome.

"|20595.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20595-boys/|5.6|Pat Healy

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21731/homepage_large.688e19d4.jpg|Frozen Niagara Falls|3478.0|Prurient|['Experimental']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2015-05-14 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:10:57.818394|"

Prurient
column2: the main guise of Dominick Fernow
column3: peels back the grislier aspects of the human condition within the boundaries of noise music. He doesn't just talk about desire and hate and pushing oneself in his music
column4: he soaks those very feelings into his works. Within his massive discography
column5: littered with limited-release tapes that can be frustrating to any would-be collector
column6: are his ""statement"" records
column7: which often introduce new elements that advance his artistic growth. Among these are 2006's Pleasure Ground
column8: where his talents for rhythm really started to bloom
column9: 2011's Bermuda Drain
column10: his blackened new wave masterpiece
column11: and 2013's Through The Window
column12: where he nearly ditched noise for unknown-hours techno. Frozen Niagara Falls
column13: Fernow's latest double album
column14: is definitely one of his ""statement records
column15: and it brings back much of the harsh noise that faded away from his more recent works
column16: but it's neither a ""return to form"" nor a retreat into his early career. With Niagara
column17: he's taken strengths from his entire oeuvre to reach deeper into himself and produce what may be his best record yet
column18: one that brings all the fulfillment of noise and transcends them all the same.

column1: Fernow's moved back to New York from L.A.
column2: where he was briefly a member of Cold Cave
column3: and Niagara cements that return. There's none of the techno of Window or any traces of his European adventures following his side project Vatican Shadow's frequent touring there
column4: and only some of Bermuda's bizzaro synth-pop. There are no remaining traces of Fernow the underground playboy posting swanky selfies on OkCupid; on Niagara
column5: he is once again the man standing shirtless outside in the New York winter. The closest to anything resembling Bermuda is ""Every Relationship Earthrise""
column6: which would make for excellent darkwave if the hiccuping beat would hold still.

column1: Fernow takes the tools most noise artists use as ends themselves and uses them to further narratives and enrich the compositions. Take ""Traditional Snowfall""
column2: which starts off as a murder-romance fantasy—""I want to rip out your lower back/ And suck the air out of your lungs/ And wrap my hands around your neck/ And collapse your throat/ And squish your thorax/ And kiss you""—but turns into a rumination on the ambiguity so prevalent in modern love: ""Friends are everywhere but I'm always leaving/ Dismantling us with rumors."" (Maybe some of the club weariness of Window stuck around after all.) Fernow takes that confusion and buries it in the hisses and frantic electronics
column3: so that it bleeds through every element of the track. Huge blasts of static and contact mic chaos come back into the fore
column4: a passionate and turbulent dance between beauty and ugliness. To work with contrasts like that
column5: on that deep a composition
column6: is a rarity in noise.

column1: It may seem weird that Prurient would have ""hits"" or ""fan favorites
column2: but they do exist. Fernow designed Niagara to be sprawling and cohesive
column3: and there are multiple competing candidates for new ones here
column4: across the spectrum. The first would probably be ""Dragonflies to Sew You Up""
column5: with percussion that resemble Godflesh's drum machine becoming sentient and suffering a panic attack. Beneath the barrage
column6: blue synthesizers and pianos chime
column7: barely surviving the mortar-fire of the percussion. In the lyrics
column8: Fernow flips the script on how lust is portrayed in noise—it's far from the simplistic objectification that comes too often with big
column9: burly loud music. There's a conflicted pain when he screams
column10: ""IN AUGUST/ YOU'RE OVERDRESSED/ PLYWOOD BROKEN/ UP ON IMPACT."" A line like ""I promise I will only fuck prostitutes"" may seem comical on paper
column11: but add in the context of Fernow's vocal performance
column12: and it's clear he takes no pleasure from yelling such a thing.

column1: Fernow's synths sound both lusher and icier than they did on Drain
column2: thanks to producer Arthur Rizk
column3: known for his work on Power Trip's Manifest Decimation
column4: Inquisition's Obscure Verses for the Multiverse
column5: and other notable recent metal and hardcore records. Fernow has pushed the limits of what lo-fi can do—Pleasure in particular is a testament to the beauty of buried synths—but with his grander ambitions
column6: he needed a bigger sound
column7: and Rizk's contributions are so invaluable he may as well be Prurient's second member. Niagara is Prurient's most developed record
column8: not just for its length
column9: but the attention to detail that Rizk provides.

column1: Fernow's original intent for Niagara was to source all of the material acoustically
column2: with no electronics at all. That would have been radical
column3: even for him. Still
column4: upon first listen
column5: it is jarring to hear acoustic guitars
column6: provided by Rizk and Fernow
column7: in the beginning of ""Greenpoint""
column8: Niagara's peak New York song. From there
column9: it descends into throbs of darkness
column10: but that's only part of the point of the song. While ""Greenpoint"" is about someone Fernow knew
column11: when I read the lyrics my mind went to Oliver Sacks' New Yorker essay on monologist Spalding Gray's descent into irreversible depression that led to his suicide in 2004. Gray's thoughts of suicide always centered around drowning and his mother
column12: whose own suicide figured heavily into his work
column13: and it's eerie that ""The East River isn't romantic anymore you know/ That's where the suicides go/ Or maybe that's what you want in the end/ To be mixed together and reunited with your mother"" are almost as if they were about him. It's specific yet flexible
column14: adding another layer of complexity as only Fernow can.

column1: Like ""Greenpoint""
column2: closer ""Christ Among the Broken Glass"" shows a side of Prurient that is sometimes overlooked: poignancy. It's also the closest thing to Fernow's original vision for Niagara
column3: which makes it an even more appropriate ending. The sound of fire combines with the guitars
column4: evoking a séance more than a campfire. Like ""I Understand You""
column5: the closing track from JK Flesh and Prurient's Worship Is the Cleansing of the Imagination where fragile glimmers of serenity are eaten without mercy by squalling feedback
column6: ""Christ"" reveals itself slowly. Niagara was recorded ""in the spirit of homelessness
column7: and Fernow's lyrics in ""Christ"" capture how winter brutalizes the homeless and how self-sacrifice can make one appear messianic
column8: especially when that figure is among the afflicted themselves. The man
column9: ""Jesus of cities
column10: becomes both more noble and more destitute with every verse—""Cobbling together syllables/ Over a frostbitten tongue/ Trying to remember the prayers""—though this isn't about pity
column11: but about reality. Fernow's hushed vocals don't even come in until close to the end of the song
column12: and they make his silent stalker tone on Window sound pronounced in comparison. Who knew that one of the least noisy Prurient songs would strike the deepest?

column1: A double noise album is a lot to take in
column2: and Prurient's never been about accessibility. He's also not about acceptable signifiers; he's bigger than noise. He offers an endless
column3: probing self-exploration that simply isn't found in noise
column4: metal
column5: hardcore
column6: power electronics
column7: whatever harsh music you can think of. In that regard
column8: Niagara is a landmark not just in Prurient's discography
column9: but within extreme music. His few utterances in ""Falling Mask"" sum up the experience of the album
column10: and of his body of work: ""What we do/ We invite pain/ It's ok to be hungry/ Hunger is normal/ I'll meet you there."" He knows Prurient isn't for everybody
column11: and that's part of the appeal
column12: but if you're not going to invite growth and reveal yourself
column13:
why bother?

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21682/homepage_large.78bbfdd0.jpg|Rivington Não Rio|3384.0|Prefuse 73|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Temporary Residence']|2015-05-14 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:10:58.283656|"

The beats Guillermo Scott Herren has been constructing as Prefuse 73 for 15 years resemble the work of a master graphic designer. The way a skilled Adobe Creative Suite architect takes old
column2: obscure fonts and images and re-appropriates them against a backdrop of razor-sharp typesetting and wide-open white space is retro-futurist art of the highest order
column3: and it is similar to the way the Miami-born
column4: Atlanta-bred producer builds his beats from fragments of voices
column5: instruments and found sounds reprocessed through his MPC. And while he got his start in the experimental/post-rock realm under his Delarosa and Asora and Savath y Savalas monikers
column6: it was Prefuse 73 that exhibited Herren's true skill set as a producer and composer. His grooves were not so much chopped up and flipped
column7: in the DJ Premier sense
column8: as they were shattered like an antique plate
column9: only to be reassembled with the delicacy of a day-camp craft project.

column1: His debut under the Prefuse handle
column2: 2001's Vocal Studies + Uprock Narratives
column3: harnessed the energy of Radiohead's Kid A and planted its formula smack in the middle of a white-hot hip-hop New York City underground
column4: in the midst of Def Jux's heyday. It also gave Herren's label at the time
column5: Warp Records
column6: the credibility it so desperately sought out upon moving their offices to New York City: In the years that followed
column7: Warp would come to depend on Herren's uncanny knowledge and talent as a de facto A&R guy to help the label transcend its rep as a purely IDM imprint by introducing them to some of their most popular acts
column8: including Anti-Pop Consortium
column9: Battles
column10: and a young DJ out of Los Angeles by the name Flying Lotus.

column1: Here in 2015
column2: FlyLo is one of the biggest names in abstract hip-hop. Meanwhile
column3: the man born Steven Ellison and the curated roster of acolytes on his own boutique label—Brainfeeder Records—are inspiring a whole new generation of DJs and beat junkies to smash their preconceptions of rhythm and piece it back together as they like. For Warp
column4: Flying Lotus has become an event artist on par with Boards of Canada and Aphex Twin. Meanwhile
column5: the man who brought the kid to the party found himself dropped from his longtime label.

column1: In 2013
column2: he launched his own micro imprint Yellow Year
column3: yet couldn't sustain the funding to keep the hustle going. Now
column4: fully empowered by a new deal with <a href=""http://temporaryresidence.com/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Temporary Residence
column5: Ltd.
column6: who picked him up on the good word of pals Kieran Hebden and Nigel Godrich
column7: Herren reboots the Prefuse brand for the first time since 2011's dicey The Only She Chapters with not one but three new titles. Some have criticized Herren in recent years for falling too deep into the chasm of his own wild ambitions
column8: exploring his Catalina heritage with Savath and losing the plot of Prefuse on such lackluster fare as 2007's Preparations and 2009's Everything She Touched Turned Ampexian. With this past April's Forsyth Gardens and new full-length Rivington Não Rio
column9: Herren returns to the essence of what made works like Uprock
column10: The 92 vs. 02 Collection and One Word Extinguisher such essential sonic backdrops for walks along the chain-linked fences of shady
column11: grass-patched lots in pre-""Girls"" Williamsburg.

column1: Following the meh response to his Warp swan song
column2: it seems like Herren has reckoned that the human voice works best for his beats when it is diced into a million fragments
column3: and he juggles the oohs and aahs of random vocalists on Forsyth highlights like ""Genderations""
column4: ""Still Pretending"" and ""Sará Teflón"" with the same deftness he showed to Erykah Badu back on Uprock in 2001. Elsewhere
column5: his ties to the old Chicago indie Hefty Records can be heard in the Tortoise-esque sway of such heady LP jams from as ""Applauded Assumptions"" and ""Jacinto Lyric Range"". ""Mojav Mating Call"" is the closest you will ever hear to an aesthetic compound of Prefuse
column6: Delarosa
column7: and Savath yet
column8: as if he is utilizing Rivington's penultimate track to fuse them all together permanently.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Herren's multi-dimensional ear remains firmly affixed to what's hot with the limited guest list space made available for these works
column3: Rivington in particular. ""Infared"" is featured on both Forsyth and Rivington
column4: and is enhanced by the stoned soul wobble of Sam Dew
column5: formerly of the severely slept-on Atlanta art-rock outfit Cloudeater. Former Savath associate Roberto Carlos Lange of Helado Negro fame helps Herren dive back into the science of their old outfit's sole Stones Throw LP
column6: 2009's La Llama on ""See More Than Just Stars""
column7: and flexes his newfound affiliation with Temporary Residence by recruiting Rob Crow on ""Quiet One""
column8: a mellow synthpop gem that's more Pet Shop Boys than Pinback. The supreme assist happens on ""140 Jabs Interlude""
column9: which features the criminally
column10: perennially overlooked Busdriver and his longtime associate Milo
column11: who uses his ""middle finger to smear shit on far-fetched idols.""<br class=""kix-line-break""/><br class=""kix-line-break""/>The relationship between Prefuse 73 and Temporary Residence has certainly inspired the producer to peel off his best work in well over a decade
column12: while proving exactly how well he will fit beside the likes of old pals from the Books Zammuto and Paul de Jong
column13: William Basinski
column14: Grails
column15: and Rachel Grimes on one of the best label stables going right now. But ultimately
column16: what Forsyth Gardens
column17: Rivington Não Rio and the upcoming trilogy finale
column18: the more ominously hued Every Color of Darkness EP
column19: accomplish is to provide a memento on where all the long division that factors into today's beloved L.A. beat science originates. And not to take anything away from FlyLo
column20: the Brainfeeder squad
column21: or their advances in bringing the fusion of jazz and hip-hop to its most progressive and organic period in years
column22: but it is rewarding to have Herren's voice at the table again
column23:
to remind the world where a sizeable chunk of this sound derived.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21764/homepage_large.58377f6a.jpg|Life of a Hot Boy 2: Real Trapper|32881.0|Bankroll Fresh|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-05-14 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:10:58.906318|"

Bankroll Fresh was once known as Yung Fresh
column2: and appeared alongside Mr. Perfect-era Gucci Mane on a small handful of records. Now
column3: with a minor hit in 2014's Cash Money-referencing ""Hot Boy""
column4: a Mike WiLL Made It cosign
column5: and Instagram shout-outs from Drake and
column6: uh
column7: Marilyn Manson
column8: he is Bankroll Fresh
column9: one of several young ATLiens making a move for his city's street rap center.

column1: Perhaps because of his older pedigree
column2: the rapper's style doesn't owe Gucci as much of a stylistic debt as others in the current Atlanta rookie class. This is his substantial advantage: at a time when most emulate a series of now-conventional flows
column3: Bankroll seems intent on scratching out his own fresh rhythmic pathways
column4: discovering his own pocket in the groove. (""Free Wop Freestyle (Free Gucci)"" is the exception that proves the rule.) Bankroll's vocal tone doesn't have the same effortless panache and character of Gucci's own; in some ways he seems downright regular. But Gucci's influence looms so large in Atlanta street rap that this is a refreshing strategy
column5: exhibiting an inner artistic confidence. Externally
column6: though
column7: Life of a Hot Boy 2: Real Trapper is a spare
column8: skeletal record
column9: more a model on which to build possible futures than a real destination.

column1: The album is least imaginative in its opening moments
column2: which feel like an overt attempt to recapture the spirit of Trap or Die/Thug Motivation-era Jeezy
column3: with producer D.Rich emulating the sheet metal symphonies of Shawty Redd. But the bulk of the tape sticks to Bankroll's core sound
column4: an unwavering flatline on a black-and-white canvas
column5: dominated by locked-in
column6: often against-the-beat flows (""Thats Whats Goin On"") that emphasize repetition with the deliberate percussiveness of a typewriter. Thus far none of his records have replicated the success of his last tape's big single ""Hot Boy""
column7: and none here seem poised to do so either. But even that record felt like something of an uphill hit
column8: its chorus successful mainly through bludgeoning repetition.

column1: The effect of this dry
column2: minimal approach to trap music is going to limit this tape's audience from the jump: to enjoy this record
column3: you've got to really love the bare-bones particulars of street music
column4: distilled not so much in the service of therapeutic aggression—as it was for Flockaveli—but as a kind of audience GPS. To put it bluntly
column5: the album's subject matter doesn't extend too far beyond that of Gucci's ""My Kitchen"". Here
column6: it suggests
column7: is Atlanta's missing piece
column8: at a time when eccentric ATLiens like Young Thug
column9: Future
column10: and Rich Homie Quan experiment with different textural palettes and shades of emotion. Bankroll
column11: by contrast
column12: hasn't fleshed out his world much yet
column13: leaving these songs as line-drawings of the dope dealer day-to-day over three-note piano loops.

column1: Not that there aren't inspired moments
column2: particularly in the tape's second half. The Zaytoven-produced ""Ten"" features some tongue-twisting lyrics (""Livin like the mob
column3: fly to Vegas just to ditch ya/ Dom Perignon sipper
column4: cigar-clipper
column5: Vuitton slippers""). The buzzing King Cee O-produced ""360""
column6: much like his ""Screen Door"" collaboration with Mike WiLL on the latter's Ransom
column7: suggests the rapper's style works best with some driving momentum behind him. The tape's best song overall is the D.Rich-produced ""Fabulous"". With brushed snares that sound lifted from former No Limit producer KLC
column8: quivering synthesizers borrowed from Gucci Mane's Fat Boi-produced ""Haunted House""
column9: and a piano loop that suggests the atmosphere of 2Pac's DeVante Swing-produced ""No More Pain""
column10: the song is at once several sounds and none—less a costume than a creation.

column1: The stripped-down sound of the record makes Bankroll easily adaptable to different styles—the album's closer is a Zaytoven version of Master P's ""I'm Bout It
column2: Bout It""—without committing too completely to anything
column3: and his facility for off-center flows is impressive. But he also stands in the shadow of more audacious experiments that have hit hip-hop in recent years: Big Sean
column4: of course
column5: has been doing the against-the-groove rap style for some time. But he's the tip of the iceberg in Detroit
column6: where artists like Pablo Skywalkin and Yae Yae Jordan experiment radically while keeping the street approach at the forefront. In the drill scene
column7: Keef has incorporated melody into his songs while virtually uncoupling himself from the rhythmic grid
column8: and King Louie experimented with repeating flow patterns (and even recorded his own similar Gucci flow tribute back in 2009).

column1: Atlanta is a hotbed of hip-hop talent
column2: it's true
column3: but that's also a marketing cliche. Now that its singular space within hip-hop has been so well-established over the past two decades
column4: each new artist arrives with the pressure of its city's proven track record behind it as decorative momentum. Only today
column5: Atlanta faces new challengers
column6: and artists like Bankroll don't have as clear a lane as they once did. This isn't to suggest Bankroll Fresh isn't an original voice. But just being from Atlanta may no longer guarantee you the biggest footprint
column7:
and Life of a Hot Boy 2 doesn’t make much of one by itself.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21708/homepage_large.02a9afaf.jpg|Send Two Sunsets|30512.0|Gacha|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Apollo']|2015-05-14 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:10:59.680711|"

In the fractured
column2: constantly evolving world of electronic music
column3: it's tempting to prioritize the shock of the the new: the post-ironic zap of PC Music
column4: the maximalist eclecticism of Hudson Mohawke
column5: the sculptural zen of Oneohtrix Point Never. But sometimes old sounds can be worth revisiting
column6: especially if they're molded by a particularly sure hand. Newcomer Gacha Bakradze
column7: who hails from Tbilisi
column8: Georgia and splits his time between Paris and his native city
column9: isn't interested in carving out a signature
column10: cutting-edge sound. Instead
column11: his debut LP
column12: Send Two Sunsets
column13: floats atop a bath of well-worn nostalgia that
column14: by definition (and purpose)
column15: asks little of its audience except to be soothed.

column1: In his press materials
column2: Gacha cites shoegazers Slowdive
column3: German experimentalists Cluster
column4: and Madchester mainstays the Durutti Column among his inspirations. Each touchstone is easy to spot—so easy
column5: that
column6: at times
column7: Two Sunsets scans as an homage to its forebears. Like much of Cluster's ambient work
column8: Gacha’s leans towards sounds that are unabashedly pleasurable to experience. The aptly titled ""Bliss""
column9: featuring Natalie Beridze—a frequent collaborator of Gacha's who also performs under the name TBA—shifts between delicate synth-pop and ambient psychedelia. ""Blue Distance""
column10: on the other hand
column11: uses MIDI plugins seemingly discovered beneath <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wHFIN55q9pQ"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Dire
column12: Dire Docks or sourced from Cisco's ""Opus Number 1"" CallManager Muzak. Though Gacha employs those tools deftly
column13: the spa-day palette recalls sounds that have also been mined by recent producers looking to revive new age in the new millennium; fans of How to Dress Well's ""Ocean Floor for Everything"" will recognize a shared sentimentality for 64-bit sequencing.

column1: Send Two Sunsets comes on the heels of two EPs
column2: Remember and When the Watchman Saw the Light
column3: both released via Apollo Records
column4: the ambient-leaning subdivision of R&S Records. R&S
column5: aside from its roots in the Belgian New Beat scene of the mid-'80s
column6: has released music from Aphex Twin
column7: C. J. Bolland
column8: and James Blake over the years. It's a label that carries three decades of history
column9: yet continues to push the medium forward. (Recent signees include genre-benders like Lone and Tessela.) But it's clear from the beginning that Send Two Sunsets is more historical excavation than vanguard innovation—a position Gacha seems happy to occupy. Sunsets can largely be seen as a continuation of Gacha's previous two releases
column10: whose tracks ebb and flowed with a similarly harmonious calm. (Just looking at the album cover will likely give you some idea of Gacha's palette
column11: whose Mediterranean rhythms evoke the Balearic '80s at their most relaxed.)

column1: Over the course of its relatively brief nine tracks
column2: Send Two Sunsets oscillates between low-key house (""Street Talk"")
column3: bubbling ambient (""Blue Distance"")
column4: and meditative pop (""Send Two Sunsets"")
column5: but all share similarly aquatic presets. Album opener ""Abandoned City"" falls into the first category
column6: with New Age arpeggios and no percussive elements to speak of. It's a sound that brings to mind Jürgen Müller's Science of the Sea
column7: an album that had originally been marketed as a rediscovered record from the early '80s only to be revealed later to be a modern production.

column1: Here
column2: there's a similar feeling of productions that have been submerged and forgotten only to be unearthed decades later. ""Waterfall""
column3: a gorgeous track that also features Beridze
column4: shimmers like refracted sunlight. Then there's ""Let Me Love You""
column5: an amalgam of deep house and deconstructed R&B that sets indistinct vocals amidst piano and understated percussion; repeat listens reveal a track not only exceedingly pretty
column6: but disarmingly soulful. More often than not
column7: Sunsets continues to reveal new facets the more time you spend with it
column8:
the familiar giving way to deeper emotional undercurrents just below the surface.

"|20440.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20440-send-two-sunsets/|7.1|Nathan Reese

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21808/homepage_large.4bf3ae6a.jpg|High on Tulsa Heat|32903.0|John Moreland|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Old Omens']|2015-05-14 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:00.495649|"

The lane is wide open for the would-be country revivalist. As the mainstream product increasingly incorporates new sounds and attitudes
column2: there will always be audiences yearning for the sparer
column3: ""rootsier"" sounds transporting them back to the days of the Highwaymen. It's an evergreen niche
column4: and it is forever welcoming to new entrants.

column1: Enter Oklahoman songwriter John Moreland. Though Moreland has been making this sort of music since 2008—his last release was 2013's In the Throes
column2: a sorrowful and spare collection of heavy-hearted country rockers—his background playing in local punk and hardcore groups gives him a good feel for forcefulness. Many of the songs on Moreland's new album High on Tulsa Heat
column3: arguably Moreland's prettiest if not his most most musically vivid release
column4: capture this feeling—""Cherokee""
column5: in particular
column6: weaves a solemn guitar line with Moreland's weathered vocal to devastating effect. (""I've got a taste for poison/ I'm giving up on ever being well/ I keep mining the horizon/ Digging for lies I've yet to tell."")

column1: High on Tulsa Heat is filled with simple delights like ""Cherokee"". Songs like opener ""Hang Me in the Tulsa County Stars"" and the title track push Moreland's voice forward while accenting its weary wisdom with simple accompaniments—sliding guitar
column2: pedal steel
column3: economically applied—and harmonies (""Heart's Too Heavy""). High on Tulsa Heat finds a nice balance between the spare and sad (""Cleveland County Blues"") and warm moods
column4: and on balance
column5: it's strangely uplifting.

column1: Moreland lacks the cynical sharpness and humor of fellow travelers like Sturgill Simpson—whose Metamodern Sounds of Country Music stands as a high watermark for this generation's wave of ""alt country"". Moreland's songs are simpler and open up in more conventional ways. On High on Tulsa Heat
column2: small details feel like major victories—for instance
column3: the soft tambourine and shaker flourishes on album highlight ""White Flag"". Moreland's music is sad
column4: to be sure—but even as he's singing about being useless and an addict (""You need something stronger/ A drug to kill the hunger/ And ease the awful pain of living here"" from ""You Don't Care for Me Enough to Cry"")
column5: you can hear a palpable hope for redemption coursing through. There is plenty of well-worn sentiment and saltiness in his music
column6: but there is also a relatable humanity that makes High on Tulsa Heat worth going back to. Though many of the songs convey images of earthiness and of dirt
column7:
there's a beauty that helps the collection soar above the ground.

"|20540.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20540-high-on-tulsa-heat/|7.0|Corban Goble

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21703/homepage_large.10a9e818.jpg|Bush|4102.0|Snoop Dogg|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2015-05-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:01.417384|"

Over the course of two decades
column2: Snoop Dogg’s adaptability has allowed him to move from the G-funk of ""Gin and Juice"" to the sweaty club anthems of ""Down 4 My N’s"" to the reggae of Snoop Lion. His voice sounds good over all kinds of production
column3: but some of his best late-period work has come when collaborating with the Neptunes. The success of ""Beautiful"" established Snoop
column4: the Neptunes
column5: and Charlie Wilson as a powerful team
column6: and led to the Virginia producers contributing several tracks (including the chart-topping ""Drop It Like It’s Hot"") to his 2004 album
column7: R&G (Rhythm & Gangsta): The Masterpiece. With Bush
column8: fans who might have yearned for a Snoop album produced entirely by the Neptunes at the time (almost) get their wish: Pharrell Williams handles the boards here
column9: with occasional assistance from his former production partner Chad Hugo.

column1: Bush was conceived as a tribute to the funk and R&B of the 1970s
column2: and the familiar wail of Stevie Wonder’s harmonica on the stand-out opener
column3: ""California Roll""
column4: establishes the mood. Over an instrumental as smooth as a ride down Rodeo Drive on an 85-degree day
column5: Snoop's croon is convincing enough to sell lines like “So if you wanna go to Melrose/ Let’s hit Adidas
column6: girl
column7: we got our own shell toes."" Pharrell positions L.A. as the nucleus of luxury and vice (""Baby you can be a movie star/ Get yourself a medical card
column8: yeah/ ‘Cause that’s how California rolls"") on the sticky hook
column9: and Wonder accents P’s trademark falsetto with background vocals.

column1: Both Snoop and Pharrell are products of the '70s
column2: so it makes sense that they'd embrace the ambiance of the music they grew up listening to
column3: and that they'd be pretty good at it. The mood holds from the bubbly disco of ""R U A Freak"" to the Nile Rodgers-inspired guitar work on ""Awake""
column4: a song that brings to mind the second wind you get during a party’s final 20 minutes. On ""Peaches N Cream""
column5: Snoop
column6: Pharrell
column7: and Wilson combine once again for an infectious retro-funk fusion. From start to finish
column8: Bush is a feel-good record.

column1: Snoop has said that he tapped Pharrell for creative guidance because he wanted a cohesive sound for the album. At just 41 minutes long
column2: Bush is indeed an easy listen
column3: but the songs also bleed together. ""I Knew That""
column4: for example
column5: opens with the same motif as the one used on the superior ""Peaches N Cream"". And although the album features just 10 songs
column6: it feels like there are only about six. Bush is designed to function as an old funk record that you can let run for an entire party’s duration
column7: but its uniformity might make it less appealing over the long haul.

column1: Still
column2: it makes sense for Snoop to be making this type of music at this stage of his career
column3: as he approaches his mid-forties and rap recedes into his past. The music puts past images of him grooving to Bootsy Collins while stoned in Baby Boy or dancing to Funkadelic in The Wash in perspective—funk has long been his lifeblood. So while Bush is strong enough musically
column4: you can’t help but wonder what would’ve happened if this crew had followed R&G with a full-length a decade ago
column5:
when everyone involved was still in his prime.

"|20435.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20435-bush/|6.5|Julian Kimble

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21787/homepage_large.bf9cb1ab.jpg|Hairless Toys|2963.0|Róisín Murphy|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['PIAS']|2015-05-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:02.099779|"

""I didn’t become a pop star
column2: and nobody knows exactly why
column3: said Róisín Murphy of her last full-length album
column4: 2007’s Overpowered. In retrospect
column5: it’s shocking everyone didn’t immediately grasp exactly why. Never mind the talk of career repositioning and the Super Glue-sticky singles and the high-fashion diva-ing—Overpowered may not have been immediate
column6: but it was classic in its own way
column7: and prescient. There’s no shortage of people dissecting her influence on other artists’ gonzo fashion
column8: and many artists are now making dancefloor tracks that embrace house piano and disco tropes
column9: even if they’d fizzle and die if held up next to ""Let Me Know"". But given the modern dance revival’s rigid stratification of artists into shrugged-away female vocalists and celebrated male producer-celebrities
column10: perhaps it’s for the best that Murphy has shied away from trends
column11: and with a few exceptions
column12: mostly foregone guest spots.

column1: Indeed
column2: Murphy’s output over the past near-decade has been wildly unpredictable
column3: ranging from dance bangers with porno guitars (""Orally Fixated"") to an Édith Piaf-inspired EP of Italian art songs not to mention two remix EPs that might have stirred the highest of emotions on the dancefloor
column4: if only people heard them. And Hairless Toys continues this trend. It’s the most cerebral work of Murphy’s decades-long career
column5: and arguably the one with her most creative control yet
column6: letting listeners closer into her head than ever yet keeping them at a distance even there.

column1: The album comes with a few preconceptions. ""Gone Fishing"" was inspired by the New York ball scene
column2: which
column3: coming from a white Irish woman well after ball culture returned to the mainstream
column4: has the potential to get dicey fast. And Murphy’s rationale for the record—""I envisioned ‘Gone Fishing’ almost as a song from a Broadway musical version of [iconic documentary Paris Is Burning]""—is not so far from Madonna co-opting vogueing into a machine to make herself endless context-free royalties. But ""Gone Fishing"" is less sonic homage
column5: more earnest expression of empathy. And if Hairless Toys takes anything from that world it’s the subtext: it’s largely an album about confronting one’s failures and anxieties and outsider feelings and mythologizing them.

column1: Sometimes others are invited in. ""Exploitation"" is nine-and-a-half minutes of circling closer and closer around one obsessive question: ""Who’s exploiting who?"" The sexual overtones are there if you’re looking for them
column2: the sociological analogies almost make themselves: artists exploiting subjects
column3: or vice versa. But that’s all overly serious for a track this deliberately whimsical: polyrhythms
column4: a cartoon cliff-dive of a guitar riff after the lyric ""the depths that they will go
column5: fax-machine noises—all fascinating sounds
column6: manipulated one after the other to make you think they mean something.

column1: ""Exploitation"" is also the most traditional single on an album mostly concerned with inner pain. ""Uninvited Guest"" is more typical
column2: describing a quite specific emotional state: the near-agoraphobic inertia—total inactivity from the outside
column3: a deafening restless twitch on the inside—that comes of anxiety and having enough money to stay there forever: ""I could get out of my head/ Even all the money I have left
column4: I could buy another day of nothing."" The music’s somewhere between synesthesia of the mood and a dark joke at its own expense: hi-hat tremors
column5: backing vocals elbowing through the mix
column6: a bridge to lose time in
column7: a helpless shrug of a whistling line. (Murphy
column8: like just about everyone who shares a genre and gender
column9: has fought off Kate Bush comparisons
column10: and continues to do so; but ""Guest""
column11: in topic and particularly in its wry gallows humor
column12: is much like an introvert’s ""Sat in Your Lap"".)

column1: ""Exile"" is a torch song delivered in a wearied whisper
column2: every note heard through smoke
column3: evoking less the dance floor than a bar that’s 2 a.m. empty. ""Unputdownable"" is a traditional Murphy extended metaphor—lover as page-turning book—with a mid-track swerve that reveals it not as a love song but something less requited
column4: more unknowable: ""I’d open up the book and climb right up out of the town...if you’d allow me to read your mind."" (Like much of Hairless Toys
column5: it almost seems like a comment on the record as well.)

column1: It’s heady stuff
column2: but the album’s emotional landscape is sketched so distinctly there’s ample reason to stick with it. There’s also
column3: three-fourths through
column4: a musical payoff. ""House of Glass"" delivers grand statements
column5: often set stark against the music as if underlined in fire: ""We were glass house girls in our plastic wigs and pearls""; ""People like us from broken homes never throw stones""; ""Little pieces of a broken dream""; ""Built a house of glass out of fragments from the blast."" Fittingly
column6: it also builds up to the album’s centerpiece: the chords from ""Exploitation""
column7: the ascending peals from ""Gone Fishing""
column8: disco guitar licks and swarming background vocals assembled into a fragile yet stunning climax. It’s all gleaming and immaculate from a distance
column9:
sharp and shattered if you get too close.

"|20518.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20518-hairless-toys/|7.4|Katherine St. Asaph

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21727/homepage_large.6431a144.jpg|Dumb Flesh|29644.0|Blanck Mass|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2015-05-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:03.906405|"

Since 2008's Street Horrrsing
column2: Fuck Buttons has served to sublimate the noise genre into something that fans with lower tolerances for extreme music might enjoy. From the band's unlikely (but fittingly epic) use in the 2012 London Olympics opening ceremony
column3: to its status as festival mainstays
column4: Fuck Buttons have brought music of the most punishing variety to an unusual level of popularity. If ""pop"" is what's popular
column5: then Fuck Buttons fit the bill by definition
column6: but no other act of their level can claim to scorch audiences with Fisher-Price-processed screams
column7: only to rocket into a stratosphere of major-key bliss. For every club-leaning detour (""Prince's Prize"") or humanist anthem (""Olympians"")
column8: there's a relentless ""Brainfreeze"" to remind us that the band is as unruly as ever.

column1: The same can be said for the duo's solo ventures. Though Dumb Flesh is the second full-length LP from Blanck Mass
column2: the stage name used by Benjamin John Power
column3: it's been four years since his self-titled debut and three since his ""White Math / Polymorph"" single. In that time Fuck Buttons also released Slow Focus
column4: their biggest-sounding record to date
column5: and Andrew Hung
column6: who records under his given name
column7: dropped the retro-bizarro weirdness that was the Rave Cave EP. (Sure
column8: Beck plays a Game Boy on stage
column9: but who can say they made an entire album on one?) Dumb Flesh is an often-fascinating document of Power's evolving tastes over that time period
column10: as well as a departure from his murky first album. While Blanck Mass often featured glacial build-ups and monotonous loops
column11: Dumb Flesh is filled with handclaps
column12: 808s and is-that-human-or-what? vocal samples. But for a record whose cover art is pinkish folds of human biomass
column13: much of Dumb Flesh is actually pretty darn accessible. It also serves as occasional proof that Power is amenable to the idea that people might actually want to
column14: like
column15: dance to his music.

column1: As the title and cover art suggest
column2: Dumb Flesh is an album about the fragility of the human body
column3: one that uses sonic degeneration as a metaphor for the biological kind. Opener ""Loam"" is a sound-collage of groaning vocals enmeshed with reversed tape hiss
column4: while a mid-tempo chillout cut with squelching synths and a head-bobbing beat is called ""Atrophies"". Across the record
column5: Power uses sounds that meld into each other fluidly
column6: an ouroboros of cyclical synths where you don't know where one loop begins and another ends.

column1: Fuck Buttons solo projects often give the chance to spot individual seams in what usually appears as a singular
column2: monolithic endeavor
column3: but Dumb Flesh could be mistaken for the latest Fuck Buttons album
column4: albeit one looser and less cohesive than usual. The themes may be dark
column5: but the songs often contain the ecstatic blissfulness of the band's best and most transcendental beauty. ""Cruel Sport""
column6: a name that echoes Fuck Buttons' enormous-sounding second album
column7: for instance
column8: starts with a driving beat similar to ""Olympians""
column9: but just before the five-minute mark the synths clatter and collapse into a squiggling pile—a breakdown in the literal and metaphorical sense. The shift plays like a commentary on Power's past; rather than achieving total liftoff
column10: Power proves he can still take us all the way there and then deliberately doesn't. While ""Cruel Sport"" works
column11: sometimes the less intense tracks don't quite land; ""Lung"" is a low-key track that sounds like you're waiting for a particularly avant-garde conference call—pleasant
column12: but it's just not what Power does best.

column1: Largely
column2: however
column3: Dumb Flesh is a pleasure. Album closer and highlight ""Detritus"" has multiple movements and features Robert Aiki Aubrey Lowe of 90 Day Men on vocals. It's here that all of Power's strengths come out at once: dark noise gives way to a pounding rhythm which
column4: in turn
column5: melts into a tapestry of airy synths. If Dumb Flesh is about the prison of the body
column6: ""Detritus"" is an entire life-cycle in eight minutes. Over his career
column7: both in Fuck Buttons and as a solo artist
column8: Power's music has been an exercise in the sweeping emotional and physical power of sound itself. Fuck Buttons may be unlikely stars
column9: but their music's pure momentum almost guaranteed its audience by force alone. Like Power's best work
column10:
Dumb Flesh moves you when it literally moves you.

"|20459.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20459-dumb-flesh/|7.6|Nathan Reese

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21775/homepage_large.728cea4f.jpg|Hud Dreems|32885.0|Knxwledge|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Stones Throw']|2015-05-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:04.468070|"

Toward the middle of Kendrick Lamar’s To Pimp a Butterfly
column2: on one of its best songs
column3: ""Momma""
column4: there's a woozy funk groove produced by Glen Boothe
column5: who records under the name Knxwledge. The beat first appeared on Boothe’s relevnt.b/sde_LP
column6: but its re-emergence on Butterfly is the biggest look of his already prolific career. Boothe’s Bandcamp page boasts more than 60 projects—""light work"" by his standards—each one made of deconstructed soul samples and thumping drums.

column1: While it’s probably too easy to compare Boothe with hip-hop producers J Dilla and Madlib
column2: the similarities are glaring: Dilla’s voice is heard throughout Boothe’s new album
column3: Hud Dreems; the music is wonky and off-kilter
column4: much like Madlib’s output
column5: though Boothe’s version is more organized. The man himself is quiet and reserved. While he rarely gives interviews
column6: in April
column7: he told Passion of the Weiss that he grew up in church and recorded sermons as a child. ""I was trying to grab everything I could grab
column8: you know?"" Boothe said. ""For the most part
column9: I was grabbing oldies on the radio when I couldn’t be at home. And when I wasn’t home
column10: I would leave that shit recording
column11: like when I had to go to church or something. Just leave that going so when I come back I have something to chop.""

column1: So
column2: in a way
column3: Boothe’s been perfecting his craft since childhood. That quote explains the scenic aspects of the producer’s music
column4: and why he opts for dusty field recordings in lieu of modern-day gloss. Boothe is an old soul. Given his work thus far
column5: it’s clear he’s in it for the long haul. Boothe isn’t here to blow up from one song; he’s looking to build a lasting legacy one beat at a time. Hud Dreems is a 26-track collection of short-bursting vignettes and random vocal clips. It’s constructed as a beat tape largely devoid of standout songs
column6: an efficient suite of head-nodding instrumentals keeping an upbeat pace. Many of these tracks barely pass the one-minute mark. They’re sequenced without breaks for a seamless listening experience.

column1: Given Butterfly’s success
column2: Hud Dreems presents Boothe to a bigger audience
column3: though the sounds contained here are typical for the Los Angeles resident. Boothe takes seemingly disparate sounds and blends them into wobbly
column4: Cali-infused compositions. He pulls largely familiar tones—a well-known song or identifiable voice
column5: for example—and remixes them into off-kilter melodies. That approach makes the music feel accessible
column6: even if the time signatures are clearly out of whack. Across several releases
column7: Boothe has flipped countless musicians—Biggie
column8: Camp Lo
column9: and D’Angelo
column10: among others—into his own mix of cosmic soul. The same goes for Hud Dreems: On ""jstowee""
column11: we hear Erykah Badu coo softly amongst the track’s stampeding bluster. There are two unmistakable Nas clips—one on ""letuleave.[geekdop]"" that borrows the intro of the rapper’s ""Money Is My Bitch""
column12: the other on ""faraway"" that samples a Nas dialogue from 1998 movie Belly. Havoc (of Mobb Deep) drifts easily
column13: his sampled line from ""Win or Lose"" working as an indirect mission statement for Boothe: ""My destination’s the top of the world.""

column1: By definition
column2: Hud Dreems is an instrumental release
column3: yet the producer skillfully arranges these verbal fragments to liven the procession. In doing so
column4: the album breezes through golden-era rap and R&B while remaining very much in the now. It properly showcases Boothe’s wide-ranging sonic palate and offers a hearty glimpse into musical yesteryear. As a result
column5: Hud Dreems feels remarkably nostalgic. It’s a fully realized effort
column6: bridging a gap between older and younger listeners
column7: and serving as a nice starting point for new Knxwledge consumers. If Kendrick brought you here
column8:
Hud Dreems will make you stay for a while.

"|20510.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20510-hud-dreems/|7.2|Marcus J. Moore

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21691/homepage_large.c19eb3dd.jpg|Danger in the Club|31056.0|Palma Violets|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rough Trade']|2015-05-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:05.000295|"

What is it with trad British indie-rock bands actively selling themselves short at the moment? Vaccines frontman Justin Young has said of their forthcoming third album
column2: ""We wanted to make something that sounds amazing next year and then terrible in 10 years."" And here's Palma Violets' co-frontman Sam Fryer: ""There's no producer in the world who could make us sound professional."" At least Catfish & the Bottlemen reach for the sky (or Glastonbury's main stage) as they're scraping the barrel. Perhaps it's a symptom of having been the barometer/straw men of the Great British Music Press Hype Machine (the sheer fact of which seems to prime the nation's indie bands for America's contempt): retreat before you get replaced.

column1: Reviews of Palma Violets' 2013 debut
column2: 180
column3: lambasted fickle British music magazines for telling teenagers that the all-male London four-piece were the next big thing (what a crime)
column4: while conceding that the record's punch-drunk mix of Gun Club swagger and the Clash's more jovial insurrection was actually alright. On Danger in the Club
column5: Palma Violets have willfully regressed
column6: from punk to pub-rock—or ""pre-punk""
column7: as they've been calling it. Spearheaded by Dr. Feelgood
column8: Brinsley Schwarz
column9: and Eddie and the Hot Rods
column10: pub rock was a reaction against prog
column11: glam
column12: and bands ascending to theater venues that priced out their early supporters. The genre was quickly trumped by punk proper
column13: and doesn't have a lot of cachet today.

column1: Palma Violets have talked about briefly hating each other by the end of the tour for their debut album
column2: and having no ideas for their second as recently as midway through 2014. 180 wasn't original
column3: but it had energy and high stakes on its side: its youthful relationships were either world-beating or the end of the world
column4: and the nonsensical titles/lyrics (""Johnny Bagga' Donuts""
column5: ""Chicken Dippers"") hinted at a wealth of winking in-jokes between besotted friends. The band members are only now in their very early 20s
column6: but the mood on Danger in the Club is misanthropic
column7: tired of life and home and girls. ""I would rather die than be in love""
column8: the band's other vocalist

In recent years
column2: we've seen plenty of indie-world talents—like St. Vincent's Annie Clark
column3: the National's Bryce Dessner
column4: and Radiohead's Jonny Greenwood—crossing over into the realm of contemporary classical music. (Dessner and Arcade Fire instrumentalist Richard Reed Parry are even working on a collaborative piece for the New York Philharmonic
column5: to be played late in 2015.) But how many of these hybrid-genre composer-performers have actually thrown over the alt-career entirely
column6: in order to make notated music an essentially full-time creative pursuit?

column1: Tyondai Braxton is the lone brave soul in that regard
column2: going back to his triumphant solo album Central Market—a ripping and riff-heavy collaboration with the Wordless Music Orchestra
column3: released on Warp Records in 2009 (while he was still a member of Battles). At the time
column4: the record signaled Braxton's growing restlessness inside the math-rock and indie scenes. Since that statement of purpose
column5: though
column6: his discography has grown at noticeably gradual pace. He wrote a short piece for an avant-garde marching band (""Pulse March"")
column7: contributed a track to a Philip Glass remix album (and collaborated onstage with the legendary composer)
column8: while occasionally playing a variety of glitzy gigs (often involving improvisation) in and around Brooklyn.

column1: The highest-profile of these performances was the 2013 debut
column2: at the Guggenheim Museum
column3: of Braxton's HIVE project: a multimedia extravaganza described in promotional materials as ""part architectural installation and part ensemble performance with five musicians sitting cross-legged atop their own space-age oval pods."" In more down-to-earth terms
column4: Braxton had conceived of a percussion-meets-electronic music piece. After some positive live reviews—and additional performances in other locations—the Nonesuch label has now released a 42-minute version of the work
column5: titled HIVE1
column6: which was recorded over a two-year span.

column1: I didn't catch the live iteration
column2: and so can't speak to its success as a multimedia affair—but as a home-listening experience
column3: HIVE1 is intriguing
column4: fitfully exciting
column5: and also sometimes a letdown. In combining an evident love for the percussion works of 20th-century modernist composers like Edgard Varèse with his own prodigious beat-making skills
column6: Braxton has created an eight-movement suite that sounds not terribly different from what you'd get if you built a playlist in which Karlheinz Stockhausen's ""Zyklus"" bumps up against Vision Creation Newsun-era Boredoms remixes by Yamantaka Eye. Sufficiently avant
column7: to be sure
column8: but also a little ragged at its edges.

column1: ""Gracka"" kicks things off with a promising arpeggiated digital riff
column2: before hand-clappy syncopations join in
column3: halfway through the three-minute running time. Later
column4: a brief
column5: stereo-panned chordal vista hints at some grand
column6: possibly-orchestral designs—right before the track peters out. The eight-minute ""Boids"" follows
column7: and its disconnected swirls of percussion make for HIVE1's most aimless stretch. It's not that sparse percussive music can't hold one's interest as a general rule (as the absurdist and entertaining theatrics of composer Mauricio Kagel's music demonstrates). But on my initial HIVE1 listens
column8: I grew impatient every time
column9: right around here. Was this surround-sound
column10: live-at-the-Guggenheim production not going to quite translate as a two-channel headphone-trip?

column1: Thankfully
column2: it's on ""Studio Mariacha""—with its plush waves of digitally warbling
column3: video-game-style exhalations—that HIVE1 takes off for real. The following number
column4: ""Amlochey""
column5: announces a steady groove
column6: straight away
column7: and features some bell-like digital timbres that carry a hint of melody
column8: too. And the lengthy closer
column9: ""Scout 1""
column10: is everything you could want from this project: drum-circle bliss
column11: grizzled low-end
column12: oscillating counterpoint in the upper pitch registers
column13: and a potent cluster chord that someone in the ensemble leans on a few times during the final seconds. A surprising
column14: ecstatic triumph—and then it's all done.

column1: Overall
column2: it's clear that HIVE1 doesn't manage to engage all of its composer's talents
column3: despite its occasionally locked-in blend of notated percussion parts and sharp electro-production. This judgment is especially difficult to avoid given that another one-off piece of Braxton's
column4: ""Casino Trem""
column5: has also made its way to market on the same release date. Written for the new-classical players in the group that is (somewhat awkwardly) named the Bang on a Can All-Stars—and appearing on that group's latest album
column6: Field Recordings—""Casino Trem"" contains some HIVE1-style beat programming
column7: but also a post-minimalist electric guitar part that recalls the most rousing moments of Central Market. Braxton's seven-minute contribution climaxes with a rave-up section that pairs a mournful clarinet line with jaunty samples that sound like they were recorded outside a local carnival's funhouse. It's weird
column8: dark and fun all at once. In short
column9: it shows an exciting way forward
column10:
whereas HIVE1 can't quite shake the feeling that it was best experienced live.

Mark Ronson and Bruno Mars’ ""Uptown Funk"" just spent fourteen consecutive weeks atop the US Billboard charts.  Two years ago
column3: Daft Punk’s ""Get Lucky"" topped the charts in 30 countries and became one of the best-selling digital singles of all time

column5: there’s a mint to be had in mining the sound of early '80s R&B
column6: boogie
column7: and electro-funk right now
column8: whether you take your cues from the Gap Band or Chic
column9: Morris Day and the Time’s ""Jungle Love"" or Thriller. By such a metric
column10: Baltimore-born
column11: Sheffield-based producer and house-music veteran Maurice Fulton should be a multi-platinum artist and in-demand producer for big artists.

column1: But in reality
column2: Fulton remains a hard-to-pin figure in the deep house underground
column3: avoiding big festival stages
column4: dropping album-length releases without notice and eschewing publicity
column5: media and interview requests. Two-plus decades into his music-making career
column6: he does whatever he damned well pleases. The past three years have seen Fulton release an album under the guise of a Finnish jazz trio Syclops
column7: a set of tough house productions to back a powerful Swahili singer Mim Suleiman
column8: a sensuous remix of Rhye
column9: a twisted EP with Japanese icon DJ Nori
column10: and a third album from Fulton with his wife Mu (under her full name Mutsumi). Almost all of them were quick blips on the dance music landscape
column11: some of them released only digitally via his BubbleTease Communications label.

column1: Two months ago
column2: one of Fulton’s many guises
column3: Boof (a project which seems preoccupied with flowers of all varieties)
column4: appeared seemingly overnight with the release of The Hydrangeas Whisper. This one gets a physical release this week courtesy of Running Back

column6: Boof finds Fulton alighting on many different sounds
column7: never quite settling into any one.

column1: In the past
column2: Boof reveled in Fulton’s jazz side
column3: and this album is no different. ""Intro to It's Sunny S Outside"" sounds like it borrowed the drum machine from George McRae’s ""Rock Your Baby"" and added a George Benson guitar figure
column4: resulting in a swirling Balearic number. Then Fulton does his one-man ""Get Lucky"" robot band on ""Birgit Boogie""
column5: a grid of go-go bells
column6: hand drums and closed hi-hats. Nagging clean guitar upstrokes and champagne-bubble synths give the track an airiness that counterbalances the fat
column7: wobbling bassline underneath. ""Just on the Swings"" imagines Nile Rodgers’ guitar lines atop a SAM Records’ groove before stomping on the overdrive and flange pedal.

column1: But from there
column2: Fulton becomes a bit restless. The title track recreates the sort of inert
column3: hissing ambience of Wolfgang Voigt’s GAS project
column4: and the suspended synth chords of ""Cat Soulcat Strut""
column5: sounds like an imagined sweet spot between the Gap Band’s 1984 hit ""You Dropped a Bomb on Me"" and Arthur Russell’s ""Go Bang #5"". The album veers into clanging metallic minimal techno accompanied by furious Cuban hand drums
column6: to arcade blips dumped into a '90s house track
column7: to a swing number on ""Emi's M"" not unlike a robot jazz ensemble tackling ""Take Five"". These jumps might derail another album
column8: but as is always the case with Fulton’s productions
column9:
he has a singular talent for making the most idiosyncratic and random of sounds seem natural.

In hindsight it's clear just how much Icky Blossoms were acting on their first album. The Omaha trio's self-titled 2012 debut was beholden to the rigid
column2: impersonal conventions of electroclash
column3: even when it seemed as if the group's interests lay elsewhere. There were moments where the band's primary singer Sarah Bohling in particular sounded as if she longed to emote
column4: but she restrained herself
column5: because genre protocol dictated she remain as dispassionate as the sequenced pulses behind her.

column1: On Icky Blossoms' sophomore album Mask
column2: Bohling recasts herself as a real
column3: vulnerable human being. Though the band still draws from the same pool of '80s synth-pop
column4: dance
column5: and electro-rock
column6: they've replaced the aura of debauched sex that hung over their first album with a sweeter
column7: more romantic focus. That retool is underscored by the change in producers. For their debut
column8: Icky Blossoms recruited TV on the Radio's Dave Sitek
column9: who manned the boards as if wearing surgical gloves
column10: but on Mask they partner with a collaborator closer to home
column11: Saddle Creek standby Mike Mogis
column12:
a producer who isn't shy about leaving fingerprints.

Mogis has some experience with electro-pop
column13: with credits on the Faint's Wet From Birth and Bright Eyes' glitchy one-off Digital Ash in a Digital Urn
column14: but generally he doesn't do genre exercises. His specialty is albums that sound unmistakably like Saddle Creek albums—snug
column15: vividly colored records that play as if crafted by a bunch of friends squeezing into a studio on a night off and helping each other out. Mask fits that mold
column16: with contributions from a half dozen or so players from the usual circles
column17: including Cursive's Patrick Newbery
column18: who plays trumpet on a track
column19: and the Faint's Todd Fink
column20:
who lends some additional production and earns an especially warm thank-you in the liner credits (""Your knowledge of electricity is invaluable and your dog is awesome."")

At its best
column21: Mask captures the spirit of the label's heyday records. With its squealing guitars and manic tempo
column22: ""Phantasmagoria"" channels the vicious side of the Faint's miswired electro-punk
column25: elbows its way toward one of those generous
column26: jubilant choruses that used to leap so effortlessly off of Bright Eyes albums. And Bohling even sounds like a typical Saddle Creek protagonist now. She sings opener ""In Folds"" as a prolonged sigh
column27: her voice quivering with echoes of Conor Oberst and Jenny Lewis. Mask's songs often place her in the same position those label luminaries used to write from
column28: unable to shake the traumas of past relationships and unsure of her ability to secure future ones. ""I get so trapped in my head sometimes I turn what I love into a monster
column29:
she laments on ""The Spiral"".

Though it lacks the sparkle of some of the album's snappier electro-pop numbers
column30: one of Mask's most lasting songs is also its most naked. On ""Want You So Bad""
column31: the band dials down the synths to a murmur
column32: accentuating Bohling's loneliness with some barren guitar strums as she pines for a lost love. ""I let go for you
column34: ""Forever I've been waiting now."" It's a decidedly un-showy track for a band that usually prefers very showy sounds
column35: and it probably would have brought the band's chic debut album to a halt. But it slots in comfortably on Mask
column36: a follow-up that finds Icky Blossoms letting their guard down and embracing the values of their music scene
column37:
where there's no higher form of fashion than wearing your heart on your sleeve.

On the second song of Elvis Depressedly's latest LP
column3: singer-songwriter Mat Cothran lays out a guiding principle: ""no more sad songs."" For those who've followed his recordings over the past half-decade
column4: this could come as something of a surprise. Both under the Depressedly banner
column5: which also includes multi-instrumentalist Delaney Mills as a permanent member
column6: and his solo project Coma Cinema
column7: Cothran has built an expansive discography that leans heavily toward the downcast. But this time around
column8: Cothran hints early on that things are going to be different and they largely are. For New Alhambra
column9: his seventh and latest release as Elvis Depressedly
column10: he's crafted a utopian sort of indie-pop
column11: an ecstatic evocation of the second coming
column12: professional wrestling
column13: and radical positivity.

column1: It's been a long journey to this point for the South Carolina-born Cothran. As a fiercely independent home-recording apologist
column2: his efforts have always been aided—or hamstrung—by whatever half-broken equipment he could get his hands on the moment the songs started pouring out. In leaner times
column3: this often meant that his releases were unapologetically lo-fi
column4: a quirk of his work that cut both ways. When outlining quiet despair
column5: the grit and grime functions as a poignant mirror for his work
column6: but on more buoyant numbers the nuances—the comedy and uplift that he often seeks to convey—could get lost in the muddle. So to hear him proclaim
column7: less than five minutes into his newest record
column8: that those gloomier moments had been excised could have been cause for concern.

column1: But with the exception of Coma Cinema's 2013 Posthumous Release
column2: recorded in Los Angeles with production help from local band TV Girl
column3: New Alhambra is his most traditionally well-produced record. Cothran's guitars roil and collapse with a multi-dimensional shimmer and Mills' keyboard parts are given body and voice that would've been impossible on the crackly Elvis Depressedly recordings of the past. With such a solid production backline
column4: Cothran's given room to experiment more than he ever has before. He coats vocals in idiosyncratic
column5: nauseous chorus effects (""Ease"")
column6: scatters pitch shifted vocals throughout
column7: and even manages to squeeze in a reversed guitar solo for good measure (""New Heaven
column8: New Earth""). Cothran and Mills achieve a textural depth that's rare for songwriters in this lane. There's far more corners to explore than on
column9: say
column10: a Jackson Scott record
column11: but they also manage not to overcomplicate things and ruin the unique magic of the brittle aesthetic.

column1: It's hard to imagine a more perfect vehicle for Cothran's wholehearted embrace of optimism. He explicitly invokes the Bible on a number of occasions throughout the record
column2: but when he does so it's only to underline themes of rebirth. He proves that he can write with delicacy about joy and love and light just as easily as he can about Satan and burning churches. On ""N.M.S.S.""
column3: he proclaims that he ""love[s] everyone that [he has] ever known"" and he ""go[es] to sleep still believing"" in an abstract ""someday"" that might come for him. It's a plain little sentiment
column4: but it works with what's around it. Watery guitars and plodding kick drums open up and buoy his open-hearted vocal. He's happy
column5: if only intermittently. And unlike Pharrell's catchy
column6: dead-eyed assertion of the same
column7: Cothran's musical encapsulation of the feeling is even-keeled and aqueous—true to the hesitant hopefulness that can follow in the wake of overwhelming depression.

column1: But maybe that's the fleeting feeling Cothran has been trying to get at all along. He's said that those who weep while listening to his songs are doing the equivalent of ""crying [while] watching 'Looney Tunes' or something."" That sells short the fragile honesty of his work
column2: but it speaks to the triumph of New Alhambra's overall enterprise
column3: that such an assertion finally makes sense. For the first time
column4:
we can laugh right along with him.

The phrase ""grown up"" often feels like a backhanded compliment when applied to a band or its sound. It praises their current efforts by way of dismissing the steps they took to arrive at that destination. In that regard
column2: Coliseum's progression over the course of 12 years and five full-lengths has been less an exercise in growing up and more one of ""growing in"" to a sound
column3: one that hits its highest point on their newest album <i>Anxiety's Kiss
column4: which sharpens all of their musical developments into their finest point yet. The result is a pop-savvy sound that 2013's Sister Faith only hinted at.

column1: In the relatively short amount of time of the group's existence
column2: Coliseum has made the label rounds
column3: releasing all but two of their records on different labels. This might be a trivial observation for other bands
column4: but it's been a continual point of distinction for the Kentucky-based three-piece
column5: with each album moving in a pointedly different direction than its predecessor while keeping a rock-solid punk-rock ethos at their base. Beneath every shift
column6: vocalist/guitarist and founding member Ryan Patterson barked his lyrics with absolute fervor and passion.

column1: While their punk roots remain wholly intact
column2: the band has grown into a comfortable but still-powerful force. Much of that growth can be attributed to bassist Kayhan Vaziri and drummer Carter Wilson
column3: both relatively recent additions to the band who have proven invaluable in fleshing out the band's sound. Paired with Wilson's straightforward
column4: loosely executed rhythmic style
column5: Vaziri's bass works as much melodic nuance into the songs as Patterson's guitar.

column1: Anxiety's Kiss wastes no time in announcing its intentions with the radio-ready ""We Are the Water""
column2: a pop-punk anthem owing as much to the Replacements as it does to Fucked Up
column3: complete with gang-vocal refrain. The post-punk-tinged followup ""Dark Light of Seduction"" chases the immediacy with a slow burning churn
column4: and a subdued layer of electronic noise that the band has folded into their mix over the last two albums. This muted sense of nuance is what gives Coliseum's music an amorphous tendency
column5: and while that's sometimes worked against them in the past
column6: here it allows them to shift weightlessly from near post-rock atmospherics on the outstanding ""Dark Light of Seduction"" to blistering anthems like ""Drums & Amplifiers""
column7: all without losing a core sense of focus.

column1: Just shy of 40 minutes
column2: Anxiety's Kiss packs in a surprising amount of singalong hooks
column3: and you can sense their comfort with them. They've always had these proclivities lurking in the background
column4: and this time around they embrace them as the next logical step. For longtime followers of the band
column5: Anxiety's Kiss has the feel of a logical endpoint
column6:
the latest natural development in an impressive career of progressions.
