The music of Kristian Matsson (who records as the Tallest Man on Earth) doesn't carry the same loneliness of other heartbroken folkies; Matsson's music
column2: instead
column3: has solitude. Loneliness is a condition
column4: a place you end up and from which you are eager to leave
column5: but solitude is a choice. Like Henry James or Emily Dickinson
column6: who best detail the workings of their mind when they are cloistered away from the world
column7: Matsson is more concerned with a wellspring of autonomous thought rather than the chirpings of modern society. His voice and his guitar jig around some distant forest maypole
column8: out of touch and out of sync with everything 21st-century. Instead
column9: he's loosely moored to his dreams
column10: his wanderlust
column11: and all the other broad stuff of poetry that glows brightest in total seclusion.

column1: It used to be easy to hear this solitude in Matsson's music. His first few albums featured only his rich
column2: bleating voice and his acoustic guitar
column3: and listening to his early records can feel like hearing someone rediscover the unfettered joy of playing music in real time. Naturally
column4: for the last few albums
column5: Matsson has been adding tiny layers of instrumentation behind him and the fire of his early days has dwindled into the mist of the songs' arrangements. Dark Bird Is Home
column6: his first album since 2012's There's No Leaving Now
column7: continues in this vein
column8: and Matsson's persona fades even more into the tapestry he's made with his music.

column1: Matsson handles most of the performances
column2: including keyboards and drums. He has some extra players—most notably background vocals and strings from Bon Iver's Mike Noyce—to fill the songs out
column3: but the majority of the starry musical textures are Matsson's. He recorded the album in odd places in his native Sweden and surrounding countries
column4: and the dusting of synths
column5: pedal steel
column6: french horns and trumpets on the album say a lot by saying very little. ""Timothy"" turns on a winsome clarinet figure played by Matsson
column7: and it's the perfect amount of simplicity to ornament his songs without upsetting the whole equation. Matsson still hasn't ""gone electric
column8: and blessedly still avoids the MOR folk-rock tropes of stomping and big-ticket whoa-oh'ing. Behind all the arrangements
column9: front and center on every track
column10: is still his voice.

column1: That voice undersells nothing: There are no wanly delivered lines
column2: no flat and dour stretches of singing. His voice is prismatic
column3: used like an old-guard storyteller who hews his words to any kind of feeling he wants. He does bittersweet reassurance on the stunning title track
column4: and the way he tip-toes down the phrase ""Still we're in the light of day"" is hypnotic. He does sockless campfire guy on ""Beginners""
column5: a song so whimsical it could land a three-movie deal with Disney. He even does the soft-rocking-through-the-sadness on ""Sagres""
column6: where whispers for the audience to ""come on"" at the end of the chorus feel like the coyest Bruce Springsteen impression in history. Words come out of his mouth brimming with so much emotion
column7: they land just shy of over-singing.

column1: Matsson has always been a little obtuse with his lyrics
column2: and that can be charming or intriguing: The ballad ""Little Nowhere Towns"" is Matsson half-drunkenly retelling a tale of heartbreak
column3: languishing in the imagery
column4: nearly impossible to pin down. There's some bitterness about his own songwriting
column5: perhaps: ""And I'm racing through my pockets now/ 'Cause I'm starting to believe/ Selling emptiness to strangers/ A little bit warmer than my dreams.""

column1: Elsewhere he's more inscrutable. The chorus of ""Singers"" goes ""But we're only gone like singers are till springtime/ Let them out
column2: if they should let them out
column3: which never opens up on repeated listens to reveal more than a tangle of words. The big choruses feel undercut by the sometimes-tangled poetry of the words
column4: which get lost in metaphor en route to making their point. On ""Sagres""
column5: he cuts through all the artifice with a striking moment: ""It's just all this fucking doubt
column6: he sings
column7: barely squeezing out the line. It feels like everything he's been trying and failing to say elsewhere.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21848/homepage_large.e198f5a3.jpg|1000 Palms|28248.0|Surfer Blood|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Joyful Noise']|2015-05-11 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:09.402253|"

Five years isn’t really a long time
column2: but in the lifespan of a band half a decade can feel like an eternity. Back in 2010
column3: Florida’s Surfer Blood were riding high on the success of Astro Coast (deservedly so
column4: considering how great that record is. Go back and listen to ""Swim"" to jog your memory). A year later
column5: the band released an EP
column6: Tarot Classics
column7: and busied themselves with endless touring
column8: including a dream stint opening for the Pixies. Though they just seemed like a bunch of kids from Florida
column9: the band—in particular frontman and primary songwriter John Paul Pitts—ripped like an heir apparent for the guitar-pop throne previously kept warm by the likes of Stephen Malkmus or Rivers Cuomo.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: it was not to be. In 2012
column3: just before the recording of the band’s major label debut
column4: Pitts was arrested (though never officially charged) after a physical altercation with his then girlfriend. Though details of the events of that night remain vague (you can read Pitts’ statement on the incident at the band’s website)
column5: the fallout from the arrest (and the seemingly endless amount of online discussion that ensued) did irrevocable damage. As a result
column6: 2013’s Pythons seemed to emerge from under a dark cloud—a fraught
column7: anxious record that
column8: whether intentional or not
column9: played out like an anguished mea culpa. A year after its release
column10: the band was dropped from Warner Brothers. The future seemed nothing if not uncertain.

column1: So now
column2: some five years after their debut
column3: Surfer Blood return with <i>1000 Palms
column4: a record that tries (and occasionally succeeds) at recapturing the messy exuberance of their debut. Self-recorded by the band largely in the living room of drummer Tyler Schwarz' parents’ house (and later nicely mixed by Rob Schnapf)
column5: the record is not only surprisingly upbeat
column6: but surprisingly clean-sounding as well. Freed from the constraints of a major label (""We weren’t better off in paradise/ All we ever got were parasites"" remarks Pitts on ""Dorian"") the band take advantage of their newfound autonomy to unpack some of the psychic trauma they've endured over the past few years. And while one might expect this to be an opportunity for some cathartic guitar shredding
column7: 1000 Palms is a little short on the epic riffs and the earworm hooks of earlier albums
column8: in favor of tastefully employed synths and an overabundance of blandly pretty mid-tempo tracks
column9: which
column10: while never terrible
column11: still feel oddly muted.

column1: The first five tracks establish a kind of emotional palette that
column2: taken on their own
column3: would make for a killer EP. Album opener ""Grand Inquisitor"" is big and booming—packed with the kind of guitar squalling and turn-on-a-dime signature changes that could almost pass for an old Pale Saints track (it helps that Pitt’s voice is a dead ringer for Pale Saints’ Ian Masters)—and evidences the kind of dynamic that made early Surfer Blood records fun. ""You wrote the finest record I’d ever heard
column4: sings Pitt
column5: ""It never occurred that you’d rather throw it all away/ Launch the CD-R into the bay."" On ""Island"" Pitt details a kind of creative discontent that pops up again and again on Palms: ""A shadow fell on me today/ It paralyzed my tongue
column6: eclipsed my brain"" while the guitars morph from overdriven fuzz into melodic lines reminiscent of early-'80s new wave.

column1: The album's poppiest moments are often married to Pitt’s most pained sentiments
column2: as on ""Feast/Famine"" where Unrest-like guitar jangle is set against Pitt’s own self-doubt: ""Sometimes I feel out touch with who I am/ I can’t see no symmetry/ It’s feast or famine."" 1000 Palms vacillates between songs about frustration and songs about love
column3: which themselves run the gamut from endearingly sweet (the gorgeous New Year’s Eve romance of ""I Can’t Explain"") to the treacly and forgettable. 1000 Palms is consistently lovely and never terribly misfires
column4: but in its same-sounding second half you can't help but wish it fired at least a little harder.

column1: Ultimately
column2: 1000 Palms sounds like emotional throat-clearing
column3: the transitional sound of a band finding their bearings
column4: resetting their dials
column5: and getting back on their feet in the wake of a lot of personal and professional turmoil. One would hope this would prove to be a pivotal turning point for the group
column6: but the recent news of guitarist Thomas Fekete’s illness (he’s been diagnosed with a rare form of cancer) seems yet another blow to the now-beleaguered band. 1000 Palms does an admirable job of squaring itself with the past
column7: as evidenced on album closer ""NW Passage""—an acoustic missive about breaking through impossible frozen barriers
column8: forgiving and forgetting
column9: and learning to get up again after falling face-first in the mud—but it ultimately all feels a bit tepid and desperately polite. Make no mistake
column10: it’s all good
column11: this business of letting go of bad baggage
column12: but now that they’ve done so
column13:
here’s hoping Surfer Blood are more willing to stick their necks out next time and jump headlong back into the fray.

The most appropriate word to describe Gabrielle Smith's solo project Eskimeaux might be ""togetherness."" The band founded Brooklyn songwriting and art collective the Epoch in 2011 along with several of their friends
column2: but this sense of mutual support and do-it-together philosophy has long been a part of Smith's M.O. She originally formed Eskimeaux in 2007
column3: all the while happily joining her peers' and fellow collective members' bands—Bellows
column4: Told Slant
column5: and Frankie Cosmos. Smith's songs reflect this type of profound concern for the well-being of those around her
column6: an eagerness to take a backseat when others need her and a longing to still express her own sharp meditations on love and loneliness.

column1: Several of the songs on O.K. are new versions of previous recordings
column2: but this time around Smith has scaled back to outline each melody in clearer brush strokes. Where certain tracks on 2013's Igluenza were monotone or drawn out
column3: they graduate to fully formed pop on this release. Before
column4: ""I Admit I'm Scared"" felt flat despite its visually compelling lyrics (""Everything I said spewed like sparklers from my mouth/ They looked pretty as they flew but now they're useless and burnt out"")
column5: while here it's one of the album's strongest moments. Subtle harmonies slowly coax Smith's gentle alto into a confident soar over Felix Walworth's galloping drum fill. She casually divulges secrets as though her arm is already on your shoulder
column6: her quiet relatability spiking upwards at the climax (""If I had a dime for every time I'm freaking out/ We could fly around the world or just get out of your parents' house"").

column1: This encouraging
column2: comforting voice permeates O.K. It may not always come in the form of a soft whisper in the night
column3: but somehow it feels as if Smith is lending her ear to you rather than the other way around. Whether she's letting you know that it's okay to be scared and sad—notably on danceable bedroom pop number ""Alone at the Party""—or tenderly confessing how important you are (""The Thunder Answered Back"")
column4: the sweetness isn't saccharine
column5: it's sincere and intimate. And when the entire band accompanies Smith on the latter track
column6: she serves gut-wrenching doses of candor: ""It must feel like fucking hell/ To be a patchwork of yourself."" Smith is a hyper-aware observer
column7: able to pinpoint others' despair just as well as her own.

column1: Sonically
column2: O.K. is the most fitting pallette for Smith's work. In the past she's played around with drum machines and broken synth beats
column3: which weighed her down in gloomy
column4: droning noise. This LP finally matches Eskimeaux's illuminating presence. She slips from sparse indie-folk to ethereal pop throughout the record
column5: each arrangement rich and meticulously composed. The band never overpowers Smith's celestial vocals
column6: and she's able to keep up with the slow-burning tension when it eventually detonates. Walworth's attentive drumming is a welcome addition that swells and retracts to complement Jack Greenleaf's twinkling synth arpeggios.

column1: At face value
column2: it's easy to mistake Smith's nursery rhyme name-dropping and misty-eyed warmth for childlike naiveté. However
column3:
she's no Pollyanna—she's simply acknowledging the darkness and aiming to move past it. O.K. invites us to view the world through Smith's eyes. The unassuming strength of her vision is what makes that invitation so worth accepting.

you!

How many albums like Songs From Suicide Bridge are out there in the world? Hundreds? Thousands? Hundreds of thousands? In 1982
column2: two aspiring singer-songwriters named David Kauffman (from Madison
column3: N.J.) and Eric Caboor (from Burbank
column4: Calif.) met at a venue called the Basement in Los Angeles
column5: threw together a couple of their best tunes
column6: pressed a couple hundred copies of a record
column7: and then went their separate ways. Since then the only album they made under their own names has been consigned to estate sales and flea markets
column8: waiting for subsequent generations of cratediggers to fish it out
column9: dust it off
column10: and find something that resonates across the decades.

column1: Private-press records such as Songs From Suicide Bridge are relics of an age of physical media
column2: but in the digital age
column3: it’s easier than ever to get lost works back in print. Labels like Light in the Attic
column4: Paradise of Bachelors
column5: Numero Group
column6: and Delmore Recordings are doing the important work of unearthing these artifacts
column7: even if the market seems to be increasingly saturated with reissues of the undiscovered and the uncelebrated
column8: the obscure and the unconsidered. These reissues are as much about what might have been as they are about what actually was. What if Songs had heralded a long and prolific career instead of an obscure cratedigger treasure? What if it was the first of many albums made by Caboor and Kauffman rather than the only one?

column1: In this case
column2: I doubt their fortunes would have changed significantly—which shouldn’t be read as an insult. Caboor and Kauffman aren’t a pair of forgotten geniuses
column3: and this new reissue flatly rejects the notion that they could have been stars: ""Fame and fortune demanded certain qualities and it became increasingly obvious that they had none
column4: writes Sam Sweet in the liner notes. And yet
column5: that only makes these songs more powerful: As its title suggests
column6: Songs From Suicide Bridge is about depression and despair
column7: about the gnawing suspicion that you don’t belong in this world
column8: and their professional frustrations only reinforced that sense of alienation.

column1: The austerity of their sound may have been a product of their limited resources—much of the album was recorded in a makeshift studio in Caboor’s backyard—but they managed to create something distinctive in its spareness
column2: with a bit of reverb in the vocals and a crisp
column3: at times percussive acoustic guitar sound that intensifies the songs intense isolation. Songs From Suicide Bridge doesn’t sound like a product of the hedonistic '80s. Instead
column4: it seems to predict the dire introspection of the '90s. ""I have nothing but the end inside of me
column5: Caboor sings on ""Angel of Mercy""
column6: nearly a decade before Nine Inch Nails and Nirvana would ride similarly dark thoughts into the mainstream.

column1: As often happens with this kind of subject matter
column2: the drama occasionally lapses into melodrama
column3: especially on ""Life and Times on the Beach"". The song begins with Kauffman reminiscing about his childhood—playing baseball
column4: going on family vacations—but the memories grow less sweet as he proceeds—dropping out of college
column5: moving to L.A.
column6: getting nowhere close to realizing his dreams. As the guitars grow tenser and the pace quickens
column7: he admits
column8: ""What I need to end it all is right… within my reach."" You might expect to hear a gunshot or a last exhalation in the brief ellipsis
column9: something to signal that the song and the life have ended.

column1: Instead
column2: the music starts back up again
column3: quiet and tentative yet offering no resolution to Kauffman’s story. It’s a startling moment
column4: yet there’s something lurid about the way it takes you right up to that life-or-death decision and just abandons you. On the other hand
column5: it also sounds like a pivotal passage on the album
column6: the point to which the first side of the album has been building. The intensity of that experience lends the second side a new and necessary lightness. Caboor and Kauffman play ""Midnight Willie' as a parody of coffeehouse singers
column7: cracking up as they compare their woes to those of a crippled hobo playing for change outside the Monterey Hotel. And closer ""One More Day (You’ll Fly Again)"" expresses something in short supply on this album: actual honest-to-God hope.

column1: Fortunately
column2: neither Caboor nor Kauffman took his own life. Both of them did
column3: however
column4: sacrifice their dreams of stardom for less glamorous but more reliable work. So Songs becomes a suicide note to the music industry explaining why these two talented singer-songwriters decided to end their careers. (Eventually
column5: they did reunite in the late 1980s for a pair of album as the Drovers.) On this would-be swan song
column6: they managed to express these dire emotions with startling candor
column7: eloquence
column8: and directness
column9: soundtracking their worst fears with furious acoustic strumming. Yet
column10: the great discrepancy between their musical and their professional accomplishments lends Songs From Suicide Bridge a sense of gravity and impossibly high stakes
column11: as though they knew they had only one chance to get everything right. Ultimately
column12: the album thrives on its own obscurity
column13:
which 30 years later thrums in the background behind all that strumming.

It is probably impossible to discuss Kamasi Washington's new record—all three impressive hours of it—without copping to at least some awareness of two extra-musical truths. The first of these holds that
column2: as a member of the studio wrecking crew that brought Kendrick Lamar's To Pimp a Butterfly into being
column3: this saxophonist-composer is unusually well poised to secure the attention of listeners who have previously been uninterested in jazz. (This past spring's celebration of all-things-TPAB was sufficiently strong that Billboard even published a well-reported piece that detailed exactly how Lamar's album came to feature so many jazz figures
column4: including Washington.)

column1: The second truth is that jazz could use a few more people with Washington's cachet in the wider world—touring with Snoop Dogg
column2: or putting out albums on Flying Lotus' Brainfeeder imprint. Admitting this is not tantamount to saying that jazz is in some unhealthy creative state (it isn't)
column3: but rather that the music currently faces an uphill struggle in the marketplace (as it often has).

column1: You can see hints of these outside considerations in some of the pre-release writing around The Epic—virtually all of which cites Washington's hip-hop associations as a reason to pay attention to his big debut as a jazz bandleader. (Washington cut one prior album as part of a collective
column3: but this set is his real coming-out party.) One can imagine other elite contemporary jazz artists grinding teeth while checking Twitter
column4: muttering to themselves: if anyone paid attention to me
column5: they'd notice the post-turntablism beats in my music.

column1: Given all this
column2: it's something of a gobsmacking paradox to discover what a hip-hop-free zone The Epic is
column3: and how enamored of jazz's past it turns out to be. This triple-album set is an extravagant love letter to (among other things): soul jazz
column4: John Coltrane (various periods)
column5: and 1970s fusion leaders like Miles Davis and Weather Report. The Epic's Disc 1 opener
column6: ""Change of the Guard""
column7: might as well be titled ""We Love All Kinds of 'Trane"". Its ringing opening piano chords sound almost entirely lifted from the playbook of McCoy Tyner
column8: the pianist in Coltrane's so-called ""Classic Quartet."" (That's the group responsible for A Love Supreme.) The opening theme in the saxes is something that could only have been written after ""Impressions"". And the harmonious writing for Washington's string section recalls posthumous Coltrane releases like Infinity—tracks from which featured orchestral overdubs supervised by Alice Coltrane (who is
column9: as you may have read
column10: Flying Lotus's aunt). Toward the end of the 12-minute tune
column11: Washington's tenor sax solo veers off into flights of screeching intensity that were the hallmark of Coltrane's later groups—specifically the ones that also included Pharoah Sanders. (Who is
column12: by the way
column13: still active—and still great
column14: on the evidence of last year's record with the São Paulo Underground.)

column1: What The Epic does come to sound like
column2: over the course of its significant running time
column3: is a generational intervention—an educational tool that widens the definition of styles that fall under ""jazz classicism."" With his writing for string sections and chorus
column4: Washington even flirts with that most dreaded of appellations: smooth. But these specific choices also wind up paying dividends: The calmly spiritual voices and Washington's wailing playing during the back half of ""Askim"" feels novel.

column1: Three hours is a lot of music
column2: and Washington uses the space to range freely—the R&B vocals of Patrice Quinn crop up roughly once per disc
column3: and there are long sections that feel indebted to grittier funk and soul. Washington has a healthy sense of melodrama
column4: which is especially clear whenever the chorus swoops in with open-hearted ""ooohs"" and ""aaahs""
column5: aiming straight for the listener's gooseflesh. Meantime
column6: some of the longer
column7: less ambitious instrumental tracks (like ""Isabelle"") play things much safer
column8: in a kind of chill-jazz mode that features greasy-soul-organ and tasteful solos from Washington's large cast of skilled supporters (like electric bassist Thundercat and trombonist Ryan Porter). While faultlessly executed
column9: these are the only moments across the music's three-hour sprawl that resemble padding. On the uptempo
column10: high-energy music
column11: like the updated Miles Davis-isms of ""Re Run Home""
column12: as well the potent Disc 3 closer
column13: ""The Message""
column14: Washington and his band truly excel.

column1: The big news is that The Epic actually makes good on its titular promise without bothering to make even a faint-hearted stab in the direction of fulfilling its pre-release hype. If you came for the hip-hop associations
column2: and can't listen for anything else
column3: you will surely be disappointed. But to listen like that is to cheat yourself. If you want rapping over contemporary jazz
column4: you can find it elsewhere. If you're in the mood for acoustic adaptations of electronic-music practices
column5: look to Vijay Iyer Trio's recent Break Stuff (specifically
column6: the track ""Hood""
column7: which is a shout-out to Detroit DJ Robert Hood). You can find more studiously contemporary R&B vocals on Robert Glasper's recent Black Radio series. Kamasi Washington's epic isn't the place for those things—though it is also a zone of surprise. Instead of a self-conscious attempt to seize someone else’s idea of the zeitgeist
column8: it's a large and generous canvas
column9: clearly created in the hopes of attracting new visitors to the post-Coltrane wing of the jazz museum. At this point
column10:
that project is its own form of radicalism.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21846/homepage_large.251880da.jpg|Full Communism|32890.0|Downtown Boys|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Don Giovanni']|2015-05-08 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:12.956829|"

If you want to know why Downtown Boys sound so angry on their debut album Full Communism
column2: watch the music video for ""Wave of History"". In the clip
column3: the Providence-based band outlines the realities of prison overcrowding
column4: the racial divide in U.S. arrest rates
column5: and the number of people killed by police—very real problems that
column6: for many
column7: are remarkably easy to ignore. Our screens offer countless alternatives to anything remotely ""unpleasant"" or ""depressing""; even as militarized police line city streets and 24-hour news networks
column8: they're forced to compete with a bottomless pit of interspecies friendship GIFs.

column1: Victoria Ruiz of Downtown Boys engages with the country's broken systems and the resulting frustration fuels her lyrics. The 28-year-old worked for the Rhode Island Public Defender
column2: aiming to combat racist and classist policing tactics. She currently works with Demand Progress
column3: and she recently wrote an op-ed on Ferguson. Joey L DeFrancesco
column5: was her co-worker at a hotel; they attempted to start a union since the employees were
column6: as he described it
column7: ""treated...like garbage."" (DeFrancesco later quit that job with magnificent flair.) ""Sometimes people ask
column8: 'Don’t you get sad worrying about this stuff all the time?'"" Ruiz said. ""It upsets me because it is negative and absolves the person of the responsibility of realizing that we all have to think about these things.""

column1: Full Communism is an album-length exercise of that responsibility. Downtown Boys have two horns and plenty of aggression in their arsenal and
column2: as they play
column3: they force you to acknowledge the world around you. The title ""Break a Few Eggs"" pretty well encapsulates the nature of the project. Songs challenge white hegemony
column4: entitled bro culture
column5: and more with churning rock'n'roll lined with Adrienne Berry and Emmett FitzGerald's saxophones. (Between this album and that Pill EP
column6: it's been a good year thus far for the rock sax.) DeFrancesco's guitar
column7: Norlan Olivo's drums
column8: and Dan Schleifer's bass lock in for a fuzzy
column9: chugging barrage. Racism and homophobia are alluded to in shouts but the music isn't cynical; everything seems to be underpinned with the sincere desire that things actually get better. ""We make
column10: we made
column11: we will make freedom
column12: Ruiz sings in rapid succession on ""Desde Arriba"". They've talked about how they encourage a ""space of collective power"" at their live shows
column13: which makes sense—Full Communism
column14: both in message and mayhem
column15: has the power to whip a roomful of people into a frenzy.

column1: And that's the important bit—this music is saying some real shit
column2: yeah
column3: but it's doing it with a completely unhinged voice. As advocates of human rights
column4: Downtown Boys are well-versed in the history of bland protest songs. ""Political music is often cheesy or boring
column5: so no one listens to it
column6: DeFrancesco has said. ""As much as we hate on aesthetics by themselves
column7: they obviously matter."" Matching substance with style is easier said than done—Downtown Boys could easily fall into punk's trap of loud and fast monotony. They don't
column8: though
column9: keeping things diverse and well-sequenced. Where the horns on ""Monstro"" lend a soft
column10: beautiful counterbalance to DeFrancesco's jagged guitar
column11: ""Traders"" is bookended by silence and goes full speed punk at the center.

column1: Full Communism's songs are performed in both English and Spanish—Ruiz said the band approach music ""with the intention to speak to as many people as possible."" The album's last two tracks are covers—one in each language. There's ""Poder Elegir"" by Los Prisioneros
column2: a song the Chilean band recorded as an effort to urge people to fight conformity and complacency during the rule of dictator Augusto Pinochet. The other: Bruce Springsteen's ""Dancing in the Dark"". When Ruiz shouts the Boss' world-weariness
column3: she sounds as though she's already started a fire of her own. The covers are effective—the ideal pairing of pop infectiousness and calls to action. Downtown Boys insist that nothing's going to change unless people actually get up and do something
column4:
and they've offered a soundtrack that makes positive action feel both attainable and liberating.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21822/homepage_large.0289c4e3.jpg|Jackie|5068.0|Ciara|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Epic']|2015-05-08 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:13.507398|"

Motherhood has often brought out the best in your fave pop stars. Mariah
column2: M.I.A.
column3: Madonna
column4: Kelis
column5: Beyoncé: all have stellar postpartum releases to their names
column6: with some explicitly riffing on the theme
column7: and others signaling a shift—sometimes patronizingly referred to as more 'mature'—in sound. These albums all sound very different
column8: but they form a sort of collective statement that motherhood isn't some aesthetic
column9: thematic or musical purgatory for women. We are not content
column10: these working women say
column11: on being aged out
column12: or matron-ized
column13: by the youth-oriented trajectory of the industry.

column1: ""Man
column2: I just delivered a nine-pound
column3: 10-ounce baby. I'm a bad motherfucker
column4: Ciara drawls on ""Jackie (B.M.F.)""
column5: the explosive intro track on her sixth album
column6: Jackie. Named after her own mother
column7: Jackie doesn't necessarily shift Ciara's sound so much as a frame it with a faint redemption narrative
column8: centered around the birth of her baby and her breakup with rapper and erstwhile ex Future. ""You actin' like you upgrading me
column9: I upgraded you/ You and me at Fashion Week in Paris
column10: I put you onto that new
column11: goes the album's first single
column12: the breakup ballad ""I Bet"". But Ciara's never been much for album-length statements. Instead the ATL-reared R&B pop star
column13: best known for her sensuous
column14: studious approach to choreography
column15: has created a career by rewiring the city's full throttle hip-hop motifs into club-friendly pop.

column1: Jackie doesn't do much to allay the feeling
column2: which has followed her for her whole career
column3: that there's better R&B pop out there. But instead of positioning herself against Rihanna—who is only just starting to really find her vocal strength
column4: and who is decidedly not a dancer—or Beyoncé (ha ha)
column5: Ciara is content to be a reliable mainstay
column6: a translator of Atlanta's ever-shifting avant-garde and the constant bringer of high-energy dance anthems. She's innovative within her own framework: Before Beyoncé started dabbling with bars
column7: Ciara was already rapping on 2013's ""Super Turnt Up"" and the album-less Mike WiLL Made It single
column8: <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TzlNPaLvVHE"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Wake Up
column9: No Make-Up"".

column1: The problems with Jackie
column2: a serviceable record that gets better with multiple listens
column3: is that unlike her previous releases it's more heavily focused on paint-by-numbers Dr. Luke electro. And
column4: an even bigger problem—and this is where Ciara has always faltered—is that it hints at a storyline
column5: but doesn't go deeper. Moms totally care about more than just being moms
column6: but consider that Ciara's records are also too often about nothing at all
column7: and it's hard not to wish she'd gone into more depth. It's an opportunity and
column8: again
column9: on Jackie
column10: she doesn't take it. There's a song called ""Lullaby"" that's not about a baby but tucking a lover in for the evening. The actual lullaby comes toward the very end
column11: with ""I Got You""; she sings ""Hush
column12: Little Baby"" while Future Zahir gurgles the outro.

column1: There are interesting moments: the hesitant merging of post-ratchet trap and drum and bass on ""B.M.F.""
column2: the Niles Rodgers-esque retro-soul bounce of ""Kiss & Tell""
column3: and her beatific
column4: waxy vocal performance on ""That's How I'm Feelin'"" and ""Fly"". Both are pillowy Polow Da Don electro-lite bangers—the former featuring Pitbull and Missy Elliott—referencing early Ciara
column5: like the jock-jam energy of <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iBHNgV6_znU"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""1
column6: 2 Step"". For Jackie's deluxe edition
column7: Ciara calls upon Joe Jonas to switch up the dewy
column8: gloriously shady ""I Bet""
column9: featuring imitation-Future yelps and adlibs. And second single ""Dance Like We're Making Love""
column10: is a gorgeous
column11: sleek midtempo track
column12: similar to Frank Ocean's ""Novocane"" but with a bigger
column13: airier hook.

column1: She carried her last album cycle off a slow jam about a very public romance (""Body Party"")
column2: but ""I Bet"" just isn't as strong. Jackie's best moments come on those Polow power jams
column3:
when the music imitates the explosiveness of Ciara's movement. What would've made Jackie better than the last album—what would've given her the edge that her peers maintain—is some insight behind Ciara's redemption songs.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21729/homepage_large.f95ff3f0.jpg|Michael Angelo|29073.0|Michael Angelo|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Anthology Recordings']|2015-05-08 00:00:00|1977|2016-06-11 16:11:14.156017|"

If reissue labels are to be believed
column2: then a staggering amount of top-shelf singer/songwriter and psychedelia albums has been slipping through the cracks for decades. In the last several years
column3: we've seen a daunting uptick in ""lost classics
column4: freshly unearthed
column5: which begins to generate a sort of uncanny ""How-can-this-be?"" tingle that you might recall from the deluge of posthumous 2Pac releases. There’s a fine line between ""rescued from history"" and ""dredged from oblivion
column6: and with each new rarity and oddity
column7: we’re given a chance to suss out where that line sits.

column1: In Michael Angelo Nigro’s case
column2: what we're being given is an interesting artifact
column3: a pleasant record
column4: and probably something that sounded both a little weirder and more interesting around the time it was recorded
column5: in 1977. Nigro was a session player in Kansas City then
column6: and he tracked the album at night and at off-hours at Liberty Recording
column7: the studio where he worked. He was interested in the Beatles and the Byrds
column8: and Cream
column9: and Greek mythology
column10: and he played everything on the album except the drums. He was very clearly in his own headspace
column11: and the record has a dreamy
column12: unhurried feel. The label didn’t want the thing when it was done
column13: so off he went
column14: to a smaller studio called Big-K
column15: which mixed and released 500 copies. The end.

column1: Except now Anthology
column2: the offshoot of Mexican Summer devoted to reissues
column3: has tracked down a sealed original copy and remastered it with Nigro's blessing
column4: presenting it to us as the latest in a line of lost psych classics. It has some scruffy bonafides in this realm; it was included on the late Acid Archives author Patrick Lundborg’s list of his favorite private-issue albums
column5: and 7”s of ""Sorcerer’s Delight"" can still fetch good prices on Discogs. But today
column6: Nigro's gentle
column7: warbly psychedelia has to fight for attention amongst similarly themed stuff being made today
column8: on labels like Drag City and Captured Tracks. Nigro's record might have technically been first
column9: but since it’s being heard in context
column10: it’s gotta wait in line
column11: just like all the rest of us.

column1: Michael Angelo Nigro’s voice is a sweet instrument
column2: and filtered through synths and ringing open guitars on ""Flight of Pegasus"" he sounds like a romantic
column3: unabashed in his visions of ""a sea of dreams and love"" and ""Grapes of Atlantis/ Falling from celestial vines."" The chord progressions feel bent backwards by acid
column4: which Nigro swore he never took in a recent interview with Aquarium Drunkard
column5: and the guitar leads alternate between reminding you forcefully of George Harrison and Arthur Lee. On ""Journey (to Find Who We Are)""
column6: his voice sounds uncannily like early Paul Simon
column7: and the verse melody that feels like it could be mapped onto Simon & Garfunkel's ""Patterns"" without too much deviation.

column1: These comparisons mount over the short album’s 10 tracks
column2: and register like little pinpricks in its aura. You might find yourself enjoying it while wondering: What is here
column3: exactly
column4: that can’t be found in the ocean of similar material
column5: stretching back decades
column6: and all of it gobbled up and apprised by thousands of psych-pop aficionados? For Nigro
column7: who has seen his album bootlegged persistently over the decades
column8: having it back in print with his blessing probably closes an important internal circle. But for us
column9:
it might be more a curio than an essential document.

"|20461.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20461-michael-angelo/|6.7|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21795/homepage_large.da816389.jpg|GRM Works|32893.0|Beatriz Ferreyra|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Recollection GRM']|2015-05-08 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:14.842232|"

Reissue culture gets derided for many reasons—they comprise the majority of RSD chum; they can obscure newer artists; they make for long queues at record pressing plants. Some see them as a pernicious symptom of something deeper: Britt Brown of 100% Silk wrote that the proliferation of past musics ""reveals a host of aesthetic anxieties
column2: disappointments
column3: and insecurities lurking beneath the surface of our 21st century music landscape."" But when reissues serve their highest calling
column4: they shed light on voices neglected by history
column5: and were it not for reissues and rediscovery
column6: a generation of vital female electronic composers might have been lost.

column1: It was in the late '90s
column2: near the end of her life
column3: for example
column4: that BBC Radiophonic Workshop member (and ""Doctor Who"" theme composer) Delia Derbyshire received some recognition for her electronic music
column5: and it's only in this century that more notice has been paid to the likes of Laurie Spiegel and Suzanne Ciani. Argentinean composer Beatriz Ferreyra
column6: an early colleague of musique concrète inventor Pierre Schaeffer who studied at the Paris Groupe de Recherches Musicales studios from 1963-70
column7: only had her work issued (by the label) in 2012. The Recollection GRM label
column8: which has done fine work reissuing epochal works from the likes of Schaeffer
column9: Luc Ferrari and Bernard Parmegiani
column10: two recent reissues investigate Ferreyra's overlooked work and a revered obscurity from Michel Redolfi.

column1: Ferreyra's release pairs two shorter '60s works with two longer
column2: more recent compositions
column3: and there's a fluidity to her work that suggests her methodology remains unchanged. The 21st century pieces are crisper and clock in at over twice the length as the earlier ones
column4: but they sound of a whole. The accompanying notes
column5: referencing alchemy and the Qabalah
column6: suggest that change and the mercurial state of the natural world is a crucial theme to Ferreyra.

column1: ""Demeures aquatiques""
column2: from 1967
column3: manipulates the sounds of metal sheets and glass rods to explore what Ferreyra writes is ""the flow constantly facing the ebb."" In it
column4: a nervous wobble of electromagnetic tape gets nearly submerged by a drone before high fluttering tones shoot up
column5: those high frequencies themselves becoming a drone. ""Médisances""
column6: from the next year
column7: is a four-channel piece turning orchestral instruments and mouth harp into salt water taffy
column8: twangs and bowed strings slowed to an exhilarating crawl
column9: all leading up to an exclamatory yelp at the last moment. There's a similar sense of speed on ""Un fil invisible""
column10: which warps its source sounds at a dizzying rate. At the same time
column11: there's far more space and silence in the mix for the smaller sounds to move about
column12: with strings zooming
column13: tactile objects bursting into stardust
column14: and small scurrying sounds suggesting mice aboard a space station.

column1: Fans of the furthest fringes of electronic dance music might recognize Michel Redolfi’s name
column2: as his music has appeared in mixes by Demdike Stare
column3: Rene Hell and early on in Four Tet’s Fabriclive mix
column4: leading into twisted UK garage. As the 3D graphics (like the original edition
column5: this reissue includes a pair of 3D glasses in its gatefold sleeve) and title attests
column6: Redolfi became enchanted with the Pacific Ocean during a seven-year period he spent in California ""attempting to musically translate my discovery of the Pacific
column7: as he puts it.

column1: Having spent one season learning to surf in the Pacific Ocean—which more often than not meant learning to read its temperamental
column2: ever-changing waves and not be overwhelmed by its powerful currents—Redolfi’s compositions are a remarkable ‘translation’ of that body of water. Deploying the then-newfangled Synclavier digital synthesizer (which around 1977-78 was used primarily by Frank Zappa and Wire producer Mike Thorne)
column3: ""Pacific Tubular Waves"" differs radically across its five movements. Redolfi conveys a wide emotional range on this side: giddiness
column4: exhilaration
column5: bewilderment
column6: glee
column7: panic
column8: uncertainty
column9: and both an eerie and sun-kissed state of calm.

column1: While one side explores the surface of the Pacific
column2: ""Immersion"" uses as its source sounds from hydrophones submerged into the ocean itself. The design of Redolfi’s compositions can feel macro and micro at once
column3: where the sensation of the Pacific’s vastness as well as the way small droplets bead up on your skin are both tangible. One can visualize the tiny bubbles surrounding each sound event here and ""Deep Immersion"" in particular is mesmerizing.

column1: There’s a peculiar contradiction at play when it comes to reassessing such obscure electronic compositions. On one hand
column2: they are cloistered soundworlds
column3: artifacts with no outside signifiers; on the other
column4: they don’t sound dated. Despite the five decades separating some of Ferreyra’s works
column5: one won’t find any correlation to the many changes that mainstream music underwent during that same time period. They both exist outside of time
column6: yet now feel at home in the modern electronic moment
column7: where it’s normal to have DJ sets in the footwork/Fade to Mind/Hudson Mohawke mode be quicksand-solid and quickly morphing. In an uncanny manner
column8:
both reissues anticipate an aesthetic that now lurks just beneath the surface of our 21st century music landscape.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21716/homepage_large.7ffc33d9.jpg|MCIII|29837.0|Mikal Cronin|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge']|2015-05-07 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:15.473416|"

On ""Turn Around""
column2: the opening track and lead single on MCIII
column3: Mikal Cronin sings some sweet bromides about the passing of time. His lyrics are punctuated by little directives
column4: like ""Turn it down
column5: ""stop
column6: or ""turn around
column7: ""here it goes
column8: and the arrangement seems to be responding to him
column9: amping up or quieting down depending on the line. Without a devastating hook—like the one on ""Weight""
column10: the opening track and lead single from Cronin’s 2013 full-length
column11: MCII—it feels a bit like listening to stage instructions from a power pop song to be finished later
column12: a rote rehearsal from a tired director.

column1: The consecutive
column2: uniform titles are apt: MCIII plays like a photocopy of MCII
column3: with added incidental noise yielding substantially diminished returns. That said
column4: MCIII was copied from good source material. Cronin sounded radiant on MCII
column5: his supple singing inflected with subtle melodic idiosyncrasies and unfussy displays of considerable vocal range. Still
column6: timing helped him. Cronin’s story—a dynamic songwriter hidden deep within San Francisco’s garage rock nouveau until Merge Records asked for an album—was perhaps one of his best hooks. Devotees of Cronin’s collaborator
column7: Ty Segall
column8: relished the idea of a pianist anomaly in a scene that seemed so singularly fixated on fuzz. It all conspired to artificially inflate MCII’s reception
column9: which helps explain how MCIII sounds so much like it and so disappointing.

column1: MCIII’s press emphasizes that it’s a bigger record
column2: stuffed with strings and horns and whatever else
column3: but it's a red herring
column4: a pretty transparent attempt to distract from the record’s fundamental shortcomings. MCIII’s string quartet contributes no more emotional heft than one violist did on MCII’s ""Change""
column5: a song that also benefited from the feeling of velocity intimated by players pushing the beat. There’s less of that live ensemble feel to propel MCIII
column6: none of the syncopated groove from a solid MCII track like ""See It My Way"". Instead
column7: there’s a Greek instrument called a tzouras on ""ii) Gold""
column8: which sounds pretty cool
column9: but that’s a regrettable swap.

column1: And even a symphony couldn’t redeem a pop-rock record without commanding lead vocals. Here
column2: too
column3: MCIII suffers a bit. Cronin’s dulcet hesitance has given way to slightly meeker delivery. The hooks are there—in the engaging vocal counterpoint to a descending horn line on the bridge of ""Say""
column4: for instance—but they’re difficult to appreciate. The pat literalism of the lyrics—""I’m not alone
column5: ""God
column6: I need some control
column7: ""I feel like I’m dying
column8: and the like—doesn't help.

column1: The conceit of MCIII’s second half involves a song suite about loss of personal agency
column2: acceptance
column3: self-discovery
column4: and other such hallmarks of personal songwriting. This quasi-concept is basically indiscernible
column5: indicated only by some hastily appended numerals at the beginning of each song title (One track
column6: the rather beautiful but interlude-like ballad
column7: ""v) Different""
column8: appeared sans numerals on a compilation last year.) Considering Sonny and the Sunsets’ recent Talent Night at the Ashram and Jack Name’s Light Show
column9: noncommittal concept records are fashionable among Californian garage outliers nowadays
column10: but even a qualified application of the tag to MCIII is a stretch. Once the numerical song suite starts
column11: the most important realization you are left with is that this record is front-loaded.

column1: That’s because ""i) Alone"" is an arduous intensity hike to nowhere
column2: ""ii) Gold"" leans on the mid-tempo thud that was tiresome back on Mikal Cronin
column3: and the outro of ""iv) Ready"" is just mercilessly redundant. Some seething guitar solos crop up
column4: but nothing especially unhinged in light of his earlier collaborative work with Segall and MCII’s ace rave-up
column5: ""Change"". Cronin’s lithe vocal melodies do sound beautiful on the spry closer
column6: ""vi) Circle""
column7: a reminder of the voice that commanded so many new listeners last time. Sequenced last
column8: the song title is probably supposed to lend some poetic finality
column9:
but it speaks better to Cronin’s creative stasis.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21557/homepage_large.42dfde64.jpg|Sprinter|30970.0|Torres|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Partisan']|2015-05-07 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:16.044196|"

Questioning what you once held fundamentally true is exhausting
column2: but in every possible way
column3: Brooklyn-via-Nashville singer-songwriter Mackenzie Scott's intense
column4: spiritual sophomore album as Torres suggests that this is work worth doing. Her 2013 self-titled debut felt inherently raw in its stripped-down folk-rock
column5: a sound akin to that of her future collaborator Sharon Van Etten. On Sprinter
column6: however
column7: Scott shrouds her voice with feedback and heavier rock instrumentation
column8: created alongside PJ Harvey producer and percussionist Rob Ellis. The sound is like a gauze bandage covering the emotional wounds
column9: the profound isolation and fear of abandonment
column10: that sit at the heart of Sprinter. But Scott lets a little red bleed through nonetheless
column11: and for listeners
column12: at least
column13: that's a good thing.

column1: An album ago
column2: Scott told what was presumed to be some version of her own adoption story with ""Moon & Back""; the song is written from the perspective of a woman who left a letter for the baby she gave up
column3: but no names are given. Though Torres continues to write from perspectives besides her own—and it continues to prove interesting—on Sprinter
column4: any trepidation she may have felt over first-person narrative is pushed aside in pursuit of unflinching honesty. On the album's stunning
column5: solo acoustic closer ""The Exchange""
column6: Scott is direct where before she was mysterious: ""Mother
column7: father
column8: I'm underwater
column9: and I don't think you can pull me out of this
column10: she coos in the chorus. ""Blew my per diem on an eighth of Blue Dream/ So I can breathe but I still can't breathe
column11: Scott adds
column12: revealing her coping method of choice—sativa-dominant hybrids. The song's arresting plainspokenness recalls Neko Case's memorable a cappella declaration of abandonment and rejection on The Worst Things Get
column13: the Harder I Fight...'s ""Nearly Midnight
column14: Honolulu"".

column1: Sprinter splits its mood between depression and rage
column2: mirrored in the album's loud-quiet musical dichotomy that is not unlike that of early PJ Harvey albums. With the aid of her co-producer Ellis (showing off his status as an underrated rock drummer who makes every beat sound crisp)
column3: Portishead guitarist Adrian Utley (who recently helped Perfume Genius also reach a musical state as real as it is deeply unsettling)
column4: and Harvey bassist Ian Oliver
column5: Scott fully inhabits her loudest moments by inching towards post-rock and synth-rock. The album's crowning achievement
column6: ""Son
column7: You Are No Island""
column8: forges a mystical through line from Celtic music to Hole's ""I Think That I Would Die""
column9: to Godspeed You! Black Emperor
column10: to Mica Levi's Under the Skin soundtrack. This song simmers with rage
column11: a stick of dynamite waiting to blow
column12: but it's Scott's restraint in delaying the explosions—first a wall of hardened distortion
column13: then via vocal loops—that hits the hardest.

column1: When she lets her depressive side out
column2: Scott can ramble slightly. On ""Ferris Wheel""
column3: Scott takes her time meandering through intense pining for another who's ""got the sadness too"" while an echoing guitar provides a woozy background twang. For such a slow pace
column4: it goes on about twice as long as it needs to (seven minutes). On the flipside sits ""Cowboy Guilt""
column5: a rare light spot that lasts less than three minutes. Scott captures the thrill of instant interpersonal connection via the quick and steady beat of a drum machine and flourishes of a music box melody.

column1: When Scott can find the right balance of these elements—dark
column2: introspective
column3: midtempo
column4: highly distorted
column5: and in the four to five-minute range—she hits a sweet spot
column6: like on ""New Skin"" and the album's title track. These are the songs where Scott seems to lay out her thesis statements with a slight nods to theology; on ""New Skin""
column7: atop a formidable '90s alt-rock build

In the run-up to II—the sophomore set from Toronto noisemakers Metz—frontman Alex Edkins promised three things: ""We are not going to clean up our sound
column2: we are not going to hire a big producer

column4: II is another snarling beast of a record
column5: 10 more all-lunging
column6: all-screaming anti-anthems crammed into another chaotic
column7: cloistered half-hour
column8: every inch as grotty and combustible and unfriendly as its predecessor. Once again produced by Holy Fuck's Graham Walsh and engineered by Alex Bonefant
column9: II is a refinement

column11: well
column12:
have another.

Metz spent five years honing their considerable strengths—Edkins' caustic fretwork and vocal agita
column13: Hayden Menzies and Chris Slorach's stampeding low-end—before unleashing their self-titled debut. And
column14: on II
column15: they seem to feel no particular need to tinker around with what got them here. They still draw most of their inspiration from turn-of-the-'90s post-hardcore and the Nirvana albums on either side of Nevermind
column16: and they still believe three-and-a-half minutes is about as long as any song has the right to be. The terse II comes in a smidge less rigid than its predecessor
column17: a shade or two darker
column18: a touch more physical. Not that you'll notice; once the bassline of opener ""Acetate"" takes hold
column19: for 30 short minutes
column20: your thoughts become a smear of white. These songs are not ""catchy"" by any traditional metric; they don't so much get stuck in your head as get lodged in your skin.

column1: Metz take great pains to avoid your standard verse-chorus-verse structures
column2: and II
column3: even more than the debut
column4: downplays the traditionally ""songier"" aspects of these songs for a series of weaponized strikes. Still
column5: beyond a few drop-outs and punch-ins
column6: these songs all seem to gnash about in a fairly similar fashion. Hayden Menzies' bull-in-a-China-shop drums are unrelenting
column7: but they rarely push too far past their original tempo; Edkins talks his way through a few of these verses
column8: but he's every bit as likely to start off in a full-on wail
column9: and his riffs
column10: while bludgeoning from the get-go
column11: never seem quite sure how to up their own antes.

column1: All of this makes the first 20 or so seconds of any Metz song roughly as thrilling as the last 20
column2: which gives II the feeling of falling down the same set of stairs ten times in a row. There is not
column3: as Edkins promised
column4: anything for the radio on II
column5: but neither is there much attempt to chart new territory
column6: no ambitious gambits or radical tempo-shifts
column7: nothing they haven't already proven themselves capable of in the past. These songs barely give themselves space to meander or develop; they pull the cord
column8: and off they go. By and large
column9: they perform their seethe-pummel-repeat routine with an almost mechanized precision. This one thing
column10: they do incredibly well. Then they do it nine more times.

column1: In fact
column2: II is often more compelling on the rare occasions when Metz pulls back on the brontosaurus riffage and focuses on the connective tissue
column3: the strands of sinew that surround many of these songs. The windchime-scrape at the tail end of ""Spit You Out""
column4: the frizzy intro lick to ""I.O.U.""
column5: the whinnying strum at the top of ""Kicking a Can of Worms"": all these strange
column6: static-y interludes
column7: brief though they may be
column8: build the kind of tension Metz are all too game to release. It's a shame they couldn't find a little more space for it. Fleeting though they are
column9:
these little interstitials provide a few much-needed valleys to II's overabundance of peaks.

Throughout II
column10: just about anything is prone to set Edkins off: crass commercialism
column11: self-loathing
column12: painkillers and—horror of horror—waiting in lines. These are angry-sounding songs
column13: no question there. But when a typical chorus goes something like ""painkiller
column14: painkiller/ that's why I feel unreal/ painkiller
column15: painkiller/ that's one hell of a deal
column16: you start to wonder if Edkins is really screaming out of some deep-seated passion

column1: In interviews
column2: Metz claim to be a punk band largely because it's the one genre the three of them could agree on. They're not claiming to be anything they're not
column3: but—after two records far more similar than different—one can't help but wonder what else they could be. Were they willing to risk more

column6: II might've sailed right past its beloved predecessor. But by sticking so closely to the script laid out by their debut
column7:
II is the one thing punk rock should never be: careful.

Noel’s creative restlessness is potent fuel.

As Voltaire said

column1: Anyways

column4: especially since her voice seems so sure of its rightness. ""Jealousy"" is addressed to those amorphous ""haters
column5: the bane of any successful person's existence
column6: and offers the deeply uncomplicated observation that ""girls will be girls and boys will be boys/ It's just the way it is."" A warning sign goes up when you consider Cosentino is no longer a broke-ish slacker sitting on the couch with her cat and her bong. She's achieved a level of success that allows her to appear in whiskey ads and design her own Urban Outfitters clothing line
column7: while ignoring the obvious political implications. And why shouldn't she? Anyone with a problem is only a hater.

you can either shrug it off or let the vibes carry you away.

Red House Painters were fairly popular in the early '90s
column2: but details on them were scarce. This was all before the Internet

column10: via Ohio). At least for me

column1: Not that any of this is bad. The songs on the first four albums—1992's Down Colorful Hill
column2: 1993's pair of self-titled albums (the first nicknamed Rollercoaster

column6: personal lyrics and were accompanied by stark
column7: often naturalistic photographs on the covers. The package came with the crystalline
column8: spacious production and Kozelek's clear
column9: powerful voice

column11: but you kind of gave up on keeping track of this kind of thing.

column2: which they increasingly do
column3: the practice usually offers a chance to hear familiar songs again
column4: sometimes with remastering

column9: with individual album reissues on black vinyl to follow) offers a unique angle: The band's cantankerous frontman (as we can now call him after that whole War on Drugs debacle) is much better known
column10: and known quite differently
column11: all these years later. Now you do know exactly who Mark Kozelek is

column1: It's important to remember
column2: though
column3: that the group wasn't just Kozelek. At least not at the beginning. For the first three full-lengths
column4: it was Kozelek on vocals and guitars along with drummer Anthony Koutsos
column5: bassist Jerry Vessel
column6: and guitarist Gorden Mack. (Koutsos and Vessel continued with Kozelek to 2001; Mack left in 1995 and was replaced by Phil Carney
column7: who still plays with Sun Kil Moon now and then.) Starting with Songs for a Blue Guitar
column8: which followed Red House Painters' last album for 4AD Ocean Beach

column1: Even accounting for the added years and maybe some Kozelek burnout
column2: the four LPs in this boxset remain Red House Painters' most magical records
column3: and some of the most beautiful works of Kozelek's career. If you're someone who's been put off by his feuds and outbursts
column4: put aside those reservations—these records deserve it. And
column5: really
column6: when you come back to them

column8: that mystery somehow still remains. In fact
column9: now and then I need to remind myself just who it is I'm listening to. Unlike later SKM
column10: the vocals are treated with airier effects. The production is deep and spacious
column11: and sounds very 4AD. Kozelek's lyrics are personal
column12: and moving

column1: The first song we heard from Red House Painters is ""24""

column3: aged 24

column1: On the anguished second track
column2: ""Medicine Bottle""
column3: he offers up some of the detail-rich run-on lyricism that he returns to later with SKM. There's a playful country western-tinged sendup ""Lord Kill the Pain""

column1: There's the nostalgic

column3: a song about someone wondering whatever happened to their best friend from years earlier with both funny (""Do you remember our first subway ride?/ Our first heavy metal haircuts?"") and moving (""I remember your smile in the sun/ The day-dreaming boy without your shirt on…"") details. It ends with Kozelek noting that the connection is still there: ""You're the oldest juvenile delinquent bum/ My best friend.""

column1: It's the gorgeous title track that hints most at the truly brilliant second collection

column3: eternally."" You get warts and all

Red House Painters were fairly popular in the early '90s
column2: but details on them were scarce. This was all before the Internet
column3: so you basically had what a jewel box told you. It's hard to imagine at this point
column4: but when I first heard them
column5: I didn't know anything about Mark Kozelek
column6: the frontman and mastermind behind the project. I'm not sure I knew his name
column7: and I definitely didn't know what he looked like
column8: or his personality outside of the songs. I also had no idea the band was a quartet
column9: or that they lived in San Francisco (in Kozelek's case
column10: via Ohio). At least for me
column11: Red House Painters existed outside of a scene
column12: too. They had a familiar record label with its own distinct aesthetic
column13: but that was the only real touchstone.

column1: Not that any of this is bad. The songs on the first four albums—1992's Down Colorful Hill
column2: 1993's pair of self-titled albums (the first nicknamed Rollercoaster
column3: the second Bridge
column4: after the photographs on their covers)
column5: and 1995's Ocean Beach (here packaged with the Shock Me EP from a year earlier)—felt personal and private enough that it was easy to get lost in your own head while listening. They featured heartbreaking
column6: personal lyrics and were accompanied by stark
column7: often naturalistic photographs on the covers. The package came with the crystalline
column8: spacious production and Kozelek's clear
column9: powerful voice
column10: and these things merged in an almost mystical way. The material felt less composed or worked over; it was more like the songs were birthed fully formed. They could drift on for more than 10 minutes
column11: but you kind of gave up on keeping track of this kind of thing.

column1: When old albums get reissued
column2: which they increasingly do
column3: the practice usually offers a chance to hear familiar songs again
column4: sometimes with remastering
column5: maybe a few bonuses. Some listeners are feeling nostalgic
column6: seeking to recreate the original context in their minds
column7: while many others are learning about the material for the first time
column8: and aren't all that clear on the context beyond the updated liner notes. 4AD's decision to reissue Red House Painters' first four albums as a fairly spare limited-edition Record Store Day box set (on bronze vinyl
column9: with individual album reissues on black vinyl to follow) offers a unique angle: The band's cantankerous frontman (as we can now call him after that whole War on Drugs debacle) is much better known
column10: and known quite differently
column11: all these years later. Now you do know exactly who Mark Kozelek is
column12: or at least you think you do.

column1: It's important to remember
column2: though
column3: that the group wasn't just Kozelek. At least not at the beginning. For the first three full-lengths
column4: it was Kozelek on vocals and guitars along with drummer Anthony Koutsos
column5: bassist Jerry Vessel
column6: and guitarist Gorden Mack. (Koutsos and Vessel continued with Kozelek to 2001; Mack left in 1995 and was replaced by Phil Carney
column7: who still plays with Sun Kil Moon now and then.) Starting with Songs for a Blue Guitar
column8: which followed Red House Painters' last album for 4AD Ocean Beach
column9: Kozelek basically started doing everything on his own. He released it on Supreme Recordings
column10: a label owned by John Hughes and under the auspices of Island Records
column11: which reminds me that he's the only person from Red House Painters who also went on to act in movies.

column1: Even accounting for the added years and maybe some Kozelek burnout
column2: the four LPs in this boxset remain Red House Painters' most magical records
column3: and some of the most beautiful works of Kozelek's career. If you're someone who's been put off by his feuds and outbursts
column4: put aside those reservations—these records deserve it. And
column5: really
column6: when you come back to them
column7: even after all these years
column8: that mystery somehow still remains. In fact
column9: now and then I need to remind myself just who it is I'm listening to. Unlike later SKM
column10: the vocals are treated with airier effects. The production is deep and spacious
column11: and sounds very 4AD. Kozelek's lyrics are personal
column12: and moving
column13: but come cloaked in ellipses and metaphor rather than the tell-all logorrhea of Benji.

column3: aged 24
column4: worrying about growing old: ""Oldness comes to rile/ The youth who dream suicide."" This is a concern across all of Kozelek's work
column5: and it's easy to imagine him worrying about these same things when he was 9 going on 10.

column1: The start of ""24"" is nearly silent—gentle minimal guitar before drums come in; it almost sounds like the start of a Codeine track. These songs were demos
column2: and are lightly touched up for the proper 4AD debut

column4: though
column5: with fuzzed guitars

column7: and more basic structures; on the slinky post-rock of ""Japanese to English""
column8: you can imagine them in a practice space

column1: There's the nostalgic

Red House Painters were fairly popular in the early '90s
column2: but details on them were scarce. This was all before the Internet
column3: so you basically had what a jewel box told you. It's hard to imagine at this point
column4: but when I first heard them
column5: I didn't know anything about Mark Kozelek
column6: the frontman and mastermind behind the project. I'm not sure I knew his name
column7: and I definitely didn't know what he looked like
column8: or his personality outside of the songs. I also had no idea the band was a quartet
column9: or that they lived in San Francisco (in Kozelek's case
column10: via Ohio). At least for me
column11: Red House Painters existed outside of a scene
column12: too. They had a familiar record label with its own distinct aesthetic
column13: but that was the only real touchstone.

column1: Not that any of this is bad. The songs on the first four albums—1992's Down Colorful Hill
column2: 1993's pair of self-titled albums (the first nicknamed Rollercoaster
column3: the second Bridge
column4: after the photographs on their covers)
column5: and 1995's Ocean Beach (here packaged with the Shock Me EP from a year earlier)—felt personal and private enough that it was easy to get lost in your own head while listening. They featured heartbreaking
column6: personal lyrics and were accompanied by stark
column7: often naturalistic photographs on the covers. The package came with the crystalline
column8: spacious production and Kozelek's clear
column9: powerful voice
column10: and these things merged in an almost mystical way. The material felt less composed or worked over; it was more like the songs were birthed fully formed. They could drift on for more than 10 minutes
column11: but you kind of gave up on keeping track of this kind of thing.

column1: When old albums get reissued
column2: which they increasingly do
column3: the practice usually offers a chance to hear familiar songs again
column4: sometimes with remastering
column5: maybe a few bonuses. Some listeners are feeling nostalgic
column6: seeking to recreate the original context in their minds
column7: while many others are learning about the material for the first time
column8: and aren't all that clear on the context beyond the updated liner notes. 4AD's decision to reissue Red House Painters' first four albums as a fairly spare limited-edition Record Store Day box set (on bronze vinyl
column9: with individual album reissues on black vinyl to follow) offers a unique angle: The band's cantankerous frontman (as we can now call him after that whole War on Drugs debacle) is much better known
column10: and known quite differently
column11: all these years later. Now you do know exactly who Mark Kozelek is
column12: or at least you think you do.

column1: It's important to remember
column2: though
column3: that the group wasn't just Kozelek. At least not at the beginning. For the first three full-lengths
column4: it was Kozelek on vocals and guitars along with drummer Anthony Koutsos
column5: bassist Jerry Vessel
column6: and guitarist Gorden Mack. (Koutsos and Vessel continued with Kozelek to 2001; Mack left in 1995 and was replaced by Phil Carney
column7: who still plays with Sun Kil Moon now and then.) Starting with Songs for a Blue Guitar
column8: which followed Red House Painters' last album for 4AD Ocean Beach
column9: Kozelek basically started doing everything on his own. He released it on Supreme Recordings
column10: a label owned by John Hughes and under the auspices of Island Records
column11: which reminds me that he's the only person from Red House Painters who also went on to act in movies.

column1: Even accounting for the added years and maybe some Kozelek burnout
column2: the four LPs in this boxset remain Red House Painters' most magical records
column3: and some of the most beautiful works of Kozelek's career. If you're someone who's been put off by his feuds and outbursts
column4: put aside those reservations—these records deserve it. And
column5: really
column6: when you come back to them
column7: even after all these years
column8: that mystery somehow still remains. In fact
column9: now and then I need to remind myself just who it is I'm listening to. Unlike later SKM
column10: the vocals are treated with airier effects. The production is deep and spacious
column11: and sounds very 4AD. Kozelek's lyrics are personal
column12: and moving
column13: but come cloaked in ellipses and metaphor rather than the tell-all logorrhea of Benji.

column1: The first song we heard from Red House Painters is ""24""
column2: the magisterial slowcore opener on 1992's Down Colorful Hill. It's from the point of view of someone
column3: aged 24
column4: worrying about growing old: ""Oldness comes to rile/ The youth who dream suicide."" This is a concern across all of Kozelek's work
column5: and it's easy to imagine him worrying about these same things when he was 9 going on 10.

column1: The start of ""24"" is nearly silent—gentle minimal guitar before drums come in; it almost sounds like the start of a Codeine track. These songs were demos
column2: and are lightly touched up for the proper 4AD debut
column3: but still sound spare and homemade and thin in the best way (a way that works with the confessional tone of the material). Red House Painters are more of a definable rock band on Colorful
column4: though
column5: with fuzzed guitars
column6: martial drumming
column7: and more basic structures; on the slinky post-rock of ""Japanese to English""
column8: you can imagine them in a practice space
column9: jamming it out. In this sense
column10: it's less otherworldly than the next two albums.

column1: On the anguished second track
column2: ""Medicine Bottle""
column3: he offers up some of the detail-rich run-on lyricism that he returns to later with SKM. There's a playful country western-tinged sendup ""Lord Kill the Pain""
column4: which takes Kozelek's depressing lyrics to a comical extreme with lines like: ""Kill my neighbors/ And all my family too/ They doubt my direction."" Of course
column5: he's likely partially serious
column6: too. This humor is something Kozelek has maintained
column7: even when his critics think of him as being peevish or over-sensitive.

column1: There's the nostalgic
column2: quietly heartbreaking ""Michael""
column3: a song about someone wondering whatever happened to their best friend from years earlier with both funny (""Do you remember our first subway ride?/ Our first heavy metal haircuts?"") and moving (""I remember your smile in the sun/ The day-dreaming boy without your shirt on…"") details. It ends with Kozelek noting that the connection is still there: ""You're the oldest juvenile delinquent bum/ My best friend.""

column1: It's the gorgeous title track that hints most at the truly brilliant second collection
column2: Rollercoaster. It's nimble. It feels effortless. It expands to 11 minutes without seeming to push very hard. It barely matters what he's saying because of how it's paced and how it's said. On Rollercoaster
column3: it felt like RHP existed outside of everything
column4: and listening now
column5: it still feels that way. Down Colorful Hill is an excellent
column6: idiosyncratic debut
column7: but it doesn't quite prepare you for the 1993 collection. Mark Kozelek produced Rollercoaster
column8: and it's proof enough that he's the best person to be handling the knobs on his own songs: the guitar sound is perfect
column9: songs burst and bloom
column10: the vocals are placed perfectly like ghosts. Overall
column11: Rollercoaster and Bridge
column12: released the same year and featuring songs from the same session
column13: move away from the more songwriterly approach of the other work in Kozelek's career—the production is more distant and expansive
column14: and the instruments are given to lengthy excursions and big blasts of guitars.

column2: but it's not the kind of album where you stop to note these kinds of distinctions: Each song feels like a detail in a large painting. On it
column3: Kozelek fears the violence in his blood
column4: remembers being an outcast

column6: dismisses a girl in New Jersey

column8: confesses that he's afraid to drive
column9: and manages to do all this in moving
column10: atmospheric anthems that resonate two decades later. The songs tend to go on forever
