As red herrings go
column2: first single ""The Way"" off Kehlani’s first official album
column3: You Should Be Here
column4: is a doozy. The song is a sensual shuffle that channels SZA
column5: Jhené Aiko
column6: and Kelela
column7: from spacey
column8: hesitant vocals
column9: to a slowed-and-pitched-down rap (from the typically nimble Chance the Rapper)
column10: to the lyrics—it’s a straightforward ode to lust
column11: all about desire and longing and waiting for the moment where wanting and having your partner collide. It’s a fascinating song
column12: and only in the most superficial ways does it suggest anything about You Should Be Here’s loftier goals.

column1: The song’s lyrics might be the biggest red herring of all. Kehlani spends most of You Should Be Here switching between telling various dudes to get their shit together and the rest on a mission to inspire humanity. Kehlani has little in common with other former-child-stars-turned-singers Zendaya or Tinashe (Kehlani and her band made it to the finals on ""America’s Got Talent"")
column2: and she has little in common with the music of cool
column3: casually misogynistic R&B bros
column4: and in spite of a connection to PARTYNEXTDOOR and hailing from Oakland
column5: neither of those facts figure much into her music
column6: at least on an obvious level. If there’s a contemporary comparison to be made
column7: it’s Frank Ocean. Kehlani
column8: along with right-hand-man producer Jahaan Sweet
column9: shares Ocean’s auteuristic vision and plainspoken eloquence. And
column10: much like Ocean
column11: when Kehlani veers toward the maudlin
column12: somehow the sincerity of it all redeems itself.

column1: The beating heart at the center of You Should Be Here forgives some of these dips into mawkishness. You Should Be Here’s dynamism and generosity is something to be amazed by
column2: especially considering Kehlani is all of 19 years old. On the stunning ""Wanted""
column3: she sings
column4: ""As a woman/ When you are broken/ You make a choice to stay down or go in
column5: but the chorus
column6: one of resounding triumph
column7: begins with the declaration
column8: ""He makes me feel wanted/ Like no one has before."" Kehlani weaves an emotional
column9: stirring thread through her songs that mostly feels joyful
column10: even when she’s lurking on Instagram (""Jealous"") or being vexed by a new flame (""Yet"").

column1: When some of these songs soar in their choruses
column2: like on ""Wanted""
column3: the title track
column4: and the synthy
column5: bubble-gummy kiss-off ""How That Taste""
column6: Kehlani’s full-throated vocals and live-band sound recall '90s R&B groups like Total. But the album also strays to lots of other places: into jazzy
column7: new jack swing-influenced R&B
column8: straight-ahead devotion hymns (penultimate stomper ""Bright"")
column9: capital-P pop ballads (closer ""Alive""
column10: which would not sound out of place in a current adult-contemporary rotation). It’s this unabashed ambition that makes You Should Be Here resonate long after one has internalized its motivational urges (""Can't nobody love somebody that do not love themselves"") and tender observations on the mechanics of relationships (see the wistful ""Unconditional""). That Kehlani manages to breathe new life into these sounds and romantic musings is inspirational. She keeps telling people to follow her lead
column11:
too—just refer to the album’s title.

Science fiction is not cool. We can quibble about the particulars—are robots cool? sure
column3: robots are cool—but in practice
column4: there is no arguing that sci-fi is not cool. Even the Sci-Fi Channel hedged its bet and changed its name to Syfy. I am talking about dimly lit basements and damp
column5: beige convention centers: these are not cool spaces. But Nosaj Thing
column6: god bless him
column7: has done his best to rebuke that notion
column8: to find the sexiness buried under the jumpsuits. Along with Flying Lotus
column9: the Brainfeeder continuum
column10: a bunch of West Coast glitch-hop
column11: and their spiritual forefather
column12: El-P
column13: Nosaj creates music that evokes at once the infinite blackness of deep space and the curving
column14: gleaming chrome that moves through it. It is what plays when you type ""Andromeda galaxy"" in as your Uber destination.

column1: Fated is Jason Chung’s third album in six years
column2: and
column3: zoomed out
column4: it’s not so much an evolution as a continuation of the style he’s established. There’s an unearthly sense of calm to the entire affair: the beats skitter
column5: sure
column6: but the hi-hats on ""Erase"" sound like they’re echoing through an empty hull
column7: not going haywire. Opener ""Sci"" takes a minute to breathe to life
column8: runs a finger down some Vangelis chimes
column9: then takes a minute to slowly retire. (At 2:22
column10: it’s one of the longer tracks here.) Listen closer
column11: though
column12: and you can hear the progression Chung’s made over time
column13: perhaps most clearly by looking at the series of ""Light"" tracks that stretch through to his first record. ""Light #1""
column14: from 2009
column15: recalls the laser-fire panic of Ikonika’s debut
column16: which would come out the next year; 2013’s ""Light 3""
column17: which closed off the warmer Home
column18: looked toward '90s drum'n'bass while still making room for keening
column19: heart-sick melodies; this album’s ""Light 5"" is a series of de-escalating pulses
column20: at times registering as little more than a heartbeat.

column1: Fated
column2: in other words
column3: is Chung’s case for himself as one of hip-hop’s preeminent modern minimalists
column4: and the results are frequently sublime. You can imagine Thom Yorke hearing the pattering melancholy of ""Medic"" and quietly snapping his copy of King of Limbs over his knee. The otherworldly Primo boom-bap of ""Realize""
column5: at 90 seconds
column6: almost evokes the Midnight Eez or one of Dilla’s dusty old beat tapes
column7: were it not for the wheezing cyborg synthesizers. All of the sonic choices on previous records were similarly meticulous
column8: but here they’re assembled with the almost architectural grace of a Oneohtrix Point Never composition. While Fated follows a direct throughline from earlier Nosaj Thing albums
column9: one can also draw a clear line to R Plus Seven’s fixation on dated computer tones
column10: as well as its sense of slow-burn
column11: alien awe. This is not without its dangers. Splitting the difference between ambient and hip-hop is generally a fast track toward adderall-core study music—shout out to Blue Sky Black Death—and
column12: to be fair
column13: Fated is an overwhelmingly pleasant listen. It is decidedly un-dazzling.

column1: But quiet doesn’t mean it can’t also be daring. So many of Nosaj Thing’s contemporaries deal with in-the-red maximalism
column2: all hyper-compressed drums and lens-flare dynamics. But while FlyLo looked at Blade Runner and saw great plumes of fire and neon street fights
column3: Nosaj Thing saw something else: two robots falling in love. Accordingly
column4: Fated’s deeply electronic soundscape is most striking for its humanity. Throughout the record
column5: Chung extracts vocal lines like threads of gossamer
column6: treating human voices like violas to bow in much the same way that
column7: say
column8: Prefuse 73 treated them as toms to thwack. On ""Cold Stares""
column9: the most vocal track of Nosaj Thing’s discography
column10: Chance the Rapper charts the dark corners of this possibility space
column11: musing and sighing and crooning in a robot-human duet. This is a very small sort of revolution
column12: suggesting
column13: like Spike Jonze’s Her
column14: that the delineations between hard sci-fi and soft sci-fi might not be so rigid
column15:
and that our transhumanist future might still find room for some of life’s more corporeal pleasures.

column1: Quite the coincidence that Peripheral Vision shares a very similar name as Title Fight’s risky
column2: triumphant reinvention Hyperview
column3: as well as its producer. In each instance
column4: a traditionalist punk band goes headfirst into more aqueous forms of indie rock
column5: but retain qualities which put them at an advantage over the countless wan
column6: limp bands who decided to sound like the Smiths from the beginning.

column1: In Turnover's case
column2: their pop punk past is nipping at their heels: Their self-titled debut EP justly earned the tag
column3: and even after 2013’s Magnolia smoothed out some of their more Warped Tour affectations
column4: they were doing shows with Dashboard Confessional 2.0
column5: This Wild Life
column6: and the <span>perpetually short-pantsed
column7: hair-gelled schlubs in New Found Glory as recently as last month. But you can tell that they come to their new sound from a realm that prizes vocal
column8: lyrical and sonic clarity—Austin Getz's vocals are unusually upfront and legible for this style of music
column9: and Will Yip’s production is crystalline and sleek. ""Radio-friendly"" is mostly theoretical in 2015
column10: but Yip tends to work with bands who've managed to find young
column11: dedicated
column12: merch-buying audiences who still believe in the idea of big-tent alternative rock as a refuge.

column1: And so you hear a lot of atypically crowd-pleasing
column2: extroverted maneuvers here—the gorgeous opening reverie of ""Cutting My Fingers Off"" is blown open by a bridge of pulse-quickening drum rolls similar to Brand New’s ""Sic Transit Gloria…"" or any given Explosions in the Sky song. The chorus of ""Take My Head"" is florid
column3: AP English self-pity delivered as a pop punk shout-along
column4: ""Humming"" is sophisticated bedsit pop that expresses the same desires as ""Dixieland Delight"" or ""Chattahoochee""
column5: minus the geographical signifiers.

column1: But just as often
column2: the gap between where Turnover is and where they want to be is painfully obvious. Throughout
column3: Getz's lyrics are either effective or seriously awkward and there’s very little in between. He's earnest enough when he's fussing over his transition into adulthood (""New Scream""
column4: ""Hello Euphoria"")
column5: but just as often
column6: he's reading off Robert Smith flashcards
column7: his imagery full of dissolution
column8: disintegration
column9: dizziness
column10: disappearance and descent—you get pretty much all of the above during ""Dizzy on the Comedown""
column11: which reveals the wisdom of bands like Wild Nothing who purposefully go blank on lyrics.

column1: Despite its stylistic reverence
column2: Peripheral Vision can actually be novel when Turnover most resemble their previous incarnation. On ""Diazepam""
column3: Getz emasculates himself as a preemptive strike against the inevitable—""Your father doesn’t like me ‘cause I’m not into sports/ And your mother won’t approve because I’m not of the cross/ I took an upper before your sister’s wedding just to help me pretend
column4: creating a heretofore-unfathomable nexus between Blink-182 and Galaxie 500. And then there’s ""I Would Hate You If I Could"". Think of your favorite Real Estate song. One of the really chill ones like ""Green Aisles"" or ""Pool Swimmers"". And then
column5: instead of a chorus reminiscing about the simple
column6: bittersweet pleasures of suburban life or the challenges of fatherhood
column7: how about the bitter memories of rough sex with your ex
column8: pinning her against the wall and trying not to wake her roommates. They still sound like Turnover’s application to Captured Tracks finishing school
column9: but retain pop punk’s main lyrical drivers of social and sexual insecurity.

column1: It's hard to figure out an appropriate emotional reaction to the raw
column2: honest
column3: and unsympathetic character in ""I Would Hate You If I Could"". Perhaps the message is that even as your tastes in music mature
column4: getting fucked over in a relationship hurts as much as it does when you’re 16. That’s not supposed to be the enduring message of Peripheral Vision
column5: at least not according to Getz. He explained the album’s overarching theme as
column6: ""I always remember things better than they were and miss people more than I should."" Those are the feelings this music is meant to convey
column7: but as a document of a young band in a sharp and tricky growth spurt
column8:
Peripheral Vision still can’t hide how messy and complicated real life can get.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21615/homepage_large.76185d18.jpg|Runddans|32934.0|Todd Rundgren/Emil Nikolaisen/Hans-Peter Lindstrøm|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Smalltown Supersound']|2015-05-05 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:23.208044|"

Todd Rundgren had mastered the art of writing the perfect pop song by the time he was 23—so he’s spent the next four decades trying out pretty much everything else. While his early-'70s chart success posited him as a stateside McCartney
column2: his subsequent career more closely resembles that of an American Eno: a musician-cum-conceptualist who didn’t so much forsake rock stardom for the avant-garde as inhabit both worlds simultaneously. Rundgren is forever at the center of infinite extremes: proto-punk instigator and prog-rock architect
column3: celebrity and cult hero
column4: casino-circuit nostalgia act and remix-ready electronica enthusiast
column5: autocratic auteur and promiscuous collaborator
column6: bitter cynic and spiritual humanist
column7: genius and jester. He’s the iconoclast revered by everyone from Daft Punk to Prince to Earl Sweatshirt; he’s also the guy arguably responsible for inventing Smash Mouth.

column1: As he gets older
column2: these internal contradictions have only become more pronounced—this spring sees the release of two albums that respectively play to his accessible and exploratory impulses. But while the song-oriented solo release Global and high-concept progasaurus Runddans couldn’t be more different in sound and scope
column3: they leave similar impressions: while it’s reassuring that Todd Rundgren is still with us in 2015 indulging his every whim
column4: the batshit-bonkers music often misses the mark on ""inspired irreverence"" and lands directly in outright embarrassment.

column1: Global is Rundgren’s small-u utopia album
column2: dressing up his meditations on the environment
column3: feminism
column4: civil rights and community in synth-slicked rock and post-rave sonics
column5: recalling 1993’s techno manifesto No World Order—albeit
column6: mercifully
column7: without the attempts at rapping. (And much like his tour for that album
column8: Rundgren’s current stage set is more superclub throwdown than a rock show
column9: with the singer flanked by Dâm-Funk and choreographed dancers.) But it’s an album where the timely
column10: ripped-from-Twitter lyrics—complete with references to Miley Cyrus and Malala Yousafzai—clash awkwardly with the dated sound.

column1: For a record so topically consumed with the here-and-now
column2: Global feels like it could’ve come out over a quarter century ago: with its gated-reverb drums
column3: robo-filtered vocal hooks
column4: and arena-rock chug
column5: the opening ""Evrybody"" recalls the Reagan-era moment when '60s veterans started lacquering up old standards with '80s production gloss. ""Blind""
column6: meanwhile
column7: rails against bible-thumping
column8: climate change-denying Republicans over boudoir-summoning soft-rock
column9: complete with a Sanbornian saxgasm. Perhaps Global’s anachronistic sound is Rundgren’s way of emphasizing that the issues he’s addressing were just as pressing three decades ago and we’re still no further ahead. But even more tasteful production couldn’t redeem the goofiness of ""Earth Mother""
column10: a salute to famous female activists torpedoed by rote songcraft and hackneyed lyrics. (""We got a little bit too much testosterone/ Need a little more progesterone."")

column1: Rundgren was the rare rocker of his vintage to embrace electronics early on (he was eagerly heralding the death of rock'n'roll as far back as 1975)
column2: but Global finds him trumpeting the music’s transformative
column3: communal virtues like a neophyte who’s just come back from his first Burning Man
column4: resulting in tracks (see: ""Global Nation"") that resemble advertising jingles for Euro-trance compilations. Likewise
column5: the acid-house throb of ""Flesh and Blood"" doesn’t simply flaunt the influence of EDM
column6: it’s about EDM; as Rundgren marvels at ""the bang-bang-banging of a drum machine"" and ""the thunderous groove
column7: he comes off like a glowstick-twirling Marv Albert doing play-by-play from the middle of a rave. When Rundgren dials down the bluster
column8: Global yields moments of understated beauty: the addiction-themed ""Fate"" boasts a dreamily ascendant chorus
column9: and the soft-focus ""Soothe"" has enough genuine ache to cut through its '80s movie-montage sheen. But for an album preaching a message of unity
column10: Global just doesn’t hold together very well.

column1: If Global overwhelms its four-minute songs with conflicting aesthetics
column2: Runddans encounters the opposite problem: it unfurls across an IMAX-sized canvas
column3: but struggles to stretch out its concept to fill the space. The product of a mutual-admiration society forged with Norwegian space-disco dynamo Hans-Peter Lindstrøm and Serena-Maneesh mastermind Emil Nikolaisen
column4: Runddans is a 39-minute album broken up into 12 tracks
column5: meant to be experienced as a single continuous piece. Cleary modelled after the side-long cosmic-fusion suites Rundgren fashioned on 1975’s Initiation or with his contemporaneous art-rock ensemble Utopia
column6: the album is an exciting proposition on paper. While Rundgren regularly communes with classic-rock peers—he’s a long-time member of Ringo Starr’s All-Star Band and appeared on the ex-Beatle's recent solo album—Runddans marks a rare instance of working with younger spiritual kin less interested in his catalog of hits than his excursions into futurist psychedelia.

column1: For its first half at least
column2: Runddans lives up to its big-event billing. Its movements are arranged along a loose cycle-of-life narrative that conflates childbirth with spiritual awakening (sample title: ""Liquid Joy From the Womb of Infinity"")
column3: with the scene set by an entrancing swirl of oscillating electronics
column4: gong-crash eruptions
column5: and wordless vocals. The moment of birth is marked by Rundgren’s first utterance of Runddans’ central lyric—""I have waited for this moment for what seems like nine lifetimes/ You will never be closer than you are now/ Put your arms around me""—like a parent casting his eyes upon his newborn for the first time; tears of joy spring forth in the form of a gushing guitar solo set atop a celestial disco groove.

column1: But once it achieves lift-off 15 minutes in
column2: Runddans must grapple with the same question all new parents face after the immediate thrill of birth wears off: What now? The trio’s answer is to instantly deconstruct what they’ve so carefully crafted
column3: randomly fiddling with console levels and chopping up the beat to bring the piece crashing down. It’s not unlike the sudden tape-slice change-up Tortoise introduced 14 minutes into their own art-rock colossus
column4: ""Djed""
column5: violently disrupting the song at its hypnotic fever pitch. But rather than use the opportunity to open up Rundanns to new structural possibilities
column6: the trio and their small orchestra of supporting players cycle through endless variations on the piece’s main melodic motif
column7: dressing it up variously in space-age bachelor pad exotica
column8: sci-fi Beach Boys harmonies and West African rhythms all while the throughline turns evermore hazy.

column1: By the time Rundgren’s incessant vocal line slips out of sync with the Pompeii-scaled Pink Floyd lurch of ""Wave of Heavy Red (Disko Nectar)""
column2: Rundanns starts to feel like the prog rock version of Too Many Cooks: one idea repeated and reformulated past the point of absurdity into the realm of insanity. And sadly
column3: there are no great rewards for your endurance here: unsure of how to end the thing
column4: the trio opt to build the penultimate house workout
column5: ""Ravende Gal (Full Circle)""
column6: around their phone conversations about how to end the thing. Maybe that outcome isn’t too surprising
column7: given Rundgren’s long-standing fondness for breaking the fourth wall. But while Rundanns has all the makings of a late-career triumph
column8: it’s less a new watermark for Rundgren’s sprawling discography than an analog to it: beautiful and baffling in equal measure
column9: all over the map
column10:
and beholden to nothing but its own inexplicable logic.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21597/homepage_large.a66ed205.jpg|Loyalty|30293.0|The Weather Station|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Paradise of Bachelors']|2015-05-05 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:23.930878|"

Tamara Lindeman is no longer singing about white lilacs
column2: wild columbine
column3: rhubarb pie and big jars of honey. On two previous albums as the Weather Station
column4: Lindeman used acoustic guitars
column5: banjos and a lexicon of bucolic imagery to write graceful
column6: generous folk songs. The material wasn’t simple so much as vernacular
column7: so that even the Toronto songwriter’s most intense reflections on love and lust espoused a downhome familiarity.

column1: But Loyalty
column2: Lindeman’s third and best LP
column3: continues the inward pull of last year’s incisive EP
column4: What Am I Going to Do with Everything I Know. Her once-plaintive confessionals have morphed into intimate but impressionistic character studies
column5: where the songwriter spares neither herself nor her subjects an analytical eye. And the acoustic instruments that once galloped or crept behind her have morphed into abstract backdrops—sophisticated but understated settings that accent the expressive voice above them. Loyalty feels like a 40-minute glimpse into a secret world
column6: where familiar people (sisters
column7: mothers
column8: lovers) and traditional sounds (a fingerpicked guitar
column9: a patient piano) lead intriguing
column10: uncanny lives. It’s a place that demands to be revisited.

column1: To make Loyalty
column2: Lindeman and a minimal crew decamped to a deteriorating French mansion for a long wintertime recording session. Collaboration has long been integral to the Weather Station’s records
column3: from a set of duets released in 2013 to the way in which Everything was recorded by two different bands in two different countries. But only Bahamas leader and multi-instrumentalist Afie Jurvanen and accomplished engineer Robbie Lackritz joined Lindeman
column5: 15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x5013ee899e841e73?sa=X&ei=SIFHVfy2O9PAgwTu64CQCw&ved=0CGsQ_BIwCg"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">along the Seine. They shared production duties
column6: while Lindeman and Jurvanen split a dozen instruments evenly. These 11 songs often suggest you’re sitting with the trio in some small parlor as they play. The drums shuffle or canter quietly. The guitars stay hushed. The only real instrumental break
column7: the smoldering electric coda at the end of ""Tapes""
column8: remains gentle
column9: hinting at an outburst but never delivering it. And whether hitting the brassy highs of ""I Could Only Stand By"" or the diffident lows of ""Personal Eclipse""
column10: Lindeman’s voice rarely rises above an elegant whisper. It’s as if she’s trusting these revelations only to the people in the room.

column1: All of this material indeed seems confidential
column2: like a list of life problems that Lindeman is still trying to sort out for herself. Opener <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/17336-weather-station-way-it-is-way-it-could-be/"">""Way It Is
column3: Way It Could Be"" sets the stage for this exacting ambiguity
column4: where the uncertainty of the future unspools from a discrete
column5: difficult present. Here
column6: a relationship is good but neither as honest nor forgiving as she hopes. The partnership’s survival suggests a Schrödinger’s cat scenario
column7: where Lindeman can simultaneously envision success and failure. During ""Personal Eclipse""
column8: she takes stock of her general discomfort with society—its catcalling men
column9: her introversion amid others’ extroversion
column10: the loneliness such tension can induce—and tries to tease out its source. It’s an open-ended self-evaluation
column11: with more lingering questions than actual answers. And ""Like Sisters"" questions the limits of friendship and choosing sides
column12: even when it imperils your own happiness. ""Sometimes you give
column13: you’re giving all you have
column14: she offers
column15: stretching those last words with what sounds like regret. ""And sometimes you’re the taker.""

column1: The detail-oriented approach that delighted on the Weather Station’s early records reappears on Loyalty. Mesas are ""strange and red and snowy."" Rivers are ""serpentine
column2: glinting."" The low sunlight of November is ""impossibly bright."" Paired with the external turmoil and internal debate of these lyrics and the private way Lindeman and Jurvanen deliver them
column3: such observations give Loyalty the feeling of fastidiously edited old journal entries—too lean and evocative to be a first draft
column4: but still true to experience. It’s an approach that puts Lindeman in the company of Bill Callahan and Joni Mitchell
column5: songwriters whose careful combinations of pedestrian details and profound insights also created secret
column6: self-sovereign worlds. And like both of those songwriters
column7: she’s a singer with an unmistakable and communicative voice
column8: able to convey hope and hurt with equal clarity.

column1: During standout ""I Mined""
column2: Lindeman admits she is stuck: There’s a fundamental but indiscernible flaw in her current relationship. It’s the pea beneath the mattress that keeps her up at night
column3: even as the seasons come and go. She alternately wants to find and fix it or just forget it and carry on. But she knows that’s impossible. ""Your trouble is like a lens through which the whole world bends
column4: she confides over prismatic piano
column5: her voice suddenly harmonizing with itself as if to emphasize that this is the record’s thesis. ""And you can’t set it straight again."" These 11 tunes are expressions of woes that you can’t quite correct but can’t let go
column6: either
column7: worries that plague you but push you onward
column8: too. These are public folk songs about the private problems—breakups and makeups
column9:
depressions and deaths—we’ve all suffered.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21823/homepage_large.cfc6ca84.jpg|Marauding in Paradise|32914.0|Jazz Cartier|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-05-05 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:11:24.560866|"

Jazz Cartier is Toronto's first post-Drake rapper
column2: an artist who benefits from Drake’s razing of American rap’s once-inviolable boundaries
column3: but with no formal ties to the OVO crew. Jazz
column4: who also goes by Jacuzzi La Fleur
column5: has managed to build a sizable local fan base—still rare in a city long referred to by local artists as the Screwface Capital—by establishing a grimier counter-narrative to Drake’s opulent
column6: uptown vision of a city newly christened The Six. On his polished debut album
column7: Marauding in Paradise
column8: he deploys the new nickname just once
column9: on ""Local Celebrity Freestyle""
column10: setting up his own us-vs-them
column11: downtown/uptown dichotomy: ""I’m from Toronto
column12: but they call it the Six.""

column1: But Marauding isn’t antagonistic: it just offers a counterpoint
column2: a glimpse into a different
column3: younger subset of Toronto’s art and party scene. Living in a city giddy off one man’s come up
column4: Jazz prefers to move to the sound of his own voice. And his elegant
column5: elastic bark is loud and clear: The best moments on Marauding are fearless
column6: theatrical. Jazz assumes the bluster of a corner preacher on ""Guardian Angel"" and gives the intro track about soured relationships a gothic vibe
column7: reminiscent of the skits on early Dungeon Family records. (After a brief verse
column8: the song tumbles into a snippet from Mista’s ""Blackberry Molasses""
column9: confirming the allusion.) Elsewhere
column10: on ""New Religion"" and ""Holy Shit""
column11: he’s unafraid to shriek
column12: wail and growl into the mic.

column1: To allow Marauding a chance to connect
column2: you have to push past some of the overt sonic and aesthetic allusions to Houston rapper Travis Scott
column3: which compromise the sound of an original voice shining through. On the evidence of Marauding
column4: however
column5: we should give ‘Cuzzi some time to distill this influence. There’s exciting trial-and-error happening everywhere on the album: His willingness to play with flows
column6: his eye for detail
column7: a surprising grip of giddy

On their Mercury Prize-nominated self-titled 2012 LP

column4: Clinic
column5: Simian
column6: Badly Drawn Boy

column1: Even so
column2:
their range of raw skill is impressive. The songs present themselves as physical challenges: Can Django Django give Stereolab’s ""Metronomic Underground"" a jamband reworking? ""Giant"" says ""yes."" Can they repurpose surf-guitar riffs without actually making surf-rock? ""Shake and Tremble"" pulls off that trick. Can the juddering bassline of Big Boi’s
""Shutterbugg"" coexist with monklike harmonies? ""First Light"" answers in affirmative. But can Django Django juxtapose starched-stiff British accents against vibrant Caribbean rhythms? There’s a thirteen-minute stretch stuck right in the middle of Born Under Saturn
column3: from ""Reflections"" to ""Shot Down""

column1: More so than their woolier debut
column2: Born Under Saturn is a demonstration of what Django Django can do rather than what they have to say or how they feel. The almost-constant harmonizing of Vincent Neff’s staid vocals surround these songs in a case of stained glass

column4: ""Shot Down"" might be a crime narrative
column5: and maybe the album title is meant to suggest a motif of planetary influence and rebirth that gets vaguely touched upon throughout.

column1: But Neff lends not a speck of vibrato
column2: grit or inflection to anything
column3: and thus
column4: not a speck of urgency or instability or any emotional resonance. The busy arrangements and serious frontloading make Born Under Saturn’s 54 minutes a demanding investment
column5: and the effort it takes to simply get any sort of visceral pleasure out of it makes it feel twice as long.

column1: And so the best record Django Django may end up putting their name on is 2014’s Late Night Tales compilation. It tells you everything about the band that Born Under Saturn does: they see themselves in the lineage of late-'60s
column2: early-'70s pop weirdos

that might be the best likeness for Django Django.

If ever anyone needed a reset button
column2: it’s Derek Stanton. Over the course of three promising but frustrating albums with his prior band Awesome Color

column4: sexual
column5: radical sounds of the Stooges and the MC5 were Awesome Color’s paint-by-numbers palette
column6: but aside from kicking out a few sweaty
column7: muscular jams

column3: Turn to Crime. With new collaborators Ian Saylor and Dorian Foerg
column4: he’s modified his basic Detroit-centric approach. As on Can’t Love

column6: spastic guitars of Awesome Color in favor of a sculptural
column7: hollowed-out thrum. Instead of finding a new method by which to draw inspiration from his influences
column8: though
column9: Stanton has simply modified that list. It’s not a dramatic shift. Action primarly sets itself apart by doing to Suicide exactly what Awesome Color did to the Stooges: mimicking them. ""This Is What You Wanted"" smears swirls of synths over a stiff
column10: faux-motorik beat that misses the tension between organic and inorganic that made Suicide so astounding.

column1: Things get worse on ""Impatience""

column3: only to lurch back to life and trudge on for another nerve-deadening minute and a half. ""Prince of Slackers"" tries harder
column4: with its loose-lipped
column5: Lou Reed sneer
column6: but its clattering guitars and cardboard-box beat result in the unfortunate—and possibly accidental—outcome of sounding like a half-assed Strokes demo.

column1: As with Awesome Color’s collected output
column2: there are glimpses of brilliance on Actions. Stanton’s barbed-wire guitar solo on ""Light"" is a spasm of inspired lunacy; the underwater funk of ""Without a Care"" has a breezily goofy hook to it. The title track is a dead ringer for Iggy’s Berlin period
column3: all chilled melody and Bowie-indebted atmospherics
column4: but stops short of being a rehash. An entire album of such stuff could be beautiful. But ""Feels Right"" highlights Stanton's deficiencies as a lyricist. ""If it feels right/ Then it is right
column5: he chants throughout the song’s eight-and-a-half-minute run time. The dedication to such a banal bit of druggy sloganeering doesn’t translate into much; it just seems lazy. But hey
column6: if it feels right
column7: right?

column1: Stanton and crew clearly adore the styles of music they emulate. But they refuse—or are simply unable—to ignite with a spark of their own. That is
column2: after all
column3: what groups like the Stooges and Suicide were all about: annihilating shit to see what might spring up in its ashes. When it comes to retroactivity in music

column6:
Stanton inches closer to the latter.

PC Music Volume 1 is anti-physical music for an anti-physical time. Like everything that A. G. Cook’s London-based label’s released since 2013
column2: these 10 songs are invocations of the hyperreal
column3: created to meet the anxieties of an age where bodies are rarely written about as sites of joy or authenticity
column4: and more frequently discussed as zones of inequity
column5: violence
column6: embarrassment and pain. The desire to exist as a well-tended garden of pixels fuels many of our culture’s dominant systems: the databases of altered thoughts
column7: distorted images
column8: the avatars that demonstrate reaction or stand in for action. Like all of these networks and products
column9: PC Music answers our desire to escape the burden of physical presence—and in the process ends up sharpening and perpetuating the desire even further.

column1: Both a label and a self-contained genre

column3: symbols that replace words that replace voices. It’s an airbrushed articulation of digital life in all its silly
column4: beautiful

column6: it’s a response to today’s alarmingly easy production glosses

column8: PC Music flips and disses that aim completely. The label’s sound resembles what aliens would produce if they sunk a jukebox in acid and then tried
column9: from the randomized wreckage
column10: to communicate some version of love. Instead of affection
column11: they’ll give you a heart-shaped simulacrum—and maybe
column12: as suggests PC Music
column13: that’s what you wanted after all. When physical presence is a source of so much complication
column14: sometimes an abstraction is the only thing a person can bear.

column1: A test of the boundaries
column2: possibilities and limitations of this ultra-focused aesthetic
column3: PC Music Volume 1 compresses two years of work into a half-hour. Taken together
column4: the rapturous
column5: nightmarish cartoon corpus is maddeningly effective; it solidifies PC Music’s ability to only produce strong reactions
column6: whether starry-eyed captivation or powerful revulsion or a nauseating juxtaposition of both poles. There’s a meaningful spectrum of approaches within the PC Music ethos—classical composer Danny L Harle’s ""In My Dreams"" has a heartbreakingly soft
column7: sweet
column8: harmonic gravity
column9: while A. G. Cook’s alter ego Lipgloss Twins’ ""Wannabe"" is a chopped-up
column10: anti-melodic spatter of brand names and robot garble—but there’s a relentless logical consistency to the sound. Every track feels almost auto-generated
column11: scrambled
column12: which makes the human precision in each arrangement even more eerie: PC Music sounds chaotic but is sneakily minimalist
column13: deliberate to the last distorted note.

column1: The calculation behind this effect is a large part of what makes it monstrous: it’s the sound of whimsy without spontaneity
column2: lightness without joy
column3: longing without knowledge
column4: aggression with no object. It’s a dollhouse universe
column5: for female voices and female figures only. The male producers and artists are controllingly invisible in PC Music
column6: and it’s hard to say whether that’s a real aesthetic constraint or a deliberate large-scale perpetuation of the idea of women as powerless
column7: squeaky
column8: sweet. The genre
column9: anyway
column10: has been slapped with labels of ""gender appropriation
column11: and the sound does feel awkwardly
column12: distinctly male sometimes
column13: in its ""South Park""-ish warehouse artlessness. But
column14: if anyone’s really in drag here
column15: it’s humans pretending to be avatars—the total elision of soul.

column1: Like a Kardashian
column2: PC Music cannot be insulted by the word ""contrived."" PC Music is deeply contrived; it’s fake as hell
column3: that’s the point
column4: that’s the entire energy. But this ethos
column5: of course
column6: has its limits. PC Music only works when its theoretical intention lines up with its physical effect: when you listen to it and become instantly depersonalized
column7: blissfully and bubbly
column8: more pixel than flesh. The best route to this end naturally centers on pleasure. In Volume 1
column9: the pastel jelly-bean melodies and baby-girl anime coos of Hannah Diamond’s ""Every Night"" and A. G. Cook’s ""Beautiful"" reach this synthetic liftoff; the two pair up again for ""Keri Baby""
column10: a maniacally playful track with a stormy bassline
column11: a bubble noise vamping
column12: a refrain of ""Give it to the girl/ Give it to the girl/ Give it to the cutest girl."" The closing track
column13: easyFun’s ""Laplander""
column14: is transcendent: all simulated mechanical longing
column15: synth squeaks and stilted voices reaching for ecstasy. In tracks that are less joyful—GFOTY’s ""Don’t Wanna / Let’s Do It""
column16: for example—the self-perpetuating darkness and denial that PC Music draws on gets a little too clear for comfort.

column1: PC Music is escapism whose primary effect is to remind us of what we’re trying to escape. We can’t trade body for avatar; we can’t displace longing forever. But for the space of an album—the sheer forcefulness of this intention smashed into a dizzy half-hour span—the sincerity within our most fundamentally artificial impulses comes calling. You wish you didn’t live in a world that produced PC Music
column2: but you do—and because you do
column3: thank the god in the machine for PC Music. It’ll come whispering and screaming in an absolute vacuum; it’s a party reconstituted long after anyone’s been there to laugh. It’s empty
column4: and yet somehow the stakes are monumental. Can you chip your way to the real through this pixelated thicket? Well
column5: you can
column6: and worse
column7:
you have to.

A quiet figure on the periphery of this generation of British electronic music
column2: George FitzGerald has spent the last half-decade carving out a space for himself with a series of increasingly refined EPs
column3: singles
column4: and remixes. If you want to think of that space in purely geographic terms

column1: As part of the larger arc of FitzGerald's career

column1: Fading Love is set up to reward the same focus it demonstrates: if you dig into each new muted meditation and immerse yourself in FitzGerald's bubbling little temples of thought
column2: you'll find yourself entranced. It doesn't have the same impact when it's flipped on in the background

column4: it verges on soporific. The guest appearances by singers Oli Bayston (a.k.a. Boxed In) and Lawrence Hart don't help: they're meant to complement FitzGerald's arrangements rather than create any sort of spark. column6:
the album is a complete statement that's comfortable in its own skin.

column2: Sheffield duo Nai Harvest has tried to talk their way out of it. In an interview from last year
column3: guitarist/vocalist Ben Thompson shrugged
column4: ""I don’t want to be picked up as an emo band in 2014 and then thrown on the floor when it’s not a trendy thing to like or talk about anymore."" The connotations and stereotypes behind that term are still a contentious hot topic (no pun intended)
column5: so it's in their best interests to keep a distance. But it was merely part of Nai Harvest’s larger concern of being pigeonholed in any way; upon shifting to a grungier
column6: more '90s-indebted sound on EP Hold Open My Head
column7: Nai Harvest stated they didn’t want to be classified as grunge or '90s-revival either. Though Hairball is far slicker and focused than their previous work
column8:
Nai Harvest's requests are still likely to fall on deaf ears: you’re more likely to misrepresent them if you don’t talk about the '90s.

As with their debut Whatever
column9: it’s an enjoyable listen because of its lack of innovation
column10: rather than in spite of it. But back in 2013
column11: Nai Harvest at least had novelty going for them: It was refreshing to hear guitarists take notes from American Football and Mineral after two straight decades of indie rock more or less acting like Pavement
column12: My Bloody Valentine
column13: Dinosaur Jr. and Sonic Youth were the only bands to exist in the '90s. However
column14: Thompson’s twiddly
column15: Kinsella-esque guitar figures of the past have fully given way to fuzzy
column16: jangly open chords. Lew Currie’s zig-zagging
column17: stop-start rhythms have now been aligned to straight-ahead sprints and brisk jogs—think of a more raw Teenage Fanclub or a punkier Ash
column18: but certainly not any bands from the American Midwest.

column1: And it does give Hairball a much broader appeal than Whatever. Freed from knotty progressions
column2: Thompson can draw out his vocals in a nasal bray accentuated by a trebly
column3: distorted mic—think of Liam Gallagher fronting the sort of modest UK indie band that Noel might scorn in print because they didn’t aspire to play Wembley. That said
column4: Nai Harvest does have populist ambitions
column5: as evidenced by the production of Bob Cooper
column6: who previously worked with Empire of the Sun and Sky Ferreira. It’s an extreme stretch to recognize his influence without checking the credits first—there’s nothing at all glam about Hairball. It is
column7: however
column8: stylishly tousled
column9: greasy and glossy in a way that makes you think ""Hairball"" would work as an ironic name for an expensive gel.

column1: When Nai Harvest are at their most edgy and brash
column2: ""Spin"" and ""Sick on My Heart"" provide a legitimate buzz
column3: just the right amount of bubblegum grunge
column4: tart pop-punk and hi-fi enough production. Which could translate to ""alt"" or ""1995""
column5: though there’s a more contemporary precedent
column6: as Nai Harvest situate themselves in the six-month span in 2010 between Wavves’ King of the Beach and Cloud Nothings’ self-titled album.

column1: But the comparisons become less flattering and more revealing as Hairball goes forward. Dylan Baldi cannot stop writing indelible hooks
column2: while Nathan Williams’ personality always manages to emerge whether his records sound like an oxidized cassette or a million dollars. Nai Harvest...well
column3: they don’t like to be confined
column4: but that’s something that comes across more clearly in their interviews. With barely any deviation in tempo
column5: tone or texture
column6: Hairball just wads up into an indistinguishable mass: Thompson’s vocals predictably trace over the chord progressions or they just double lead riffs. Throughout
column7: he’s bummed about something or other
column8: girls
column9: growing up
column10: himself—it's all part of the same malaise.

column1: ""Ocean of Madness"" is the standout by default
column2: since it has an actual bassline and an appealing
column3: ""Semi-Charmed Life""-style cadence in its bridge. But just when it appears that Nai Harvest has set itself up for the big score
column4: Thompson offers this as the chorus: ""Don’t let me drown in an ocean of madness/ I wanna swim in an ocean of you."" This may be the first revelation of Thompson’s songwriting personality
column5: as ""Gimme Gimme"" shows a similar sweet tooth for cloying power-pop. But when he sings
column6: ""gimme gimme your sugar joy
column7: it doesn't feel like sincerity
column8: but that most unfortunate of '90s influences: sarcasm. Hairball is certainly an evolution for Nai Harvest
column9:
but it’s tough to really call it progress.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21555/homepage_large.d3a6b8f6.jpg|+-|4872.0|Mew|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Universal'

A summation of Mew's position: Mew are seriously uncool; they are also too cool to be popular; they are somehow both at the same time. Blame prog-rock for giving them a raw deal. The Danish quartet certainly had the optics to earn the tag: witness their magnificent hair and garish album covers. They've also released only two LPs in the past nine years
column3: and one was meant to be listened to as a continuous 54-minute suite and had a 23-word poem as its title. But unlike contemporaries Muse or the Mars Volta or Coheed and Cambria
column4: Mew isn’t alerting sheeple to the mindcrimes of the Matrix
column5: nor does their technical ability manifest in 64th-note runs in 11/8 time. They mostly write love songs. All of which made them one of the more unique
column6: if not necessarily successful
column7: rock bands on a major label in the past decade. Those days are done
column8: but thankfully
column9: you wouldn't know it from +-.

column1: Despite technically being an indie rock band now
column2: Mew brings back Michael Beinhorn as a producer
column3: a guy who was last convinced to come out of hiding by Courtney Love. And that was five years ago. If you’re unfamiliar with Beinhorn’s work
column4: he produced Superunknown
column5: but also a lot of very
column6: very expensive-sounding albums that would frequently sell for pennies in used CD stores throughout the '90s—we’re talking Ozzmosis
column7: Mechanical Animals
column8: the Verve Pipe album after the one with ""The Freshman"" on it.

column1: As a result
column2: +- is liable to be one of the more magnificent-sounding rock records you’ll hear all year: The first thing you hear is a harp
column3: while Jonas Bjerre’s pristine vocals continue to be exempt from the inexorable march of time. There’s some serious technique at play and Beinhorn ensures you hear all of it in high definition—Bo Madsen engages in some nifty pull-off runs
column4: Silas Utke Graae Jørgensen plays impossible-sounding fills on tom drums. There are numerous moments where Mew switch tempos and time signatures and others where it could pass as King Arthur on Ice in Space. The removal from any earthly concerns or obligations is echoed in the chorus from +-’s opener as Bjerre sings
column5: ""I’d rather be a satellite.""

column1: The blinding
column2: gilded tone is charming rather than obnoxious because Mew never use their exquisite and excessive tastes to glorify themselves as rock overlords. Their songs continue to be sweet
column3: almost twee at their core. ""Satellites"" is probably the most grandiose song ever written about ""movie night"" and Bjerre’s lyrics remain curious
column4: obtuse and playful—""The Night Believer"" and ""Interview the Girls"" spin elaborate conceits out of what sound like true stories at their core
column5: and somehow work on both the mundane and fantastical levels.

column1: A gushing romanticism unifies both the lyrics and the music itself
column2: which takes Mew past black lights and dry ice and into the neons and pastels of '80s pop cinema. ""Making Friends"" is a startling foray into cocktail-hour jazz
column3: replete with stiff
column4: Quincy Jones-style riffs. Both Bjerre and Kimbra's vocals on ""The Night Believer"" have the eerie
column5: almost inhuman perfection of a Eurovision competitor. The dazzling ""My Complications"" could be taken as Mew joining the War on Drugs
column6: Lower Dens and Twin Shadow in paying homage to Rod Stewart’s ""Young Turks""
column7: though they bring in Bloc Party's Russell Lissack to play Top Gun leads and create a more comprehensive time capsule.

column1: The range allows +- to be Mew’s most consistently engaging record
column2: even if it’s also the longest on both a cumulative and per-song basis. Unlike with No More Stories... and Glass Handed Kites
column3: there’s no delineation between what they perceive as an interlude
column4: exposition or proper song. You’re still guaranteed stretches where everything becomes a gorgeous mirage and Mew conveniently packages almost all of these lulls into the 11-minute ""Rows"". Still
column5: in light of the theatrics and grand gestures that precede it
column6: ""Rows"" feels like a necessary comedown before the closing prom theme ""Cross the River on Your Own"". It’s also perhaps the best proof of Mew’s aesthetic singularity: ""Cross the River"" accidentally and unmistakably evokes the chorus of N.W.A.’s ""Automobile"" and still could be used by Baz Luhrmann to soundtrack a slow dance in the Sistine Chapel. So despite maintaining just about every quality that got them plugged as prog
column7:
+- argues for the reframing of Mew as a dream-pop act.

On last year’s self-titled double LP
column2: the Chicago-based trio Bitchin Bajas—which began as an offshoot of psych-rock ensemble Cave—paid expert homage to the zone-out music of the 1960s and '70s
column3: perfectly reconstructing the psychedelic easy-listening of the era. The group—Cooper Crain
column4: Roberty Frye
column5: and Dan Quinlivan—got all of the ingredients right. The record’s eight compositions were perfectly dialed in
column6: both in terms of influences (Terry Riley
column7: Laraaji
column8: Popol Vuh) and the vintage gear and methods required to channel them (tape machines
column9: loops
column10: electric organs). It was like taking a stroll through a museum exhibit
column11: a blissed-out reminder that
column12: at this point
column13: ambient music has a deep and well-established history.

column1: Bitchin Bajas appeal is that they so expertly recreate a style of music designed for simple pleasure. This might make the trio sound like some sort of New Age cover band
column2: but that’s not exactly the case. They don't create knock-offs or copies. Instead
column3: they apply the same compositional methods and get results that are unique
column4: but familiar. If you've spent some time with Terry Riley’s A Rainbow in Curved Air
column5: Fripp and Eno’s Evening Star
column6: or the Kuckkuck label catalog
column7: Bitchin Bajas will register as more of a good thing. But on the group's latest EP
column8: Transporteur
column9: the trio has stepped back from their influences a little. The music is still meditative and trance inducing
column10: but it’s harder to draw a direct line to an existing work or style.

column1: Even though it’s labeled as an EP
column2: at 34 minutes Transporteur is a sizeable chunk of music—four pieces that almost all stretch out to around nine minutes. The tracks are still based on repetitive looping phrases
column3: but the instrumental palate has shifted
column4: moving away from sounds that were wedded to yesterday's mystical moment (mainly
column5: the electric organ) and relying more heavily on sequenced analog synthesizers.

column1: The first two tracks
column2: ""Rias Baixas"" and ""Planete T""
column3: hew more closely to the Bitchin Bajas' established formula. A droney loop is introduced
column4: then augmented with lush keyboard figures. It's great and thoroughly drifty stuff
column5: if reminiscent of pastoral German synth noodlers like Cluster.

column1: The EP's second half moves into more distinctive territory. On ""No Tabac""
column2: a percussive synthesizer sequence is paired up with flute doodles
column3: which slowly evolve and accumulate urgency. Closer ""Marimba"" is particularly unusual. The process is basically the same—a burbling synthesizer loop evolves with the accumulation of additional instrumentation. Only here
column4: the focus is on rhythm and percussion
column5: rather than ethereal tones and pads
column6: with seemingly random bongo-like sounds
column7: hand claps
column8: shakers
column9: and additional percussive elements. At times
column10: the music recalls Congolese electric thumb piano ensemble Konono N°1
column11: albeit with a more overtly psychedelic bent. It’s excellent modern ambient music
column12: exercising restraint
column13: never crashing into a crescendo
column14: and sustaining interest while remaining rooted in repetition.

column1: In addition to a great record collection and a well curated studio
column2: Bitchin Bajas have also internalized the concepts that made vintage ambient music engaging. Particularly
column3: how tape loop-based or repetitive compositions can distort your perception of time
column4: that they can supply a sense of stillness in motion
column5:
where seven minutes can slip by almost entirely unnoticed.

Oddisee’s music has taken many forms over the years: On his early compilations—101
column2: Foot in the Door and Mental Liberation—Odd was the scrappy upstart
column3: his distinct D.C. drawl and heavy drums carrying a unique ""golden-era"" hip-hop tinge. As leader of the Diamond District with rappers yU and Uptown XO
column4: Odd is the mature figurehead: The group’s 2009 debut
column5: In the Ruff
column6: is a widely heralded classic in D.C.’s underground rap circles. In 2011
column7: Oddisee released what’s probably his most lauded project to date
column8: Rock Creek Park
column9: a mostly instrumental album dedicated to his own bike rides through the sprawling D.C. landscape. By 2012’s Odd Renditions
column10: you got a sense that he wanted greater visibility: He spit rhymes on Bon Iver samples and flipped Marvin Gaye into a danceable rap tune.

column1: Though in recent years
column2: Oddisee’s tone has grown more acerbic. On his 2013 mixtape
column3: Tangible Dream
column4: Odd wagged the finger at fake friends and naysayers. He reserves some vitriol for The Good Fight
column5: his sophomore album
column6: though he sounds remarkably comfortable throughout its 12 tracks. He does more singing (""First Choice""
column7: ""Meant It When I Said It"") and flirts with different time signatures (""Counter-Clockwise""). ""That’s Love"" recalls spacious funk
column8: and on ""Fight Delays""
column9: he brags a little more than usual: ""They tell me I ain’t buzzin’
column10: well
column11: last year I made well over a hunnid stacks."" That sort of straight-ahead statement is rare for Oddisee
column12: who’s largely kept silent about his financial gains
column13: though in 2010 he moved to Brooklyn from the D.C. area to further monetize his career.

column1: The Good Fight is technically a hip-hop record
column2: but the vibe here is decidedly eclectic
column3: building upon the kaleidoscopic method he’s employed for 13 years. If Odd’s debut album addressed the uncertainty he felt about his artistic trek
column4: The Good Fight proclaims the success of said path. He references a ""working"" plan that eschews mainstream attention and the fame that comes with it
column5: choosing instead to be the low-key jetsetter culling inspiration from his global travels. As a result
column6: The Good Fight exudes a sense of artistic freedom not heard on Oddisee’s previous releases. The music feels distinctly international and unhindered
column7: far removed from the straight-ahead boom-bap he used to make. He’s always created on his own terms
column8: but The Good Fight feels like a hearty ""fuck you"" to prevailing groupthink and the industry’s creative limitations.

column1: Still
column2: it’s clear Odd has grown tired of the false starts. On ""Want Something Done""
column3: he complains about the phone meetings. He bemoans superficial demands and his own struggles to be heard. ""Glorifying music that’s abusive and a threat to us
column4: Odd quips
column5: ""and if you got a message in your records
column6: you collecting dust."" That’s become a common theme for him
column7: in particular
column8: on 2012’s ""That Real""
column9: where the rapper contemplated his vision and the widespread anonymity felt by underground rappers. He revisits the notion on Good Fight standout ""What They’ll Say""
column10: but the message quickly floats by: ""I know that my intentions go unnoticed
column11: a part of me wants attention."" That’s long been Oddisee’s dilemma: On the surface
column12: you’d think he doesn’t care about making it
column13: yet there’s a part of him that values mainstream acceptance. The Good Fight is a streamlined reminder to ignore the restraints. Great music is great music
column14:
no matter where it comes from.

Preceding nearly every line on Foremost & Fair is a gasp. On the opener
column2: ""Seven Thirty""
column3: Home Blitz frontman Daniel DiMaggio erratically sucks air in before he pushes any out. Those spasms anticipate the album’s pace: Foremost & Fair is a spritely
column4: frantic power-pop record
column5: and when it does lose momentum
column6: it’s an act of willful
column7: jarring derailment. Which is fantastic
column8: since DiMaggio knows the mechanisms of a song intimately enough to enact swift sabotage and leave a gorgeous wreck.

column1: While other recent power-pop records have owed a debt to tuneful punks like the Buzzcocks
column2: Home Blitz is more evocative of power-pop’s nonstarters: the now-marketable misfortunes of Big Star and Rockin' Horse and the skinny-tie flops who disappointed label execs in the wake of ""My Sharona"". It’s a good time to be into that stuff. Labels like Sing Sing Records have redeemed scores of bands once snubbed by market forces or their own immutable peculiarities. Foremost & Fair brings the latter camp to mind
column3: except Home Blitz sounds simply committed to its left-field flourishes. Sure
column4: nowadays the genre has relatively little commercial potential to squander
column5: but DiMaggio flaunts his oblique streak like a point of pride
column6: or protest. It’s what compels repeated listening.

column1: To begin
column2: there’s his voice: Breathy like Brett Smiley or Milk ‘n Cookies’ Ian North
column3: unapologetically affected like Game Theory’s late Scott Miller
column4: and often a bit pitchy. DiMaggio spikes saccharine melodies with bratty little gestures
column5: rebelling against his own compositional knowhow. Also
column6: the vocals rest decidedly on top of a mix that’s saturated with shimmery tones: teeming harpsichord
column7: zippy keyboard
column8: sunburst acoustic guitar picking. There’s little low-end to temper all of that
column9: which amounts to an almost unrelentingly bright listen and underscores the album’s insistent urgency. The very first line goes
column10: ""Seven-thirty headed towards seven forty-five."" The 37-minute record scrambles to fit into that 15-minute window.

column1: Foremost & Fair’s A side is a salvo of impeccable songs. ""I'm That Key""
column2: sequenced second
column3: surges with radiant vocal hooks
column4: careens through a solo
column5: and stumbles into a busted outro. On ""The Tide""
column6: DiMaggio cheekily narrates romance and seaside whimsy
column7: while ""A in E"" is reminiscent of approximately eight swaggering Big Star tracks. ""Downtown"" is the album’s punchiest song
column8: where a clipped riff trades jabs with the trap kit before it collapses into an arrhythmic bridge and then regains velocity.

column1: The longest song
column2: at almost five minutes
column3: is ""The Hall""
column4: where chintzy snare and clinking metal keep a glacial pace as sharp keys and guitar ring out beneath DiMaggio’s bleating. It’s an audacious centerpiece
column5: like grandiose glam balladry running a glitter deficit
column6: and a signal that DiMaggio isn’t content to dish sugary ditties
column7: which ""Why It Cries"" almost immediately reinforces—without the same listening pleasure.

column1: ""Why It Cries"" is longer than ""The Hall""
column2: but it can’t exactly be called a song. For over five minutes
column3: it sounds like someone is looking for something in a cluttered music studio
column4: appended by an impromptu Celtic jam. Since DiMaggio’s songs tend to implode in one way or another
column5: ""Why It Cries"" seems like the autodestruct function planted at the core of Foremost & Fair as a whole. Or maybe it’s an elaborate set-up for a cruel joke: Slog through the tedium and meet ""Sick and Crazy""
column6: an exultant song that’s punishingly short at a mere 44 seconds.

column1: DiMaggio
column2: who has helmed Home Blitz for about 10 years
column3: has issued scores of format
column4: label
column5: and genre-ambivalent recordings. Considering all of that
column6: the initial panting on ""Seven Thirty"" is less like anticipation of the upcoming sprint and more like reeling from an earlier marathon. In hindsight
column7: that bit of sputtering will also emerge as a clarion call for the whole of Foremost & Fair: DiMaggio foregrounds eccentricities
column8:
which only outlines the strength of his conventional songwriting in relief.

""I'm getting so tired of trying to always be nice

column1: Since My Morning Jacket abandoned the grain silo on their 2005 masterwork

column10: not just the range of My Morning Jacket. You can’t fake something like ""Believe (Nobody Knows)"" if you haven’t played in front of tens of thousands of festival goers.

column1: Then again

column5: which tails off into a coda of keyboard flutter and falsetto after flaunting Chvrches electronic stomp and Some Girls strut. ""Get the Point"" delivers James’ most biting lyrics to date within a McCartney-esque acoustic ditty (""I'm trying to tell you plainly how I'm feeling day to day/ And I'm so sorry now that you ain't feeling the same way""). The electronic cut-and-paste of ""Spring (Among the Living)"" is a sleek
column6: modernist iPad compared to ""Cobra""’s bulky
column7: retro ENIAC
column8: while Eastern modes poking through ""Like a River"" and ""Tropics (Erase Traces)"" scent the chillout tent with lavender incense rather than the usual weed smoke. It reaffirms that MMJ are one of the most exciting American rock bands going when they’re at their most generous

column1: But ""Big Decisions"" puts the focus squarely on a new place for an MMJ record: the lyrics. The song
column2: and the album as a whole

column5: James has been open with the big picture while skimping on the details—after 15 or so years of giving his all on stage
column6: he’s left just as much off it
column7: and here he is at 37
column8: nearly crippled by workplace injuries
column9: spent from partying and wondering aloud in Rolling Stone
column10: ""what have I done wrong in every relationship I've been in until now?""

column1: There are legitimate personal stakes here and The Waterfall allows for James to express some uncharacteristic negativity without dwelling on it. For a record of spiritual and romantic reckoning
column2: it’s remarkably level-headed and pragmatic. James sweetly coos over Chi-Lites psych-soul
column3: ""It’s a thin line/ Between love and wasting my time""
column4: clearly assessing a broken situation to which he mends on ""Get the Point"": ""Daydreaming of leaving/ I only had to do it."" He wishes his ex the best of luck and then immediately celebrates the exhilarating
column5: frightening rush of single living on ""Spring (Among the Living)""—during each rambling guitar solo
column6: you can picture James right-swiping to his heart’s content.

column1: For many
column2: Jim James is basically synonymous with My Morning Jacket
column3: so it’s justifiable to find parallels in the rejuvenation of each—My Morning Jacket has another album on the way some time next year. It’s welcome news for the band's fans

column6: it might have matched At Dawn's cohesion or Z's dazzling diversity: The misty-eyed reflection of ""Only Memories Remain"" cycles back to a breakup narrative on Side B that otherwise feels like it was put on shuffle

column8: a bit broken
column9:
more skeptical but very much among the living.

What remains of a relationship after it ends? Pictures
column2: text messages

column4: sure

column6: the feeling of first standing naked in front of them
column7: the dent in the pillow where a lover’s head once laid. Braids’ third album Deep in the Iris plays as a record of all these tiny memories

column11: vivid and unreal

column5: skittering jazz percussion
column6: crackling beats and stuttering cuts in vocals

column8: classical piano runs beneath the electronic instrumentals. The glitchy

column1: On ""Taste""

column4: she muses). And sometimes the band examines that isolation in a larger
column5: societal context. ""It’s not like I’m feeling much different than a woman my age years ago
column6: Standell-Preston begins on ""Miniskirt""
column7: a song about rape culture and the cutting feeling of being objectified by men.  On ""Sore Eyes"" the synths rise
column8: hinting at an actual dance track
column9: before they fall back to the throbbing repetition of the song's bassline. The movement echoes the push and pull of the song’s message
column10: as Standell-Preston breathily relays her dual desire and disgust in a song about watching porn on the Internet. Deep in the Iris never lets you get quite too familiar
column11: or comfortable.

column1: In the album’s track ""Bunny Rose""
column2: Standell-Preston contemplates getting a dog to ail her loneliness
column3: one which will always be waiting for her to come home. And it’s this sort of heartbreakingly simple desire

column6:
on Deep in the Iris it’s clear they are nevertheless always somewhere within you.

The colossal pieces on Four Phantoms
column2: the second album from Seattle duo Bell Witch

column4: they detail painful

column6: earth
column7: water
column8: and wind—that the dead are forced to endure for eternity. There’s a suffocation
column9: where the victim breaks teeth to keep breathing

column11: where the narrator becomes ""the blooming ash."" One ghost falls into an endless canyon forever
column12: while another buried at sea swims in salt water and skin. A case-by-case survey of horrible ways to go
column13: Four Phantoms is appropriately and hyperbolically morose for the subgenre known as ""funeral doom."" But Bell Witch answers the extreme
column14: existential despondency of these motifs with absolutely triumphant songs

column16: then

column1: Though Bell Witch were good from the start of their 2012 debut Longing
column2: bassist Dylan Desmond and drummer Adrian Guerra are great on Four Phantoms because they’ve recognized and addressed their own faults. Longing

column5: moving between lethargic 20-minute slogs and mid-tempo marches
column6: horror-sample instrumentals and tone-obsessed drifts. Desmond plays a six-string bass
column7: meaning he’s able to elicit piercing
column8: guitar-like leads and subdural lines from one instrument. On Longing
column9: the capability felt like a compositional toy he was still learning to wield.

column1: But the pair refined their approach for Four Phantoms

column3: this hour is sharper
column4: louder and brighter than the last one. Too often with doom or stoner metal

column7: for instance

column9: Four Phantoms feels sculpted
column10: each part perfectly visible and framed.

column1: The result is a high-tension

These four pieces collectively suggest that metal is an incremental form: Substantial differences in how something sounds and in what niche it lands stem from subtle decisions about how fast
column4: long or loud certain parts are played. Bits of opener ""Suffocation
column5: A Burial"" sound like thrash metal drugged to stoner speed. ""Judgment
column6: in Fire"" suggests Sunn O))) exploring liturgical music and adding a percussive pulse.

column1: This hybridized scheme gives Bell Witch an uncanny appreciation of momentum. The type of low-and-slow music Bell Witch makes often requires a real commitment from the listener
column2: a certain patience with songs that creep through half-hour spans to reach their high-volume peaks. But even during the pair of Four Phantoms numbers that break the 22-minute mark
column3: Bell Witch don’t stall. Sure
column4: they lock into loud
column5: sustained roars
column6: as with the start of ""Judgment: In Air""
column7: and lurk in muted valleys
column8: as when Desmond takes a glacially paced bass solo during ""Suffocation
column9: A Burial"". But they emerge from that last reverie with a  jolt so loud it’s terrifying
column10: especially if you’ve fallen for the bass’s soporific sway. As the song marches toward its end
column11: Guerra doubles and triples his steady beat

column1: Bell Witch's commitment to progress is most obvious on ""Suffocation
column2: A Drowning""
column3: the longest song of their career and their best use of a guest musician to date. Both Guerra and Desmond sing

Bell Witch turns funeral doom and its moribund focus into a beautiful hymn meant for the living.

column1: Puce Mary

column6: grinding monoliths of sound

column11: a throbbing generator drone gradually takes on an increasingly gnarly
column12: growling texture as Rahbek issues abrupt commands: ""Arms bent/ Hips forced apart.""

column11: she shadows her monologue with panned and processed recordings of her own voice choking and crying out. In exertion

column3: leaving a lingering sense that its experiments in fantasy and intimacy come from a place which we

The best bits on Depeche Mode's 2013 album Delta Machine were the intros. Once the songs got underway

column1: For anyone who heard the distant promise of a far different

column3: you're in luck: Gore's new solo album is an all-synthesizer affair. No guitars
column4: no drums
column5: no blues riffs
column6: and
column7: most important of all
column8: no vocals—which means no tangled religious conceits

column11: both collections of synth-pop covers of songs by Nick Cave

column18: unlike VCMG's visceral
column19: sternum-punching
column21: 000-watt techno throb

column1: Some tracks feature subtle beats

column1: A few tracks here began life as demos for Delta Machine; Gore finished MG in 2013
column2: after the band finished touring. He recorded it in his home studio on
column3: principally
column4: a modular synthesizer system. Modular systems are something like the Legos of electronic music: Users build their own
column5: custom synthesizers by patching together various devices into mazelike configurations
column6: the functionality of which is often pretty fuzzy even to the person cabling them together. That unpredictability is important: it means that the process of wiring things together is largely inseparable from the process of composition. It is experimental in the most basic sense—Let's see what happens when we plug this into this—and that sense of curiosity is at the heart of MG. It sounds pretty much like what it is—someone alone in the studio at night
column7: twisting knobs
column8: feeling his way gingerly along the signal chain. In both its restraint and its moodiness

column10: not outward. To listen to it feels a little like eavesdropping on someone else's thoughts.

column6: but the utter blankness of ""Save the World"" makes its Dr. Seuss-quoting chorus (""Oh the places that you’ll go/ When you’re far too young to know"") come off like a Korn-y gimmick.

column1: Had Sunshine Redux preceded Melbourne
column2: perhaps it could be heard as the work of an immature artist trying to develop a feel for songwriting voice and production. Or
column3: like the hundreds of passable records of crudely recorded psych-pop to which it’s comparable
column4: perhaps it wouldn’t be heard at all. But Scott seemed like he was already beyond that. There’s one lyric from ""PRPLMTV"" that could be read as introspective—but ""when you went to college to blossom in folly/ You took lots of molly

he’s just subverting himself.

On paper
column2: the pairing of Neil Michael Hagerty and James Jackson Toth is too on-the-nose. Both have histories in groups (Royal Trux and Wooden Wand and the Vanishing Voice
column3: respectively) who began as sprawling avant-rock outfits
column4: then gradually incorporated traditional influences— blues
column5: country
column6: classic rock—without losing their eccentric edges. Their solo careers have followed similar paths
column7: glancing at the past while breaking open the future. Even Hagerty and Toth’s singing voices—a mix of nasally twang and slacker drawl—are similar. The prospect of a collaboration seems redundant
column8: likely to sound like just another record in their vast discographies.

column1: It takes Qalgebra about 10 seconds to blow those worries away. The coiled riffs and crackling beat of tightly-wound opener ""Spindizzy"" sound more like vintage Meat Puppets than anything Hagerty or Toth has done before. The song’s taut energy doesn’t last for all of Qalgebra
column2: half of which is occupied by a single 18-minute title track filled with ebbs and flows. And the overall sound isn’t a radical departure for either artist; you’ll easily recognize their voices
column3: riffs
column4: and sly senses of humor.

column1: But for the majority of Qalgebra’s five songs
column2: Hagerty and Toth (alongisde bassist Darin Gray and drummer Eric Van Leuven) find a level of urgency and sharpness distinct from their previous efforts. It's as if they were only able to play for a weekend and had to make the most of every moment. Nothing sounds rushed
column3: but everything moves forward at a steady
column4: enthralling clip. The pair feed off each other naturally
column5: their adventurous guitar playing bleeding across every moment while never obscuring basic
column6: uncomplicated songs.

column1: There’s also something funny and oddly joyful about Qalgebra. Most of the tunes swing with a casual levity that at times approaches giddiness. The music’s playful atmosphere is made literal by Hagerty and Toth’s deadpan banter at the end of tracks
column2: which sounds like an aging stoner’s version of mid-album rap skits. (Representative sample: ""What’s the best word?"" ""Biggie fries."" ""That’s two words."") Whatever the pair might have been smoking
column3: it gives Qalgebra an endearing breeziness.

column1: That feeling is what makes the long
column2: album-ending title track fitting
column3: despite being a stylistic opposite to the rest of Qalgebra. At first glance its improv aura makes it seem like filler
column4: an easy way to pad an EP out into an LP. But a few listens reveal logic in the sonic rambling
column5: much the way Yo La Tengo’s extended jams are like stretched-out echoes of tighter tunes. The expansion comes as a bit of a relief after four much snappier songs
column6: but what matters most is how psyched everyone sounds about playing with each other. Both Hagerty and Toth have traversed dark places in their work
column7: but Qalgebra is unabashedly happy
column8:
and all the better for it.

Daniele Baldelli is often cast as the Italian counterpart to Larry Levan
column2: and the two have a lot in common. In 1977
column3: as Levan was opening the Paradise Garage in the gritty heart of Hudson Square
column4: Baldelli was brought in as the resident DJ at posh discotheque Baia Degli Angeli
column5: looking out onto the Adriatic Sea. As Levan drew on countless genres to craft what would become the ""Garage"" sound (disco
column6: new wave
column7: synth reggae)
column8: Baldelli took eclectic records ranging from Steve Reich to Eurodisco cheese to Fela Kuti
column9: sometimes layering three to four records to craft a sound soon dubbed ""Afro/Cosmic"" when he moved over to the Italian club Cosmic in 1979. Defined by synths that aim towards outer space and hard percussion influenced by thundering tribal drums
column10: Baldelli’s mesmeric
column11: head-widening sound and eclectic selections have influenced numerous generations of DJs and producers
column12: from DJ Harvey to Todd Terje.

column1: But while Levan descended into drugs and died at a tragically young age
column2: Baldelli—now in his sixties—has had a renaissance of sorts. He’s remixed Museum of Love as well as Róisín Murphy and recently turned in a marathon set in Coachella
column3: Ca. After numerous mix CDs
column4: edits made in conjunction with younger Italian artists like Marco Dionigi and Luca Roccatagliati
column5: this month sees the legend release Cosmic Drag. With its title and four other song titles bearing the word ""cosmic"" (two more reference space) you can already anticipate what Baldelli has in store here.

column1: Even if there isn't a new sound to be discovered across these dozen tracks
column2: Cosmic Drag exceeds expectations
column3: with almost every track bearing a shooting-star thrill. And as one would expect from an iconic DJ known to unearth rare tracks
column4: Baldelli excels in sussing out the sweet spot between genres and exploring the new space between. So while ""Ballbearing"" opens with electro pings and a metallic chug
column5: midway through a vintage synth melody emerges and gives the track buoyancy and lift. The rubber band bass of ""Space Dumper"" suggests where '70s funk meets German kosmische
column6: with a psychedelic guitar lick made to sound like rippling water on top.

column1: There’s a sameness to some of Baldelli’s productions here
column2: to where I’d have a difficult time telling you which track is ""Cosmic Particles"" and which is ""Cosmic Glide""
column3: much less which one is ""Cosmic Drag"". But there are standouts: the upbeat disco-funk of ""Mooneyes"" and the heavy Afro drums that roil across grandiose melody and Speak-&-Spell vocals of ""Chop and Roll"" are worthy of entry into the Afro/Cosmic canon. If he hadn’t rendered them himself
column4:
no doubt Baldelli would want to weave them into his set.
