Slug leader Ian Black is from Sunderland—about as far northeast as you can go in England before reaching Scotland—and he used to be a touring member of Field Music. The Brewis brothers engineered and played on Ripe
column2: which was recorded at their small studio on the banks of the River Tyne and bears all the hallmarks of their flinching funk deconstructions. That connection is the obvious reason to listen to Slug’s debut
column3: which works as a fine stopgap while Field Music work on the followup to 2012’s Plumb. But Black is more than just a caretaker
column4: indulging the prog specter that only haunts the edge of the Brewises’ compositions.

column1: Black dots his nervy songs with imperious choruses that owe a debt to Queen and Greek tragedy
column2: and there are two lengthy instrumental interludes here: ""Weight of Violence"" is a muted steel drum dream that acts as a palate-cleanser
column3: but ""Peng Peng""
column4: a baroque piano suite that breaks into a yowling guitar solo
column5: is a bit ostentatious in context. The best of Ripe maintains an invigorating tension between this introversion and theatricality: the pointillist percussion and surf guitar of ""Sha La La""; the sleazy funk guitar that romps through ""Cockeyed Rabbit Wrapped in Plastic""
column6: as Black adopts a passionless falsetto to indict the untouchable elite. On ""Greasy Mind""
column7: he slithers between tightly coiled guitar parts
column8: while ""At Least"" pairs a barbershop chorus with a searching
column9: forlorn synth part that recalls the Specials’ ""Ghost Town"".

column1: Slug’s debut took four years to make
column2: but it feels right that it’s finally out a month shy of the British General Election—in his calm courtroom tone
column3: Black spends much of Ripe criticizing electioneering and the deliberate narrowing of message for political gain. He sings in a combative
column4: sly tone
column5: condemning a single
column6: repellent ""you"": the powerful character preserving the status quo to save his own neck on ""Eggs and Eyes""
column7: the right-wing figures claiming to be the voice of the working class on ""At Least"". Whoever it was written about
column8: it’s impossible to hear that song’s ""creepy crawly fatigue of your mouth/ That does sup beer and shout"" without thinking of Nigel Farage
column9: the leader of the rising but hapless right-wing UKIP party
column10: who is rarely pictured without a pint and his Cheshire Cat grin.

column1: Contrary to the saying that good music thrives in bad times
column2: the tenure of the right-leaning Conservative Party (in coalition with the left-wing Liberal Democrats) hasn’t provoked a particularly visible upsurge in politicized British music. But if the idea of hard times as a creative impulse was ever going to hold up
column3: it’s in the North East
column4: the area hit often hardest by government cuts. There’s little choice but to be self-sufficient 300 miles from London
column5: a model that Field Music have pioneered. For all its minor stylistic differences
column6: Ripe is very much forged in their image. But if any traditions in British indie rock are worth perpetuating right now
column7: this inventive
column8:
engaged stable is the one to back.

Early in the jarring opening pages of science fiction novelist Ray Bradbury’s 1953 masterpiece Fahrenheit 451
column2: the author appears to catch a glimmer of the actual future. Protagonist Guy Montag comes home from work to find his wife limp and dying of an overdose on sleeping pills. Montag calls for assistance and hangs back helplessly as paramedics revive her
column3: thinking to himself
column4: ""There are too many of us. There are billions of us and that’s too many. Nobody knows anyone."" Could Bradbury have foreseen the quiet anomie of faces bathed in smartphone light
column5: shuttling through overcrowded cities
column6: alone together in only tangential acknowledgement of one other’s humanity? Perhaps. Perhaps not.

column1: Singer-songwriter Damon Albarn invokes Bradbury’s sentiment on ""There Are Too Many of Us""
column2: the emotional centerpiece of The Magic Whip
column3: the reunion album from his reconstituted flagship Blur
column4: as he muses about an Australian hostage crisis he once spectated on television from a hotel room above it. ""For a moment I was dislocated by terror on the loop elsewhere
column5: he admits in verse two—not horrified
column6: just momentarily ""dislocated""—as if to call into question our dwindling concern for people in places outside our cubicles of convenience. Technology has made our world smaller
column7: but it hasn’t made us less isolated. Ease of access doesn’t equal closeness.

column1: The Magic Whip is the first Blur album since 2003’s Think Tank
column2: the first with guitarist Graham Coxon onboard since 1999’s 13 (Coxon was booted from the Think Tank sessions a week in and summarily quit)
column3: and the first with producer Stephen Street since 1997’s Blur. In 2013
column4: a lucky twist of fate netted the group some downtime between festival dates in South China and Indonesia
column5: and Blur holed up in a Hong Kong studio to workshop new material. Anyone who’s waited a decade and a half for Albarn and his songwriting foil to resume tussling over bassist Alex James and drummer Dave Rowntree’s lithe low end will find a lot to enjoy; something special happens when these four get in a room
column6: and you can still hear some of it happening here.

column1: The distant traveler’s conflicting sense of wonder and alienation is the running theme here. ""New World Towers"" gazes at the web of neon signs overhead in awe of their glow
column2: ""Go Out"" details nights alone at the bar and defeated late-night self-love. On ""Thought I Was a Spaceman"" Albarn recasts a longing for the comforting familiarity of London as a space-wrecked astronaut’s homesickness. The Magic Whip was conceived as Albarn wrapped work on his 2014 solo album Everyday Robots
column3: and it’s tempting to see its disaffected tourism as a sister to Robots’ shattered workaday ennui back home.

column1: Sensibilities from Albarn’s extracurricular projects frequently bleed into the frame
column2: especially the Gorillaz
column3: which shows both in dubby
column4: beat-oriented cuts like ""New World Towers"" and in the lyrics’ pervasive sense of Englishness-in-exile. ""Thought I Was a Spaceman"" could easily serve as a prequel to Demon Days’ post-apocalyptic opener ""Last Living Souls"" in sound and story
column5: and ""Ghost Ship"" wouldn’t look out of place anchored off the shores of Plastic Beach. At times the sonic tug-of-war feels like Albarn clawing at the restrictions of a framework his ideas have outgrown.

column1: In the moments when The Magic Whip is most interested in sounding like a Blur album
column2: it is perhaps too interested. There’s a nod to nearly every epoch
column3: from the synth-accented Parklife alt-rockisms of ""I Broadcast"" to the busy Great Escape pop of ""Lonesome Street""
column4: the Blur-ish guitar squall of ""Go Out"" and the winding 13-influenced electro-psych of ""Spaceman"". Whip functions as a career travelogue in that sense; one wonders whether the decision to have Street
column5: the band’s Britpop-era producer
column6: helm the sessions hasn’t aroused a certain sense of nostalgia. Restless innovators deserve a cycle back through the worlds they’ve crafted here and there (see: the last decade worth of Prince and Beck) but it’s disorienting for a band as keenly interested in artistic recombination as Blur.

column1: Sometimes the album veers into sleepy territory: The ambient washes and close mic’d
column2: reverb-drenched strumming of ""Spaceman"" are welcome flourishes
column3: as is the cluttered keyboard-and-acoustic bounce of ""Ice Cream Man""
column4: but both are better showcases for production than song structure. There’s also sluggish
column5: saccharine adult contemporary on ""My Terracotta Heart"" and closer ""Mirrorball""
column6: though
column7: momentum-killers in a back end that sometimes lags where it should lift. The tempo only picks up on ""Lonesome Street""
column8: ""Go Out""
column9: and ""I Broadcast""; the rest of the album bobs calmly adrift. It suits the album’s geographical fixation on Hong Kong
column10: Indonesia
column11: and especially the beaches and waters in between
column12: but not the band’s own sweet spot.

column1: All these frustrations fall away when the quartet locks into its signature jangly strut
column2: as it does on the late album highlight ""Ong Ong""
column3: a chugging rocker outfitted with a chorus of lilting la-la’s. Its sunny soul is infectious
column4: as Albarn
column5: who once lamented he had ""no distance left to run
column6: professes a love no measure of forbidding space could quell. Coxon’s in the wings playing hokey luau guitar
column7: zeroing in on Damon’s seafaring yearning and playing it up for yaks until he storms center stage as the song draws to a noisy close. Blur’s always been puckish in spirit
column8: its greatest gift the identification and gleeful subversion of listener expectations
column9: a<span>nd in moments like these it re-emerges
column10:
untarnished by the passage of time.

The Books left the world just as quietly as they entered it. Guitarist and vocalist Nick Zammuto and cellist Paul de Jong seemed to appear from thin air with 2002's Thought for Food
column2: a startlingly innovative album that exuded a strange ease. The dark humor they squeezed from thrift-store VHS tapes and home videos in the decade to follow was both unnerving and sedative
column3: recalling bouts of nostalgia just vague enough to belong to anyone
column4: spliced deftly on the three albums that followed. After uploading a 12-minute video detailing their farewell box set
column5: A Dot In Time
column6: they disbanded in 2012. Nick Zammuto quickly began his own endeavors under his last name. Paul de Jong
column7: however
column8: went into hiding.

column1: After the exhaustion of The Way Out
column2: de Jong uses IF to return refreshed and willing to reveal sides previously overshadowed. The cello was merely an instrument in the Books’ work
column3: for instance
column4: but here it becomes its own character. He filters it through glitches on ""Debt Free"" and anxious whirring during ""Golden Gate""
column5: but it truly comes into its own on ""Age of the Sea"". Moody chords resonate in an empty room
column6: giving off a hollow tone before lo-fi field recordings from a beach enter. A seagull calls out as de Jong creates one of his most beautiful cello lines to date
column7: leaning into the instrument and breathing life into what seems to be an uncovered personal memory sanded down by time.

column1: De Jong hasn't abandoned the duo’s trademark collage-pop absurdity
column2: but he has refined it. Zammuto's last two albums
column3: while farcical and energetic
column4: had numerous throwaway tracks; IF is more calculated. At 51 years old
column5: ten years Zammuto's elder
column6: de Jong plays with his toys differently
column7: and the tracks are always
column8: no matter what
column9: kept tidy. Slapstick number ""Snakes"" indulges in a man’s manic hallucinations of serpents for under a minute
column10: as if de Jong seeks to prove he’s capable of matching Zammuto's colorful
column11: campy energy.  Otherwise he evokes a grave solitude: a man standing in an open field
column12: maybe
column13: palms grazing over the tips of tall grass
column14: muting his thoughts to let the sound of air fill his skull.

column1: De Jong dips into the shadows of jazz in album’s final moments
column2: for the bleak solitude of ""Purpose"". Wind audibly brushes against the microphone as a piano traces some meandering chords
column3: evoking a forlorn sense of resignation and acceptance. It is the sound of someone at the halfway point of their life
column4: looking forward and backward. In that
column5: it's a quiet return to 2003's The Lemon of Pink. IF is patient and spacious
column6: suggesting that de Jong has found solitude
column7: if not peace
column8:
between the strings of his cello.

In 1997
column2: Stuart David was Belle and Sebastian's bass player
column3: and Looper was his side project with his wife Karn David. Then he left Belle and Sebastian to concentrate on Looper
column4: who made three albums and a few singles between 1998 and 2002 before going wherever it is that pleasant
column5: unassuming little bands go.

column1: And now we have this five-disc boxed set of Looper's (nearly) complete discography
column2: including the new ""guess what
column3: we're back"" album Offgrid: Offline (available separately only as a download). It's not straightforward reissues
column4: though: all the tracks have been resequenced into thematic compilations with neologistic titles. One
column5: which starts with their most-frequently-used-in-movies-and-such track ""Mondo '77""
column6: is devoted to instrumentals and near-instrumentals. Another
column7: which starts with one version of the how-Karn-and-Stuart-met story ""Impossible Things"" (and features another half an hour or so later)
column8: collects the tracks on which Stuart reads spoken-word pieces in a subdued voice over not-especially-intrusive musical beds—the sort of thing he'd done with Belle and Sebastian on ""A Century of Elvis"" and ""A Space Boy Dream"".

column1: A third assembles the band's more straightforward pop songs
column2: like 2002's ""Fucking Around""
column3: an unnervingly violent cousin to ""Raindrops Keep Fallin' on My Head"". Then there are two further catchall song-based discs. One of them claims to draw on hip-hop and R&B-inspired ideas about beats (Looper always did like DJ-scratch sounds)
column4: and the other on a broader range of electronic music
column5: but the distinctions aren't especially clear in practice. Both are also generally the Looper recordings that have aged most poorly
column6: like a 1999 single called ""Who's Afraid of Y2K?""
column7: in which Stuart's repeated murmur of ""maybe Y2K will bring the rain"" occasionally gives way to weary electro-burbles.

column1: This seems like a very strange way to reframe the work of a band whose three previous albums can be found used online for a penny apiece. Looper have always been a mix-CD band—a track at a time can be a refreshing interlude in a collection of music by other people—and if their earlier records rarely stuck their heads up too high
column2: at least they had a welcome variety of approaches. But sorting their music into stylistic piles exposes their weaknesses. Their best songs (""Uncle Ray""
column3: ""Burning Flies"") have a bit of bitterness and swagger about them
column4: but too many others are anemic sketches—they've got a nice keyboard tone
column5: or a decent rhythm loop
column6: and perhaps a little snippet of melody
column7: and then they just shrug their shoulders and do their thing for a few minutes.

column1: ""It was mainly Best Ofs I liked when I was growing up
column2: Stuart noted in a recent Philthy Mag interview. ""That was what really made me want to rearrange the tracks for the boxset. Into something like a collection of Best Of CDs."" That's not how best-ofs work—and
column3: actually
column4: a tight
column5: smartly sequenced Looper greatest-hits album would be a likable addition to an indie-pop shelf. These Things clarifies the band's aesthetic
column6:
but it makes them harder to listen to.

Yelawolf has spent years making Love Story
column3: his second official album as a major label artist and first release since 2013’s Trunk Muzik Returns. The title of that last project
column4: a mixtape
column5: says plenty: Yelawolf was trying to recapture something he’d lost along the way. In the early years of his career
column6: Yela seemed to be rattling around an industry that didn’t quite know how to deal with him. By 2009 he’d been signed and dropped by Columbia Records—an official debut got lost along the way—and then found his stride with a mixtape that might remain his best work to date. Trunk Musik 0-60
column7: Interscope’s street album rehash of that mixtape

column1: When Radioactive rolled around in 2011 it felt like Yelawolf had broken a promise

column3: in failed (and weird) crossover attempts. Unfortunately
column4: and for different reasons
column5: Love Story vies with that last album as the worst music of his career; as a result

column1: With 18 tracks spanning more than 74 minutes
column2: Love Story is far too long to accomplish so little and hits the same notes over and over again. It’s draining. Most glaring is Yelawolf’s devolution as a rapper: He’s developed a bad habit of leaning on cringey similes and seems to have forfeited the snappy
column3: accelatory delivery that made 0-60 so fun to listen to and hard to rap along with. ""Still on that grass like John Deeres
column4: he raps on ""Whiskey in a Bottle""; on ""Love Story""
column5: he offers ""Got my weight up like I’m carrying fat people."" Here he is denouncing wannabe rednecks on ""Change"": ""Yellin' redneck
column6: you about as red as the color blue is."" Those types of lines not only sound worse the second (and third) time around
column7: they run rampant. On ""Disappear"" he feigns a cathartic letter to an estranged father—""You told me what you did
column8: carpentry
column9: right?""—and then at the end of the song a supposed-to-be-big reveal falls hopelessly flat: ""I love you daddy
column10: or should I say Christ?""

column1: Love Story has moments that seem to aim at Americana. Sometimes that means thigh-slapping
column2: rootsy country (""Have a Great Flight"") and sometimes it’s psychedelic southern rock. In either case
column3: they cast Yela as a cheesy pastiche artist. ""Johnny Cash"" features the rapper narrating his arms-length relationship with a live audience and then for a hook he just says ""Johnny Cash"" like half-a-dozen times. At surface level at least
column4: ""Best Friend"" is the album’s attention-grabber with the solitary feature in the form of an extended
column5: rambling Eminem verse. The appearance is the first we’ve heard from Em in 2015 and it’s a characteristically jumbled bit of technical braggadocio. At one point he strings together a series of bars that internally carry ""shiggy-shock"" and ""im-piggy-possible"" and ends with
column6: ""word to the diggy doc/ Stiggy-stopping is not an option."" It’s like Eminem is breaking down a complicated piece of Ikea furniture and purposefully veering away from the instructions in putting it back together. Once it all fits
column7: it’s hard to see what the point was.

column1: As both an executive producer and label-head
column2: Love Story signals a failure for Eminem as well
column3: and bears the same structural flaws that nag his own late-career output—namely
column4: a lot of filler
column5: poor sequencing
column6: and just too much of the same damn thing. Em’s fingerprints are all over the music and his own production credits yield plodding
column7: heavy-handed beats that don’t suit Yelawolf’s once-erratic flow. The WillPower produced ""Till It’s Gone""

column9: feels like the best the album has to offer. Yelawolf doesn’t strain his singing here and settles into a marching flow over the looped-up acoustic guitar and heel-stomping bottom end. The hook is still full of platitudes and a not-so-productive tautology
column10: but as a whole it’s better than everything else here.<span> ""Fiddle Me This"" caps off the album with a rote ""Devil Went Down to Georgia"" interpolation bleeding into a gratuitous scratching interlude
column11: and Yelawolf raps

After Ryan Adams finishes ""Come Pick Me Up""
column3: his definitive song and the one which ends both performances captured on Live at Carnegie Hall

column5: because thousands of people have discovered that listening to Ryan Adams alone is akin to giving your sadness a spa day. But ""Come Pick Me Up"" actually transforms into something uplifting in a live setting these days. For both the performer and the audience
column6: “Rescue Blues” and “Why Do They Leave” and “Amy” are bittersweet

column8: who gets to laugh at himself. The original ache is gone and everyone can just admit to each other
column9: ""man

column1: Live at Carnegie Hall makes Adams’ impromptu comedy the main draw: somewhere within this three-and-a-half-hour package is one of the funniest standup records you’ll hear in 2015. And the subject of nearly all of Ryan Adams’ jokes is Ryan Adams. This is a career-spanning project
column2: so ""Ryan Adams"" becomes a very
column3: very broad topic. Adams offers countless punchlines about the prevalence of tears and rain in his music as well as his penchant for using this reputation to his advantage—""Probably like 86% of you are on Paxil
column4: so you understand about depression. So... you're at a fucking Ryan Adams show

column1: The most cutting material aims at Adams' most self-serious phase
column2: also known as his ""New York"" phase. On records like Gold and Love Is Hell
column3: Adams relied on New York City to grant his music instant gravitas and urbane legitimacy. It was literally personified on his biggest single (<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hmHgY_J63Ik"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""New York
column4: New York"")
column5: and his residence in the East Village felt like method acting. At one point on Carnegie Hall
column6: he claims Love Is Hell highlight ""Please Do Not Let Me Go"" as one of his proudest moments and a song he wrote out on a pizza box while stoned as fuck and ruminating on the purpose of shoes.

column1: Live at Carnegie Hall is available as a 10-song sampler and a 216-minute 6xLP
column2: though both versions have the casual Ryan Adams fan in mind. This isn’t for the hardcore Ryan Adams fan
column3: the kind who will claim to have bootlegged B-side comps and shelved records that bests anything he’ll ever publicly release. This isn’t Ryan Adams’ Greatest Hits or the Definitive Ryan Adams either

column7: just a handful of B-sides and only the Love Is Hell tracks long-established as fan favorites.

column1: All of his selections here work beautifully with just an acoustic guitar as accompaniment

The performances themselves are flawless and the recording is as well; everything is so crisp and clear that Carnegie Hall might as well be your living room. But the later songs remain what they were on record: tuneful
column4: workmanlike numbers that can’t possibly generate the emotional payload of Heartbreaker but aren’t really trying to. Ryan Adams' music often gets called ""effortless
column5: which cuts both ways—it can sound elemental and eternal and also like something he dashed off in five minutes. He’s very much aware of this reputation as well—Adams ad libs a presumably impromptu funk number on piano based on a hypothetical text message exchange between Billy Ocean and Michael McDonald.

column1: It all highlights the various odd turns Ryan Adams' persona has taken over the past 20 years. After his blatant crossover bid Gold

column3: the other was too ""sad"" and both were considered career-killers. He rebounded in 2005 with three albums that were vastly superior but no more compromising—in half a year
column4: he was a honky-tonk traditionalist
column5: a Deadhead and Jeff Buckley. More recently
column6: oddball vanity projects Orion and 1984 give glimmers of hope that they may one day not be the exception to the rule set by Ashes & Fire and Ryan Adams. But Live at Carnegie Hall is the Ryan Adams Ryan Adams
column7: the one who redefined himself at 40 years old as three things no one thought he’d ever be: reliable
column8:
consistent and a consummate people pleaser.

column3: even tone

But Fay seems to have few regrets about the way things went

column1: In recent years

Few singers of Mavis Staples' era have managed to stay as prolific or as relevant; Bettye LaVette comes in a close second
column2: Aretha isn’t even in the race. A pop-gospel lifer who started singing in public when she was barely a teenager
column3: she enjoyed massive success in the '60s and '70s as the mightiest voice in the Staple Singers and as an avatar of post-Civil Rights optimism. Even after a few decades in the wilderness (during which she made a string of fine
column4: yet largely overlooked solo albums
column5: including one produced by Prince)
column6: she experienced a resurgence in the new century with a string of albums that updated her message first to the Bush era and next to the age of Obama. She has recorded two (three if you count Pops Staples’ posthumous Don’t Lose This) excellent albums with Jeff Tweedy
column7: one of which—2010’s You Are Not Alone­—won a Grammy for Best Americana Album. Decades into her storied career

column1: Her latest release is a four-song EP with Son Little: two originals and two new versions of songs long associated with the Staple Singers. The man born Aaron Livingston has only a single solo EP to his name

column3: bass

column11: however

Two years ago

Jones and Steve Cropper—on the classic 1967 blues track ""Born Under a Bad Sign"". Barack and Michelle nodded their heads in respectful rhythm. Malia seemed mildly amused. Sasha

column6: Howard wore earrings emblazoned with Prince’s face. ""We just don’t wanna own the classic R&B title and let people down
column7: guitarist Heath Fogg diplomatically stated around the release of Boys & Girls
column8: ""because when we go electronic on the next record it might break some hearts.""

column1: Sound & Color is not an electronic record. But it is strange and mystical and unexpected—more Houses of the Holy than ""Holy Cow"". It’s got past lives and future people
column2: traces of Curtis Mayfield
column3: Erykah Badu
column4: MC5
column5: the Strokes. There’s a song called ""Shoegaze"" that could find a second home on the Rolling Stones’ Tattoo You. Bon Iver collaborator Rob Moose provides eerie string arrangements that slowly encroach on songs like ivy climbing up a fence while the band and co-producer Blake Mills tweak tones and rhythms to make guitars and drums and bass and keyboards sound genuinely exciting—fresh
column6: even—in 2015. This is stadium soul with one eye peeking toward another galaxy while hands and feet and throats desperately try to suss out life here on Earth.

column1: Of course
column2: Howard is at the center of it all. Over the course of the last three years
column3: she’s managed to take complete control over her unbridled voice without losing a smidge of spontaneity. She’s no longer just building toward an ecstatic climax (though there are several of those here)
column4: but rather exploring the upper reaches of her register
column5: cajoling instead of hollering
column6: taking on operatic cadences. The singer
column7: who took part in both raucous Baptist services as well as a cappella hymns in the Church of Christ growing up
column8: layers her vocals on almost every track
column9: offering harmonies and ghosts that can’t help but follow her around; on one bipolar love song
column10: what sounds like ghoulish laughter echoes behind Howard as she pours her being into the words ""gimme all your love!"" Is she reveling in her desires? Sending up her larger-than-life voice? Smiling into the void of unrequited love? Yes
column11: yes
column12: and yes.

column1: As a lyricist
column2: Howard excels at spinning down-home profundity that make her sound her age
column4: and years beyond. Along with her tales of haunted love
column5: cautious optimism
column6: and impassioned pacifism come more impressionistic songs that mean to find connections between epochs and space. She and her band travel through the blues back to a bad sign—or is it a good one?—on ""Gemini""
column7: a six-and-a-half-minute excursion into zero-gravity funk. Whereas Alabama Shakes once seemed destined to relive the history of others
column8: they invent their own genesis here
column9: as weeds grow near the Tennessee River and eyes reveal dreams that eventually must wake up. And just as the song comes to a close
column10:
it keeps going for a little while longer.

A new Death album in 2015 is an odd thing to comprehend.
column2: serif;""><span>The trio of brothers—Bobby
column3: Dannis
column4: and David Hackney—formed in Detroit in the 1970s
column5: offering loud
column6: fast
column7: and heavy rock'n'roll inspired by bands like the Who and Alice Cooper. Occasionally
column8: they ebbed toward more introspective spiritual music
column9: but their legacy lies in their status as a lost proto-punk band: They came close to breaking through—the famous story is that Clive Davis said he’d sign them if they changed their name. David refused and they quietly broke up in 1977.

column1: Of course
column2: that’s not the end of the story. When Drag City released their archival material
column3: Bobby and Dannis
column4: joined by Bobbie Duncan on guitar
column5: started playing the old stuff to rapturous receptions. Their narrative in recent years
column6: outlined well by the documentary A Band Called Death
column7: goes roughly like this: ""Whoa
column8: who are this band Death? Wait
column9: they're still around? Holy shit
column10: they’re playing in front of me right now! This is awesome!"" And it could’ve stayed that way
column11: too. Thanks to the nature of their return
column12: Death's very presence in this century is an exciting prospect.

column1: N.E.W. is their first collection of new stuff since they split in the 1970s (aside from one 1990s one-off that appeared on III) and quietly moved on to play in other bands (reggae and Christian rock outfits among them). It's also their first recorded output without the band's spiritual center and creative mastermind David
column2: who died in 2000. Sure enough
column3: it sounds like Death. They move along at a beefy rock'n'roll chug; they rip through impressive guitar solos; their rhythms are unpredictable. They scream and they growl. At their best
column4: Death 2015 deliver the chest-beating
column5: all-power proto-punk that made people flip when they heard ""Keep on Knocking"" and ""Politicians in My Eyes"" for the first time. And structurally speaking
column6: ""Relief"" is one of their best songs ever—a muscular earworm with a shout-along chorus
column7: screaming breakdowns
column8: and some well-done (and understated) guitar work from Duncan.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: that song also represents the biggest problem with N.E.W.: each theme and message is oversold. ""Detroit rocks
column3: they shout
column4: but decide that's probably too specific. ""East Coast rocks! West Coast rocks! The whole world rocks!"" At times
column5: their lyrics are cornball and completely devoid of nuance. If we’ve learned anything from Death’s fellow Michigander Andrew W.K. (or other maximal carpe diem screamers like Junior Senior and Icona Pop)
column6:
aggressively positive music works best when it’s pitched right over the top. Death rarely hit full boil. Their performances are technically impressive but feel tepid.

Understandably
column7: their journey is a central narrative on N.E.W. At this point
column8: though
column9: the band's biography has been well-documented. When they sing about existing in the underground
column10: how they ""feel the love"" now that they've been brought to the light
column11: and note that ""the fun has just begun"" on ""Resurrection""
column12: the message feels superfluous. Watch Death perform in the closing scenes of A Band Called Death—every word of ""Resurrection"" is spelled out more eloquently and concisely in the Hackneys' earnest
column13: smiling expressions. The themes of resurrection
column14: return
column15: and revival are implicit to the album's mere existence
column16: and the Hackneys do a better job of navigating those concepts when they leave some room for subtext (""Who Am I"").

column1: Death were worthy of thinkpieces and a documentary because their very good
column2: very heavy recordings predated and portended punk without actually influencing it. The rock'n'roll playing field is drastically different at this point in their careers—they're operating in a sprawling
column3: endless landscape of heavy guitar music. Unlike ...For the Whole World to See
column4: N.E.W. does not sound like a lost proto-punk classic; it's just a pretty good rock record made by guys who have been at it for a long time. They're much older men now
column5: and if you can get past some of their more embarrassing phrases (most of ""Playtime"")
column6:
you'll find a band who are still very good at their bread and butter.

In pop music years
column2: 2008 feels like eons ago. That was the year that Radioclit—a duo of UK-based beat makers Etienne Tron and Johan Karlberg—and Malawian-born
column3: London-based vocalist Esau Mwamwaya hopped on M.I.A.'s ""Paper Planes"". Sampling the Clash's ""Straight to Hell""
column4: this British punk beat about Vietnamese bastard children of American GIs
column5: as appropriated by a Sri Lankan refugee
column6: and in turn recast by a Swede-French-African amalgam as ""Tengazako"" doubled as hip-pop utopia. But the world's turned plenty since then
column7: from M.I.A.'s one-finger Super Bowl salute to a Kenyan-American presidency. And seven years on
column8: the giddy pleasures of a Europop/African mash-up has become
column9: if not exactly commonplace
column10: then no longer the aural speedball it once was.

column1: The Very Best (now a duo of Karlberg and Mwamwaya) did euphoric
column2: Afro dance pop with their 2009 debut and then widened their scope and Rolodex with 2012's MTMTMK. Their sleekest album to date
column3: it shoehorned in the likes of Amadou & Miriam
column4: Senegalese singer Baaba Maal
column5: frequent David Guetta vocalist Taio Cruz
column6: Somali-Canadian rapper K'naan
column7: and even Bruno Mars
column8: making them all heel to their African sun-bright sound. Guest credits on their third album
column9: Makes a King
column10: include another Vampire Weekend member (Chris Baio this time rather than Ezra Koenig
column11: who contributed to their debut)
column12: the Vaccines's guitarist Freddie Cowan
column13: and EDM newcomer Jutty Ranx
column14: but it’s hard to pick out individual contributions. And for the most part
column15: even the Very Best know that they can’t remain only at the ecstatic end of the musical spectrum.

column1: Much like its predecessor
column2: Makes a King was rendered on Malawian soil
column3: but now the Very Best are settled in the lakeside village of M’dala Chikowa rather than the country’s capital Lilongwe. And while MTMTMK at times had the odd feel of a superclub transposed to that impoverished African country
column4: King rarely aims for the club stratosphere early on. Instead
column5: it feels much closer to the earth and sounds most comfortable there: Low-key electronic buzzes around the opening call and response of ""Nkhondo""
column6: a noticeable shift away from the explosive beats and bright glare of synths that previous albums made their trademark.

column1: That humble sound carries over to ""Hear Me""
column2: Karlberg’s programmed beat and somber piano chords set somewhere between Boards of Canada’s Music Has the Right to Children and Portishead’s Dummy: slow
column3: filtered
column4: and at a shuffling pace. There’s the chant of a Malawian choir
column5: some staticky voices lifted from the radio
column6: and above it all
column7: Mwamwaya’s strong yet controlled voice
column8: elegant as a cloud drifting across the track. His voice interacts with that choir again on the unadorned chants of ""Bilimankhwe""
column9: sounding like something Smithsonian-Folkways (or Hugh Tracey) might have captured to tape in the 1950s. The clean guitar that carries the ballad ""Mwana Wanga"" finds the group at its most hushed and appealing.

column1: From there though
column2: that unassuming yet new wrinkle to the Very Best’s sound gets pushed to the side by more club-friendly fare
column3: and the results are not nearly as charming as the first half. The break that comes three minutes into ""Sweka"" is an ambient oasis of wordless vocals and electronic trickles
column4: but on either side is a generic chicken-scratch guitar and filtered thump. Where the duo’s ability to wed political African lyricism to production that might smuggle it into a DJ set once played to their strong suit
column5: now when the chintzy synth chords and Ibiza-acceptable thump of ""Mariana"" lurch to the fore
column6: it sounds like shameless pandering. There’s moments where the Very Best show that rather than merely parlay exuberance and global harmony
column7: they can also manage the somber aspect of their music. But when Karlberg slows the beat to a crawl again on ""The Dead and the Dreaming""
column8: he also sullies the clear timbre of Mwamwaya’s voice with distortion. In the process
column9:
what was once their most distinguished trait winds up sounding muddled.

East Coast fans of West Coast rap
column2: rejoice: a new Roach Gigz project has arrived in time for warmer weather. Anyone familiar with the Bay Area rapper’s work and has driven a car in summer with the windows down will appreciate the significance of this event. Roach’s track record with delivering effectively primordial
column3: trunk-rattling post-hyphy rap music has been consistent since he first gained national attention with his mixtape Roachy Balboa in 2010. The title fit the music’s contentious charm: Roach’s hyperactive approach seemed to be a means of proving himself against naysayers
column4: as well as a reflection of his influences
column5: including noted hometown syllable-crammers from E-40 to Keak da Sneak. Like his first retail release—2012’s Bugged Out—Roach’s new studio album is centered around tight
column6: single-ready songwriting and slicker
column7: more flourish-filled production. But The Float is a much more significant stylistic departure
column8: which finds the rapper venturing well outside of his comfort zone both lyrically and musically.

column1: Appropriately
column2: the album is framed like a dream vacation
column3: bookended by loudspeaker chatter on an airplane to Hawaii during ascent and descent. Roach’s writing is unusually introspective and tranquil: He dabbles in loose
column4: pseudo-philosophical ruminations
column5: ones that might surface while lounging (a bit faded) on a beach at sundown. One of the touchstones of a Roach release is the proverbial fire-spitting cut; tracks of <a href=""https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0CCAQyCkwAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DJ6-F4NKGSz0&ei=2K82VeL-OfDbsASh5IGYBw&usg=AFQjCNExeT09Jg9iWZWjW2Qx4_c9myAQ_w&sig2=9Iv9mC1GMEMyvKN4ev21HA&bvm=bv.91071109
column6: d.b2w"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">this type constitute a large fraction of his output
column7: sometimes leaving him breathless and ready for the James Brown cape-drape. But Roach cuts back on that overstuffed style on The Float—compartmentalizing his verses and maintaining an unflappable cool.

column1: Writing more painstakingly
column2: however
column3: steers him away from the jester role he’s played so well in the past; you have to wait four tracks for the first quintessential Roach-ism
column4: and by that point it sticks out like a sore thumb: ""A couple likes don’t up amounts in your bank account/ And in this climate
column5: I’m the Heimlich/ Don’t fuck with me
column6: or you could choke on vomit."" Taunts and lecherous punchlines are frequently subbed out in favor of self-help truisms and some moments of wide-angle paranoia
column7: the dark side of the high. Lyrically
column8: there’s nothing cringe-worthy on this album (that’s not something Roach seems capable of)
column9: but it’s hard not to wish he’d incorporated a few more firebrand moments.

column1: But the much more noticeably atypical element of the album is its production. In the past
column2: Roach’s songs have been grounded by bare
column3: stuttering kick drums
column4: handclaps
column5: wobbly synth leads
column6: and not much else. But on The Float
column7: Roach’s producers (including long-time collaborator C-Loz) infuse that unmistakably West Coast architecture with gestures from rock
column8: soul
column9: and house. The impulse to diversify is reasonable considering how long Roach has stayed the course with that sound
column10: but since it’s his first major step away
column11: the results are variegated in quality. The most puzzling moment is a re-pitched interpolation of No Doubt’s ""Don’t Speak"" as minimalist techno; it’s made stranger by the fact that Roach raps for only 45 seconds of its three-and-a-half minutes. Other lukewarm moments include ""Hippy""
column12: which employs an overdriven rock aesthetic
column13: and the practiced DJ Mustard-esque swagger and come-on R&B hook of ""Drunk With You"". Unfortunately
column14: Roach doesn’t pack enough lyrical punches in these songs to improve their replay value.

column1: The best tracks walk the line between the flashy
column2: battle-rapping Roach of old and his more enlightened upgrade. Opener ""Mob Right Thru"" is one of his best singles to date
column3: grounded by a glossy slide-guitar-like riff and spare beat which leaves Roach space to duck and weave. ""No End in Sight"" is equally understated
column4: a piece of pleasantly harmonized underwater disco which features Roach’s best lines on the tape: He juxtaposes vaunting wisecracks with evocative autobiographical details
column5: even a brief aside to his son. These postulate a future Roach capable of both embracing a more mature
column6: restrained sound while still playing to his strengths.

column1: It’s never felt like Roach needed to change his formula. He has almost an excess of personality
column2: and finds ways to vary his results and build excitement over anything he’s rapping over—if he tackled over the same beat four times on a tape
column3: you might not be able to tell
column4: and you probably wouldn’t care. But all good things must come to an end
column5: even if it’s only for his sake. If The Float is not the crossover some fans might hope for (it always seemed like Roach should be more popular than he is)
column6: it at least provides evidence that Roach is thinking critically about his future
column7: pulling parts of his sound apart and rebuilding them in creative ways. ""Even when I’m bad
column8: I’m great
column9: he raps on ""Bounce Back""; this rule

column12:
and it seems unlikely that it will change anytime soon.

Chaos Echoes
column2: a French group formed by brothers Kalevi (guitars
column3: vocals) and Ilmar (drums) Uibo of defunct death metal group Bloody Sign
column4: take a freeform approach to death metal
column5: looking to uproot it from its rigid soil. <span>Metal
column6: especially not death metal
column7: has never been exactly improvisation-friendly
column8: and the prospect of Chaos Echoes' mission is exciting. Despite their intentions
column9: though
column10: they wind up seeming too free
column11: and their first full-length Transient
column12: while an intriguing listen with moments of promise
column13: suffers from a lack of direction that squanders their potential.

column1: Even the most outre metal groups have some sort of defined mission. Impetuous Ritual are committed to building seemingly endless oppressive walls of death-metal noise; post-Obscura Gorguts and Kayo Dot seek to bridge the gap between metal and modern classical; Mastery shows how utter chaos can be carefully spliced and reconfigured for maximum impact. Chaos Echoes' aims on Transient are more difficult to pin down. Opening track ""Senses of the Nonexistent"" thuds on and on for nine-plus minutes; cut in half
column2: it would be twice as compelling. The song's length doesn't seem to serve any larger purpose; it just traps them (and us) in purgatory.  ""Interzone IV: Intoxicating Beauty""
column3: the following track
column4: contines in the same vein. It's not until two minutes into ""Advent of My Genesis""
column5: the third track
column6: that Chaos offer any catharsis. Their tone
column7: on the breakdown
column8: evokes the howling walls of the aforementioned Impetuous Ritual
column9: or their sister band Grave Upheaval
column10: forced screeching and wailing into sunlight. The brightness works
column11: contrasting murk with airiness.

column1: ""Genesis"" shows
column2: again
column3: their map-burning working against them. Considering that drummer Ilmar is one of the founding members
column4: one would expect the band to sync with him
column5: but much of ""Genesis"" sounds as though he's going rogue
column6: his rolls ignoring the tension being built by the guitars. (Considering how often they struggle with plodding on Transient
column7: maybe they need to stop by Paris and visit experimental American ex-pat Stephen O'Malley.) There's a fine line between looseness and simply not knowing what the hell is going on
column8: and ""Genesis"" communicates more of the latter than the former.

column1: Intriguingly
column2: Chaos Echoes' more (relatively) conventional moments are
column3: more often than not
column4: their strongest. The black metal surge on the latter half of ""Genesis"" connects powerfully. ""Kyôrakushugi"" further expands on their black metal side
column5: and it's one of their most defined tracks. Even when the rest of the band vaporizes into a mist of plucks and groans
column6: Ilmar keeps on blasting
column7: giving momentum they sorely need. ""<span>Interzone VI: Realization”
column8: meanwhile
column9: combines drones too understated for their own good with an unfocused half-moan
column10: half-growl vocal
column11: like a bad Sunn O))) outtake.

column1: ""Soul Ruiner"" suggests a midpoint between their ambitions and their grasp. Staring out with frenzied picking with a slightly no-wave inflection
column2: the band finally achieves that ""free death metal"" sound. Hallowed solos and ghostly runs sound disembodied while still leaning forward. Is this what they were wanting to go for the whole time? Transient takes too long to find any pulse
column3: but ""Ruiner"" provides a molecule of closure for a confusing album.

column1: There should be more metal bands like Chaos Echoes
column2: ones that challenge the notions of what metal is and what it can be. But even experiments need purpose and direction. On their Bandcamp page
column3: there's a Wayne Shorter quote: ""To hell with the rules
column4: I am going for the unknown."" Chaos Echoes heeded this advice and dove headfirst
column5: but on Transient
column6: they don't make it back. Who knows how they will expand
column7: contract
column8: or mutate in the future; for now
column9:
the idea of Chaos Echoes exceeds that of their execution.

Keep your ears open
column2: and you can hear Passion Pit everywhere around you: in fast food commercials and YouTube pre-roll ads you can’t wait to skip
column3: the skewed pop maximalism of PC Music and its imitators
column4: the glossy hybrid EDM-pop of Madeon and Zedd
column5: even the clutter of Taylor Swift’s work with Jack Antonoff on 1989. It’s easy to take for granted now
column6: but Michael Angelakos’ first two records shifted the pop paradigm in meaningful ways. Manners hooked up the '80s synth-pop of M83’s Saturdays=Youth to a glucose IV
column7: piling on children’s choirs and waves of orchestration and Angelakos’ signature falsetto until it forced you into submission; three years later
column8: Gossamer ramped up the density
column9: scale
column10: and emotional rawness of Angelakos’ writing
column11: as he built glittering castles around love
column12: death
column13: and the redeeming power of joy. That rawness is what separates Passion Pit from its lesser contemporaries
column14: and from bands who would seek to duplicate their success: Angelakos' songs dance on the line between sweet and saccharine
column15: but they’re anchored by real stakes. They’re full of light because you can use a lot of it when you’re holding a candle to the darkness.

column1: Kindred is Angelakos’ first record after conducting an unflinching
column2: very public self-examination of his mental health and its effects on his life and loved ones
column3: a process that dominated both Gossamer and the press cycle around the record. Instead of doubling down on that kind of reflection
column4: Angelakos shifts focus to the parts of his life that gave him strength as he endured personal and professional turmoil: his family
column5: his faith
column6: and the radiant love that springs from both. It’s also his most concise record to date
column7: a far cry from the sprawl of both Manners and Gossamer: it’s only 10 songs
column8: and the songs themselves are more interested in speed and economy.

column1: The best songs are the ones that really take that idea of efficiency to heart
column2: stripping away fluff and frippery to focus on core melodic ideas or compositional concepts. This marks a major change in Angelakos’ songwriting: most listeners would agree that Gossamer’s best moments were its biggest
column3: whether the frenzied Rustie-isms of ""I’ll Be Alright"" or the massive
column4: starlit ""Hideaway"". That’s not the case here on Kindred
column5: where the highlights hew closer to the soulful heartbreaker ""Constant Conversations"". There are a lot of moving parts on something like ""Whole Life Story""
column6: a song-length apology to Angelakos’ wife for the scrutiny placed on their lives post-Gossamer
column7: but each of them are clear and discernible rather than overwhelming
column8: and lithe pop-funk jam ""Where the Sky Hangs"" sets a new record for ""audible space in a Passion Pit song.""

column1: When Angelakos opts for an arrangement that recalls the density of his older work
column2: you find yourself wishing he had opted for a similarly pared down approach. ""All I Want"" is a good example. Its core message—being struck dizzy and dumb by your love for someone
column3: and rejoicing in it with a simple
column4: gorgeous melody—is compromised by the use of every tool in Angelakos’ toolbox: whirring dervishes spat out on guitar
column5: vocal pieces whispering like ghosts in the background
column6: glittering doodads glued on like rhinestones. On earlier albums
column7: the tremendous scale and layering of his songs felt purposeful
column8: like it was meant to reflect the buzzing hornets’ nest in Angelakos’ brain; when he tries to do the same thing on Kindred it feels aimless
column9: a choice that doesn’t move songs forward or help to advance any ideas.

column1: This is also a very spiritual record
column2: which shouldn't be a surprise if you've pored over Angelakos' lyric sheets before. (Consider Gossamer closer ""Where We Belong""
column3: where after alluding to a suicide attempt Angelakos sings
column4: ""Who says that God exists?/ We can't see icons or myths
column5: but/ Well
column6: I believe in you/ Do you believe in me
column7: too?"") Opener ""Lifted Up (1985)"" is another glowing ode to Angelakos' wife
column8: but it traffics in the language of apotheosis: Instead of being born
column9: she descends from heaven
column10: and when she threatens to float back Angelakos grounds her with the force of their love. The album is otherwise scattered with references to prayer and the exertion of subtle divine force
column11: like the conspicuous cloud cover of ""Looks Like Rain"" and the baptism/savior imagery of ""My Brother Taught Me How to Swim"". This kind of writing isn't as obviously courageous as the work he did on Gossamer
column12: but it still takes plenty of bravery to write frankly about faith in a medium where it's usually ignored or neglected. It takes guts to say
column13: in effect
column14: ""I had to work really hard to get better
column15: and embracing something bigger than myself really helped me."" And while Angelakos has never been a particularly artful lyricist
column16: he writes with a wide-eyed sincerity and frankness that makes you want to root for him.

column1: As the first document of Angelakos' shift towards a different songwriting approach
column2: one more focused on efficiency and pop purity than complexity or breadth
column3: Kindred is ultimately both a transitional moment and a mixed bag. Not every song on Manners and Gossamer worked
column4: but at their very least they had something to keep your attention
column5: some grippy sonic piece. Kindred lives and dies on the strength of its melodies
column6: and some of those melodies are submarined by excess rather than enhanced by it. When the album's highlights click (""Whole Life Story""
column7: ""Where the Sky Hangs""
column8: ""Looks Like Rain"") they're as powerful and resonant as anything in the band's discography

column3: the London-born producer Adrian Sherwood is a sort of bass-music activist
column4: fighting to keep the ""dub"" in dubstep with solo albums like 2012's Survival and Resistance and lecturing on studio-recording history and technique at Red Bull Music Academy. But Sherwood made his deepest mark 30-some years ago
column5: working in the slipstream between post-punk
column6: industrial and Jamaican music that ran between London and New York. Once you start picking at the threads of his CV
column7: you'll discover an adventurous
column8: refined musical talent whose singular sound helped generate momentum for a slew of edgy
column9: iconic bands and ensured his own placement in the producers' pantheon.

column1: To stimulate the inevitable reassessment
column2: Sherwood is releasing music from his back catalog on his On-U Sound label
column3: which he originally founded in 1979 as a repository for the work he was doing with Jamaican musicians. <i>Sherwood at the Controls
column4: Vol. I: 1979-1984 explores a thrilling period in music history and makes a compelling point of entry for appreciating Sherwood's influence. Among its 14 selections
column5: dub is a persistent thread. In the London music scene of the late '70s
column6: the sonic touchstones of Jamaican music—oceanic bass
column7: cavernous reverb
column8: spacious syncopation
column9: an overarching sense of studio-applied patience and distance—appeared in surprising places
column10: applied to far-flung genres.

column1: By that stage in his career
column2: young Sherwood had cultivated a reputation beyond his early association with Jamaican expats in London's reggae scene. He was known as a production auteur with a serious ear and bands like the Fall
column3: the Slits and the Pop Group
column4: all represented here in various incarnations
column5: sought his signature touch. On the Fall's ""Middle Mass""
column6: they sound like a more minimalist version of themselves
column7: demonstrating both Sherwood's collaborative subtlety and Mark E. Smith's predilection for bubbling bass. The Pop Group frontman Mark Stewart's ""Learning to Cope with Cowardice"" is one of the more contemporary-sounding jams here
column8: the kind of crunchy digi-dub that we associate from modern purveyors like Glasgow's Scotch Bonnet Records or Leipzig's Jahtari.

column1: Stewart wasn't the only Pop Group member to enlist Sherwood after the band's breakup: Guitarist John Waddington recorded with him as part of a group called Maximum Joy. ""Let It Take You There"" is one of the comp's highlights
column2: six minutes of spaced-out and infectiously upbeat post-punk funk à la ESG. It follows album opener ""Hungry
column3: So Angry"" by Medium Medium—another fantastic
column4: dancefloor-oriented
column5: sax-driven number
column6: this one leaning toward Talking Heads-like jitter-pop. Several songs later
column7: Sherwood and Shriekback—which consisted of Barry Andrews of XTC and Dave Allen of Gang of Four—push the limits of a LinnDrum machine on the proto-industrial ""Mistah Linn He Head"".

column1: If you sense a theme
column2: that's not an accident: These songs and artists form a nexus of references for a slew of more recognizable early '80s bands. Sherwood was a physical link between the Jamaican underground to the white avant-garde
column3: and collectively
column4: over the course of years
column5: they pushed unconventional musical ideas into the mainstream
column6: where the likes of David Byrne and the Police made them popular.

column1: But Sherwood—and Sherwood at the Controls—remains unpopulist. The second half of the compilation is especially and deliciously weird. Here we meet Jamaican music luminaries like producer Prince Far I
column2: whose Linton Kwesi Johnson-sampling ""Nuclear Weapon"" flows at a lava-like pace
column3: and vocalist Bim Sherman
column4: who performs ""Reaching the Bad Man"" as part of Sherwood's studio ensemble Singers and Players
column5: unspooling an eight-minute foray into deep
column6: skeletal dub. To this day
column7: African Head Charge is one of On-U's flagship bands; their 1982 cut ""In a Trap"" sizzles with Nyabinghi-style percussion
column8: rubbery bass and faraway guitar.

column1: The depth and breadth of Sherwood at the Controls stuns. These songs aren't just curious footnotes in one man's extensive discography—a bunch of them legitimately bang

column4:
and hopefully there is more on the way to round out the picture.

column1: Red Death

column3: step up

column7: less in the speedier L.A. tradition (think Cryptic Slaughter) than in the heavier New York tradition (think D.R.I.). The band roars
column8: gnashes
column9: howls
column10: and divebombs its way through 16 minutes and 47 seconds
column11: and when it’s over

column15: you know the feeling.

column1: Permanent Exile never feels relentless or too formulaic
column2: two easy traps for hardcore and metal records to fall into. There are thousands of mundane releases out there that in under 20 minutes can cause a listener’s eyes to glaze over—what song is this one again? It sounds exactly the same as the last three. With taut
column3: well-written songs that vary in tempo and even stray into noise-ambience in places (""Atomic Howl"")
column4: Red Death expertly avoid these pitfalls. The record blazes the whole way through

column1: My one small quibble with Permanent Exile is the mix
column2: and this is really a matter of taste; I tend to prefer a more layered hardcore-style mix in which the bass and guitar are slightly disentangled and the vocals just under the surface rather than a more metal-style mix in which the bass and guitar lay thick in the middle and the vocals sit directly on top. There are plenty of records from the original crossover thrash mini-boom of the mid-'80s that are mixed exactly like this one
column3: so it’s not that it’s not the right sound for the subgenre. It’s just that crossover thrash is a continuum
column4: and I tend to prefer recordings that lay closer to the set of hardcore production aesthetics than the metal ones.

column1: Whatever your particular sonic subgenre production style allegiance is

column7:
crabbiest scene vet sit up and take notice.

column1: Built to Spill albums have themes
column2: but they fit loosely
column3: like the stretched-out tees and flannels Martsch wears onstage. Perfect from Now On was cosmic; Keep It Like a Secret explored miscommunication; There Is No Enemy seemed haunted by personal loss
column4: unspecific but sharply painful. (""It doesn’t matter if you’re good or smart/ Goddamn it

column7: when I woke up

column1: This is the point to note that if you’ve loved Built to Spill’s music your whole life

column1: Still
column2: the familiarity of Built to Spill is a balm

column4: no one’s much different
column5: someone’s hair is longer or shorter

column7: everything drops out for him to play a little three-note figure surrounded by silence

column9: too"")

column6: he sings

column1: In general

There is even some audible self-deprecation creeping into his song titles: On There Is No Enemy

column7: Jewel gets his first real score
column8: writing a soundtrack that runs excess of 90 minutes.

column1: Jewel doesn’t really deal in concision
column2: at least not in album form. His Themes For an Imaginary Film
column3: released under the Symmetry guise
column4: stretched to around two hours
column5: while Chromatics’ acclaimed Kill for Love clocks in at a similar length to this score
column6: indulging in multifarious impulses along the way. Jewel's ease with writing frosted
column7: clipped pop songs (Chromatics' ""Yes""
column8: from this album
column9: is a great example) provides a fascinating contrast to the way he approaches bigger works. Jewel might be trying to make his own Tusk or Screamadelica
column10: but he hasn't managed a consistent project yet
column11: leaving behind a handful of works that sometimes fall on the wrong side of indulgence. He’s enviably talented
column12: but with each passing album his lack of editing feels more like an Achilles heel.

column1: The material on Lost River falls into three categories. There’s Jewel's familiar
column2: heavily opiated glassy pop
column3: represented by Chromatics
column4: Desire
column5: and Glass Candy; a stretch of drifty
column6: incidental film music; and moments culled directly from the cast of the film
column7: including vocal turns by actors Red Kateb
column8: Ben Mendelsohn (channeling his inner Nick Cave)
column9: and former Possum Dixon frontman Rob Zabrecky. Jewel sequences these contrasting bits to make it sound like the music is emerging from a dream. Even the '50s R&B of Billy Ward & his Dominoes
column10: included here in a brief interlude
column11: sounds like it’s floating in from an abstract plane. Jewel finds unlikely common ground between his contemporary work
column12: music for the ages
column13: and drone-y instrumental pieces.

column1: Again
column2: though
column3: Jewel's include-everything impulse works against him. Chromatics’ ""Yes"" is the standout
column4: alternating between haunting and beautiful passages
column5: perfectly strung across a tightrope of bliss and unease. But there’s no need for three versions of it to be included on the soundtrack
column6: and the three versions of ""Deep Purple"" and two versions of ""Tell Me"" feel equally excessive. It’s a shame
column7: because Saoirse Ronan's powerful version of ""Tell Me"" may have had more weight if it was just a standalone. Chromatics’ version of ""Blue Moon""
column8: originally featured on the Running from the Sun outtakes compilation
column9: works precisely because it emerges from the gloom
column10: strikes a chord
column11: and never returns.

column1: There’s a trove of solo Jewel compositions outside of the song-oriented tracks here
column2: most of them leaning toward ambient and occasionally bringing to mind Tangerine Dream’s incidental film music. Shorn of context
column3: there isn’t much to hold onto—a tough gap to bridge whenever film music is removed from its visual stimulus. The depth and breadth of this album makes it feel archival
column4: as if someone excavated Jewel’s vaults for material long after the film was released—possibly an unfortunate downside of the exhaustive boom soundtracks have been undergoing in the past decade or so
column5: where every last scrap of B-movie music warrants a $45 luxury vinyl release. This is a cut above the rest
column6:
but listening to it occasionally feels like sifting through a yard sale looking for gold.

The Children of the Night
column2: the glorious third album from Swedish metal charmers Tribulation
column3: begins with an invitation. A backdrop of cello
column4: church organ and piano gives way to a midtempo full-band rumble
column5: and then Johannes Andersson grunts like a mad old man curling a finger and commanding you to come along. ""Beckoning the children of the night
column6: the spirits of the undead and the lesser lights
column7: he sings on ""Strange Gateways Beckon"". These first two minutes suggest the beginning of some grand adventure—a Tolkien-like walk through the woods
column8: a Dante-like descent into depravity. And they are: A heavy metal record that wanders beyond any comfort zone
column9: the hour-long The Children of the Night is a sprawling
column10: compulsory tale that doesn’t turn dull.

column1: Tribulation have never made an album quite like this: More than a decade ago
column2: most of the band played adolescent
column3: hair-whipping trash as Hazard. Five years after a name change
column4: they re-emerged with The Horror
column5: a claustrophobic mixture of death metal
column6: black metal and thrash
column7: intertwined by arty interludes that suggested major ambition. They pursued it unapologetically and even to excess on 2013’s The Formulas of Death
column8: which began with a tambura drone and ended with a shape-shifting 13-minute mess called ""Apparitions"".

column1: On The Children of the Night
column2: Tribulation push all those influences and ideas toward the center. It’s as if they’ve pondered the relatively populist successes of their fellow countrymen—Ghost B.C.
column3: In Flames
column4: even Watain—and rediscovered the value of concision and motion. Psych rock and prog metal
column5: thrash and classic rock commingle in three-to-seven-minute songs
column6: bearing echoes of not just Mercyful Fate and At the Gates but Led Zeppelin and Hawkwind
column7: the Doors and dub. Led by brilliant guitarists Jonathan Hultén and Adam Zaars
column8: these ten incisive songs cut away tangents and bristle with urgency. “Holy Libations”  is heroic and surging
column9: with one seeming crescendo and dashing solo piled atop another. The racing “Melancholia” powers through death metal before cresting with a rock-god solo that feels forever on the verge of falling apart.

column1: By and large
column2: though
column3: it’s the band that makes these songs so stunning
column4: not Andersson. He sings in a perpetually gruff monotone
column5: offering morose observations and dramatic revelations. During ""Holy Libations""
column6: he delivers a dense verse about the solidarity of misery and then tries his best to break his typical pace with a sort of staccato half-rap. He stumbles around the beat
column7: straining with effort. Tribulation
column8: then
column9: are a little like metal’s the Hold Steady—a righteous rock band burnished by high-flying guitars and big keyboards but led by a singer who seems to have shown up late for practice with a notebook full of quips and a belly full of booze.

column1: Tribulation let Andersson’s thorny vocals stand alone
column2: backing him only occasionally with harmonies; for a band that composes with near-classical rigor
column3: he remains the scratch that can’t be buffed. This tension becomes apparent when it disappears. Mid-album instrumental “Själaflykt” moves from doom-like dirge to mid-tempo boogie
column4: like The Ventures penning a summertime special for the Trans-Siberian Orchestra. But by song’s end
column5: the action feels bloated and defanged. When his growl bullies its way into “The Motherhood of God
column6: ” the friction is newly welcome.

column1: Metal critics sometimes snipe at each other for preferring extreme or arty metal to the sort of music to which actually raise beers and fists. There is no way to arrive at a consensus artist who will satisfy everyone
column2: of course
column3: but The Children of the Night comes close.  On one hand
column4: the irascible Andersson sounds like the kind of bandleader who hopes to follow you into an alley with a lead pipe. But the organ-loaded
column5: solo-bejeweled “Strains of Horror” is an anthem. The hook of “Strange Gateways Beckon” just begs to be shouted back at the band. Sure
column6: Andersson is a bit too brusque for complete crossover success
column7:
but the exceptional The Children of the Nightextends an open invitation to a very wide audience.

More and more
column2: it feels like the first thing a new death metal band decides is which older group to ape. Are you going to become a crusty Bolt Thrower clone? Dare you get as filthy as Autopsy? Do you set to write tributes to Obituary? These bands are all worth copying
column3: but who says you have to choose just one? Canadian quintet Abyss
column4: for one
column5: don’t think you do. On their debut full-length
column6: Heretical Anatomy
column7: the group soaks in several styles of old-school death metal
column8: overcoming the tyranny of influence to make an exciting tribute to the bands they love
column9: while also offering up something of their own.

column1: The opening title track splits the difference between two modes of Carcass worship; Necroticism’s refinement comes head to head with the rawness of Symphonies of Sickness. The track showcases Abyss’ penchant for borrowing from death metal’s legends
column2: creating faithful renditions packed with their own punk personality. Anatomy has plenty of Nordic riffs
column3: taken from the likes of Entombed and Carnage and then dipped in dirtier
column4: more American tar. The punk leanings really come through on the third track
column5: ""Chained to Extinction"": a bulldozer bass segues into a palm-muted Swedish refrain so on-point you’ll envision waves of bobbing blonde hair before it all eventually explodes into thrashing catharsis. This release makes vocalist David Kristiansen exert himself more
column6: going for an urgent hardcore yalp in line with the panicked rhythms.

column1: ""Flesh Cult"" is even more to the point
column2: sounding like a death metal interpretation of Kristiansen’s main group
column3: powerviolence band Column of Heaven. (It’s worth noting that he
column4: along with CoH bassist Andrew Nolan and drummer Eric King
column5: had a punky death metal group called Slaughter Strike between 2009 and 2011.) And
column6: while it may seem like a strange quality for death metal
column7: Abyss know when enough is enough. ""The Atonement"" flirts with Incantation-style dirge
column8: but the affair ends there. To exploit it would take away from Anatomy’s energy. ""Thrall of the Elder Gods"" is their slowest and longest
column9: but it’s also a lesson in conservation. They’re able to drive the same terror from a cliffhanger riff as they do a full-on blastbeat-ridden assault.

column1: Of all the influences
column2: one is the most prominent: Flint
column3: Michigan grindcore pioneers Repulsion. Beneath their macabre obsessions and noisy racket
column4: there was a rock'n'roll heart beating at the center of their sound. Abyss could be likened to Repulsion with a cut and a shave: the presentation may be a little cleaner
column5: but the hunger doesn’t subside. Much of Repulsion’s youthful stride is found in how Abyss execute their riffs; there’s no joking around
column6: but they still swing like Paul Speckmann and Chris Reifert just brought fresh kegs to the best death metal house party ever. You can hear that in the intro to ""Atonement""
column7: where leads scamper around frantically
column8: while remaining in sync with the rest of the band. Closer ""Nightmares in Skin"" also bears a heavy Repulsion branding
column9: while maintaining some Swedish sickness.

column1: While Abyss clearly bounce between styles
column2: Anatomy resembles
column3: in spirit
column4: the formative days of death metal
column5: where it hadn’t quite weaned itself off its thrash
column6: Discharge
column7: and Motörhead. Forms hadn’t jelled and folks hadn't gotten too serious just yet. Strange as it may sound
column8: Anatomy is one of the most flat-out fun death metal records to come out in some time. It doesn’t strain and break its neck to be ""funny
column9:
it’s just an unpretentious but still interesting collection from a fresh new face.

On Speedy Ortiz’s 2013 debut Major Arcana
column2: Sadie Dupuis crafted her barbed-wire wordplay into wounded callouts of those who had hurt her. Now
column3: she's wielding it like a weapon. Foil Deer
column4: the Massachusetts indie rock traditionalists' sophomore full-length
column5: opens with Dupuis noting on ""Good Neck"" that she's good with a knife and she knows when to use it. She takes a lap around the block to cool down—like all good bosses should—before coming back with a world-beating declaration of autonomy on “Raising the Skate”: “I'm chief
column6: not the overthrown/ Captain
column7: not a crony/So if you wanna row
column8: you better have an awfully big boat.”

column1: With Foil Deer
column2: Dupuis doesn't scold; she warns. The album is ferocious and visceral
column3: the lyrics gleaming with threats involving sharp blades both literal and figurative (""Don't ever touch my blade
column4: you fool/ You'll be cursed for a lifetime
column5: she taunts knowingly on ""Dot X""). As Dupuis grows more self-possessed
column6: she and her bandmates veer into their most ambitious compositions to date. Knotty melodies shift gears in an instant
column7: giving Foil Deer a jumpy
column8: enthralling energy. God bless ‘em
column9: Speedy believe that every song ideally should have three or four musical ideas.

column1: For its first 47 seconds
column2: ""Zig"" scans like vintage folk-pop until the song abruptly steers into a thorny chunk of dissonance led by Dupuis’ contrasting falsetto. A minute passes and it sounds like yet another song—a much more melodic thing this time—before a nightmarish jumble of riffs and cymbals grinds the pace to a halt. A defeated Dupuis wonders aloud ""How many laps does it take to decide you’re back at the start?"" as she and her bandmates double back on the the song’s original theme. It’s a clever construction
column3: representing just how much thought went into crafting each of these songs.

column1: In Speedy Ortiz
column2: both the music and lyrics work overtime
column3: bringing a surplus of conflicting ideas to the table that they somehow manage to cram into tight spaces. The magic is that they never sound overworked
column4: and in fact when they go more straighforward—""Puffer""
column5: for instance
column6: in which they try the pleather sleaze of '90s industrial rock on for size—it feels like not quite enough by comparison. Despite its clever kiss-offs (""Take me off your list or elect a lobotomy"")
column7: the chipper pop-punk of ""Swell Content"" would have sufficed on last year’s Real Hair EP
column8: but here it feels like filler. It goes to show that the members of Speedy Ortiz can barely keep up with their own progress.

column1: Dupuis
column2: a recent MFA candidate in poetry at UMass Amherst
column3: is among the most talented lyricists of her musical class. She writes vivid-yet-mysterious scenes that require interpretive work on the listeners' behalf—such as ""My Dead Girl""
column4: a cryptic tale about living fast and risking becoming a missing face on a milk carton. But Dupuis’ greatest strength as a lyricist is her ability to turn her sour experiences into anthems about clawing back from self-doubt. On Foil Deer
column5: Dupuis makes standing up for yourself—in the face of double standards
column6: struggles with addiction
column7: and the general carelessness of youth—sound like a no-brainer
column8: but she also never tries to hide how complicated everything can be. As the band continues to evolve around and with her
column9:
Speedy Ortiz’s music finally sounds as complex as its leader dares to be.

Composer and producer Squarepusher (nee Tom Jenkinson) is almost always up to something. I mean this not in the sense that he is prolific (though he is)
column2: but that with each new release
column3: he tweaks his sound
column4: experimenting with new textures
column5: technologies or conceptual limitations. Fairweather fans who lose track of his movements for awhile are usually surprised
column6: in one way or another
column7: when they return to sample whatever he’s working on. A new Squarepusher album is usually repelling
column8: intriguing (possibly more in theory than practice) or captivating; more often
column9: it's a little of all three.

column1: On Damogen Furies
column2: his first solo LP in three years
column3: Jenkinson is in (the Squarepusher version of) pop mode. He grounds his unrelentingly brittle
column4: electronic compositions with catchy synth melodies. Though his customary warp-speed drum loops still run off the rails
column5: he relegates them to the role of accompaniment. Dynamics are largely dispensed with—the range is loud to extremely loud. It’s an approach he prototyped on his last album
column6: Ufabulum. For live shows around that time
column7: he adopted a new
column8: flashy stage act
column9: donning a Boba Fett-like LED helmet
column10: and incorporating a complex light show of blinding flashing matrices dancing around his podium. Suddenly
column11: like the great masked dance music connoisseurs of today
column12: he became no longer just a guy with a laptop— he was suddenly
column13: perhaps
column14: someone capable of bigger
column15: more zeitgeist-riding things.

column1: Damogen Furies is less subtle and funky than Ufabulum
column2: but it’s more focused. Here
column3: Jenkinson commits to one primary thematic idea per song
column4: and develops and interrupts it within the bounds of a clear larger structure. Tracks like opener ""Stor Eiglass"" and ""Exjag Nives"" introduce pleasant
column5: portamento synth melodies that develop cleverly
column6: spaced out with breakbeat and boiled wah-bass interludes. Tracks like these are the closest Squarepusher has gotten to festival-ready EDM.

column1: But he pushes against these sometimes-generic breakbeats
column2: in his perverse way
column3: tossing in conflicting elements and then rending everything apart into errant bits of space trash
column4: like a child building a LEGO castle and then hurling his blocks in the air. ""Rayc Fire 2"" is a good (and non-anxiety-inducing) example: Beginning with a mechanistic
column5: mid-tempo groove and pointillistic melody
column6: it becomes increasingly fragmented and fitful
column7: interrupted by jazz fusion-informed flights of fancy. The similarly restless ""Kontenjaz"" breaks down into rhythmic semi-choas
column8: its meter deteriorating in a way that has more to do with Ornette Coleman & Prime Time than The Richard D. James Album.

column1: Moments like these get at what is most interesting about Squarepusher’s work. Even on an album as wholly electronic-sounding as Damogen Furies
column2: Jenkinson's musicality remains organic and responsive. Rather than using technology to surpass the limitations of live acoustic instruments
column3: he creates moments of human flexibility with it (see also his music for robot performers from last year). It is this exploratory drive which has always made him notable
column4:
the the face behind his many musical masks.

Ellis Ludwig-Leone
column2: who records as San Fermin
column3: studied composition at Yale University
column4: served as a musical assistant under Nico Muhly and is a young
column5: pop-classical fixture in New York City. It all sounds quite a lot like the backstory of Dave Longstreth

column7: and the resultant record followed suit with highbrow
column8: heavily orchestrated chamber indie with literary aspirations. Ludwig-Leone remains the project’s primary songwriter
column9: composer
column10: arranger and lyricist
column11: but he takes the focus off himself for Jackrabbit
