column13: eight-person touring band. Once again
column14: the experience is more likely to make you think of other indie A-listers rather than San Fermin.

column1: This was mostly true of San Fermin as well
column2: though it had a debut’s charm. Ludwig-Leone had chops and taste; perhaps a distinct point of view would emerge with experience and time. And besides
column3: its unwieldy ambitions were welcome at a time when the Decemberists

column4: get lost in ""The Woods""
column5: and fall ""down

column7: down the rabbit hole"" without much further elaboration. Kaye’s features are more enjoyable

column10: and they allow you to indulge in some circa-2005 indie rock fantasy booking: What if Sufjan Stevens got a hold of Amber Coffman and put her at the forefront of his most bombastic Illinois orchestrations? That’s pretty much the pitch for ""Jackrabbit"" and ""Philosopher""
column11: songs where Ludwig-Leone’s bold melodies and gushing orchestration have a vocalist who can keep up.

column1: And at the very least
column2: Kaye’s songs tend to evoke several bands at once. Allen Tate
column3: however
column4: has either never heard the National or has never listened to any band other than the National. There’s no other way to explain the staggering degree to which Allen Tate sounds exactly like Matt Berninger. Not Leonard Cohen
column5: not Mark Kozelek
column6: or anyone else in the lineage of dour
column7: baritone barstool bards. Just Matt Berninger. His vocals are subject to the same exact cadences
column8: the exact melodic contours
column9: the same wink-and-nod affectations
column10: the same grim humor
column11: the same vocabulary. When Tate takes the lead
column12: San Fermin becomes the equivalent of a shaky music biopic
column13: completely compromised by the uncanny valley effect of having someone not quite be the person he constantly reminds you of. The script
column14: the setting
column15: the soundtrack—all of it is rendered moot.

column1: Worse yet
column2: the melodramatic production on ""Emily"" and ""Woman in Red"" ensures they can't even pass as pleasant mimicry. The wearying volume of Jackrabbit is the most taxing aspect of a record that already arrives intentionally overstuffed. Ludwig-Leone has revealed himself to be a pop maximalist
column3: as even the minute-long interludes are given to Backdraft-like bursts of horns and strings. Maybe the guy's heart is truly in theater
column4:
as Jackrabbit's overwrought spectacle unintentionally doubles as ""Indie Rock in the Aughts: The Musical.""

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21661/homepage_large.8d2c0ad2.jpg|The Early Years EP|31978.0|Girl Band|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rough Trade']|2015-04-20 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:07.077999|"

The obvious joke with Girl Band is that the Irish quartet features no girls (and not everyone’s laughing)
column2: but really
column3: the bigger misdirection lies in calling themselves a band. Sure
column4: their composition conforms to standard punk-rock parameters—yelping singer
column5: fuzzbox-tweaking guitarist and bassist
column6: pugilistic drummer—but even at its most ferocious
column7: their music lacks the emotionally raw
column8: primal catharsis we associate with post-hardcore acts. They come off more like steely lab technicians administering shock treatment for dubious purposes. You don’t so much listen to a Girl Band song as get strapped into it: militaristic drum stomps mimic the beat of your pounding heart; foreboding
column9: unidentifiable noises emerge suddenly from unseen corners seemingly by the push of a button; and
column10: as they pile on the punishment with sadistic glee
column11: your convulsions effectively form a new dance move.

column1: It’s a drill that Girl Band have been gradually perfecting over the past two years
column2: through a string of singles that have showcased their bone-crushing force
column3: but through markedly different demonstrations
column4: be it 25-second circle-pit blurts or updates of songs by everyone from Beat Happening to Blawan. While these tracks have been compiled by Rough Trade on The Early Years to introduce Girl Band to North American audiences
column5: the EP is also a snapshot of a band still figuring out how to harness the nihilistic noise of punk and the architectural precision of dance music without conforming to the conventions of either.

column1: It’s no insult to say that Girl Band’s signature song at this point is a cover—because it's one that perfectly encapsulates both their antagonistic essence and unorthodox methodology. Their grueling distension of Blawan’s ""Why They Hide Their Bodies Under My Garage""from 2013 not only betrayed a vision that looked far beyond punk for inspiration
column2: but proved to be an ideal vehicle for frontman Dara Kiely to assert his split personality: part arch absurdist
column3: part panic-attacked nervous wreck. The band’s hammering 2014 single ""Lawman"" further entrenched these sarcastic/spastic extremes
column4: though
column5: after the past year of awful police-related headlines
column6: the satirical non sequitirs (""He starts every sentence with 'I know I’m not a racist
column7: but…'"") and the song’s violent meltdown climax have acquired an accidental
column8: uncomfortably topical resonance.

column1: Girl Band’s singular qualities are best appreciated in these longer tracks
column2: which clear adequate space for Kiely's wild mood swings
column3: while affording the band enough time to experiment and find just the right dissonant frequencies to power their apocalyptic finales. The more concentrated songs
column4: naturally
column5: give them less to do: the rumble through Beat Happening’s ""I Love You"" is ultimately more a reverential nod to Girl Band’s smart-ass indie ancestors than something they try to fully claim as their own
column6: while the group were in such a rush to unleash half-minute no-fi thrasher ""The Cha Cha Cha"" that they seemingly neglected to master it properly. But ""De Bom Bom"" marks the point where Girl Band’s primordial aggression and burgeoning ambitions start to coalesce
column7: packing all the textural disorientation and mounting intensity of their extended workouts into a taut
column8: three-and-a-half-minute shot.

column1: Like the Girl Band name itself
column2: the title of The Early Years is a silly joke—for one
column3: the EP doesn’t even include the band’s earliest recordings (that would be 2012’s France 98 mini-album)
column4: and the period that it faux-nostalgically canonizes covers a mere 19-month span that ended just last summer. But the mercurial
column5: combustible potential within suggests we may not be laughing at it for much longer—like patron saints Liars’ equally feral 2001 debut
column6:
The Early Years could one day seem like a mere baby step for a band that has evolved into something even more imposing.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21750/homepage_large.2231a187.jpg|Mars Is a Very Bad Place For Love|32871.0|The Breathing Effect|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Alpha Pup']|2015-04-20 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:07.631246|"

column5: toes a line between traditional and turn up. As a unit

column7: it scans as ""jazz fusion
column8: but the results conjure '70s R&B as well as the contemporary Los Angeles beat scene and hip-hop. Clearly
column9: Goss and Terrell study Pink Floyd and the Soft Machine
column10: but it seems they dig Thundercat and Stevie Wonder
column11: too.

column1: The genesis of the Breathing Effect can be traced to its fascinating 2014 EP
column2: on which Goss and Terrell spread aquatic rhythms over five tracks. From ""Layers of Thought"" to ""Losing My Mind""
column3: the resulting mixture was equally soothing and mesmerizing; the EP as a whole worked just as well under clear or gray skies. Mars is more upbeat than its predecessor
column4: though the opening tunes—""Forestial Things"" and ""Cloudy Afternoon""—continue the EP’s mellow ambience. Yet by the third song
column5: the two-tiered ""Cold Meteor Showers""
column6: Goss and Terrell hit a stride.

column1: In a way
column2: Mars plays like musical theater: It’s driven by space travel
column3: and follows the story of two lovers cruising the galaxy with no concept of time. Tracks like ""One for the Mountains By the Sea"" and ""Twenty Years Altogether"" recall spacious isolation
column4: of couples escaping life’s hustle to be alone with each other. It’s a notion evoked on album standout
column5: ""Weightless Reality""
column6: where Goss
column7: Terrell and guest vocalist Kalia Vandever sing of a fantasy world of waterfalls and underwater utopia.<span> Whether or not they’re depicting planet Mars is anyone’s guess.  Still
column8: the music conveys a very real narrative while using few words
column9: which is usually a tough task for most instrumental albums.

column1: The vocals
column2: sparing as they are
column3: come from Goss
column4: Terrell
column5: Vandever and Michael Mayo<span>
column6: who tend to float along the periphery of the music
column7: underlining the instrumentals. On ""Streetlights Out of Focus""
column8: Mayo drifts softly
column9: his wails a breezy compliment to Goss and Terrell’s composition. And of all the great things happening here—the Isley Brothers vibe on ""Fireflies""
column10: the dense layers of ""Visions""—you can actually feel the melodies
column11: which remain at the forefront even though the music drifts in all directions. The blend seeps into the background if you let it
column12: but dominates your attention in headphones
column13: played loudly. ""Rising Inside""—the LP’s best song and one of the group’s finest to date—uses swift percussion
column14: bright synths and a Vocoder
column15: working up a loud bounce that would fit comfortably within rap circles and jazz crowds
column16:
two sects that couldn’t be farther apart these days. It’s a grand culmination for the Breathing Effect: experimental jazz with the potential for huge resonance.

column3: and
column4: it should go without saying

column10: to its strength and detriment

""Pilot"" and the title track to me recall none other than Big Black—drum machine-led walls of sound that break down and start up again as Tyler struggles to be heard over the noise. He is friends with Toro Y Moi’s Chaz Bundick (who makes an anonymous appearance on filler track ""Run"")

KMD's Black Bastards (sometimes stylized as Bl_ck B_st_rds) has become one of the more storied albums in hip-hop
column2: and with good reason—its route to consumer ears was at first barred
column3: then clandestine
column4: then piecemeal and underground. But before the album was even semi-properly released
column5: it
column6: by all accounts
column7: birthed MF DOOM
column8: who is perhaps the most revered
column9: enigmatic popular underground rapper of the past twenty years. It's not conjecture or a stretch to say that the Black Bastards story is DOOM's origin story
column10: and without it there's no Madvillainy
column11: no Special Herbs
column12: no reason for Mos Def to make seven cover videos
column13: no metal-faced Villain getting barred from all bars and kicked out the Carvel.

column1: Originally scheduled for a 1994 release
column2: Black Bastards was shelved by Elektra Records—ostensibly due to the album's incendiary and controversial artwork—less than a month before it was set to be in stores. The shuttling itself was reportedly low on ceremony and dialogue
column3: but the conversation around the album was not. Billboard columnists Terri Rossi and Havelock Nelson had taken offense to the Black Bastards project in separate columns; The Source magazine editor Jon Shecter
column4: meanwhile
column5: rebutted with an editorial titled ""Corporate Hysteria""
column6: writing
column7: ""[A]s we've seen over the years
column8: it doesn't take much for the bottom-line bigwigs of big business to flip on hip-hop. It seems inevitable that the raw honesty of many rap records would offend enough of mainstream America to put the product at odds with the company selling it.""

column1: Elektra's decision was based in both fiscal and political realities. Much like Epic Records has abandoned Bobby Shmurda in wake of their sister company Sony Pictures Entertainment's email hack
column2: Elektra washed their hands of KMD in no small part because of their sister label and distributor's troubles. Warner Bros. had already suffered a stinging blow in 1992
column3: when shareholders voted to remove Ice-T's ""Cop Killer"" from his metal side-project Body Count after protracted finger-pointing and naysaying from then-President George H. W. Bush
column4: Vice President Dan Quayle
column5: and co-founder of the Parents Music Resource Center (and future Second Lady) Tipper Gore. This was the struggle that birthed the current version of the black-and-white Parental Advisory label; one that included Dan Quayle pressuring Time Warner to pull 2Pacalypse Now off shelves.

column1: The shelving was the second blow that the group would suffer. A year before
column2: KMD—which had whittled down to a duo
column3: losing Onyx The Birthstone Kid
column4: who performed on their masterful 1991 debut
column5: Mr. Hood—had effectively ceased to exist as a group when Dingilizwe Dumile
column6: aka DJ Subroc
column7: was struck by a car and killed while crossing the Long Island Expressway. Subroc's brother
column8: Daniel Dumile—then known as Zev Love X
column9: now known as MF DOOM—was left to finish the album. It was these twin tragedies that led to Daniel becoming the man in the iron mask; and it's the legend that defines Black Bastards
column10: which is now getting <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/news/58800-doom-reissues-kmds-black-bastards-in-childrens-pop-up-book-package/"">its most glamorous re-release yet
column11: some twenty-one years later.

column1: Given the backstory
column2: it's no wonder that Black Bastards is being treated like a plot device from the Star Wars reboot. This latest reissue fetishizes the album to the extreme—it's a children's pop-up book. (Rare advance copies and copies of copies have existed since the '90s; in 2001 and 2008
column3: it was made available
column4: respectively by Sub Verse and DOOM's own Metalface Records
column5: the latter who is also responsible for this version.) Black Bastards is often hailed as the best rap album that you've never heard
column6: and this newest reintroduction is not likely to change that: It's targeted exclusively towards collectors and archivists—most of whom would already have the music.

column1: Still
column2: it's apropos
column3: given KMD's tone—they released their first album as teenagers and it featured wide-eyed gazes on heady topics
column4: all delivered with the help of excerpts from foreign language tapes
column5: children's audios
column6: Malcolm X and ""Sesame Street"" characters.   Mr. Hood was whimsical and pointed and prescient—""Bananapeel Blues"" hosted a spoken-word mediation on race with a sped-up Gil Scott-Heron sample (from ""H2Ogate Blues"": ""How much more evidence do the citizens need?"") that is still embarrassingly poignant today when the cultural spectacle of Black men being murdered by police has become social media snuff porn.

column1: But Black Bastards was so much more and less than its predecessor. It was always a very good record
column2: a promising one—but not a great one. Musically
column3: it sounds like a mid-'90s rap record—copious samples of jazz and R&B over big
column4: dirty drums. It's more angry and less fun that what came before it
column5: but also more intimate and less expansive. Where Mr. Hood focused on the big themes out there
column6: Black Bastards turned inward
column7: dealing with the personal coming-of-age revelations. It's largely the story of two devout followers of Dr. York's Nuwaubianism struggling with the vices of the carnal world. ""Sweet Premium Wine"" is about their newfound love of alcohol—""I don't drink
column8: I guzzle 'til I'm distorted."" On ""Contact Blitt""
column9: they treat smoking weed the way ""Game of Thrones"" treats magic— something wondrous but common
column10: like dragons.

column1: At the time of Black Bastards
column2: corporate rap was still in its infancy
column3: and the music industry was deeply entrenched as a trickle-down gerontocracy
column4: one where the voices of power were largely disconnected from the street-level youth that it fed upon. Harder songs on the album
column5: like ""Get-U-Now"" and ""Gimme!""
column6: can be seen not only as a response to self and label expectations
column7: but also a document of rap's darkening tone and the rites of passage that both entail. When the album deals with women on ""Plumskinzz""
column8: it's deeply lascivious: ""Damned
column9: I wouldn't want my plum to turn prune/ Unless it be all that
column10: be all that/ It won't matter 'cause black sweet ones come fatter/ I'm kinda
column11: kinda picky with my fruit mix."" It's a far cry from the jingly innocence of Mr. Hood's ""Peach Fuzz"" and as genuinely awkward as burgeoning sexual awareness.

column1: Despite the album's title and artwork
column2: Black Bastards is much less direct about racial politics than Mr. Hood. Where Mr. Hood was incisive and righteous
column3: Black Bastards is searching and confused.   None of this makes it any less worthy of a listen—there's something that's still very real and new about hearing the group move through their emotional spaces. Moreso than listening to the birth of MF DOOM
column4: it's the death of KMD
column5: not just the group
column6: but of both of the guys who made Mr. Hood. And for all of its darkness
column7: there's the unbridled brightness of growing artists still exploring the limits of their medium and textures of their own voices. There's a glee in Subroc's voice when he begins rapping on ""It Sounded Like a Roc!"": ""It's my thing/ Yo
column8: it's my thing/ The way I swing
column9: not even an orangutan can hang/ On my ding! ding!/ Saved by the bell rang/ I talk
column10: yell
column11: whisper
column12:
mumble street slang."" It's like wacky Nicki Minaj meets To Pimp a Butterfly and it's the kind of rap that just couldn't be released today. Or rather it can. But only in a pop-up book.

The beaches and deserts of Los Santos
column3: one of the settings for the Grand Theft Auto franchise
column4: sometimes felt as if designed by
column5: or at least for
column6: their soundtrack. While Grand Theft Auto V's radio stations followed in the tradition of all GTA soundtracks—disc after disc of meticulously curated mood music
column7: organized by genre—it felt more essentially of the game-world than its predecessors. It was also much larger. Where once there was a rap station

column1: But if GTAV was a digital space meant to evoke and satirize a real-world one
column2: Welcome to Los Santos is engineered to do the opposite. It is a real-world product meant to inspire memories of your time in a digital world. Compiled by Oh No and the Alchemist

column4: say

Its panoply of guests and tones suggests not the well-curated sampling of a film soundtrack or the ambient pulse of the best video game soundtracks but the high-quality ephemerality of a Gorillaz record. It’s been more than 10 years since Great Lake Swimmers released their self-titled debut. Recorded in an empty Ontario grain silo
column2: it was mostly Tony Dekker’s acoustic guitar and honeyed voice singing about silent films and the natural world. The album seemed at first like an ideal sedative—its hushed reverberating folk songs are enhanced with the sound of actual crickets chirping. But the songs were too engaging and eventful to be lullabies.

column1: On A Forest of Arms

column7: reprising nearly the same lyrics in closing track ""Expecting You"". Once was nice
column8: twice is overkill.

column1: It’s probably no coincidence this album’s best tracks are the ones where Dekker is singing in a cave with only subtle accompaniment. ""Don’t Leave Me Hanging"" is gorgeous—simple and direct. ""You had different hair when I saw you last
column2: Dekker sings
column3: delicately fingerpicking amid the violins
column4: before pleading for his lover (and/or a bird) not to leave him hanging and ""drowning in shallow water.""

column1: The natural world consistently elicits a contagious sense of awe from Dekker. The album takes its title from a line in ""The Great Bear""
column2: another song in this vein. ""You won’t believe what’s out there
column3: he sings
column4: and and he's convincing. These moments are as absorbing as those old grain-silo songs
column5: with the same sort of hypnotic pull
column6: as you picture the winding streams and forests Dekker traces. But too often
column7:
he strays from the hushed mode he's mastered and ends up supplanting the band’s strengths with its weaknesses.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21687/homepage_large.4cf4d70b.jpg|Commissions II|28187.0|Oneohtrix Point Never|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2015-04-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:11.257019|"

Since 2010
column2: Daniel Lopatin's Oneohtrix Point Never project has never remained in one place for long. Returnal melded the analog synth tapestries of his earliest output to extreme noise
column3: while the very next year Replica ditched the keys almost entirely to delve into mesmeric loop songs. But by 2013’s masterful R Plus Seven
column4: Lopatin was exploring the plasticity of synthesized computer sound: shape-shifting church organs into marimbas
column5: rave anthem tropes into synthesized tropicalia
column6: majestic choirs into intimate female coos.

column1: Following on the heels of last year's Commissions I
column2: this Record Store Day EP documents Lopatin's most recent series of commissions
column3: from two projects situated in Japan. For an artist who overhauls his aesthetic with almost every full-length release
column4: suggesting someone whose identity is as reliable as Mystique
column5: such stop gaps become a necessity for keeping track of his discography. Commissioned by Red Bull Music Academy in Tokyo last November
column6: the first half of the EP
column7: ""Bullet Hell Abstraction""
column8: serves as homage to the popular danmaku (sometimes translated as ""bullet curtain"" or ""bullet hell"") scrolling shooter video games popular in the late '90s
column9: a sensory overload of firepower
column10: swarming enemies and explosions.

column1: The opening volley of ""Bullet Hell Abstraction I"" suggests that Lopatin can mimic thrash metal guitars and make sawed metal dissonance with the best of them (additionally
column2: he also throws in some drill'n'bass delirium worthy of his Warp labelmates). But such a racket barely lasts past the minute mark before dissolving into shrapnel shards
column3: the elegant ambient drift that was the hallmark of early OPN. From there the track moves in spurts and stops. ""Bullet Hell Abstraction III"" (""BHA II"" and ""IV"" were exclusive to the live concert
column4: according to the label) meanwhile opens with some of the wonky fusion-funk that Lopatin likes to reference with side gigs like Ford & Lopatin and Chuck Person. The piece begins with a shiny
column5: overblown theme that’s soon pulled apart like taffy
column6: knotting together high frequencies
column7: white noise
column8: and shimmering keys in a scrambled manner last heard on Returnal’s ""‡ Nil Admirari"" and rarely revisited since.

column1: The highlight of Commissions II comes on the 19-minute opus ""Suite from Magnetic Rose"". Commissioned by Abandon Normal Devices and performed as a live accompaniment in Manchester to Koji Morimoto’s 1995 anime film Magnetic Rose (itself part of a trilogy of short anime from multiple animators entitled Memories)
column2: it’s perhaps Lopatin’s most sumptuous and satisfying long-form piece of music to date. ""Magnetic Rose"" feels like the summation of Seven's explorations
column3: quicksilver in its changes in some regards
column4: yet also taking time to fully revel in some of its most exquisite moments. Electrified water drips turn into weightless drones
column5: Japanese koto plucks melt into bell-like tones. And while parts of R Plus Seven flashed mere glimpses of hallucinatory chorale passages
column6: the latter half of ""Magnetic Rose"" expands these sounds to majestic proportions
column7: evoking those haunting György Ligeti-scored moments of Stanley Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey
column8: be it the black monolith or eerie deep space drift. With a forthcoming collaboration with Antony Hegarty announced as well as a new studio album in the works
column9: one wonders if this might be our last glimpse at this particular side of Lopatin’s polygonal sound. If so
column10:
it makes for a satisfying souvenir.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21650/homepage_large.f6114432.jpg|Little Earthquakes|83.0|Tori Amos|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Rhino']|2015-04-16 00:00:00|1992|2016-06-11 16:12:11.815757|"

Myra Ellen Amos got used to dazzling and perplexing adults early on. At age 5 she became the youngest-ever student to enroll at Johns Hopkins University’s Peabody Institute. At 11
column2: she was thrown out due to her inability to sight-read as well as she could play by ear. At 13
column3: she started performing at Washington
column4: D.C.’s piano bars
column5: some of them gay
column6: where—chaperoned by her pastor dad in his clerical collar—she’d take requests and try out her own material. And by 24
column7: she tasted failure when her band Y Kant Tori Read released one Pat Benatar-esque 1988 album that instantly flopped as though it had never even existed.

column1: Being misrepresented on its cover as a sword-wielding
column2: flame-haired metal vixen forced Amos to take control of her image while struggling to satisfy expectations that her prodigious genius generated.  (""I had come from child prodigy to 'vapid bimbo
column3: ' "" she told Rolling Stone in 2009.) Still contracted to Atlantic Records
column4: she paired with former singer-songwriter Davitt Sigerson
column5: and then with paramour Eric Rosse
column6: but the label nixed both batches of results. So Amos kept on writing and recording
column7: streamlining her music until a tearful viewing of Thelma & Louise prompted a song that didn’t need any accompaniment whatsoever. After ""Me and a Gun""
column8: no suit dared argue that her album wasn’t finished.

column1: Whereas nearly all of her songs invite interpretation
column2: this one is unquestionably about Amos getting raped. She changed a few details: Her real-life attacker wielded not a gun but a knife
column3: and demanded that his victim sing hymns while he violated her. In the song
column4: Amos mimics simple regimented intervals learned from psalms. Abruptly she breaks free from this steady keel as if mirroring how her psyche detaches from her body in order to deal with what’s happening to her. ""Do you know Carolina where the biscuits are soft and sweet?"" she suddenly wails with startling force before returning to the song's melodic core to explain
column5: ""These things go through your head when there’s a man on your back and you’re pushed flat on your stomach.""

column1: This snapped Atlantic to its senses. Drawn almost exclusively from the initial reject pile
column2: Little Earthquakes finally appeared in early 1992
column3: right when Nirvana’s Nevermind topped the charts. Amos’ solo debut
column4: though it was rarely talked about this way
column5: was similarly radical—an alternately flirty and harrowing work that juxtaposed barbed truths against symphonic flights of fancy. It was lyrically nuanced and harmonically sophisticated exactly when grunge moved rock in a raw and brutish direction
column6: which made her achievement even more striking. Amos was early Queen
column7: early Elton John
column8: and early Kate Bush with Rachmaninoff chops. Decades after prog-rock’s peak
column9: her technical perfection was particularly shocking in the virtuoso-renouncing '90s: Not even Elton could tear into a song both vocally and instrumentally while staring down attendees with a Cheshire Cat grin.

column1: She did (and still does) this by straddling her piano bench like a lover with one foot pumping pedals and the other beating time
column2: as if sending out long-suppressed erotic urges directly through her music
column3: right at her audience. Listen to the live B-sides sequenced together at the end of each bonus disc that joins these reverently remastered editions of Little Earthquakes and Under the Pink
column4: and you’ll hear this carnal communion evolve: At first her delivery is slightly mannered
column5: and the crowd’s dead silent. But by the second disc
column6: she’s flowing freely
column7: and her following screams ecstatically in kind.

column1: Earthquakes
column2: serif;"">chronicles a woman coming to terms with post-traumatic stress disorder. As she’d much later
column3: serif;"">explore on 2007’s American Doll Posse
column4: serif;"">
column5: Amos had split her psyche into separate personas so she could deal with the pressure of being a both a minister’s daughter and prodigy. On this album
column6: Amos finds her truest primary voice
column7: no more so than on her inaugural U.S. single
column8: ""Silent All These Years""
column9: which chronicles that discovery in real time.

column1: It was here that she discovered how to obey her compositional muse: Establish a theme
column2: wander from it
column3: and then return via pop’s reassuring verse/chorus/verse structure. Amos would soon drift much
column4: much further from her motifs
column5: but here she’s uncommonly focused: The song’s circling introduction references her conservatory roots by evoking practice exercises
column6: yet it’s catchy
column7: and the bluntest moments in the melody fall exactly when Amos sings the title
column8: a reliable songwriter’s trick.

column1: Yet even in the singer’s most accessible song
column2: idiosyncrasies abound: From intro to opening verse
column3: the tempo slows drastically
column4: and remains irregular. Her right hand on the piano doesn’t always sync with what her left is doing and often accentuates different beats
column5: while her lyric references Satan and menstruation amidst soothing classical filigree. ""Sometimes
column6: I said
column7: sometimes I hear my voice
column8: she sings in a tone occasionally irked but ultimately joyful: Her real self
column9: muted since childhood
column10: finally comes out to play.

column1: For the outsider women and gay men who initially propelled Amos’ success
column2: this hard-won message served as a clarion call
column3: and they embraced her as if uncovering the challenging and most vulnerable parts of themselves. Tracy Chapman
column4: Melissa Etheridge
column5: Sarah McLachlan
column6: k.d. lang
column7: Sinéad O'Connor
column8: and the Indigo Girls had already begun to reach the same flock
column9: but Amos—by virtue of her sexual intensity and subject matter—instantly commanded a bond only rivaled by Madonna
column10: whose eroticism peaked just as Amos arrived. ""Look
column11: I’m standing naked before you/ Don’t you want more than my sex
column12: she teased in ""Leather"" over strutting chords that recall Queen’s ""Killer Queen"". Like Madonna
column13: Amos put earthly passions on display not necessarily to seduce her congregation
column14: but to empower herself—and
column15: by extension—her fans.

column1: The difference between '94’s Under the Pink and its predecessor was that by this time Amos had sold enough to keep Atlantic execs at bay. In their absence
column2: she and Rosse accentuated the orchestral pomp on some tracks while shrewdly deviating from it on others. Whereas she’d flatly rejected previous requests to replace Little Earthquakes’ pianos with guitars
column3: here she fits in a few fleetingly noisy ones and bolsters the beat until it grooves.

column1: These adjustments transformed Amos from rising singer-songwriter to major alt-rock upstart: ""Cornflake Girl""—the cartwheeling UK hit that preceded the album and showcases one of her spunkiest solos—helped Pink enter the UK chart at #1
column2: while ""God""—the grousing
column3: gnarly U.S. single—topped modern rock playlists. It’s nice that Sam Smith and Hozier subvert the religious overtones of their churchy presentations with orthodoxy-slamming videos
column4: but both lack the clarity and courage of Amos chanting
column5: ""God sometimes you just don’t come through.""

column1: The rest wasn’t as pointed as that
column2: but Pink’s extroverted arrangements worked as hard as Earthquakes’ lyrics and melodies. Amidst other overseas hits like ""Pretty Good Year""
column3: Amos dug deeper
column4: particularly on ""Bells for Her""
column5: which suggests a ghost pirouetting across John Cage’s prepared piano. The pitch on certain keys is way off
column6: like an old upright in your grandparents’ basement
column7: but the effect is finessed the way Jimi Hendrix bent notes from music to cacophony and back again. ""Can’t stop what’s coming
column8: she moans repeatedly while refusing to name her subject. Adulthood? The rupture of a childhood friendship? Orgasm? Amos’ mysteriousness sometimes subsequently got the best of her
column9: but here she masters it.

column1: Before
column2: during
column3: and immediately after these breakthroughs
column4: Amos generated enough outtakes
column5: covers
column6: remixes
column7: and live tracks to fill several UK and U.S. variations on each album’s many singles and EPs
column8: all of them designed to generate enough sales from devotees to force radio’s hand. Here
column9: on generous bonus discs
column10: they flow like autonomous albums; the Earthquakes addendum favors tracks Amos and Atlantic dropped in search of an ideal launch
column11: while the Pink supplement emphasizes the singer’s knack for reinventing her material on the fly.

column1: Leading with a disc-long alternate version of Earthquakes
column2: Amos’ 2006 box set A Piano: The Collection already argued that ""Upside Down"" and ""Flying Dutchman""—both Sigerson-produced
column3: string-wrapped efforts—equaled most everything that made the cut. Here
column4: those fan favorites better complement Amos’ impulsive material
column5: like ""Sweet Dreams""
column6: which rewrites David Bowie’s ""Panic in Detroit"" as a Gallic jig
column7: and ""The Pool""
column8: an eerie excursion in extended overdubbed vocal tones that proved Amos boasted the harmonic chops to become a credible avant-garde classical composer. As her many cover versions attest
column9: Amos honed discerning interpretive skills in her piano-bar adolescence: Her eerily funereal 1992 treatment of ""Smells Like Teen Spirit"" gently accentuates Kurt Cobain’s desperation while showcasing her exquisite phrasing. Check her timing and dynamics
column10: the way she estranges his melody by pulling buried notes from chords while riding her sustain pedal and then releasing it as if drawing a breath. Even when she holds back
column11: as she does here
column12: Amos seethes.

column1: Pink’s outtakes aren’t generally as memorable as Earthquakes’: Aside from her ominous ""Honey""
column2: an eleventh-hour omission she’s said she regrets
column3: the Pink B-sides explore the same mesmeric side of Amos’ songbook as the album’s long and winding ballads. The seven live tracks
column4: however
column5: affirm that Amos could pull more drama from one acoustic piano than ordinary bands draw from several amplified instruments
column6: and not just on the hits. ""Here. In My Head""
column7: a feather-light flip she also admits should’ve been on Pink
column8: gets the knockout climax its studio incarnation denies
column9: while ""Winter""—her disciplined and devastating invocation of childhood’s paradise lost—gets elevated to the level of ""Me and a Gun""
column10: as Amos emotionally amplifies and musically fleshes out every quietly anguished second. It’s astounding.

column1: Tori Amos arrived in an era when an unconventional
column2: confrontational artist could also be commercial. Both Earthquakes and Pink went double-platinum in the U.S.
column3: and although American Top 40 radio never accommodated her
column4: Amos managed to generate modern rock
column5: adult contemporary
column6: and dance club hits for 10 solid years before settling into cult-heroine status. Naturally
column7: others came to wear her crown of anomalies and thorns: Lana Del Rey remains the sole mainstream act to adroitly juxtapose and underplay personal trauma with classical finery
column8: yet the legacy of these milestones linger over today’s underground: Sufjan Stevens
column9: Bat for Lashes
column10: John Grant
column11: Lykke Li
column12: Owen Pallett
column13: St. Vincent
column14: Perfume Genius
column15: FKA twigs
column16: Antony Hegarty
column17: and others all wear their sensitivities as strengths as she did. Effervescent
column18: but at this peak still grounded by adversity
column19:
Amos taught her strange children well.

This Is the Kit wasn’t the most popular name to appear on Folk Off
column2: the 2006 state-of-freak-folk compilation that pitted US artists (Sufjan Stevens
column3: Animal Collective) against their UK counterparts (Vashti Bunyan
column4: Tunng). At the time Kit captain Kate Stables hadn’t even released a debut single
column5: let alone a full album
column6: but that made her an ideal inclusion: a less established artist who could benefit from proximity to more popular names while demonstrating the depth and breadth of the scene. Built around a deftly picked guitar theme and showcasing her earthy vocals
column7: ""2 Wooden Spoons"" held its own against Stables’ contemporaries. But nearly a decade later—when folk has fully embedded itself in the indie mainstream such that we’ve dropped the ""freak"" appendage altogether—the song carries very few of the signifiers that might anchor it to that long-past trend.

column1: Stables wears her eccentricities comfortably
column2: whether she's bending an old word into new shapes or displaying a curious sense of professional timing. Sunday Best
column3: the label that released Folk Off
column4: quickly issued her debut 7''
column5: with a full-length debut
column6: Krulle Bol
column7: released a year later. Wriggle Out the Restless followed in 2010
column8: and the folksy austerity of her music caught the ear of Aaron Dessner
column9: who not only signed her to his Brassland label but secured an opening slot for This Is the Kit when the National played New York in 2011. Four years later
column10: Stables is releasing her third album
column11: Bashed Out
column12: which Dessner inevitably produced. This is Slow Music: patiently and carefully handcrafted
column13: as though the process were just as important as the result
column14: and released on her own whim rather than by industry dictate.

column1: These new songs don’t sound terribly different from Stables’ first recordings nearly a decade ago
column2: but the music is bolder and more purposeful
column3: with a broader
column4: richer palette of sounds. Dessner works in a minimalist vein
column5: placing a handful of instruments at various levels in the mix but never locking them into place. A barely audible bassline rocks softly against Stables’ plaintive guitar theme on opener ""Misunderstanding"". ""Silver John"" blossoms into a swell of synths (courtesy of Thomas Bartlett a.k.a. Doveman) and builds to a chorus of odd siren vocal calls. There’s a parallax quality to the music
column6: an immersive sense of depth that makes the songs sound larger with each listen.

column1: Even as he expands her range and emphasizes her idiosyncrasies
column2: Dessner wisely stays out of Stables’ way
column3: and she emerges easily as the dominant force on Bashed Out. Her guitar work is nimble but not fussy
column4: and she conjures a sense of nameless menace on closer ""Cold and Got Colder"". On ""Spores All Settling"" her banjo playing is almost pointedly rudimentary
column5: emphasizing the present moment rather than the perfect performance. She’s a complex and compelling personality
column6: spiking her folksy whimsy (there’s a song about the smell of mushrooms) with shots of prickly wisdom. ""And so the outside
column7: it bashes us in
column8: bashes us about a bit
column9: she sings on the title track
column10: one of the album’s weightiest moments.

column1: For Stables
column2: creating music—or making art of any kind—means bashing right back at life
column3: matching it blow for blow. Yet
column4: this resilient album is less concerned with enduring immense tribulations than it is with enjoying life’s simple pleasures. Stables’ concerns are microcosmically personal
column5: trading in minute details and small observations that provide immense contentment. ""Vitamins"" is an ode to fresh greens
column6: while ""Nits"" describes sheep on a hillside as ""happy little fatties."" Both songs land just this side of unbearably precious
column7: but Stables doesn’t seem to care how such moments strike the listener. After almost a decade presenting herself as This Is the Kit
column8:
she has learned to root her music firmly in her own quirks rather than in the demands of any particular genre or trend.

Low Jack (aka Philippe Hallais) is one of the more exciting producers to emerge from the experimental techno community clustered around Parisian labels like In Paradisum and L.I.E.S.
column2: a New York transplant. To take rudimentary machine beats and attack them with scouring pads is neither new nor even particularly interesting in and of itself
column3: but what distinguishes Low Jack's work is the way he seems to be groping his way towards his own musical language
column4: one beyond the limits of either noise or techno as conventionally rendered. On his debut album
column5: last year's Garifuna Variations
column6: he twisted archival recordings of Central America's Garifuna people into grimy knots as part of a commission from Paris' Quai Branley Museum. Cut loose from the conceptual framework and institutional ties
column7: Sewing Machine is a far freer album
column8: and a lot more fun.

column1: Most of the tracks here play out pretty much the same way: fire up the drum machine
column2: run it through a mazelike signal path
column3: and twist at the knobs until the air itself seems to bleed. Of all the people making distorted techno right now (Kyle Hall
column4: Delroy Edwards
column5: Florian Kupfer)
column6: few make their noise sing quite as expressively as Low Jack. It's impressive how much mileage he gets from a simple distorted bass drum. On each track
column7: it's treated in a slightly different way
column8: so that it has a different color and shape—round here
column9: lumpy there
column10: and over there
column11: pocked with metal studs. In the turgid ""Fubu Knight""
column12: through some arcane feat of audio sculpting
column13: the snare drum sounds almost like a drawn-out scream. On the headbanging ""Sweatpants Chick""
column14: probably the most unabashedly lunkheaded thing here right down to the title
column15: he plays his filter's resonance knob like an instrument
column16: wringing the approximation of a melody out of its swoops and shrieks. The filter also takes center stage on ""Zaltan's Jackets""; this time it quacks like Donald Duck
column17: strutting and squelching in between medicine-ball-sized kick drums.

column1: Not a lot of daylight typically makes it onto a Low Jack production
column2: and that's particularly true of Sewing Machine; he might just as well have called it 50 Words for Coal. ""Pocket Pussy"" begins with a squall of sooty white noise that's even uglier than the introductory track
column3: which is an 87-second blast that sounds like a gurgle from the bowels of hell. But stick with it
column4: and Hallais begins to show his handiwork. A minute in
column5: kick drums come bursting through the murk followed by blotchy bass frequencies
column6: and then the high-end chatter descends
column7: alien and insistent. Fading out over a rhythm that might be sharpening knives
column8: the six-minute track has the dramatic arc of a radio play—not bad for something made with little more than a drum machine and fuzzbox. Sewing Machine certainly isn't for everyone
column9: but for listeners who like their noise as expressive as it is brutal
column10:
this slim album speaks volumes.

A late addition to an already crowded cast

column3: who at the time rarely toured with the group. At the time Calder seemed like a mismatch for a group defined by outsized presences: She’s not a born star like Case
column4: nor is she an enigma like Dan Bejar
column5: or a pop savant like A.C. Newman. Her defining characteristic is her ordinariness

column7: and while she may not be a marquee attraction
column8: over their last few albums
column9:
her spotlight turns have become reliable standouts.

As with most of her co-leads in the Pornographers
column10: the music Calder releases on her own shares little relation to that band’s escapist pop. For one thing
column11: nobody ever dies on a New Pornographers record. Though its cover promised precious twee
column12: Calder’s 2010 solo debut Are You My Mother? was an emotionally heavy listen shaped by her mother’s battle with ALS. The shadow of death also hung over her more assertive and synth-driven follow-up Bright and Vivid
column13:
which added her father to her list of loved ones to grieve.

Death has been such a constant on her solo albums that by now its presence is just assumed. Even though she seldom addresses it directly on her self-titled third album
column14: it’s always there. It’s present in the opener ""Slow Burning""
column15: when she pleads for help coping with the nightmares that wake her
column16: and it lingers to the very end of ""Remembering""
column17: when she shares an afternoon in the sun with her lover and sings
column18:
""Time will smoke us out but it’s really good to be here just like this.""

The album is filled with anecdotes like that
column19: peaceful moments interrupted by reminders of life’s impermanence. It’s as if every time Calder set out to write a love song
column20: she emerged instead with a portrait of survivor's guilt. But even at their most melancholy
column21: Calder’s songs are less concerned with mourning than with living. To judge by these songs
column22: her losses have reshaped her view or the world
column23: leaving her with a Zen-like sense of acceptance. On the jaunty ""Take a Little Time""
column24: the closest the album comes to New Pornographers-style hookiness
column25: she assures her lover she’s not interested in holding grudges. Even the prospect of romantic failure doesn’t faze her. ""If we fall

column1: Like Calder’s previous solo albums
column2: this one was produced with the man she ostensibly wrote many of these songs about
column3: her husband Colin Stewart. But this effort feels distinct from its predecessors
column4: more intimate but also more considered. It does more while calling less attention to itself. Calder often sings in little more than a murmur
column5: as if retreating from the world
column6: and Stewart’s production matches her voice. The understated mix disguises just how much instrumental and textural variation runs through these songs. Save for a few moments when the guitars boil over
column7:
the record plays as if covered by a blanket of snow.

Apparently it took some trial and error to capture that delicate mode. In interviews
column8: Calder has described the album as a second attempt
column9: following an LP’s worth of material she recorded then scrapped. That do-over involved writing new songs and rewriting others
column10: but it’s easy to imagine her just re-recording the same album
column11: only quieter. In Calder's songs solace proves elusive and fleeting
column12: but when she finds it
column13:
it's always during moments of calm.

On their first LP Confusion Is Sex
column2: Kim Gordon

column6: in thrall to subversion and half in love with nihilism. So it came as a surprise that they followed it up with a pitch-black
column7: punishing take on Americana titled after

column10: arriving amidst the culture wars of the Reagan era: Gordon and Moore cast a shadowy portrait slicked in sweat and blood

column1: But the band’s fury ran deeper than that. As Gordon recalls in her recent memoir Girl in a Band: ""I ... preferred to sing about the darkness shimmering beneath the shiny quilt of American pop culture""—more specifically
column2: ""the westward pull

column5: Gordon and Moore raised up the leering specter of Charles Manson

column1: Bad Moon Rising is obsessed with sex and power

column3: and among its darkest. ""I Love Her All the Time""
column4: ""I’m Insane""

column6: ceding their bodies (and therefore
column7: their identities) to them as if there’s no other choice. ""She’s on my side

column10: Gordon struggles to identify just what it is that makes her succumb to a man’s wiles
column11: finally theorizing ""it’s the devil in me"": the female sex drive
column12: corrupted.

column1: Bad Moon Rising is not so much a collection of songs as it is an extended
column2: unending uproar
column3: seamless in sound and theme.  This is partially due to the band’s recording strategy
column4: which translated the ebb-and-flow of their live show at the time into a singular composition. At this point in their career

column1: In Bad Moon Rising’s world

column3: chronicled in the terrifying ""Ghost Bitch"". Moore sounds possessed on the following
column4: mournful track
column5: ""I’m Insane""
column6: a sinister piece assembled entirely of fragments from pulp novels like ""a steaming swamp
column7: ""murdered angels
column8: and the head-scratching ""inside my head my dog’s a bear."" It’s less a song and more the no wave aural equivalent of refrigerator magnet poetry
column9: but it functions remarkably well within the album’s overarching narrative.

column1: But what happens when women reclaim their bodies and fight back? Years before riot grrrl
column2: ""Flower"" (a bonus track released after Bad Moon Rising alongside ""Halloween"" on 12” and added to the album in subsequent reissues) encapsulated the sex-positive sentiments
column3: as well as the noise
column4: of the forthcoming movement. Gordon's chanted manifesto
column5: delivered over a paranoid
column6: unstable rumble

column8: of course

column10: but Gordon’s vision encompasses more than the act itself; her culminating directive of ""Use the word/ FUCK!"" commands a recognition of women as carnal
column11: sexual beings. ""The word is love

column1: Bad Moon Rising reaches both its climax and conclusion with the Manson-inspired madness of ""Death Valley ’69""
column2: Moore’s infamous duet with Lydia Lunch
column3: and the closest the album comes to producing a viable single. A tortured yell drags the record out of the doldrums of the preceding ""Justice Is Might"" and into a busted-up Chevy parked in Death Valley on some dead night
column4: in the Summer of Love. Moore and Lunch don’t try to harmonize or sing on key
column5: because their minds aren’t on the melody; they wail over and under one another like coyotes in heat. A single glance over the lyrics suggests another instance of male-on-female violence (""She started to holler/ I didn't wanna/ But she started to holler/ So I had to hit it""). And yet
column6: the ecstasy with which Lunch vocalizes all but says ""This is a game
column7: I’m trying to get you
column8: and I’m winning."" The balance of power shifts once more as Lunch unleashes that orgasmic shriek at song's end: a brilliant imitation of the whimpering guitars
column9: a final paean to chaos before the fade to black.

column1: Despite its compelling aesthetic
column2: Bad Moon Rising suffers from a few technical shortcomings which become more evident in this remastering
column3: specifically Bob Bert’s tom-heavy approach to the drums. They play a critical role in conveying the primal energy coursing through ""Brave Men Run (In My Family)"" and ""Society Is a Hole""
column4: but the atmospheric boost quickly wears thin: not just because he sounds like he’s drumming with crab mallets

column6: the hardcore-schooled
column7: improvisatory percussionist who succeeded Bert. Additionally
column8: your mileage may vary where vocal melodies

column10: are concerned; his grating refrains on ""Society Is a Hole"" and ""I Love Her All the Time"" show he hadn’t yet developed the tightness and control he would exhibit later. That said
column11: this dissonance is a defining aspect of early Sonic Youth albums

column13: say
column14: ""Incinerate"".

column1: Since its release
column2: Bad Moon Rising has left behind many legacies. Thanks to the mangled mass of the guitars
column3: as well as the lack of anthemic verse-chorus-verses structure that dominated Daydream Nation and Goo
column4: the LP is regarded by many as Sonic Youth's most ""difficult"" album. Fans of contemporary acts like Swans (who Sonic Youth toured with prior to the Bad Moon Rising sessions) might find in the record’s structure a source of catharsis and narrative strength. Those who became fans post Daydream Nation
column5: meanwhile

column8: it’s jarring to return to the real one—and perhaps
column9: by extension
column10: Sonic Youth’s subsequent catalog
column11:
which never quite revisited the sheer alienation of Bad Moon Rising.

According to musician/author Michael Tenzer in Balinese Gamelan Music
column4: the term ""Batu Malablab"" is a Balinese pejorative that’s ""typically hurled at unprepared musicians."" Tenzer goes on to break down the etymology: ""Batu means rock or stone
column5: and malablab is the active form of the incisively onamonopedic verb ‘to boil.’ A gamelan deserving of the sobriquet ‘boiling rock’ is likely going nowhere fast."" It’s tempting to assume that by adopting this phrase as the title of his debut solo LP
column6: M.C. Schmidt is essentially taking the piss

column1: Less plainly predetermined than thrillingly accidental
column2: Batu Malablab seems
column3: at times

column5: the clamor retains a hint of streamlined anarchy that is

column8: seething ambience that quotes a number of genres—New Age
column9: opera
column10: world music
column11: assorted species of avant-garde that Sonic Youth celebrated on Goodbye 20th Century—without being fully in thrall to any of them. Think a more omnivorous
column12: porous take on The Carl Stalling Project.

column1: Over the 39 minutes
column2: segues and splashes accrue
column3: evoking a din that is either felt or heard depending on the listener’s attention level at the time. Either way
column4: when those final notes sound and the record cuts out

and Batu Malablab announces Schmidt as a collagist force in his own right.

Mike Simonetti has never sat still. Troubleman Unlimited
column3: the label he founded in 1993
column4: started from a foundation of noisy hardcore—bands like Rorschach
column5: Unwound
column6: and Rye Coalition—and expanded to include a staggering range of music

column1: Pale Blue is Simonetti’s latest project. A new alias on a new label (2MR

column14: meanwhile
column15: resembles a zoned-out road worker painting stripes on a lonely stretch of desert highway: Not a lot changes
column16: but then
column17: it’s not supposed to. The intensity rises and falls with the rolling hills
column18: but the vistas remain the same
column19: and the horizon never gets any closer.

column1: Despite the uniformity
column2: there are clear highlights. The title track is a big
column3: bold
column4: feel-good bummer of a tune that finds Wight testing the lower limits of her register
column5: sounding a little like Siouxsie amidst a gleaming array of contrapuntal synths. ""Dusk in Parts""
column6: the other obvious single
column7: makes the most of Jana Hunter’s desolate wail
column8: while the monotone bassline offers a sullen deadweight counterpoint to sentimental Rhodes melodies and chimes that glint like tear-stained cheeks. ""The Math"" could actually be mistaken for a Kompakt release—if the recent ""Blurred Lines"" verdict actually counted as legal precedent
column9: Heiko Voss and DJ Koze might conceivably take Simonetti to court for so skillfully replicating the vibe of Voss’ Kompakt Pop classic ""I Think About You (DJ Koze Mix)""
column10: and I say that in the most complimentary way possible. From the strings to the horn stabs to the buoyant background vocals
column11: it’s a triumphant example of Simonetti at his extroverted best. The Bruce Springsteen cover ""Tougher""
column12: on the other hand
column13: represents the other end of the spectrum: it plays its cards close to the vest
column14: with a trim arpeggio opening up only as much as necessary while Wight mutters come-ons. Her spoken-word vocals never quite synch with the beat
column15: either
column16: and as a result
column17: it yanks us out of the production’s hypnotic swirl.

column1: Some of the album’s more middling tracks—""Distance to the Waves""
column2: ""Myself""
column3: ""The Eye""—feel only halfway there. Simonetti has no issue letting a track that consists only of a single wavering chord and some ethereal background vocals drag on for seven-and-a-half minutes (""The Rain""). But if this 67-minute album is not without filler
column4: even those airy expanses are perfectly pleasant. This unwillingness to edit himself was also an issue on Simonetti’s solo EP Capricorn Rising
column5: in which one song appeared in three different versions

column8: perhaps

column11: at unabridged lengths. But maybe that has to do with a desire to wring the most out of a given idea—the most pleasure
column12: the most yearning

column14:
lost-in-a-dream intensity beneath a slowly twirling disco ball.

On their third full-length
column2: the Brooklyn quintet Ava Luna is
column3: as always
column4: toying with a collection of ideas that should not work together in theory. There are traces of genres they’ve already spent some time exploring: British post-punk
column5: '70s soul and funk
column6: late '60s krautrock. The band recorded Infinite House in wildly different environments—Benton
column7: Mississippi and Brooklyn—which serve as central and opposing life forces for the album. One minute murmuring
column8: echoed vocals imitate spirits in a Southern forest
column9: and the next frontman Carlos Hernandez is texting a lover and bemoaning the cost of living. It’s a scatterbrained trip
column10: one that invites you to nestle into its grooves and get comfy before it rudely catapults you out again.

column1: Take
column2: for example
column3: opener ""Company"". A muted bass line thumps through the first minute
column4: joined by some leisurely strumming and a faint hi-hat. Drummer Julian Fader abruptly cues the rest of the band in for an outburst of noise and distortion as Hernandez hollers in sheer desperation
column5: ""Do you appreciate my company?"" This is a group that basks in these kinds of bipolar switches
column6: slinking away to a new mood just as they’d gotten grips on the one preceding it.

column1: Nonsense is intrinsic to Ava Luna
column2: and either of its two backup singers (Felicia Douglass and Becca Kauffman) is prone to breaking out into gibberish at any given moment. But they take this tendency to a new level on ""Tenderize"" when Kauffman breathily scats between Hernandez’s anxious yelps like a jazz club singer. Douglass’ shadowy harmonies counteracts them both
column3: closing in the gaps at exactly the right points. When the group builds on each other this way
column4: the result is eerily mystical. This layering works similarly on ""Coat of Shellac""
column5: blending the slickness of R&B with the harshness of post-punk and unpredictability of no wave.

column1: The album has a loose
column2: playful energy
column3: and always seems to be ready to pounce on you. Skittish guitar improvisations tangle with neo-soul percussion on ""Steve Polyester""
column4: while Kauffman alternates between speaking and sliding into song sporadically
column5: as if by accident. ""Black Dog"" starts off with Hernandez telling a seductive
column6: drowsy tale over a few simple guitar chords
column7: allowing for a much-needed moment of respite. Of course
column8: that too gives way to the dissonance
column9: accompanied by haunting
column10: gospel choir gang vocals. He often riffs on freewheeling blues-rock in the style of Captain Beefheart
column11: most prominently during the serrated rhythms of ""Best Hexagon"".

column1: The most bizarre track—if forced to pick one—is ""Victoria"". Primal utterances dance circles around distorted
column2: intergalactic synth beats. Kauffman takes a beguiling taunt (""You’re no good
column3: baby!"")
column4: deconstructs it
column5: then pieces it back together repeatedly. It’s a disorienting thrill that draws out the band’s innate ingenuity. There are plenty of other high points on the album—the aching chorus of ""Billz"" is arguably Hernandez’s most addictive yet—but listening to Ava Luna play off of each others’ quirks here is intoxicating. Minimalism has never been their strong suit
column6: and they wrestle with controlling their lawless tendencies
column7: yet Infinite House doesn’t compromise the group’s hyperactive curiosity. Keeping up with it requires careful attention
column8:
though unpacking it hardly feels laborious. Just don’t expect Ava Luna to do any hand-holding for you throughout the process.

Alongside his famous stints playing boisterous
column2: stadium-sized guitar in Red Hot Chili Peppers
column3: John Frusciante has quietly developed a reputation as an experimentalist. The wildly disparate and disjointed solo albums he's released over the last decade-plus have been generally engaging
column4: though occasionally laborious
column5: explorations of the outer-bounds of guitar-based pop music. They've showcased
column6: first and foremost
column7: an inclination to use more abstract elements to push beyond the straightforward riffery he put forth in his more famous gig. His new project Trickfinger
column8: a tribute to the clatter of acid house
column9: puts Frusciante in ostensibly unfamiliar territory. But as he's included more electronic flourishes on his solo efforts
column10: it was only a matter of time before he decided to embrace the mechanized whirr of a host of synthesizers and drum machines en masse.

column1: Frusciante's self-titled full-length debut under the moniker demonstrates his grasp of the intricacies of the form. As he's proven over time with his guitar work
column2: he has a knack for capably conjuring not just the sound
column3: but the feeling of long-past musical eras. From even the first judders of opener ""After Below""
column4: he taps into the stark
column5: subdued rattle of the earliest Warp Records releases. Digitalist melodies become percussive and pummeling in their mechanistic repetition
column6: locked-groove drum programming putters along for minutes at a time. Jittery snare work and rigidly interlocking synth lines populate both that track and the record as a whole
column7: rendering it foreboding and overcast
column8: and affecting at times. Tracks like ""Exlam"" and ""Phurip"" are able to channel the fidgety nervousness of this Autechre-indebted gridlike construction into something uniquely unsettling. If you can give yourself over to Frusciante's aural panic attacks they can be as transcendent as those of his acid house forefathers.

column1: But the less overwhelming moments of Trickfinger suffer from a surprising anonymity. Even when his seasick Sebadoh-like exercises under his own name turned obtuse and atonal
column2: they were still immediately identifiable as products of his warped perspective. The flatulent bass runs on ""85h"" and ""Sain"" make them recognizable as acid house tracks
column3: but there's not much more of interest going on than capable pastiche. Without the dynamic play and overstimulation that rules elsewhere
column4: the endless repetition of these tracks starts to cut both ways. Trickfinger often provokes an engaging anxiety
column5: but when Frusciante's not pushing at the edges of the form it can lack the magic of his otherwise unapologetically experimental solo work.

column1: That could have something to do with the fact that this is only Frusciante's first album-length foray into the field. When looking back on the gradual shift toward synth programming
column2: Frusciante talks about these efforts as an attempt to learn the ""language"" of legendary electronic acts like Aphex Twin and Venetian Snares. Trickfinger is
column3: if nothing else
column4:
proof that he's finally fluent in that language. But it's also a reminder that Frusciante is at his best when he's jabbering away in a tongue of his own invention.

The-Dream's first three albums—in particular
column3: his 2007 debut Love/Hate—relied upon a delicate balance of songcraft with the singer/songwriter's foibles and quirks. There was a playfulness to his best songs which never undercut their sincere emotional power; if anything

column6: executed in a more modern style; by the time R. Kelly released the obviously The-Dream-inspired ""Echo"" in 2010
column7: the snake was eating his own tail

column1: But The-Dream spent the past five years slipping from that sweet spot of effortless transcendence: there's a sharp divide between The-Dream songs which work
column2: and those that don't
column3: and the latter category stacked some substantial gains over the course of the 2010s. Perhaps buying into the hype around his steadily growing stanbase and critical acclaim
column4: he abandoned the high-pressure lottery of hits-first craftsmanship and tilted autobiographical
column5: personal. But The-Dream is not a charismatic personality
column6: and after he was caught cheating on his then-wife Christina Milian
column7: he wasn't a sympathetic one either. As cruel as it sounds

column9: his melodic sense

column1: Chastened

column3: a two-tone stop-start organ tiptoeing forward on synthesized finger snaps
column4: his protagonist's confidence underlined by the ""Yup!"" vocal interjections in the background. For the dancer
column5: its use of space allows for a freer range of motion. The melody is equally relaxed
column6: a barely-there nursery rhyme that taunts his target until the reassuring piano tones anchor his certainty at the chorus. But what makes ""That's My Shit"" so singular is the way The-Dream conveys an unconventional theme with emotional precision. The conviction with which he sings ""I know how to push that button
column7: trust me y'all just fuckin'"" is funny
column8: yet he is unafraid to let his heart show—boldly ""catching feelings.""

column1: The rest of The Crown EP does not thread the needle quite so gracefully. ""Prime"" is an example of one such failure: The-Dream is at his best when he isolates and emphasizes the familiar. But where ""That's My Shit"" epitomizes the bulletproof swagger of romantic confidence
column2: ""Prime"" feels distant: Convincing a future lover of your value typically requires a bit more show-don't-tell than ""I know you think you're out of my league/ But I'm trying to tell you girl
column3: I'm in my prime."" Even if interpreted as internal monologue
column4: ""Prime"" suggests uncertainty and insecurity—relatable emotions
column5: maybe
column6: but not ones you'd sing about with pride.

column1: In part
column2: the misses might be a product of the format: ""All I Need"" links to ""Fruition"" like the infamous ""Yamaha""-""Nikki Part 2""-""Abyss"" triptych of Love King
column3: but on a 6-track record
column4: it feels forced
column5: his old ambitions with R&B form reduced to mannerism. There's always been a certain degree of generosity to The-Dream's work
column6: a feeling that one hook wasn't enough
column7: that Tricky Stewart's production would be lusher and more ornamental
column8: each record a compact snow globe of ideas and emotions. Yet closer ""Cedes Benz"" feels like a product of pressure. Each of its disparate parts—the grinding aggro opener
column9: the menacing second act
column10: the sensuous slow jam—feel undercooked
column11: repetitious
column12: combined in the hopes that no one would recognize the reheated elements interspersed throughout. It's not entirely empty of ideas
column13: but the good ones are buried.

column1: ""Fruition"" feels like the rare middleweight The-Dream track: held together entirely by a perfect guitar loop repeated as if it were a memory
column2: an average song is redeemed by a single melody. ""All I Need""
column3: however
column4: almost lives up to our memory of The-Dream's earliest peaks
column5: compelling and grandiose: it is unafraid to fail
column6: to overreach. And in that ambition
column7: it wrings more from the formula The-Dream approached on records like Love vs. Money's ""Fancy"". It points to a key strength of The-Dream's songwriting. While we may never have really understood him
column8:
it was that yearning to be understood that his music so evocatively conveys: a willingness to risk embarrassment in an effort to convey human emotion through the boldest possible gestures.

In electronic-music circles
column2: the piano seems to be enjoying a curious moment in the sun. Not only is it a suddenly ubiquitous fixture in dance music (so much so that the classical pianist Franceso Tristano was tapped to mix the latest installment of Get Physical's Body Language series); it occupies center stage on Chilly Gonzales' new neo-classical work
column3: Chambers
column4: and Nils Frahm's free album of prepared-piano miniatures
column5: Solo. Frahm feels so strongly about the instrument that he recently declared March 29—the 88th day of the year
column6: matching the instrument's 88 keys—Piano Day
column7: a celebration of not just the instrument but also its builders
column8: tuners
column9: and
column10: of course
column11: players and fans.

column1: Delia Gonzalez's new album is the latest addition to this small bumper crop. It's largely conceptual
column2: not particularly virtuosic
column3: but it's effective for its own purposes
column4: which
column5: in this case
column6: amount to inducing hypnotic focus and transmitting vague melancholy. Its main attraction is a suite of four meditative pieces for multi-tracked piano with subtle post-processing (there is also a second disc of remixes). The four pieces were originally written for a 2010 solo show at Naples' Galleria Fonti
column7: where Gonzalez presented four short 16mm films of ballerinas dancing in front of mirrors. (The 2LP edition of the album includes all four films on a bonus DVD.) That piece
column8: says Gonzalez
column9: was inspired in part by a maxim from the Russian composer and spiritual teacher George Gurdjieff: ""To play scales is to become more in tune with your inner self."" That lone adage says more about the intentions of the project than any of the rest of its backstory.

column1: It's not hard to draw a line from Gonzalez's new album back to The Days of Mars
column2: her 2005 album with Gavin Russom
column3: and their assorted singles
column4: despite the shift from synthesizers to coiled steel strings. Like that body of work
column5: In Remembrance is fundamentally about lines and ways to braid them. ""I"" begins with a lonely descending figure that's vaguely reminiscent of the theme from Halloween—until it softens and turns inward
column6: tangling up in a ball of contrapuntal phrases. The song
column7: like the pieces that follow it
column8: feels less composed than sculpted
column9: a multi-track collage of piled-on arpeggios and cadenzas and trills. In ""II""
column10: the left hand initially takes the lead
column11: and the effect feels both more somber and more determined. ""III"" is the most lyrical of the set
column12: and it's also the most obviously treated with delay; in ""IV""
column13: she pounds away at bold
column14: declarative chords
column15: her foot firmly pressed down on the sustain pedal.

column1: Given her emphasis on repetition
column2: it's tempting to invoke the influence of American minimalists like Philip Glass
column3: but In Remembrance doesn't have his rhythmic or tonal complexity. By design
column4: I think
column5: it's meant to sound unpolished; it's less about formal brilliance than the attainment of a kind of trance state. The occasional jarring dissonance recalls alternate-tuning buffs like Michael Harrison
column6: though it's unclear whether they're intentional
column7: the product of an unconventional tuning system
column8: or simply the happy accident of an intemperate concert grand
column9: astringent as a Sour Patch Kid. A closer comparison might be Grouper's Ruins
column10: which evinced a similarly idiosyncratic approach to the instrument. But the closest precedent might be a wonderful 1996 album called While by the Chicago musician Thymme Jones
column11: of Brise-Glace and Yona-Kit
column12: made with a lone piano and a four-track cassette recorder. Like In Remembrance
column13: While weaves together contrapuntal phrases into dense nests and thickets of sound.

column1: The four remixes
column2: one per piece
column3: come from the Brooklyn producer Bryce Hackford. In keeping with the simplicity of the music
column4: he hasn't overcomplicated his interventions. ""Remix I"" takes an eraser to the percussive side of the piano—the moment that each note is struck—and leaves only the sustain and the decay; the result is like a game of ping-pong played with dandelion tufts. ""Remix II""
column5: with its looming kick drum and washed-out keys
column6: recalls the heavier recordings in Wolfgang Voigt's Gas catalog
column7: and the lumpy sample stabs of ""Remix IV"" faintly suggest Kompakt's Dettinger. The best of the bunch is ""Remix III""
column8: which stretches out a right-hand trill over a spring-loaded rhythm and atonal synth bleats on loan from minimal techno innovator Robert Hood. Like Carl Craig's now-classic remix of Gonzalez and Russom's ""Relevee""
column9: it uses the original—just a scrap of it
column10:
but enough—as the springboard for a 10-minute-plus foray into techno at its most psychedelic. It's a testament to the strength of Gonzalez's work that she can provide the foundations for something so wild with such humble materials.

Nine years after their first album
column2: Matt & Kim have never strayed from their initial elevator pitch: they’re still a pop band in indie clothing

column4: DIY spin. In 2015

column6: the concept of scrappy outsiders engaging with pop and dance music doesn’t carry the quixotic novelty it once did. As the boundaries between pop
column7: indie
column8: and alternative have blurred or disappeared over the last decade
column9: Top 40 has become a less exclusive club. With re-tailored punk bands like Fall Out Boy and Paramore scoring pop radio play and Karmin trading their shticky YouTube covers of pop hits for hits of their own

column11: skateboarding keyboard-and-drums duo could play in the mainstream no longer seems at all farfetched.

column1: On New Glow

column4: including Kanye West’s longtime engineer Andrew Dawson and Jesse Shatkin

column3: nasal whine

column7: his heart still belongs to pop-punk. The same way that country stars play up their drawls when they sing crossover pop songs
column8: lest their rural fanbase think they’ve forsaken their roots
column9: New Glow’s contemporary aesthetic pushes Johnson to lean extra hard on his old
column10: dopey vocal affectations. In the album’s most cartoonish display of overcompensation

column4: to ""Hoodie On""

Since forming in 2000
column2: Tal National have been on a quest to make it known to the world that Niger is not in fact Nigeria. Besides everything else
column3: musically
column4: the land-locked Sahelian nation never went through the same kind of cosmopolitan musical explosion that many other West African nations did in the 1960s post-independence era. Only around the turn of the century have some Nigerien artists broken into the international market
column5: including Mamar Kassey and Tuareg groups like Etran Finatawa or Bombino. And now
column6: of course

column1: While Tal National’s 2008 sophomore album A Na Waya made them the most popular group in Niger
column2: their following album and first international release Kaani officially established them outside the continent. Led by band leader Hamadal Issoufou Moumine and produced by Chicago-based engineer Jamie Carter
column3: Kaani was a joyful barrage of traditional Hausa and Zarma vocals
column4: soukous guitars
column5: reggae synths
column6: and percussion
column7: all rolled up into a decidedly rock aesthetic. Then as now

column9: Zoy Zoy

column1: Zoy Zoy's themes are as diverse as the traditions it pulls from. On ""Sey Wata Gaya""
column2: for example

column5: a region frequented by the Tuareg. Fittingly

column7: which ripples mirage-like over hissy
column8: subdividing hi-hats and a steady kick drum beat. The Hausa and Zarma vocals—mainly male lead vocal and female backing vocals—bound and echo across these arrangements. Altogether
column9: these threads form a sort of tangled maze of melodic lines and jagged edges
column10: interlocking motifs that repeat themselves like squares in a kaleidoscope.

column1: The music is colorful and bright and dizzying. It recalls the energy and wall-of-sound quality of Konono No 1
column2: except more frenzied and texturally varied. Tal National are masters of lightning-speed time changes too
column3: able to lock into a slower bluesy guitar solo as easily as an impromptu mbalax dance break (see ""Farila""). In spots

column5: but sped-up and with a hypnotic psych rock edge.

column1: That hypnotic effect is nowhere more evident than in the last two tracks. ""Kodaje"" and ""Saraounia"" are dances of possession. The tracks’ namesakes are spirits (genie in French)
column2: the former Zarma and the latter Hausa
column3: and both can speak through those they possess. The lead vocalist sings himself into a fever pitch
column4: chanting and grunting and careening—this is the distilled version of the energy that propels the entire album. And it’s this energy that holds Zoy Zoy together

column1: Tal National’s ability to weave together all these thematic and musical elements with unflagging speed and energy is breathtaking. But it can also feel claustrophobic at times
column2: especially when listening the whole way through and with headphones on. The two or three different polyrhythmic guitar lines present on every track are more or less split between the left and right channels. So to those raised on Western music

column4: on the other hand
column5: opens up another dimension of the album—you can visualize where the artists are positioned as they play. The artists’ emerge spatially before the listener
column6: as if performing live
column7: and Tal National are
column8: first and foremost
column9:
a live band. They are the ouragan that they sing of—a thing hardly containable in the space of mere megabytes.

The songs convey a sense of yearning for some alternate reality or paradisiacal afterlife—a place where ""trees don’t shake their heads in sorrow and nobody shakes in fear when they think about tomorrow."" That longing is key to the record. It’s what makes you realize Cohen cares about what he’s singing and that he wants something more
