""Millennial"" is one of those terms whose definition was nebulous even before it reached a supersaturation point in the culture—feel free to file it alongside ""indie"" and ""hipster"" in that regard—but if there’s any one artist who grasps its spirit
column2: it’s Makonnen Sheran

column6: his openness
column7: his sense of possibility. He’s a product of the Internet and incredible tragedy: A witness to the accidental death of his best friend at age 18
column8: he spent seven years bouncing between jail
column9: house arrest
column10: and probationary purgatory. The online world served as a safe haven
column11: a place for therapy and creative expression. He posted songs on Myspace
column12: interviewed musicians and businesspeople on his personal blog
column13: wrote and sang and drew and designed. His probation finally ended in May 2014; three months later

column1: Perhaps it’s easy for young people to see themselves in Makonnen because many of them grew up spending their nights the same way: devouring every bit of culture in sight whether it’s the Killers’ greatest hits or old episodes of ""Dragon Ball Z""

column4: and Makonnen’s no different.

column1: That’s not to suggest that ""Tuesday"" was a fluke
column2: or a product of sheer coincidence rather than talent or hard work. It became a hit because of Makonnen’s genial nature
column3: his oddball charisma
column4: and his ability to craft a perfect
column5: simple hook

column7: hyper-lean catalogue. You can hear it in the early versions of songs like ""I Don’t Sell Molly No More"" and ""Whip It""
column8: in arrangements that are raw but ooze melody. Self-produced until 2013
column9: his work took an immediate leap forward when he began working with outside producers on 2014 mixtape Drink More Water 4. Played against strange
column10: vaguely gothic beats with real momentum and heft rather than the plinky
column11: tinny sounds of his keyboard
column12: Makonnen's own strangeness and versatility was amplified: his workmanlike relationship with drugs and alcohol
column13: his wobbly vocal takes
column14: the way he doodles arrhythmically like a kid coloring with the wrong hand. The iLoveMakonnen EP
column15: released later that year (and again
column16: with a slightly adjusted tracklist
column17: a little later still)
column18: took that new formula and refined it further.

column5: wild strikeout. In ""Tuesday"" and ""I Don't Sell Molly No More""—and his verse on Father's louche breakout single ""Look at Wrist""

column8: particularly the songs that feature other
column9: more conventional rappers.

column1: In the same way Makonnen took a step forward when he emerged from his DIY cocoon to work with other producers
column2: he's a powerful complementary force

column4: he's a welcome burst of color against the hyperkinetic human fireworks of Migos; on ""No Ma'am"" and the remix of his earlier ""Dodging 12""

column6: more aggressive drug rapping.

column3: like the dewy ""Super Clean"" or ""Other Guys""

column5: like stark confessional ""Get Loose With Me""
column6: are an inch away from the blue

being asked to accomplish things their creator doesn't seem all that interested in pursuing.

This year marks the 20th anniversary of Superchunk’s Here’s Where the Strings Come In

column4: sophistication

column10: pre-hiatus discography. Not coincidentally
column11: around the same time
column12: McCaughan promoted his solo project Portastatic from scrappy
column13: sporadic pursuit to an equally prolific going concern
column14: allowing him to not just quiet down
column15: but branch out and explore sounds—easy-listening pop
column16: Tropicalia
column17: jazz
column18: incidental soundtrack music
column19: Prefab Sprout covers—that even a mellowing Superchunk wouldn’t accommodate.

column1: Just as Superchunk sat out the 2000s—partly because their Merge Records imprint had transformed from beloved indie label to job-generating local-economy savior—Portastatic would likewise fall silent after 2006’s Be Still Please
column2: its transformation from home-recording free-for-all to dignified

column6: he’s not hiding behind a self-deprecating alias—with Non-Believers

column1: This album could have easily been titled Here’s Where the Synths Come In: though McCaughan is no stranger to keyboards

column4: its small-scaled but vigorous sound emblematic of the music’s transition into mechanistic New Wave at the dawn of the '80s (when synths essentially became the punk equivalent of hiring a string section). But while the bright
column5: buzzy
column6: fuzzy tones are redolent of a bygone era when these machines really sounded like the future

column1: Throughout McCaughan’s career
column2: the lines separating his artistic
column3: professional
column4: and personal lives have been routinely blurred
column5: so it’s fitting that the songs on Non-Believers double as pledges of romantic commitment and DIY self-sufficiency: The exultant chorus of ""Only Do""—""there is no try/ there is only do""—is both an invitation to elope and an epitaph-worthy summation of McCaughan’s work ethic. Lyrically

column7: whether channelling the rich observational detail of the Go-Betweens on the high-school house-party reminiscences of ""Your Hologram"" or the hard-scrabble wisdom of latter-day Paul Westerberg on ""Our Way Free"" (a galloping
column8: gently ascendent anthem that Arcade Fire should really select as their local-hero cover-song tribute the next time they roll through Durham).

column3: affecting moments without tipping the scales to sentimentality. Even the sleek dream-pop R&B groove and smooth harmony hooks of ""Real Darkness"" are undercut by a despairing account of locked-in-the-bathroom teenage depression; ""family friends and strangers lift your chin and go
column4: ‘smile kid’

column1: But as much as Non-Believers mines memories of McCaughan’s formative years—be it the blown-out ghetto-blaster-fetishism of ""Box Batteries"" or the sight of ""an '82 Honda getting its tapes stolen"" on ""Your Hologram""—it’s ultimately a portrait of his current condition

column3: principled

like an indie-rock lifer who’s got a permanent burn mark above his elbow from decades of spooling guitar cables around his arm at load-out. It’s a line he could’ve written when he was 15—and it sounds just as meaningful and virtuous on the cusp of 50.

It’s hard not to be a little bit awed by Cleveland’s veteran underground rock juggernaut Lamont Thomas. Know America is his fifth LP in four years as Obnox (not to mention the bounty of singles he has in his catalog). Hot on the heels of January's excellent Boogalou Reed
column2: Know America prents another stunning collection of blown-out
column3: catchy
column4: soulful garage rock. It is hardly a departure for Thomas
column5: but it also shows growth – with each release Thomas’ stature and legend grows.

column1: Lamont has said that Know America is a punk rock concept album about taking over a record station and playing his friends' records
column2: and the album boasts an appropriately joyous
column3: ferocious energy. The pleasure of belonging to a community where your friends are your competition
column4: your inspiration
column5: and your favorite musicians is one of the best things about being part of any kind of DIY music scene
column6: and Know America crackles with that communal glee.

column1: Under all the noise
column2: he’s never forgotten the value of hooks or honesty: “Menocause”
column3: the album’s first single
column4: is a gospel-psych plea that rambles through heartache
column5: not seeking salvation or resolution but simply honoring feelings that can’t be shoved down any longer. Contrast that with “Freaky”
column6: a delightful
column7: uncompromisingly sexual trashpile that sounds like the brash punk son of Funkadelic’s noisiest moments. They are part and parcel of the same human experience – desire
column8: longing – and Thomas handles the whole range with a pop songwriter's ease.

column1: Thomas has sat in the drummer’s seat for years for Cleveland outfits like Bassholes and This Moment in Black History
column2: and he is also an excellent guitarist who knows when to pull out a short
column3: searing solo and when to lean back. The constant
column4: menacing guitar fuzz that runs throughout
column5: occasionally swelling up and nearly overwhelming a song
column6: is the glue welding together the disparate styles that make up Thomas’ distinct voice. He’s a singer with a lovely tone first made evident by Louder Space
column7: his first record as Obnox in a proper studio
column8: but he still knows how to manipulate and highlight rhythm. “Loudpack”
column9: at the center of the track list
column10: is a monster of a percussive noise track.

column1: The goofiest moment on the record – “Hillbilly Intervention”
column2: where Thomas pretends to be an ignorant bumpkin calling into the radio station to protest “Obnox and that whole n****r-ish punk movement” – is also the most serious. There is a  a tendency both within rock subgenre scenes and within criticism to cast rock as by and for white people
column3: an ahistorical erasure Thomas refuses. His blackness is
column4: of course
column5: part of who he is
column6: and he refuses to compromise any aspect of himself.

column1: If you somehow haven’t been paying attention to Thomas before this
column2: hopefully Know America will rectify that situation. (If you get a chance to see him live
column3: take it – he puts himself into his performance in a way that is exhilarating
column4: exhausting and always worthwhile.) His music is alive in a way few records are these days – complex
column5: emotional
column6:
and political in a way that resists sloganeering and cuts to the quick of what matters.

""It took a little time to get where I wanted/ It took a little time to get free/ It took a little time to be honest/ It took a little time to be me
column2: sings Conor O’Brien on the first track to Villagers’ new album. As opening lines go
column3: it’s hard to get more direct than that. It’s fitting then that the song itself is called ""Courage""—a phenomenon that the Villagers’ frontman describes as ""a feeling like no other
column4: let me tell you."" The song is a kind of pat on the back for O’Brien but also a way of steeling himself to open up and reveal what the album’s remaining songs have yet to say—namely
column5: that romance is the pits no matter who you happen to fall in love with
column6: but romantic love is not nearly as hard as coming to terms with your own mysterious and complicated self.

column1: Previous Villagers records—2010’s Becoming a Jackal and 2013’s {Awayland}—were much busier affairs
column2: each Mercury Prize nominees in which O’Brien’s grandly orchestral and electronic-infused folk music is supported by a full band and a preponderance of big ideas. Darling Arithmetic
column3: by contrast
column4: is a radically subdued affair—nine mostly acoustic-based tracks that O’Brien recorded at home alone
column5: playing every instrument and mixing the record on his own. It makes sense then that the record is also the most strikingly personal he’s ever made—an emotional missive about love and relationships—in which the notoriously shy Dubliner finally opens up in a more direct way about his own sexuality.

column1: Earlier this year O’Brien spoke to the Irish Times about the motivations for his new record by saying
column2: ""It’s not a news story: ‘Man is gay.’ I don’t want that to be the main focus. I wanted the album to be a human love album because everyone in the world feels those emotions at some stage. I really wanted to make sure that anyone who was listening could relate to the songs. I didn’t want to cut anyone off or make it seem as if I was only singing to my younger self.""

column1: While O’Brien’s goal of speaking to the universal experience—rather than simply making what could be ostensibly pigeonholed as a specifically ""coming out"" record—is understandable
column2: his lingering reticence leaves some of the material wanting. Tracks like ""Dawning on Me"" and ""No One to Blame"" are undeniably pretty—understated bits of finely distilled yearning—but they suffer from an intentional vagueness
column3: the genderless and pronoun-free lyrics occasionally treading a fine line between charmingly sweet and frustratingly precious (""Excuse me while I die/ A million times before I meet your eyes with mine"").

column1: For an album of mostly acoustic singer/songwriter fare released only weeks after Sufjan Stevens’ stunning Carrie & Lowell
column2: the simple loveliness of Darling Arithmetic doesn’t always feel like quite enough. O'Brien is a deft songwriter with a wonderfully emotive voice
column3: but it’s only when his lyrics become more pointed—as they do on ""Little Bigot""—that the record soars. Addressing a sort of of everyman asshole
column4: O’Brien advises his would-be hater by singing that ""It’s okay to be tired/ So take the blame
column5: little bigot/ And throw that hatred onto the fire."" Elsewhere
column6: on ""Hot Scary Summer""
column7: he charmingly recollects a lost love—""Remember kissing on the cobblestone/ In the heat of the night/ And all the pretty young homophobes/ Looking out for a fight""—before getting to the real heart of the matter: ""We got good at pretending/ Then pretending got us good."" For anyone who might have spent years grappling with their own idenity—or logged countless hours loving the one who didn't quite love them back the right way—the song hits every perfect bittersweet note.

column1: The need to stop pretending—to admitting one’s deepest insecurities and wants—seems central to Darling Arithmetic
column2: an album that delivers a gorgeous
column3: if somewhat restrained
column4: step forward. It’s a document of quiet
column5: if not necessarily earth-shattering
column6: revelations. ""In the darkness and the light/ I give you every side
column7: O’Brien sings at one point
column8: in what seems as much a promise to a lover as to the listener. Regardless of whether or not O’Brien chooses to go further down the troubadour path of working solo or will fall back into a full band scenario
column9: one can only hope that making this record has proven to be a kind of emotional throat-clearing
column10: a way of moving into potentially murkier and possibly even more personal waters. ""How did I get here?/ Am I ever gonna get back?"" he asks on the album-closing ""So Naïve"" as if revealing oneself so fully has stranded him in uncharted territory. That needn’t be a bad thing though. Previous Villagers records too often felt like puzzles—layers of densely-packed metaphors that
column11: when unraveled
column12: didn’t always add up to much. If Darling Arithmetic is the sound of someone dipping their toes into the waters and finding it to their liking
column13:
then perhaps the next Villagers record will be the sound of O’Brien diving in headfirst—even more fearlessly himself.

Newbridge
column2: the fictional New Jersey suburb invented by Tom Scharpling and Jon Wurster
column3: is a town run on hubris and populated by people who either don't know or refuse to believe that they're deluded failures. That blend of reliable comedy tropes can drive inspiration for a long time
column4: and when Tom Scharpling announced in 2013 that ""The Best Show on WFMU"" was coming to an end
column5: the general consensus was that it was going out on top. Scharpling's alternately cranky and enthusiastic rapport with his callers and the inspired regular-Joe insight of the monologues woven in with them demonstrated his mastery of the radio comedy format
column6: while the extended bits Scharpling did with Superchunk drummer and top-flight weirdo Jon Wurster made it the stuff of legend. This was the kind of phenomenon that sustained a more-or-less-weekly show over 12-plus years
column7: which means their ""greatest hits"" collection is a sixteen-disc
column8: 20-plus hour box set—with a bonus USB stick that includes another 4 ¾-hours' worth of material—that still could be described as ""scraping the surface.""

column1: That's a lot of mileage to get out of just two people
column2: though the trick is that these people actually represent multitudes. Wurster's weirdly sympathetic call-in characters
column3: co-created and co-written with Scharpling
column4: are exercises in gradual-reveal lunacy that ramp up a conversation until both Scharpling and the listener are left repeating Wurster's ludicrous claims (""you are two inches tall"") and malaprops (""laser beans"") with a bewildered disbelief. Over the course of a call that can stretch past the 20- or 30-minute mark
column5: a friendly conversation mutates into a series of escalating threats
column6: an arrogant display of untouchability that eventually crumbles to reveal the hapless loser beneath
column7: or
column8: as the origin-point ""Rock
column9: Rot & Rule"" perfectly revealed
column10: a self-proclaimed expert revealing just how arbitrary and flimsy his knowledge really is. It's comedy that breaks down just how funny it can be to hear somebody with way too much self-confidence obliviously dig his own grave.

column1: It's a cult phenomenon
column2: but nothing about The Best of the Best Show feels closed off or for-fans-only
column3: even given an overstuffed deluxe-package treatment that feels aimed directly at the diehards. The diehards might even find an excuse or two to gripe about omissions (where's ""The Chippert Report"" and its daring exposé of Davenport
column4: Iowa's ""toilet rock"" scene?)
column5: but what's included is definitive and varied enough to draw in both entry-level listeners and longtime fans who snapped up all their previous collections on Stereolaffs.

column1: Of course there are usual suspects and recurring characters. New Jersey-defaming hoagie enthusiast Philly Boy Roy details his family's felonious Memorial Day exploits
column2: battles post-Eagles playoff loss depression
column3: and gets his wife to call in to reveal just how obsessed he is with Scharpling. The aimless
column4: low-energy Pudge gets a few laughs as the call-in regular who has literally nothing to say short of ""I'unno."" And even with his central conceit basically being ""hippie Deadhead who takes bong rips mid-call
column5: Wurster's giggly
column6: wheezy-falsetto performances as Bryce and his rapport with the aggravated-yet patient Scharpling elevate a concept that other comedy acts would make into a one-dimensional caricature.

column1: Couple these regulars with a few of the show's most notorious calls
column2: including the first appearance by Fonzie inspiration/violent elderly sociopath Roland ""The Gorch"" Gorchnik and the introduction of splatter-flick auteur Trent L. Strauss (famed for The Tool Belt Killer
column3: The Hacksawist
column4: and Art School Arson)
column5: and you've got a strong cross-section of what makes the ""Best Show"" canon so beloved. When Wurster gathers more than a dozen of his most popular characters together in an hour-and-a-half panel discussion for Newbridge's highest office during 2008's ""Mayubinatorial Debate""
column6: hearing him inhabit all these different characters in close quarters—Roy
column7: Pudge
column8: monstrously obese barbershop singer Zachary Brimstead
column9: legendary drummer/erotic fiction author Marky Ramone—is pretty astounding. It's worldbuilding of a kind you don't often get from two people in any medium—and they did it pretty much pro bono.

column1: A lot of Scharpling and Wurster's appeal rides on a certain sort of deep-knowledge obsession with the absurd minutiae of popular music and the people that take it extra-seriously. ""Rock
column2: Rot & Rule"" came in the middle of one of Scharpling's pre-""Best Show"" airings and provoked angry fans to call in to object to the rankings of Wurster's know-it-some musicologist Ronald Thomas Clontle. Wannabe rock stars who have unrealistic dreams of making it (""Count Rockula""
column3: whose own box-set vision is trashed by notable music website shovel.com) share space with rock stars who have unrealistic ideas of what ""making it"" entitles them to (Wurster's version of Gene Simmons has a grand old time arrogantly auditioning the actual
column4: in-studio Ted Leo and Carl Newman to be replacement members of KISS). The ""Best Show"" fandom in indie rock is well-documented
column5: and has roped in everyone from Michael Azerrad (briefly interrogated by Wurster on the air as to why Wire Train weren't included in Our Band Could Be Your Life) to Damian Abraham (who became an evangelical enthusiast of the show and broke the ice on tour with Kurt Vile by swapping Philly Boy Roy anecdotes).

column1: You get a ridiculous amount of stuff with this box set
column2: sure: all that audio content
column3: plus a book featuring some great essays by the aforementioned Abraham
column4: comedian Julie Klausner
column5: and call screener A.P. Mike
column6: an extensive interview on the show's origins and developments with Jake Fogelnest
column7: photos of archival material (including crib sheets Wurster used for some of the calls); and illustrations by longtime show-associated cartoonists Neil Numberman and Casey Burns. But what you're really buying
column8: whether you're new to the world of Scharpling and Wurster or a Friend of Tom from back in the day
column9: is an acknowledgement of a hard-won
column10: rightly-earned cult. It's an in-group that always has more room for anyone willing to forge a deep connection with the town that's comin' to get ya. And it can't be stopped—even Scharpling's 2013 farewell turned out to be a hiatus instead
column11: and ""The Best Show"" continues to this day as an Internet show delving deep into the one of the biggest
column12: strangest
column13: best worlds in comedy. There's more—way more—where this box set came from
column14:
and this collection is a prime reminder of why we're lucky that it's not slowing down anytime soon.

"|20203.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20203-scharpling-and-wurster-the-best-of-the-best-show/|8.8|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21734/homepage_large.890e087e.jpg|Pilot Talk III|29043.0|Curren$y|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jet Life']|2015-04-10 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:26.895702|"

Curren$y is such a niche artist that he can seemingly vanish into the air like the weed smoke he so lovingly describes even when he's still active. The New Orleans native tours regularly and continues to release quality projects like last year’s The Drive In Theater
column2: 2013’s New Jet City
column3: and 2011’s Alchemist joint-effort
column4: Covert Coup
column5: but hasn’t been able to duplicate the bite of his 2010 breakthroughs
column6: Pilot Talk and Pilot Talk II. News of the third installation’s arrival sparked more interest than he'd enjoyed in awhile
column7: as those outside of his core fanbase were curious to see if the next volume would do the series justice.

column1: Curren$y is a bit of a cinephile
column2: and treats each individual work like a grand production; it’s evident in the titles of his projects (see his 2012 tribute
column3: Priest Andretti)
column4: and Pilot Talk III begins with ""Opening Credits""
column5: where he strolls over an authoritative soul sample like Max Julien in The Mack. For just over two minutes
column6: he reflects on his career’s trajectory: ""It was right around the time/ I thought I’d have to move back with my mom/ I had to sell my first low-rider/ Halfway to the top went to sleep
column7: woke up at the bottom."" The hopscotch path Curren$y has taken to success (from No Limit
column8: to Cash Money
column9: to independent juggernaut) is well-documented
column10: but he rarely deviates from his cool-guy persona to reflect on his struggles.

column1: Curren$y remains as irreverent as always
column2: but he sounds more focused on Pilot Talk III than he has in awhile. The ominous ""Cargo Planes""
column3: produced by Joey Fatts
column4: sounds like the opening of a cinematic crime saga
column5: but in this case it's a typical Spitta infraction: the theft of someone else’s girlfriend. ""Never displaying affection when we out in public/ 'Cause mufuckas lookin'
column6: and shit could get ugly/ So walk right past me homegirl
column7: and don’t say nothin'"" he advises a female acquaintance. On ""Froze""
column8: eccentric jester RiFF RAFF appears like the ghastly clown from Spawn to exchange swank over Harry Fraud’s slow-burn production
column9: and Curren$y keeps his cool.

column1: Although Spitta's range is limited
column2: it’s never been a disadvantage; he’s a purveyor of lifestyle rap. His song titles
column3: often named after random
column4: inanimate objects or people (in the past we've gotten ""Chandelier""
column5: ""Breakfast""
column6: and ""Scottie Pippen""
column7: and here we have ""Pot Jar
column8: ""Briefcase""
column9: ""Lemonade Mimosas"") testify his ability to find something worthy of appreciation in the seemingly ordinary. On ""Long as the Lord Say""
column10: he sketches familiar imagery: ""Plottin’ like always/ Marble floor hallways/ Smoked out all day/ Tryin’ to get more paid."" His lyrics are like an ad from a men’s magazine targeting the 18 to 25 age demographic in real time.

column1: Because Curren$y himself is a control variable
column2: production typically influences the quality of his output. Ski Beatz
column3: who produced the bulk of the original Pilot Talk and its sequel
column4: has left his imprint on everything from Jay Z’s Reasonable Doubt to Camp Lo’s Uptown Saturday Night. Noticeably absent from Curren$y’s discography following Pilot Talk II
column5: it’s Ski's presence that makes Pilot Talk III so strong. The shimmering crash of the cymbals and pop of the drums on ""Alert"" are vintage Ski and very welcome.

column1: Curren$y may not do ""new
column2: but he is very good at what he does: riffing on cars
column3: money
column4: women
column5: weed
column6: and obscure moments from television shows. It’s difficult for the third version of something to truly reign supreme
column7: especially when there’s little variation differentiating them. ""Audio Dope 5"" is solid
column8: but nowhere near as experimental as the intoxicated stumble of ""Audio Dope II"". Regardless
column9: Curren$y’s sharp wit
column10: the smooth chop of the Sylvers’ ""How Love Hurts"" heard on ""All I Know""
column11: and the return of Ski make Pilot Talk III more than worth it. He's never bad company
column12:
even if you forget he's there from time to time.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21739/homepage_large.dc28abce.jpg|Solo|28863.0|Nils Frahm|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Erased Tapes']|2015-04-10 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:27.469341|"

For many music obsessives
column2: a first close listen to Erik Satie’s Trois Gymnopédies changes everything. The French composer’s three 19th-century piano works serve as an introduction to one kind of minimalism—maximum emotion created with the fewest ingredients—and they show what can happen when you have the right note in the right place at the right time. The formal elegance of the pieces
column3: along with the underlying sense of yearning and clear surface beauty
column4: have made them a natural fit for advertising and film
column5: and the Gymnopédies long ago became ubiquitous
column6: their structure a sort of auditory cliché. But even with the overexposure
column7: the power of Satie’s pieces are still there inside of us
column8: guiding how we respond to simple piano music that leaves a lot of space. Whenever contemporary composers—from Chilly Gonzales to Eluvium to Jandek to Grouper to Aphex Twin—use a piano in this way
column9: they tap into these buried associations.

column1: German composer and producer Nils Frahm’s most recent full-length
column2: his fine 2013 album Spaces
column3: featured plenty of piano but found him putting the instrument into a number of different contexts and adding electronics (the set also included live tracks). But among the earliest works of his career were two albums of solo piano work
column4: and he returns here with a third
column5: an album he gave away free on Twitter two weeks ago. Solo is almost exactly what you might expect from a record like this one; it’s spare
column6: it’s lyrical
column7: it’s generally quiet
column8: and it’s very pretty. Your mileage will vary based on whether that is enough.

column1: Sometimes solo piano albums can get too sentimental
column2: and can begin to sound like bad TV cues; sometimes they can be a little dry and academic
column3: and can come over like an instrumental exercise. This one mostly fits into ""just right"" territory
column4: balancing general loveliness with space and suggestion. Frahm's piano is creaky and there's a percussive tone coursing through some of these tracks
column5: an extra ""pling"" that marks time with every keystroke. That extra texture gives a piece like ""Merry"" a tiny bit of grit to offset a gorgeous melody that might otherwise be overbearing
column6: and gives the more downcast ""Some"" an extra ounce of dark weight. During its best moments Solo brings to mind some of the lower-stakes work of Harold Budd
column7: where melody and mood become two sides of the same coin.

column1: The album’s second half finds Frahm playing more with form
column2: but oddly the variety
column3: rather than being welcome
column4: actually breaks the spell of the album’s first half. ""Wall"" is a loud
column5: pulsing piece that is interesting enough on its own but derails the album’s gentle mood
column6: while ""Immerse!"" leans toward meandering abstraction
column7: foregoing melody and in no way justifying its almost 11-minute length. Still
column8: for a free album that sounds very nice in a room
column9: Solo mostly delivers
column10:
tapping into that very specific identification with the solo piano as an expression of wistful sadness.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21614/homepage_large.3f96ba98.jpg|Suuns and Jerusalem in My Heart|32878.0|Suuns and Jerusalem in My Heart|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Secretly Canadian']|2015-04-10 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:28.263421|"

Judging from their respective recorded output to date
column2: Suuns and Jerusalem in My Heart don’t seem to share anything beyond Montreal postal codes. The former is an archetypal indie rock band—four white guys in standard guitar/bass/synth/drums formation
column3: belonging to a distinctly Western tradition of dystopian art-punk. The latter is the multimedia recording project of Radwan Ghazi Moumneh
column4: a producer of Lebanese descent refracting traditional Middle Eastern music through a modernist
column5: avant-garde lens (right down to the numerically dense song titles that reflect Arabic text-speak for sounds not represented by English characters). Suuns release albums through populist indie labels like Secret City (in Canada) and Secretly Canadian (in the United States) and have reached the ""what the fuck
column6: we’ll do a Nike commercial"" stage of their careers. Moumneh records for the defiantly non-conformist Constellation label
column7: and works as a sound engineer
column8: producer and co-owner at the Godspeed-affiliated Hotel2Tango studio. Suuns thrive on structural linearity and rhythmic precision; Jerusalem in My Heart demonstrates what you can do when you completely disavow both.

column1: But for a city of millions of people
column2: Montreal is a small town when it comes to Anglophone musicians with experimental leanings
column3: and in the case of Suuns and Jerusalem in My Heart
column4: there exists not just a mutual-admiration society but a full-blown recording collaboration. The seven pieces on their jointly billed eponymous debut were actually recorded during a week-long session back in November 2012
column5: but put on the backburner as both principals prepped their respective 2013 albums (Suuns’ Images Du Futur and Jerusalem in My Heart’s debut
column6: Mo7it Al-Mo7it). However
column7: the extended gestation period between conception and delivery proves immaterial
column8: because Suuns and Jerusalem in My Heart sounds very little like the music either was making on their own at the time of its recording. The album’s success is contingent on the very fact that it never feels like a forced collision of two opposing musical approaches
column9: but rather a natural cultivation of a shared underlying philosophy.

column1: What Suuns and Jerusalem in My Heart ultimately do have in common is a desired end goal of transcendence—the former’s two albums to date attempt it through lock-step grooves
column2: synth-throbbed hypnosis
column3: and Ben Shemie’s smeared vocalese; on Mo7it Al-Mo7it
column4: the latter opted for free-form acoustic meditations
column5: analog-electronic oscillations
column6: and equilibrium-upsetting chants. On Suuns and Jerusalem in My Heart
column7: the collaborators unite Western rock convention with their ancient old-world antecedents: The appropriately clanging instrumental ""Metal"" plays like a call-and-response between a distorted Arabic melody—a distant echo of the Syrian wedding-singer boombox bootlegs that are foundational to the JIMH sound—and a mimicking fuzz-toned guitar that effectively turns it into a '60s surf riff. The glitchy and twitchy ""Seif"" relocates Panda Bear to Beirut; the exhilarating closer ""3attam Babey"" hits pause on its whirring
column8: motorik
column9: synth-punk drive to accommodate Moumneh’s meditative vocal breaks
column10: before an extended outro fuses them into the same third-eye-prying frequency.

column1: Suuns and Jerusalem in My Heart does leave you wondering what more the two entities could have accomplished had they worked on this for more than a week: the ominously intensifying clatter of ""Gazelles in Flight"" fades out just as the track seems ready to truly take off
column2: while the incongruously off-the-cuff lullaby ""Leyla"" feels like a rough Suuns song sketch that lacks any of the collaborative frisson heard elsewhere on the record. But for both parties
column3: the benefits of this recording experiment are obvious: For Suuns
column4: it’s an opportunity to break out of their hermetic aesthetic and explore more open-ended modes of composition; for Moumneh
column5: it’s a chance to forsake meticulously crafted soundscapes to indulge his love of raw punk and thumping techno. And whether they’re channeling the serene spirit of '70s krautrock or the corrosive croon of a Damascus busker
column6: the implicit message is the same: for these two
column7:
there’s no place like drone.

"|20348.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20348-suuns-and-jerusalem-in-my-heart/|7.2|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21553/homepage_large.804835dd.jpg|Culture of Volume|31096.0|East India Youth|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['XL']|2015-04-10 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:29.182510|"

William Doyle has an unassuming presence. His voice has a crystalline
column2: choirboy quality
column3: a projection of pure light
column4: and on the cover of <i>Culture of Volume
column5: he's wearing a navy blazer with a tie clip and a tousled haircut; it could be ripped from his prep school yearbook. He performs alone
column6: standing behind a standard setup of MacBooks
column7: samplers and holding a bass guitar.

column1: And yet
column2: his East India Youth project has a distinctly intimidating air. Here is an incomplete list of the bulletproof influences he's namedropped for Culture of Volume: Brian Eno
column3: Pet Shop Boys
column4: Cluster
column5: Andy Warhol
column6: David Bowie
column7: Yellow Magic Orchestra. The album title is taken from a poem written by Eno collaborator Rick Holland. Music critics started a label for the sole purpose of releasing his first 12” and of course
column8: he was nominated for a Mercury Prize a year later. Coming on the heels of the idea-packed but unfocused Total Strife Forever
column9: Culture of Volume is poised for a presumable ""pop"" breakout
column10: but it still comes off as an academic pursuit
column11: a veritable thesis on the legends of avant-garde art-pop. Culture of Volume doesn't just want to impress you; it wants you to behold it with chin-stroking
column12: head-nodding awe.

column1: At times this is the only pose even Doyle can muster towards his work. In the credits
column2: he refers to the making of Culture of Volume as The Process and the first vocal track details the process of creating The Process. ""The end result is not what was in mind/ The end result is always hard to find
column3: Doyle sings during ""End Result""
column4: treating inspiration like a forensics expert. It’s preceded by a lengthy Station to Station homage of daunting electronic noise called ""The Juddering"". The guy likes definitive articles.

column1: And so Culture of Volume presents itself as a record of Big Ideas and Big Statements and it sure as hell sounds big. ""Beaming White"" is the third track here
column2: and that title about sums up the production's hyperclarity. Every drum pattern
column3: every synth pad
column4: every orchestral frill is a tool used to build gleaming edifices to house his spotless vocals. It sounds fantastic
column5: which is to be expected of a record mixed by Graham Sutton. The Bark Psychosis frontman has also worked with These New Puritans and British Sea Power and very few others; he’s not getting involved if the artist doesn’t aspire for a certain museum-ready quality. But those bands also understand the idea of art as entertainment; they’re showmen
column6: whereas Doyle is a curator.

column1: ""Don’t Look Backwards"" toys with the idea of Balearic
column2: but it's a picture of Ibiza without the partygoers
column3: presenting a ""vague horizon set ablaze."" To convey a heightened emotional state
column4: Doyle will say
column5: ""At the point of passion/ I am inflamed""; it’s a rather chilly way of saying you’ve got the hots for someone. ""Entirety"" and ""Hearts That Never"" are futuristic electro-pop for dance clubs that always meet sanitation codes. And even if they are highbrow pop songs
column6: they’re still pop songs all the same—Doyle needs to sell them.

column1: He could one day evolve into a Patrick Wolf or Owen Pallett-style auteur
column2: but he currently lacks their capacity for theatrics
column3: for personal revelation
column4: for a vocal mode that conveys something other than bathos
column5: for melodies that actually pop. If he’s going to try for a show-stopping
column6: six-minute ballad
column7: like he does on ""Carousel""
column8: there has to be a show to stop in the first place; here
column9: ""Carousel"" is a confession to an empty arena. The same applies to ""A Manner of Words""; Doyle asks
column10: ""Turn this dull roar down""
column11: and then the song goes on to serve as the record's 10-minute anticlimax. For a record so bent on impressing the listener
column12:
Culture of Volume somehow never manages to leave a mark.

"|20286.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20286-culture-of-volume/|5.7|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21658/homepage_large.c44f4eaf.jpg|White Men Are Black Men Too|30771.0|Young Fathers|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Big Dada']|2015-04-09 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:29.721050|"

The Edinburgh trio Young Fathers have always confounded categories—Tape One and Tape Two
column2: the EPs they released in 2011 and 2013
column3: were often called rap
column4: but always trailing qualifiers—""alt-
column5: ""art-
column6: ""psych-"". Then
column7: as their Shabazz-on-uppers verses (""I Heard"") and grimy Yeezus shrieks (""Effigy"") faded
column8: they shifted again: their Mercury Prize-winning debut full-length Dead landed somewhere close to what people thought of as ""hip-hop
column9: if similarly prefaced—""experimental
column10: ""alternative
column11: or just ""Scottish.""

column1: You don’t call your record White Men Are Black Men Too unless you’re looking to stir up some questions about classification
column2: and with their new album
column3: Young Fathers double down on the confusion they inspired with their earliest releases. Their label bio even leads with the statement that the group has ""no ancestors
column4: which is a funny thing to say about three men calling themselves Young Fathers because they all inherited their dads’ names. But their lineage is important
column5: and audible: Graham ""G"" Hastings was born in Edinburgh; Alloysious Massaquoi hails from Liberia via Ghana
column6: and Kayus Bankole was raised in the US by Nigerian parents. Young Fathers not only have ancestors but draw an enormous amount of energy from them
column7: as White Men Are Black Men Too makes obvious: The record is a direct descendent of TV on the Radio
column8: a grandson of krautrock
column9: a distant relative of the earnest Streets
column10: a grungy nephew of Arcade Fire. And
column11: though it might change by the next time around
column12: they’ve hit an unqualified category
column13: for the first time: this is a rock record
column14: almost a pop record. It’s raucous
column15: messy
column16: marked by a profound sense of urgency
column17: intended to uplift and discomfit.

column1: Remarkably
column2: White Men Are Black Men Too also addresses the questions posed by its name. The lyrics begin the conversation
column3: but only get so far:  ""Old Rock N Roll"" starts with ""I’m tired of playing the good black/ I’m tired of having to hold back/ I’m tired of wearing this hallmark for some evils that happened way back."" Then
column4: the speaker flips his loyalty—""I’m tired of blaming the white men/ His indiscretion don’t betray him""-—and reverses the album title: ""A black man can play him."" Then it flips back: ""Some white men are black men too
column5: nigga to them
column6: a gentleman to you.""

column1: The idea is jumbled
column2: a little hollow
column3: mostly a venting of frustration. More to the point is this simple line on ""Rain or Shine"": ""I ain’t strange enough."" And the most honest moment on the album
column4: the moment where Young Fathers delineate their worldview the most clearly
column5: is on the album’s standout (and most overtly TV on the Radio-soundalike) single ""Shame""
column6: which begins with a dusty
column7: drum-machine twinkle and rises up into a big
column8: ragged
column9: radio-ready melody. The chorus
column10: self-flagellating and triumphant
column11: switches between cries of ""It ain’t right
column12: baby"" and ""What you do to feel better! What you do to feel good!""

column1: But at any rate
column2: the words are just the address on the envelope; the music is the letter itself. There is an appealing coherence in the album’s composition. Most of the tracks are built on juxtaposition between the low and high register: a vamping bass riff against a shrill glockenspiel
column3: a dark guitar loop beneath a top cacophony of horns
column4: synths
column5: vocal wails. It’s a simple framework and a strong mirror to Young Fathers’ submerged cultural project: delineating a foundational reality (race
column6: genre) and then mounting a tantrum against it. And
column7: in the midst of this dissonance
column8: the album’s sound is all tied together by shreds of surefooted
column9: strong pop melody: ""27"" sounds almost like pitch-warped Passion Pit by way of the Avalanches
column10: and ""Dare Me"" seems like a sweet little organ-backed ballad until it throws up a middle finger and breaks into an atonal
column11: menacing shuffle.

column1: It’s not all coherent or wholly successful. Young Fathers’ people’s-mic earnestness can combine with their penchant for major-chord toplines to produce a funky but unmistakable cheese
column2: as in ""Sirens"". Their fractious energy slants unfocused at times
column3: too
column4: and though the group does answer the question provoked by their album title
column5: they do so by throwing their hands up—compacting the past like so much garbage and charging ahead. The sound of White Men Are Black Men Too is telling enough. It’s triumphant music for the hyperactive
column6: plural city; it’s confrontational as a means to achieving communality
column7: with no particular loyalties except to an anonymous
column8: shifting collective of people who all want the same thing as Young Fathers—to be one thing
column9: then the next
column10:
then the next.

"|20391.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20391-white-men-are-black-men-too/|6.8|Jia Tolentino

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21623/homepage_large.8a8c51f9.jpg|All Are Saved|30908.0|Fred Thomas|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Polyvinyl']|2015-04-09 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:30.349204|"

Talk to anyone who’s seen an indie rock show in Michigan during the 21st century and you’ll probably get a Fred Thomas story within the first thirty minutes or so. Maybe it was the time their band played with one of Thomas' 156 (give or take) musical projects at a warehouse in Ypsilanti. Or maybe they crossed paths at a demonstration in Detroit. To quote a colleague
column2: ""Fred Thomas is always standing right behind you at a basement show in Ann Arbor."" Which is to say that Thomas is a ""lifer""
column3: that mainstay of the local scene usually viewed with some combination of admiration and concern. Their commitment is cool even if they’re pushing 40 and clearly not in it for the money
column4: but what are their alternatives? Do they have any marketable job skills?

column1: Thomas' most well-known project
column2: the lo-fi throwback pop troupe Saturday Looks Good to Me
column3: developed a cult following
column4: but was always on the verge of a mainstream-indie breakthrough that never happened. He's also released eight albums under his own name
column5: but All Are Saved is the first to see widespread release. From the sound of things
column6: Fred Thomas would be at peace if it was his last. It's in the tradition of a very specific kind of record
column7: including Father John Misty’s Fear Fun
column8: Sun Kil Moon’s Among the Leaves and the Wrens’ The Meadowlands—artists reinventing themselves as their actual self
column9: lifers tired of watching their life pass by
column10: tired of public indifference. With nothing to lose
column11: Thomas ditches any pretense of metaphor to speak on every embarrassment and sleep-depriving doubt. And the results are devastating and funny in ways that previous releases barely even considered
column12: a biographical work of art capable of leveling people who have never heard of Fred Thomas until the previous paragraph.

column1: This is a record of epiphany
column2: but there are no easy resolutions and false triumph. Despite its title
column3: All Are Saved does not wrestle with mortality and arise with The Truth About What it All Means. It does not glorify the preciousness of our short existence. Most of it is derived from the realization that life
column4: as it’s keenly described on ""Cops Don’t Care Pt. II""
column5: ""is so incredibly long/ Like a kiss on a bridge between two nervous ass kids/ Terrified of doing everything wrong."" The image of teenage lip-locking pops up on two different songs: on ""When They Built the Schools""
column6: Thomas recognizes the ""jelly legs and awkward elbows"" of first-timers who have no time for the ""burden of nostalgia"" that clings to him like a wetsuit and essentially translates to ""regret"".

column1: Most of the memories Thomas processes on All Are Saved aren’t even good ones
column2: and yet they’re revived with piercing clarity—drunkenly smashing his flip phone in a Baltimore basement in 2003; watching a girl get embarrassed by her dad’s use of slang on an airplane; the role reversal of going to a free dental clinic and having his dentist turn out to be a drummer he produced eight years ago. These are the types of situations that fill up an impossibly long life
column3: so when Thomas opens the album asking his dog in its dying days whether trading 13 years of ""walking in a clear straight line"" for a human’s eight potential decades of fumbling is a ""shitty deal""
column4: well... the answer is obvious
column5: right?

column1: The album at least sounds uplifting
column2: adding layer after layer while Thomas spins desperately in place. The aesthetic reflects the two cities in which this album was created
column3: honoring Athens' indie rock lineage by its Elephant 6-style thrift shop orchestration. If you’ve followed Thomas over the past two decades
column4: this is a culminating work: the contrast of peppy horn blasts and foul-mouthed misanthropy on ""Expo '87"" recall Saturday Looks Good to Me; the spindly arpeggios of ""When They Built the Schools"" nod towards his emo-ish offshoot Lovesick; and the aquatic gurgling and electronic interludes make a case for reappreciation of his Type Records outlier City Center (namechecked in ""Unfading Flower"").

column1: But otherwise
column2: this is an idiosyncratic ""singer-songwriter"" record
column3: filled with surprises and unorthodox percussion choices—a soupy tabla sample on ""Unfading Flower""
column4: an erratic pound of a floor tom guiding the drunken amble of ""When They Built the Schools"". Vocally
column5: Thomas largely abandons conventional song structure and melodies
column6: taking on a quasi spoken-word approach that allows him the maximum word count and lends a sarcastic edge to his sly note on""Bedbugs"": ""If I seem too entertaining
column7: I’m not singing
column8: I’m just talking to you.""

column1: The most entertaining songs on All Are Saved are generally the cruelest: Both ""Bedbugs"" and ""Bad Blood"" speak in a language simultaneously more truthful and cutting than most of us allow ourselves. These rambling
column2: bilious one-sided conversations might be mislabeled as ""rants""; more accurately
column3: they’re the kind of righteously angry emails you spend all night honing to a fine point
column4: and then sleep on
column5: waking up relieved you never hit ""Send."" Thomas provides us vicarious catharsis
column6: but during the toxic airing of grievances of ""Bedbugs""
column7: he makes the risks of such an approach perfectly clear—""You can’t tell everybody to fuck off forever.../ And be mortified when they finally do.""

column1: Thomas trudges through difficult relationships like most of us
column2: being ""so stilted and silent
column3: not awkward
column4: just angry."" That’s how he describes his presumable run-in with a more successful artist on ""Bad Blood""
column5: whose music he likens to ""a pile of brown sweaters."" All at once
column6: he wishes he could go beyond their brief exchange and express his envy and resentments
column7: that it could be Thomas on TV in 2015 had things worked out just a little bit differently for Saturday Looks Good to Me. Instead
column8: he blasts through the fourth wall
column9: summarizing the futility of his past decade with a gut punch—""This ‘first day of school’ shit just seems to keep happening...the smiles are so big and there’s no one at the gig."" The most painful lines are Thomas quoting other people—""Hey I gotta go
column10: but I’ll see you at the show!""
column11: ""Man
column12: it’s so cool
column13: we’re glad you’re doing your own thing."" It's the sound of Thomas realizing that most of his interactions are compromised by his own self-pity and dishonesty.

column1: And yet
column2: this realization is the strange source of hope in All Are Saved: Thomas seems inspired
column3: even moved
column4: by the possibility that the sharp
column5: overwhelming and temporary pain of being forthright with someone can be a breakthrough after years and years of silence and half-truths.  It ties back to that line about those kids on the bridge and how Thomas sets an example throughout All Are Saved—life is incredibly long when you’re terrified of doing anything wrong
column6: and in the process of connecting with another person
column7:
it’s best to just go for it as directly as possible.

It’s very possible that we’ve heard the last of Brian Wilson. Not because the opulent pop of the Beach Boys
column2: or his rich and tortured personal mythology
column3: are showing any fade in ubiquity—a movie about both
column4: with Paul Dano and John Cusack playing younger and current-day versions of him
column5: respectively
column6: comes out this summer—but because the man himself is speaking bluntly of his possible retirement from music this year.

column1: So for anyone who grew up with a reverence for Wilson’s brilliant work—which
column2: especially if you’re from California
column3: can veer into a fanatic sort of transposed paternal empathy—his new and eleventh solo album No Pier Pressure carries the burden of serving as his gold watch. Yet the record largely cedes the floor to duets with trendy young singers (Kacey Musgraves
column4: Nate Ruess of fun.
column5: Zooey Deschanel
column6: all audibly rhapsodic)
column7: a foreign and not entirely flattering experiment for Wilson. The album’s clearest predecessor is Santana’s Supernatural (1999)
column8: from which sprang the malevolent radio hydra ""Smooth""
column9: and other forays into May-September duet hinterland. (There’s been an upswing of the latter in the past year
column10: from Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga fluttering their jazz hands all hither and thither to Barry Manilow’s gauche
column11: grave-digging extreme of shoving his voice into dusty audio of Whitney Houston and Marilyn Monroe.)

column1: Unlike Carlos Santana
column2: though
column3: who could just wedge in a noodling guitar break and shuffle back to his inexplicable stiletto empire
column4: Wilson’s chipper duets never reach equilibrium. Either his presence feels underutilized—the syrupy ""On the Island"" with She & Him
column5: in which his vocals are scant—or the guests feel shoehorned into musty production that undermines their own charisma. It’s apparent throughout that this album was originally intended as a reunited Beach Boys effort
column6: as their songwriting staples are faithfully represented: the orchestrations are lush and swooning
column7: the lyrics set in beatific seaside tableaus and brimming with sepia wistfulness. Wilson sounds most confident with his former band cohorts; several tracks feature amiable turns from Al Jardine and David Marks. Of the whippersnapper duets
column8: Wilson’s coziest harmonizing with Ruess
column9: whose high
column10: earnest keening could’ve been plucked from the Beach Boys’ Sunflower era.

column1: In listening to No Pier Pressure
column2: uneasy questions rise about base motives. Wilson freely admits that he doesn’t listen to modern music
column3: and was so surprised to hear Frank Ocean rap that he dismissed him from the album. That likely means that these duet artists were pitched to him for the project
column4: with the hopes that some of those younger fanbases would follow along. It’s a pretty farfetched expectation: are Zooey Deschanel’s fans now really going to stampede en masse to the nearest Urban Outfitters and demand Orange Crate Art?

column1: But to speculate this project was foisted whole on Wilson would infantilize him
column2: a casual disservice done all too readily in the press (what other 72-year-old Grammy winner’s collaborations would prompt the caveat ""whether he’s aware of it or not
column3: despite his ability to still deliver an incisive interview?). And there’s a warm timbre to all these artists’ voices that could surely appeal to Wilson. Whatever the cause
column4: this is new territory for him: He’s sat in with young bucks here and there (Mini Mansions
column5: Emile Haynie
column6: the adulatory Brian Fest concert last month in Los Angeles) but he’s never been gregarious with his own material. His most recent album collaborators have been old friends returned to the fold
column7: from a reunion with Smile lyricist Van Dyke Parks to the global Beach Boys reunion of 2012.

column1: There’s a happy accident in disunion
column2: though: the closing track ""The Last Song""
column3: which was originally intended for Lana Del Rey before she sulked off into the sunset. It’s the autonomous note Wilson deserves to end on
column4: a lovely
column5: bittersweet swath of the elegiac strings and gilded harmonies he perfected in his youth with ""The Warmth of the Sun"" and ""Caroline
column6: No"". Wilson sighs
column7: ""Don’t be sad/ There was a time and place for what we had/ If there was just another chance for me to sing to you."" It’s a worthy
column8: prideful summation of a gorgeous life’s work
column9:
both innocent and wizened at once. And he didn’t need any young blood to get there.

column13: sample-based avant-pop. It all reads like a young

column1: Lesser Evil made good on that promise in 2013
column2: revealing that Woodhead's frenzied melodic sensibilities and nasally squeak could transcend the cresting wave of Merriweather Post Pavilion devotees. Lesser Evil was also fortunate enough to be wedged between the ascending stars of Grimes' Visions and Majical Cloudz's Impersonator: It was a good time to be an arty millennial with a laptop
column3: and better still to be an information-hungry sound collagist with a distinctive voice. But where Visions embraced fluttering digitalia and Impersonator took a more direct
column4: humanist approach
column5: Doldrums' first LP burrowed into the uncanny valley
column6: forging its identity from the schizophrenic clutter of online media and the hallucinatory states readily available in everyday life. Sleep
column7: lucid dreaming
column8: technology
column9: ancient mysticism
column10: prescription drugs
column11: obscure YouTube clips
column12: popular music
column13: obsession
column14: anxiety
column15: love
column16: death—Lesser Evil somehow made it all fit inside a puzzling logic that was more intriguing for its inscrutable delirium.

column1: So it makes sense that Woodhead would continue his train of thought on album two
column2: The Air Conditioned Nightmare. But if Lesser Evil took a macro view of that mania through a greased fisheye lens
column3: then Nightmare examines it with a magnifying glass under harsh fluorescent light. And that can be just as unflattering as it sounds. The elements and production methods haven't been replaced so much as they've been reassessed and recalibrated. No longer is Woodhead's Yorke-ian tenor awash in whirlpools of clipped audio and choppy beat fragments; now the underlying synths have taken a forceful lead next to polished and pronounced drum machines. Doldrums has effectively cleaned up his act
column4: and in the process he's rendered his music's least remarkable parts the loudest and most integral.

column1: A bonkers track like ""HOTFOOT""
column2: or the elegiac splendor of ""Funeral for Lightning""
column3: works best in this new setting
column4: largely because the energy and songwriting are powerful enough to wheedle some emotional magic out of the machines. More often than not
column5: though
column6: Nightmare buries the details in favor of a generic synth hook or noodly freakout. The saccharine bassline in ""Loops""

column9: when the song doesn't digress into a beatless murk of pitchy vocals and awkward sample juggling. On ""Industry City""
column10: Doldrums attempts to balance aggressive electro
column11: slippery machine funk
column12: aerial singalongs
column13: and noisy rave approximations. It might go over well at a midday festival performance
column14: but on record it sounds like tracklist filler.

column1: There are good ideas somewhere inside The Air Conditioned Nightmare
column2: and anyone determined enough to look might get something out of them. Lyrics ranging from naively clichéd to slyly astute—often within the same verse—sketch a rough picture of Woodhead coming to grips with routine
column3: non-transitory life. He fears the impending threat of mundane domestic relationships (""Blown Away"")
column4: condemns technological dependence (""My Friend Simjen""
column5: ""Industry City"")
column6: illustrates the throes of romance (""We Awake""

column8: and ponders the loss of art and artists (""Funeral for Lightning""). The themes here are vaguely linked to a collection of Henry Miller essays on America's growing disconnection from nature and mankind
column9: but no one would fault you for not catching any similarities outside of their shared title. Not even the singer himself can find a clear through line for his scattered coming-of-age musings. Some might call it simply ""growing up.""

column1: Of all the songs
column2: ""Video Hostage"" is the most significant. It also happens to be Nightmare's unrivaled highlight. Over a rhythmic sample set that billows and sways like something off Oneohtrix Point Never's Replica
column3: Woodhead waxes analytical while in a trauma-induced existential trance. He's said it's loosely about desensitization

column7: and nature. Woodhead seems to shed the world around him

column10: and the music's effortless
column11: unassuming composition mirrors his effort. You could say it's a rare sign of growth on the capricious Nightmare
column12:
but maybe it's just Doldrums finding himself right where he needs to be.

What if the voice weren’t the original instrument? What if it all began with breath? That’s one question at the heart of Gabrielle Herbst’s debut album as GABI
column2: in which the singer and composer takes gorgeous

column1: Pop records written with this kind of academic rigor are rare. Herbst studied composition at Bard with new-music heavyweights like Zeena Parkins and Marina Rosenfeld; later
column2: she was an artist-in-residence at Robert Wilson’s Watermill Center

column7: kaleidoscopic arrays.

column8: ""electricity

column11: the occasional flash of language.

The text of ""Home"" is just five words long (""Stay with him/ I’m home"") and the closing ""Hymn"" even shorter: ""Hallelujah! Blood and water."" But words on the page are hardly the point. The magic is in the way she embodies them—in the idea of breath incarnate. In repetition
column3: they take on the weight of ritual

column3: random but with a sense of purpose and believability. I seek to make organic rhythms with an internal logic even if that logic is not obvious or straightforward."" In Sympathy
column4: that takes the form of tidal forces: phrases imperceptibly speeding and slowing

Captain of None
column2: the sixth solo album from Colleen (née French multi-instrumentalist Cécile Schott)
column3: is the product of an unusual series of creative decisions. Her primary instrument is once again a Renaissance-era treble viola da gamba

column1: The gut-string viola da gamba first appeared in the mid-15th century and it's seldom heard these days outside of early music ensembles. This general lack of use and natural versatility make the instrument difficult for modern ears to easily identify. When bowed
column2: it can sound like a cello or a modern viola; when plucked or strummed
column3: it can sound like a harp or lute; and when tapped or thumped
column4: it can even sound something like a hammered dulcimer. Schott has made use of all of these techniques at various points
column5: but on earlier albums such as 2007’s Les Ondes Silencieuses
column6: her playing style was more traditional and her compositions more closely centered on post-Baroque chamber music.

column1: On Captain of None
column2: however
column3: Schott casts tradition aside and frequently uses her viola da gamba as a percussion instrument to create impressively rich
column4: dub-inflected basslines. In live performance and on past records
column5: she has used various samples
column6: loops
column7: and delay pedals to layer her voice and instruments back upon themselves. Here
column8: on such tracks as ""This Hammer Breaks"" she pushes these techniques to a new level of invention
column9: with the strings of her viola refracted beyond all recognition.

column1: In fact

column1: The album’s dub influence is felt most strongly on the bass-heavy ""Eclipse"" or ""Salina Stars""
column2: which is laced with an Augustus Pablo-style melodica. It’s tricky to make a true dub album without the benefit of an actual rhythm section

column5: and the way Colleen uses classical acoustic instruments to reconfigure modern idioms recalls Arthur Russell’s cello-driven World of Echo or Hauschka’s house music variations on Salon des Amateurs. Somehow

Lately it seems like 1980s revivalism won’t subside. But there’s something wistful about the latest variety. The synths have the sculpted plastic bigness of Aquanet coifs
column2: the rhythms sway like prom dances
column3: and the lyrics seem tailored toward movie makeouts (or at least heavy stares). It’s become the default sound for a certain rising artist: think small-pop as mall-pop. Even the world of mainstream pop is there: see ""Doing It""
column4: Charli XCX’s moon-eyed pastiche of ""Lucky Star"" and ""Crazy For You""
column5: or Taylor Swift’s record named after and sounding just like 1989
column6: or Carly Rae Jepsen abandoning her prior tween squees for the Dev Hynes-produced prom slow dance ""All That"". Listening to the revivalists
column7: one would be forgiven for thinking the entire decade took place entirely inside roller rinks
column8: at night
column9: during one long
column10: teary last dance.

column1: As the twin daughters of Steve Kilbey of the Church
column2: Elektra and Miranda Kilbey have a better connection to this side of the '80s than most. Their father's band is best known for the dreamily acoustic ""Under the Milky Way""
column3: but is also responsible between its members for a small pantheon of side projects
column4: most somewhere in the folk/dream pop realm. And the Kilbey sisters aren't new to the form either: they've trod the pop boards as Say Lou Lou (formerly Saint Lou Lou) since 2012
column5: and at this point
column6: their sound’s crystallized into a formula. The setting will be night
column7: or at least dark: one early track was titled ""Better in the Dark""
column8: and the sentiment’s repeated at least twice on Lucid Dreaming. Their voices will keen plaintively over the beat. The reverb will sound reverbed. Enough gold and glitter will flow through photography and lyrics to put Tinkerbell
column9: El Dorado
column10: and Kesha out of commission. Listen to more than a few of their songs
column11: and these start seeming less like running motifs and more like a drinking game.

column1: Whether this comes off as heady atmosphere or anemic samey blur depends mostly on how many tracks have passed in succession—their first label
column2: Kitsuné
column3: is best known as a singles label—but there are some highs amid the fog. Opener ""Everything We Touch"" is as good a condensation of the Say Lou Lou sound as any: a midtempo track that sparkles like an ice palace
column4: full of poetaster plaints (""there’s a ghost in the machine and there’s a glowing light"") that do indeed sound better in the dark. ""Glitter"" is among the more substantial cuts
column5: a lite disco throb reminiscent of the highlights of Little Boots’ Nocturnes.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: sonic departures are so few that they’re almost welcome merely for existing. Lindstrøm collaboration ""Games For Girls"" uses the twins’ breathy blankness to taunting effect: ""I never tell you what I’m thinking about/ I don’t do anything at all
column3: they coo over Lindstrøm’s politely louche disco strut
column4: and the effect is provocative if a bit obvious. Liam Howe-penned ""Peppermint"" churns the atmosphere into a storm swell: the foregrounded piano
column5: strings
column6: and whispers conjure enough heaving melodrama that the twins get across a truly silly central metaphor.

column1: This isn’t necessarily a given. Early track ""Julian"" tries for plot
column2: namely that of a young-adult dystopia—""I’ll get us through the checkpoint
column3: I know we’ll be alright""—a Sarah Cracknellian conceit undermined by the Kilbey twins singing it as if the car’s pumping out soma. The entire back half of the album is undeniably pretty in patches—some Eurythmics arpeggiation here
column4: Robert Miles piano there
column5: an obvious hook more or less—but otherwise an indistinguishable haze
column6: put over neither by the bleary-pretty instrumentation or the twins’ somewhat thin voices.

column1: Lucid Dreaming arrives after a succession of delays: debut single ""Maybe You"" dates back to 2012
column2: they made the BBC Sound of 2014 longlist for tracks that emerged in early 2013
column3: and the new material on Lucid Dreaming isn’t much of a departure from those. For an act so consistent in their sound
column4: it’s hard to get a bead on their ambitions. The chanted hook and big drums of ""Nothing But a Heartbeat"" suggest Top 40 hopes
column5: but that ground’s been trod often and better. Say Lou Lou’s place would be something like Tove Lo without the biting lyrical voice
column6: or maybe Tegan and Sara’s Heartthrob without the rush of feelings or huge legacy fanbase. They could go full-on dance—a promising option
column7: if not always as starmaking for female vocalists than the usually-men behind the boards. Or they could remain in their current blog-pop lane—a slow
column8: steady path with devotees to be found along the way. After all
column9:
nocturnal melancholia sounds glorious during the night. It's just that something’s got to happen once the lights come up.

Last year was a hard one for Henry Laufer. The Los Angeles native
column3: who records and performs as Shlohmo
column4: saw a collaborative EP with Jeremih delayed for months by mismanagement at Def Jam. In July
column5: the two artists gave up and released the record for free
column6: only to receive lukewarm reviews. Laufer also suffered through some personal losses
column7: ones that he’s done his best to keep private. He’s spoken of hospital visits and funerals

column1: His second full-length
column2: Dark Red
column3: channels that heavy energy. The album is jarringly different from Laufer’s past work and a difficult
column4: oft-deafening listen. The emotional anguish contained in many of these tracks was hinted at on his 2013 solo EP
column5: Laid Out
column6: but some internal dial has spun from ""ennui"" to ""cold rage."" The album’s third track
column7: ""Buried""
column8: is most representative

column10: distorted into fragments and underscored with menacing guitar progressions. Shlohmo has always been a fan of distortion
column11: but on Dark Red he’s beating his synths to hell
column12: from the opening chords of ""Meet Ur Maker""

column1: Shlohmo has testified many times recently that he is looking to avoid the trappings of his more pop-leaning projects. Once
column2: he made an avant-garde R&B that resembled the production of mainstream foils like Drake and the Weeknd. Now he’s dabbling in ambient noise and prog with dashes of drum’n’bass and allusions to footwork. Vocals are gone
column3: samples chopped and buried. Collaborations have largely been nixed: ""I just want to do my own fucking thing
column4: Laufer said in a recent profile.

column1: Fans of the producer’s older work may blanche at the aggression of the first three tracks here
column2: which function as an aural ""Beware of Dog"" sign
column3: warning the faint of heart away. Yet after repeated listens

column5: demanding attention but also meriting it. Those who want the old Shlohmo will have to wait for the final two tracks
column6: ""Fading"" and ""Beams""
column7: which concede to fans
column8: and constitute a kind of middle ground between the producer’s past work and the new album.

column1: If Dark Red were another EP
column2: all that fury boiled down to a manageable five or six tracks might make an impressive statement. At an hour run-time
column3: Shlohmo’s change in tenor loses its shock value and becomes a slog. The four tracks that make up the album’s mid-section are unmemorable
column4: a fact that their names—""Apathy""
column5: ""Relentless""
column6: ""Ditch""
column7: ""Remains""—seem to acknowledge explicitly. When the album’s rhythm finally picks up again on the drum and bass influenced ""Fading""
column8: it comes as a major relief.

column1: Los Angeles’s Low End Theory club was an early site of the alchemical process that has melded hip-hop kids and beatheads together into a formidable coalition. Laufer was a frequent attendee and in response he formed the Wedidit collective
column2: a group of producers including RL Grime
column3: Groundislava
column4: Salva
column5: and Ryan Hemsworth. All of these artists were early in working with modern electronic dance genres that share the musical vocabulary and dynamism of hip-hop.

column1: But the rest of the world has caught up with this style of music-making
column2: so on<i> Dark Red
column3: Laufer is scrawling furiously outside the lines. Early in his career
column4: before he dropped out of art school
column5: he talked about music as a diversion
column6: something that was less serious and less restrictive than learning how to paint the right way. His experiences with the mainstream and the colonization of his own genre seem to have had a similar effect. With Dark Red
column7: he’s taken another turn

column9:
but compromised by its own disorder.

Take it from French philosopher Roland Barthes
column2: who summarized the appeal of professional wrestling thusly in his landmark essay collection
column3: Mythologies. ""What wrestling is above all meant to portray is a purely moral concept: that of justice
column4: he wrote. Elemental forces faced off in the form of nearly naked men and women hustling and tussling with each other in the squared circle. There was a good guy and a bad guy
column5: and you cheered for one of them.

column1: Since Barthes’ time
column2: professional wrestling has developed in more complex—and some purists would say less satisfying—ways. But John Darnielle
column3: leader of the Mountain Goats
column4: grew up with the old wrestling. ""These were comic-book heroes who existed in physical space
column5: he writes of his formative fandom in the promotional copy for Beat the Champ
column6: the band’s new album. ""I was a child. I needed them
column7: and
column8: every week
column9: they came through for me."" Darnielle rooted for the heroes. His stepfather
column10: who he’s memorialized as a troublesome if not frequently terrifying presence in many Mountain Goats songs
column11: rooted for the villains.

column1: Beat the Champ is not about Darnielle’s relationship with his stepfather. Instead
column2: it’s about those men and women who were the wrestlers of his childhood
column3: and what they went through while bringing him and children like him their weekly entertainment. These wrestlers don’t make appearances on ""Today"". Like the hero of ""Southwestern Territory""
column4: they suffer long drives between sleepy towns for the promise of a few bucks and a patchy broadcast on black-and-white TV. Darnielle crawls inside their heads
column5: his voice switching between his recognizably nasal drill and a tender lower register as he chronicles their camaraderie and willingness to hurl their bodies into each other.

column1: The Mountain Goats have been a proper band for more than a decade
column2: and Darnielle is once again backed by the sturdy rhythm section of Peter Hughes and Jon Wurster
column3: who push him forward without getting in his way. The horns from 2012’s Transcendental Youth return on ""Foreign Object""
column4: in which Darnielle acts out a promo—those speeches where wrestlers shout threats and taunts at each other—by vowing that he ""personally will stab you in the eye"" with an improvised shiv made from tape.

column1: The rest of the record isn’t as brassy as ""Foreign Object""
column2: an obvious crowd-pleaser
column3: but it’s occasionally as bold. Darnielle’s exhortations on ""Choked Out"" channel the bloodlust of a wrestler ready to risk it all for fame. The down-tuned
column4: menacing ""Werewolf Gimmick"" echoes ""Psalms 40:2"" from 2009’s The Life of the World to Come as it eulogizes those ""nameless bodies in unremembered rooms
column5: the arrangement rumbling like a car coming apart at the screws. ""Stabbed to Death Outside San Juan""
column6: which loosely tells the story of real-life wrestler Bruiser Brody (who
column7: yes
column8: was stabbed to death outside San Juan) unfolds like a radio play
column9: as Darnielle’s speak-song delivery is intermittently interrupted by a tremendous crash of strings and organs.

column1: These songs describe the psychological states of the wrestlers (""I try to remember what life was like long ago/ But it’s gone
column2: you know?""
column3: from ""Southwestern Territory"") but they also find ways to fit into the mythology of Darnielle’s life. That tyrannical stepfather does pop up on lead single ""The Legend of Chavo Guerrero""
column4: which narrates the title character's life from Darnielle's young eyes. The case for Chavo as Darnielle’s personal hero is as earnest as it is heart-tugging
column5: and it explains why he made this record: ""You let me down
column6: but Chavo never once did/ You called him names to try to get beneath my skin/ Now your ashes are scattered on the wind.""

column1: One of Darnielle’s premier talents as a musician is his ability to cast personal mantras as singalong anthems. At his best
column2: his songs feel as essential as water. Mountain Goats fans will testify to the healing powers of standing arm-to-arm with hundreds of people while shouting ""I am going to make it through this year if it kills me."" Beat the Champ
column3: however
column4: eschews universality by coming from such a specific point of view. You don't necessarily need to know what a heel turn is in order to connect with ""Heel Turn 2""
column5: but it doesn't hurt.

column1: There’s a noble simplicity to these songs
column2: though
column3: reflecting Darnielle’s warm memories of his wrestling fandom. The respect he has for these men and women
column4: and what they must have been through
column5: is obvious. On ""Unmasked!""
column6: a wrestler sings to his costumed opponent
column7: whom he's about to defeat and subsequently unmask before the world. For wrestlers who choose to perform with a mask
column8: hiding their real face is everything. To reveal it is an incredibly serious act. But the pressure of maintaining this illusion for the dwindling crowds has gotten to this anonymous masked man
column9: who is ready to move on. ""By way of honoring the things we once both held dear
column10: I will reveal you

column13:
you grow up and learn the truth.
