It’s hard to capture the complexity of a cultural scene in something as brief and necessarily cherry-picked as a CD-length compilation of music. And Strut hasn’t done that with the fourth volume of their Next Stop Soweto series. But in adding a fourth volume to the original three
column3: the label has inched a step closer to focusing the musical kaleidoscope of 1960s and '70s South Africa into a coherent image. Perhaps 10 volumes from now
column4: they’ll complete the trick. The first three sets focused
column5: respectively
column6: on mbaqanga and other township sounds
column7: psychedelia and soul
column8: and jazz. This one picks up most clearly where Vol. 2 left off
column9: following the march of underground psych and soul into the disco era. In the process
column10: it gives us a glimpse at the South Africa that grooved under apartheid’s heel; there aren’t attention-grabbing headlines in it
column11: but people find a way to live and have a good time in even the most oppressive circumstances.

column1: In spite of the series title
column2: not all of the music was made in Soweto
column3: the sprawling city that grew organically on the edge of officially white Johannesburg. Likewise
column4: while economic stratification in South Africa during this period was severe
column5: don’t come expecting something too gritty—this is hi-fi music recorded on good gear. It’s also almost entirely unknown outside of the communities it was made for; most of these bands don’t yield much information when you look them up online. The pop music of South Africa
column6: for whatever reason
column7: hasn’t received as much attention from Western reissue labels as West and East Africa
column8: so most listeners will find themselves getting acquainted with a whole lot of artists they’ve never heard of before.

column1: Almost all of them had something hot to offer
column2: though. The Drive’s ""Ain’t Sittin’ Down Doin’ Nothing"" is a crunching funk instrumental with dive-bombing Moog and a slow-burning horn section
column3: Abafana Bama Soul offers funk underpinned by the four-on-the-floor thump and bouncing basslines of mbaqanga
column4: and the Movers’ ""Soweto Disco"" sounds like an <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/14686-earth-wind-fire/"">Earth
column5: Wind & Fire on-stage jam. Saitana’s group backing vocals on ""1
column7: 3"" cloak a pointed political message (""One
column8: two
column9: three
column10: your turn is over/ ...our turn has started"") in disco glitter
column11: and the song builds tension and release with odd key changes and unexpected melodic shifts that mirror the message.

column1: During this period South Africans were steeped in American sounds
column2: and the English-descended white population
column3: which tended to be more anti-apartheid and more likely to associate with the black population than the Boer-descended Afrikaners
column4: was well-connected to the British music scene
column5: a connection that sometimes bled over sonically into the townships. Kabasa’s ""Unga Pfula a Chi Pfalo"" is charging heavy funk
column6: but the guitar seems to be on loan from some British hard rock band
column7: and it gives the song a nasty
column8: ass-kicking edge. The cold synths of Damara’s ""Mmamakhabtha"" have an affinity with new romantic synth-pop and sound oddly up-to-date in a post-chillwave world.

column1: The excitement of hearing all these tracks for the first time is bolstered somewhat by knowing that this is just a first pass at South Africa’s disco era; there is a lot more to unearth and reassess. If there’s a chink in the armor here
column2: it’s that the sheer amount of music there is to uncover from this place and time suggests that a generalist compilation may ultimately be a less effective way to explore it than to go deeper into the individual scenes and recording companies to find the stories that underlie the music. Nevertheless
column3:
Next Stop Soweto Vol. 4 is another well-assembled look at lesser-known music from a very complicated time and place.

Using a drum machine to replicate a live backing band tends to have the opposite effect
column2: making solo home recorders sound even more isolated. Case in point
column3: American Wrestlers’ self-titled debut. As of now
column4: it’s Gary McClure’s project and his alone
column5: but the songs won’t require a lot of maintenance to be ready for the road: guitars
column6: bass
column7: piano and vocals are layered about the same way they would have if American Wrestlers were just four guys in a cheap studio. But there’s always that rigid
column8: so on-the-beat-it’s-actually-off thwack of a snare
column9: a bass drum that sounds like a blown subwoofer and the occasional hint of McClure hitting the power switch on the thing—all reminders that American Wrestlers is McClure starting a rock band with his imaginary friends.

column1: Until about a month ago
column2: American Wrestlers was in fact a pointedly anonymous project
column3: an attention-seeking tactic that went out of fashion right about the time Burial went public.  The music feels a few steps behind the times as well
column4: but that's a major component of its charm. Perhaps coincidentally
column5: the album shares some of the best qualities of Fat Possum's major 2011 releases: the dog-eared alt-rock melodies of Yuck’s debut; the lo-fi
column6: low-end thump of Youth Lagoon’s The Year of Hibernation; the (also formerly incognito) Unknown Mortal Orchestra’s oddball psych odysseys.

column1: Regardless of the promo-cycle theatrics
column2: the songs themselves tend to make strong first impressions. McClure leads songs off with breezy guitar leads
column3: memorable titles become indelible lyrics
column4: choruses make satisfying
column5: expected leaps. And despite its disheveled exterior
column6: McClure’s lyrics generate positive energy out of bad vibes: ""There’s No One Crying Over Me Either"" and ""I Can Do No Wrong"" respectively turn self-pity and a lack of introspection into superpowers.

column1: There’s no simple genre tag for American Wrestlers
column2: though singles ""Kelly"" and ""I Can Do No Wrong"" imagine an alternate history where Phoenix started their career as Tascam 4-trackers. The grubby production appears to be a product of necessity
column3: the natural result of McClure’s rudimentary equipment and skills rather than an allegiance to lo-fi aesthetics
column4: but it still lends American Wrestlers a distinct character: The 12-string sparkle of ""I Can Do No Wrong"" gets toned down just enough to not be blinding. And had the singles been given a properly sync-ready production
column5: you might already be tired of hearing them from a commercial for macrobrews or luxury sedans.

column1: The highlights of American Wrestlers reveal themselves immediately
column2: but elsewhere on the record McClure demonstrates a curious ability to bury concise hooks in otherwise-doughy or unfinished songs. The contrast between the southern rock lead of ""Holy"" and its passages of National-esque piano is intriguing on first exposure; it is not enough intrigue to sustain a six-minute song on its own. ""Wild Yonder"" evokes the ear-turning pitter-patter of Sparklehorse’s balladry and would’ve served as a nice shift in tone had it been three minutes
column3: but it goes on for nearly twice that long.

column1: This pattern repeats itself on the album's Side B
column2: when ""Kelly"" is followed by ""Left"" and ""Cheapshot""
column3: 18 minutes of music that you can hear straining for ""epic"" but fail to generate any real volume dynamics or textural motion. These shots at a bigger sound only end up fully demonstrating the limitations of McClure’s compositional methods.

column1: It's in these moments where it occurs to you that the biggest problem with a solo project is that there's no one there to tell you ""no."" At some point during the ponderous stretches of ""Wild Yonder"" or ""Cheapshot"" or ""Left""
column2: perhaps McClure would've noticed someone else in the band starting to drift off or suggested that maybe he should get to the chorus more quickly. ""I Can Do No Wrong"" may be a highlight on <i>American Wrestlers
column3:
but the title sentiment is his project's Achilles heel.

"|20285.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20285-american-wrestlers/|6.9|Ian Cohen

On his debut album
column2: 2013's Nostalchic
column3: producer Stuart Howard (aka Lapalux) showed a strong affection for 1990s R&B. He sifted the era's body-rolling sensuality through computerized filters
column4: piecing the threads into cryptic slow jams and bastardized dance tracks. His music
column5: across Nostalchic and several EPs
column6: thrives on a patchwork approach
column7: a mismatched blend of glued-together tape strands
column8: heavy drums
column9: and warped vocals. It's wonky enough to fit alongside that of Brainfeeder label mates Daedelus and Gaslamp Killer
column10: but it's distinguished by a cosmopolitan sophistication
column11: conjuring images of pretty people in dark clubs
column12: sipping mixed drinks in trendy clothes.

column1: The producer establishes a more aquatic vibe throughout sophomore album Lustmore. The compositions are more straightforward than those on Nostalchic
column2: merging saxophones and billowing synths with results resting somewhere between James Blake's sparsity and early 2000s neo-soul. ""We Lost""
column3: in particular
column4: resembles a Musiq Soulchild track—the instrumental is decidedly Soulquarian; the vocals are mostly indecipherable. ""Whenever I think about the album I think about the bar scene in The Shining
column5: Howard told FACT in January
column6: speaking of Lustmore. ""There's something about that strange
column7: hallucinatory psychological madness that relates to the music."" To that end
column8: Lustmore doesn't really move; it lingers like dense fog until it slowly dissolves.

column1: In a way
column2: the disoriented mood better aligns with another Kubrick flick—1999's Eyes Wide Shut.  But Lustmore suffers from a lack of coherence. Its various feint and detours feel purposeful
column3: but the album buckles under the weight of Howard's ambition
column4: leading to a leading to a disjointed listen. Sultry numbers like ""U Never Know"" and ""Closure"" fit into Howard's overall aesthetic
column5: but the mix of straight-ahead singing and woozy ambience feels outdated and timid alongside the more fluid
column6: strange ""Sum Body"" and ""Midnight Peelers"".

column1: The guest singers aren’t filtered so heavily
column2: which makes for an easier listen
column3: yet the output feels staid compared with his previous offerings
column4: where he achieved the right mix of airy and bizarre.Nostalchic was tough to get into
column5: but there was a certain charm to Howard’s esoteric style that set him apart. Lustmore doesn’t feel honed in; it sounds like a vast collection of songs that never quite go anywhere. Much like The Shining
column6: there’s no telling what you’ll get from one scene to the next on Lustmore
column7: but it ultimately ends with a thud.

column1: Howard shows flashes of ingenuity on Lustmore's ""Don't Mean a Thing""
column2: the album's most realized offering. Here
column3: Howard finds a nice groove and stays put
column4: looping the vocals into sporadic bursts while forgoing the stilted patterns of other songs—namely ""Push N' Spun"" and ""Make Money"". On ""1004""
column5: Howard builds a nice shape-shifting atmosphere; the track smoothly transitions into a spacey upbeat gem that punctuates the LP. Ultimately
column6: though
column7: it's tough to discern just what Lustmore aims to be. It's dubbed as a hypnagogic release
column8: but in Howard's quest to explore the void between sleep and alertness
column9: the album frequently veers off the path
column10: leaving me to wonder if there were clear directions to begin with. Instead of a full movie
column11: Lustmore is a collection of half-edited scenes that don't quite gel.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21704/homepage_large.e5e84144.jpg|This World Is Not Enough|30766.0|Marching Church|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2015-04-06 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:43.982110|"

Describing the motivation for his project Marching Church
column2: Elias Bender Rønnenfelt wrote
column3: ""I had a picture in my head of me in a comfortable chair
column4: adorned in a golden robe
column5: leading a band while a girl kept pouring me champagne. ‘What would this picture sound like?’ was the question."" Judging from that image
column6: you wouldn't be faulted for assuming the band's debut
column7: This World Is Not Enough
column8: may end up being the unintentional comedy album of the year
column9: but looking at Rønnenfelt’s track record
column10: it's worth indulging him for a quick minute.

column1: As the frontman for Iceage
column2: he’s carried the Danish punk firebrands across three good-to-great albums
column3: from the wild-eyed pummel of New Brigade through last year’s curveball Plowing Into the Field of Love
column4: which offered country-informed punk rave-ups as well as desperately drunken ballads
column5: all with uncommonly successful results. Now with Marching Church
column6: which has been around in some capacity since 2010
column7: Rønnenfelt seems to be doubling down on Field of Love’s risk-taking
column8: enlisting members of Lower
column9: Puce Mary
column10: and others for an improvisational avant-garde LP that stretches the boundaries of the soul recordings (James Brown
column11: Sam Cooke) that inspired it.

column1: How you approach This World Is Not Enough
column2: and how patient a listener you consider yourself to be
column3: will factor heavily in your enjoyment of it. ""Well I’m still being convinced that I contain some kind of godlike charm
column4: Rønnenfelt croaks over the rapture-heralding drums and slashing guitars of opener ""Living In Doubt""
column5: and it's often hard to disagree with him. As on Field of Love
column6: he cuts a striking figure
column7: a confident but conflicted young man who rambles like a junior year philosophy major in the throes of a fever dream. And while his rakish sexuality and winking sense of humor are on display once again
column8: this time he seems to have crawled a little too far into his own head.

column1: He holds off for approximately two songs—including the great
column2: sax-laden ""King of Song""
column3: which kind of sounds like ""Sympathy for the Devil"" as performed by people who’ve never actually heard ""Sympathy for the Devil""—before going off-the-rails. So
column4: just as quickly as things seem to be shaping up for This World Is Not Enough
column5: ""Hungry for Love""—a seven minute panic attack of clattering cymbals
column6: strained strings
column7: and Rønnenfelt's trademark mad spouting—rears its head. It’s fascinating but also purposefully repellent
column8: a moment when the idea of self-indulgence threatens to mutate into a wildly pretentious guilty pleasure. From here on
column9: the record follows ""Hungry for Love""’s lead
column10: and it never quite finds its way back.

column1: And yet
column2: This World Is Not Enough displays little moments of greatness amid the chaos and confusion. You’ll have to wade through almost five soupy minutes of rusty bells
column3: anguished moaning
column4: and hovering guitars on ""Your Father’s Eyes"" before being rewarded with a soulful
column5: horn-assisted death waltz
column6: though it’s a nice reward anyway. But
column7: all said
column8: there’s just too much wide open space to fill here
column9: and especially on the album’s draggy back half
column10: it’s fairly clear that Rønnenfelt and company have absolutely no idea what to fill it with
column11: but decide to try anyways.

column1: This usually means more shapeless
column2: frequently unpleasantly calamitous dicking around from the players
column3: and more moaning from Rønnenfelt. (It can also mean a painfully dull cover of the eternal ""The Dark End of the Street"".) And while he is often quite good at conjuring up vividly disquieting imagery
column4: it’s rarely enough to keep your attention. But somehow
column5: This World Is Not Enough is too cluelessly conceived and sloppily executed to get very mad about it. What is frustrating are the infrequent but genuinely interesting moments of creativity and cohesion
column6: which suggest that if Marching Church had taken their time and laid off the improv a little
column7:
there might have been something special here.

"|20436.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20436-this-world-is-not-enough/|5.6|Zach Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21480/homepage_large.76d67361.jpg|Escape From Evil|28880.0|Lower Dens|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Ribbon Music']|2015-04-03 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:44.706029|"

Lower Dens have toyed with the raw pleasure of pop music in the past
column2: but they’ve never embraced it like this. Three years ago
column3: the Baltimore band’s standout single ""Brains"" shone as a melodic gem inside the largely experimental Nootropics; now
column4: on the band’s third album
column5: core songwriter Jana Hunter embraces open
column6: ringing melodies. Like a lot of current music
column7: Escape From Evil siphons its aesthetic from the storied pop of the '80s
column8: but it’s not content to stop at homage. Lower Dens use the past—its clichés and its innocence—as a lens through which to imagine a queer and open future.

column1: As an aesthetic reservoir
column2: the '80s continue to feed an abundance of nostalgia
column3: from the American highway fantasies of the War on Drugs to Twin Shadow’s boy-meets-girl melodramas. Inhabiting characters from the past can lend a singer a certain gravitas; unburdened by modern irony
column4: big emotions play bigger on a decades-old frame. But few artists have seized that retrospection as an opportunity to flip the power dynamics that governed pop culture 30 years ago. For Lower Dens
column5: a neon palette serves as fertile ground for subversion. Hunter absorbs the range of gendered feeling from Billy Idol to Bonnie Tyler
column6: emerging as a bandleader capable of flipping effortlessly between extremes of masculine aggression and feminine yearning.

column1: The word ""genderfluid"" didn’t exist 30 years ago
column2: but it’s a useful term for gripping the edges of this new work. The video for the album’s lead single ""To Die in L.A."" works almost as a queer retelling of William Friedkin’s 1985 drama To Live and Die in L.A.
column3: complete with characters that aren’t cast based on their actors’ birth-assigned gender. Hunter appears as a masculine presence in a buzz cut and suit to glower at the video’s lead femme
column4: who’s vying for movie stardom; in the clip’s last image
column5: the main character sets fire to a painting of herself
column6: then she and Hunter gaze into the flames as it burns away.

column1: The video is full of ambiguous
column2: evocative imagery
column3: and Escape From Evil also runs thick with powerful
column4: slippery emotions. While Hunter seems more enamored of radio hits by the likes of Gary Numan and Flock of Seagulls here
column5: Lower Dens never quite settle into an easy genre hook. A krautrock chug left over from 2012’s Nootropics powers ""Company""
column6: where Hunter assumes the role of anonymous authority figure with lines like ""you look really uncomfortable if I might be honest"" and ""we just want to help."" You can hear the same smirk that Mike Patton wore on Faith No More’s ""Land of Sunshine""
column7: the same glee in inhabiting a vague malice disguised as aid.

column1: Hunter is a charismatic singer willing to deal in grand
column2: sweeping gestures and also idiosyncratic specifics. Escape From Evil is a vivid world of queer retrofuturism
column3: a wide open space that offers access the emotionality of the recent past without subscribing to its violence. Hunter embraces retro-pop as a channel of escape from the power that routes us in our mundane outer lives. In the world of this album
column4:
no one will tell you who to be or where to go; it’s all yours to become.

"|20213.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20213-escape-from-evil/|8.3|Sasha Geffen

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21678/homepage_large.247c79b6.jpg|Deeper|28699.0|The Soft Moon|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2015-04-03 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:46.316976|"

Because there will always be miserable teenagers and because nihilism and disaffection are just as much a part of the human condition as falling in love
column2: there will always be a place—and a market—for explorations of abject darkness set to music. Since 2010
column3: Luis Vasquez of the Soft Moon has twisted his personal demons into songs
column4: quietly breathing new life into gothy post-punk. On his new album
column5: Deeper
column6: he pushes his foreboding synth-pop even further.

column1: Given the nature of Vasquez’s music
column2: it’s almost too perfect that Deeper was recorded in seclusion in the mountains of Italy at a studio simply called Hate. Even though the Soft Moon has always essentially been a one-man show
column3: the tracks on Deeper are light years beyond the fuzzy bedroom recordings on the project’s 2010 debut. Working alongside producer Maurizio Baggio
column4: Vasquez has married his old school goth pop sensibilities (imagine a dalliance between NIN’s The Downward Spiral
column5: Depeche Mode’s Black Celebration
column6: and Chris & Cosey’s Songs of Love and Lust) with production that positions the album firmly in the now. He still lays a thick sonic fog over these tracks but the songs operate with a kind of icy precision
column7: leading to a record is both unrelentingly dark and amazingly fastidious.

column1: Like its predecessors
column2: Deeper leans more heavily on overall mood than it does on obvious hooks
column3: but there are catchy moments. “Far” is the kind of hyper-morose electro pop that wouldn’t have been out of place making kids pogo at the Batcave back in the early ’80s
column4: while “Wrong” has the kind of jackhammering synths and stuttering beats that could have dropped off an old Nitzer Ebb single. But Deeper is more than a collection of cleverly assembled references. It splits the difference between the more glacial dirges (“Without”
column5: “Wasting”) and intricately-layered synth tracks (“Feel”
column6: “Black”) without feeling too turgid or weighed down by the record’s decidedly bleak subject matter.

column1: Vasquez himself remains a kind of cipher—a detached vocal presence too often content to float along the periphery of the songs. When he abandons the processed vocals or the Reznor-esque sing/speak and let’s his voice come through
column2: the results are often surprising. On “Wasting” when he ominously intones “You’ve gotta take life by the hand/ Let the substance close you in/ Hope to one day come alive
column3: ” it provides what is one of the album’s few moments of emotional reprieve. And the record occasionally suffers a fate common to aggressively “dark” music—the lyrics
column4: though undoubtedly deeply personal
column5: tread a fine line between effectively bracing and the stuff of bad teenage poetry.

column1: Occasional goth clichés aside
column2: Deeper is a thing of beauty. Few contemporary artists have managed such a clever reimagining of post-punk and spooky new wave in a way that sounds both familiar and somehow fresh. Nowhere on Deeper is this more evident than on the album’s closing track
column3: “Being”
column4: a six-minute stunner that builds from bits of collaged tape loops and whispers before evolving into a pulsing industrial track and ultimately exploding into a wall of white noise as Vasquez screams “I can’t see my face/ I don’t know where I am.” For an artist who seems hell-bent on finding new ways to take listeners somewhere both beautiful and frightening
column5:
the song’s final three minutes of hiss and roiling noise seems like a perfectly appropriate place to end up.

"|20411.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20411-deeper/|7.8|T. Cole Rachel

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21639/homepage_large.a0e58819.jpg|Ludaversal|4944.0|Ludacris|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['EMI'

At the Comedy Central Roast of Justin Bieber
column3: Kevin Hart introduced Ludacris as “one of the most successful rappers of 2001.” It was a joke premised on a few things: Luda's age
column4: maybe
column5: or his drift from the rap world as he moves deeper into his acting career. (He is now a two-time Fast & Furious franchise cast member.) Regardless
column6: it was an accurate
column7: if incomplete
column8: descriptor: In the early-’00s glory days of throwback jerseys and meticulous cornrows
column9: Ludacris led a wave of Atlanta-helmed rap into crossover success
column10: transforming dancefloors around the world into microcosms of the city’s sound. Without staunchly regionalist classics like the libidinous Shawnna-starring “What’s Your Fantasy” and instant mosh pit starter “Southern Hospitality”
column11: there would likely be no so-called New Atlanta
column12: the catchall term for the landscape of boundlessly engaging rappers like Future
column13: Migos
column14: and Father’s Awful Records crew.

column1: Ludacris’ ninth album
column2: Ludaversal
column3: is his first in five years
column4: and it’s a not-very-subtle attempt at testing his staying power against this backdrop. “They say Luda don't want it no mo’ / Nah
column5: nigga
column6: I'm as hungry as the first day
column7: ” he raps on the album’s opener
column8: over a double-time beat courtesy of David Banner. I’m still here
column9: seems to be the 37-year-old’s cri de coeur on Ludaversal
column10: as he meditates on the music industry and his place within it.

column1: Luda is one of the most technically inventive rappers of his era
column2: with lithe
column3: adaptable flows
column4: but he emerges on Ludaversal as an unlikely hip-hop traditionalist
column5: at times sounding like an ""Empire"" approximation of himself. Despite production from current-day heavy hitters like Da Internz and Mike WiLL Made It
column6: he still comes off like a relic from the past
column7: the class clown who never quite grew up. When they don’t land
column8: the jokes and double-entendres are egregious
column9: landing with a practically audible Amirite? Notable example: “I leave rappers confused like Will.i.am’s barber” on “Beast Mode.” Sandwiched in the album’s first half
column10: apropos of nothing
column11: is a skit called “Viagra”
column12: a recording of a 911 phone call placed by a man with an ostensibly never-ending erection.

column1: There are some high points
column2: though: In interviews Luda has described the project as his most personal yet—that’s often a marketing phrase bandied about too generously
column3: but it rings true in this case. On songs like “Grass Is Always Greener” and “Charge It to the Rap Game
column4: ” he grapples with the downsides of fame; for every luxury he can afford
column5: he has to contend with a money-grubbing family member or a vicious press mechanism that feeds on celebrity gossip. “Ocean Skies
column6: ” a song about his father’s fatal alcoholism and his own struggles with substance abuse
column7: is the album's centerpiece
column8: but
column9: like much of Ludaversal
column10: the value is in his emotional honesty
column11: not his execution.

column1: Rap fans with memories of the early ‘00s will always have a fondness for Ludacris
column2: and it’s hard not to want to root for him. It’s never a bad thing
column3: exactly
column4: to hear his voice on a track
column5: even a silly one. But on Ludaversal
column6: I can’t help but think of Young Thug’s casual yet searing critique of Jay Z in a recent GQ interview: ""If you're 30
column7: 40 years old
column8:
you're not getting listened to by minors.”

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21479/homepage_large.00c5e560.jpg|This Is the Sonics|8974.0|The Sonics|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Revox']|2015-04-03 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:47.512886|"

If garage rock was conceived in the ’60s as the primal sound of teenage boredom
column2: frustration
column3: and angst
column4: what does it mean when men in their seventies attempt to play it? There’s probably a deep and worthy discussion to be had somewhere in there
column5: but the Sonics don’t give a shit about that
column6: nor should they. The Tacoma band’s new release This Is the Sonics is their first studio album of all-new material in 49 years
column7: and that fact alone is staggering. What’s even more remarkable
column8: though
column9: is how one of garage rock’s most legendary bands has dared to test their legend by making a record that spits
column10: snarls
column11: drools
column12: honks
column13: wails
column14: and screams as if it were 1966 all over again.

column1: Granted
column2: recording with Jim Diamond doesn’t hurt. The former Dirtbombs bassist and famed producer of the White Stripes’ self-titled debut spares no grime or fuzz. The album was recorded mono
column3: live in the studio. “Bad Betty”
column4: the most powerful original composition on the album
column5: hints at the rock-appropriated folklore of Black Betty in its title while remaining gleefully ignorant of anything except how to pound a riff into the ground in execution. Vocalist/keyboardist Jerry Roslie sings of the wild
column6: leather-clad woman who puts his own savagery to shame
column7: the septeguenarian whooping and screeching like a tomcat in heat.

column1: Roslie is joined by fellow founding members Larry Parypa on guitar and vocals and Rob Lind on saxophone and vocals; the lineup is rounded out by bassist Freddie Dennis (a veteran of the Kingsmen
column2: one of the Sonics’ Pacific Northwest garage-rock brethren in the ’60s) and drummer Dusty Watson. Together they lock into a single-minded
column3: almost monomaniacal unit
column4: pulverizing numbers like “Be a Woman” and “Spend the Night” into lumps of distorted
column5: house-wrecking lust. Roslie’s voice
column6: though
column7: is the star. Still steeped in the R&B of his youth
column8: his corroded pipes—which produced godlike shrieks on ’60s Sonics classics like “Strychnine”
column9: “The Witch”
column10: and “Have Love Will Travel”—sound somehow rawer.

column1: R&B informed the Sonics’ unhinged passion from the get-go
column2: and This Is the Sonics pays proper homage to the group’s roots. Willie Dixon’s “You Can’t Judge a Book by the Cover”—by way of Bo Diddley’s iconic version—is given a giddy workout
column3: with Lind’s sax squawking nauseously over a jackhammer backbeat. Eddie Holland’s “Leaving Here” gets similar treatment; the fact that it’s one of garage rock’s most threadbare standards doesn’t keep the Sonics from putting a fresh coat of paint on it. The best cover on the album
column4: though
column5: is of Hank Ballard and the Midnighters’ “Look at Little Sister”
column6: whose hoot-and-holler horniness is rendered simultaneously sleazy and boyish. Less successful is a rendition of The Kinks' “The Hard Way”
column7: which the Sonics rip through a little too quickly for the melody to survive intact.

column1: No song on This Is the Sonics summarizes the band’s grizzled
column2: miraculous resurrection like “Save the Planet”. In it
column3: they thumb their noses at the hippie platitudes that helped render garage rock (briefly) extinct in the ’60s; Parypa’s bluesy
column4: sneering riff is more of a taunt than a hook
column5: and Roslie makes it crystal clear why he believes Earth should be preserved: “We have to save the planet / It’s the only one with beer!” King Khan
column6: one of the Sonics’ most faithful spiritual offspring
column7: couldn’t have put it better himself. The Sonics’ children are legion
column8: and every generation of garage rockers owes them. Roslie and crew surely know this
column9: but from the timeless sound of This Is the Sonics
column10:
they might just as well be oblivious to their legacy. Legacies are for the dead. The Sonics are alive and viciously well.

"|20212.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20212-this-is-the-sonics/|7.5|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21613/homepage_large.dd7d0f9a.jpg|Living Daylight|32811.0|Michael Rault|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Burger']|2015-04-03 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:48.049901|"

When Michael Rault first emerged out of Edmonton
column2: Alberta five years ago
column3: he resembled the sort of matinee-idol rock star his country doesn’t really produce anymore
column4: with <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fom_NDpdBnw"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">a stylish
column5: Ray-Ban-wrapped look and preference for retro album-cover design that blatantly advertised his allegiance to early rock ‘n’ roll pioneers like Buddy Holly and The Everly Brothers.  His initial ascent was guided through established industry channels by Pirates Blend
column6: the Sony Canada-affiliated imprint founded by reggae-pop hitmakers Bedouin Soundclash (aka the proto-Magic! of the mid-2000s). But since relocating to Toronto in 2012
column7: Rault has been acting more like the high-school heartthrob with straight-A grades and football-scholarship potential who ditched class to drop acid with the freaks beneath the bleachers.

column1: After sharing bills and making friends with local eccentrics like Slim Twig
column2: U.S. Girls
column3: Actual Water
column4: and Young Guv
column5: it's probably no coincidence that Rault’s hair has gotten longer and greasier
column6: his clothes more torn
column7: and his face more razor-resistant. But most importantly
column8: his traditionalism has been corrupted into wonderfully woozy
column9: glitter-speckled power pop. Rault’s recently Tuffened-up sound makes him a natural fit on the roster of California’s Burger Records
column10: a veritable Disneyland for retro-gazing rough-cat rockers. While Living Daylight was initially released last year in Canada on Pirates Blend in seven-song EP form
column11: this enlarged 10-song version is being promoted by Burger as Rault’s proper introduction to the world. (His current website noticeably downplays his earlier discography.)

column1: Rault belongs to a growing legion of modern-day garage-spawned rockers—The Smith Westerns and Foxygen among them—who seem less interested in mining the standard British Invasion/Nuggets/CBGB continuum than the phenomena that sprung up between those movements: bubblegum
column2: glam
column3: Rundgrenian soft-rock
column4: solo-Beatle solipsism. Recorded partially at home and in an Edmonton studio with Rault’s cousin Renny Wilson
column5: Living Daylight strikes a playfully wobbly balance between in-the-room rawness and cerebral strangeness. And when Rault pounces on the fuzz pedal—like on the T. Rex boogie of “Real Love (Yeah)” or the Plastic Ono blues of “Hiding From a Heartache”—the ensuing distortion feels less decorative than rhythmic
column6: like the subliminal rev of a car motor. Rault’s simple lyrics sound as if they belong to a more innocent era
column7: but while he may stick to tried ‘n’ true themes of looking for love and/or losing it
column8: he’s as adept at conveying the hormonal frustration of the former (the taut
column9: soul-stompin’ “All Alone (On My Own)”) as the crestfallen pathos of the latter (the lush
column10: candlelit ballad “Lovers Lie”).

column1: The three additional tracks on this new edition are dropped right into the middle of the original tracklisting
column2: and they reinforce the perception that the record’s strongest songs are still its original ones. The expanded format is more of an opportunity for Rault to retrofit some of his back catalogue with his new sound: “I Wanna Love You” toughens up a sock-hop romp from Rault’s 2010 debut Ma-Me-O
column3: while the sneering  ""Suckcess"" is thrust into a “Jeepster” drag race. But Rault’s experimentation never tips over into excess: with songs kept to a tight three-minute average
column4: and the singer’s winsome way with melody anchoring each
column5:
Living Daylight shows that it’ll take more than unkempt hair and production trickery to obscure Rault’s essential charms.

"|20347.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20347-living-daylight/|7.3|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21718/homepage_large.5d22f88f.jpg|Dark Energy|32851.0|Jlin|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2015-04-02 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:48.898405|"

Menace is a sensation endemic to footwork
column2: the Chicago-borne genre of heart-racing house music that is predicated on going harder and better than anyone else on the floor. Dark Energy
column3: the first album from Gary
column4: Ind. producer Jlin
column5: hints at this idea of combativeness
column6: bending all matter of percussion
column7: vocal clips and pre-existing ideas about footwork into submission. Jlin’s talked about the mediocrity that can result from working from a happy place
column8: but that doesn’t mean there isn’t some joy at work in her music—it’s found in the process of creating and
column9: for listeners
column10: in the release of the dancefloor. That sly flip—the thrill and release in activating anger—is the emotional ingenuity in Jlin’s music. It’s a certain mindfulness she has in common with Rick Owens
column11: who used her music—and that of pioneering footworker RP Boo—for his FW 2014/15 Paris Fashion Week show. Grim
column12: monochrome upper; mind-altering interior.

column1: Dark Energy has all the hallmarks of footwork—its frenzied pacing
column2: arrhythmic kick drums
column3: a graphic command of blank space—executed with clear-eyed self-determination. This gives the album an opaque
column4: thoughtful quality. It's Jlin’s first release
column5: centered around a track that first went live in 2010 (""Erotic Heart"")
column6: which means she’s had time to think about what she’s doing and
column7: more importantly
column8: what she is not doing. While working shifts at one of Gary’s many large steel mills
column9: Jlin spent months perfecting the music
column10: including songs like ""Guantanamo""
column11: which cleaves hair-raising dialogue from The Ring with a grip of pin-sharp synths. Her tenacity feels even more significant when you consider that she’s a woman working in the man-saturated field of electronic production
column12: and footwork in particular. For women
column13: producer’s anonymity is both gift and curse.

column1: A bunch of these song titles also invite loose contemplation on narratives of blackness
column2: and/or racialized peoples. ""Black Diamond"" and “Black Ballet” scan more literally
column3: whereas songs like “Guantanamo
column4: ” “Ra” and “Mansa Musa” prompt ideas about history
column5: mythology
column6: imprisonment
column7: culture wars and a clash of civilizations. Jlin doesn’t editorialize
column8: and this record isn’t specifically about identity politics. But she’s from Gary
column9: a blue collar
column10: black-majority city
column11: making a record within a genre created for and by African-Americans at a time when the non-white citizenry is growing increasingly restless and hella loud about owning its art and likeness
column12: its safety and life expectancy. Dark Energy has absorbed some of the shock. It has knowledge of self. Throw it onto the list of recent albums
column13: like Heems’ Eat Pray Thug and Kendrick Lamar’s To Pimp A Butterfly
column14: that take personal
column15: political and temporal stock of our lives and refuse to be one-dimensional in chronicling these experiences.

column1: This sense of brooding becomes music that feels venomous. ""Mansa Musa""—the name of a prominent ruler and cultural benefactor of the Mali Empire—clarifies Dark Energy’s happy-scary tension best. Halfway through the album
column2: its fizzy
column3: midtempo gait feels like a break from the intensity. But it’s a feint. Effervescent synths and skeletal drums lift the song up only to have a descending bassline and stiff snares prick its rise
column4: sending it flopping to its death like a deflated balloon.

column1: With the exception of vocal snippets
column2: which appear frequently
column3: Jlin doesn’t bother with traditional sampling. She’s generated her own instrumentation: from the winding
column4: symphonic piano loop that opens the album on ""Black Ballet"" and the atonal moan of a Chinese erhu violin on ""Unknown Tongues"" to the guttural synths that skim the bottom of ""Ra"". Like Jlin it’s unconventional
column5: particularly within footwork. Her homespun mutation of the genre feels like she’s staging an interrogation
column6: and there’s the sense of threat: What do you feel when you hear the hollowed-out militant stomp and shiver of ""Black Diamond""? What physical realm does this song slip into and out of as pinched
column7:
tweaked-out synths whirr ecstatically to life then stop? Are you having fun yet?

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21609/homepage_large.040b3734.jpg|Kintsugi|1039.0|Death Cab for Cutie|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Atlantic']|2015-04-02 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:49.782965|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".1iqe23w62v4.1.6:0.1.0.$20343/=1$20343.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div class=""ii gt m14c765b69a6579f9 adP adO"" id="":1r4"">
<div class=""a3s"" id="":1r5"">
<div dir=""ltr"">
Chris Walla quit Death Cab for Cutie last year
column2: which means he will never again be called the band's ""secret weapon."" His nuanced craftsmanship served as a buffer against Ben Gibbard’s increasingly broad and bland songwriting on recent LPs Narrow Stairs and Codes & Keys
column3: but Walla ""long[ed] for the unknown"" and Gibbard felt the band was becoming stagnant and ""self-referential"". Though Walla contributes guitar and electronic collage to the band's eighth LP Kintsugi
column4: he abdicates the producer’s role for the first time in the band’s history—in his stead is a proper big-budget pop guy
column5: the preposterously and perfectly named Rich Costey (Muse
column6: Foster the People
column7: Chvrches). But it wouldn’t have mattered if DJ Mustard or Steve Albini produced Kintsugi: as with Codes & Keys
column8: Gibbard promises reinvention and continues to play against his strengths without developing new ones.

column1: Gibbard’s desire to write from a less personal standpoint is understandable
column2: considering the widespread misunderstanding that any song in the first-person has to be autobiographical—his private life is a matter of public record these days
column3: and surely he’s grown tired of having to clarify that wasn’t him eating Thanksgiving dinner in a suburban Denver Catholic church after dad bounced or treating that girl from Silver Lake like complete shit. But even when Gibbard was clearly writing in character
column4: the sketches were<i> personalized
column5: and therein lay the genius of his work—he had an uncanny ability to see things as others might
column6: penning deeply felt and detailed lyrics
column7: willing to risk certain sentiments and awkward phrasings to reward the listener with a richer
column8: more complex and relatable experience. They were someone’s stories. This is why Death Cab for Cutie played the KeyArena in Seattle and not
column9: say
column10: Matt Pond PA or Rogue Wave or any of their other peers from the ""O.C. indie"" era.

column1: But Gibbard's change in approach hasn't coincided with a change of subject; Death Cab for Cutie has not developed a political conscience
column2: nor is Gibbard suddenly experimenting with tone poems. The same relationship breakdowns and travelogues captured on The Photo Album have gone big screen as Gibbard strives for universal
column3: one-feel-fits-all songs meant to be shared but not owned. Take ""Little Wanderer""
column4: where the narrator (not Gibbard
column5: y’all) is stuck at home and the girl is showing him pictures of her very commonplace vacation spots (Tokyo and Paris) through Messenger. Gibbard knows how to wring pathos out of long-distance relationships; he invented a damn word for it. He can also tease out how technological improvements in communication can leave even more unsaid. And yet
column6: here’s the chorus: ""You’re my wanderer
column7: little wanderer/ Off across the sea/ You’re my wanderer
column8: little wanderer/ Won’t you wander back to me?"" It’s startling
column9: almost amusing
column10: to hear a hackneyed line like that cutting against the stonefaced sobriety of his delivery and plangent reverbed guitars—every pejorative stereotype of Death Cab becomes true for four minutes.

column1: And yet Gibbard also indulges some explicit nostalgia for older Death Cab—during the climactic kiss in the baggage claim
column2: the song reveals itself as basically fan-fic to the video for ""A Movie Script Ending"". This spark of recognition happens far too often on Kintsugi
column3: resulting in songs that just sound like an impersonal reading of better ones from the past. Solo acoustic centerpiece ""Hold No Guns"" wants badly to be Kintsugi’s ""I Will Follow You Into the Dark""
column4: but the narrator pleads harmlessness rather than ""til death do us part and then some"" devotion. ""Binary Sea"" makes a blatant metaphorical callback to the planetary myth-making of  ""Transatlanticism"" and a number of previous weepy closers (""Stable Song""
column5: ""A Lack of Color""). The lightly chiding tone and basic structure of  ""Your Heart Is an Empty Room"" is reprised for ""Everything’s a Ceiling""—little of Kintsugi gives the impression that Gibbard’s motivation to reboot Death Cab is matched by legitimate inspiration.

column1: The newly luxurious production sets Costey up as a convenient scapegoat; ""Everything’s a Ceiling"" and ""Good Help (Is So Hard to Find)"" are the newest sounds here
column2: and they recall the pop-funk Silly Putty of the 1975 or the Neighbourhood
column3: both of whom are currently competing with Death Cab for KROQ spins. Otherwise
column4: Kintsugi sounds not altogether different than Plans
column5: with Costey's chromed-out glossiness subbed in for Walla's fragile glassiness. Costey keeps Gibbard’s voice as high as possible in the mix
column6: just as Walla would have; the sole exception is the distorted cloak on late-album highlight ""Ingenue""
column7: which is the one track that makes good on Death Cab’s hope to integrate electronic influences like Flying Lotus and Jon Hopkins without just sounding like the Postal Service. In the context of the full album
column8: this just feels like their latest well-meaning
column9: but ultimately empty promise of a cred infusion (see also: Can
column10: Brian Eno).

column1: ""Kintsugi"" actually refers to a Japanese style of art where broken ceramics are fused together with gold
column2: an apt metaphor but a weirdly honest one. And yet
column3: when Kintsugi gets broken into individual pieces
column4: there are heirlooms worth treasuring. Advance singles ""No Room in Frame"" and ""The Ghosts of Beverly Drive"" are where Gibbard remembers to write great Death Cab for Cutie songs the way he knows how—zooming on important specifics that speak on a larger idea
column5: trying to make sense of newly formed concepts as he’s explaining them to someone else
column6: rather than starting with the most broad
column7: market-tested metaphors. Maybe it’s not Gibbard driving down I-5 through Fresno Valley
column8: maybe it’s not him doomed to live with regrets in a city he still harbors resentments towards. It probably is
column9: but at least Gibbard is willing to share some of himself while leaving plenty to the imagination. It also helps that these songs deliver Death Cab’s proprietary chorus melodies
column10: winding
column11: thrilling and sunlit like the Pacific Coast Highway of which Gibbard sings so fondly.

column1: But I get it: Death Cab for Cutie have gone platinum
column2: they’ve hit #1 on Billboard
column3: they’ve been nominated for a Grammy and lost to ""My Humps""
column4: they’ve played the former NBA arena in the city where they started and now they’ll play the Hollywood Bowl in Gibbard’s new home. If he’s straining to go against his instincts by writing self-explanatory songs like ""Good Help (Is So Hard to Find)"" and ""You’ve Haunted Me All My Life"" with equally pat arrangements and melodies
column5: well
column6: he’s got cheap seats to reach now. But after 12 years of hearing him repeat ""I need you so much closer"" ad infinitum
column7: that line never hurt more than it does now.

Wale’s alignment with the Top 40 rap crowd never felt like a healthy fit. Since his 2011 alliance with Rick Ross’ Maybach Music
column3: the D.C. rapper has found success but has never seemed comfortable with it. And the critical failure of his last album
column4: 2013’s The Gifted
column5: must have shaken him to his core
column6: because at first blush
column7: his latest effort
column8: The Album About Nothing
column9: screams ""return-to-form."" Its title nods to his 2008 ""Seinfeld""-referencing breakout The Mixtape About Nothing
column10: a freebie hosted by Fool’s Gold impresario Nick Catchdubs. This was around the time when the first wave of ""weirdo"" nerd guys like himself
column11: Charles Hamilton
column12: a pre-pop B.o.B and Kid Cudi were springing forward—emotional
column13: obsessed with melody
column14: ambitious
column15: accessible. Wale promptly eschewed that sensibility for guest verses on songs like Waka Flocka Flame’s strip club paean ""No Hands"" and Ross’ my-cum-tastes-good commercial ""Diced Pineapples"". Through it all
column16: he struggled to exude palpable confidence. So what does it mean that after all of this push-and-pull
column17: his fourth studio album finds him gazing back towards his origins?

column1: The Album About Nothing begins by holding a mirror to Wale’s past
column2: which reflects some of the trappings of his more-famous present. The intro is informed by go-go
column3: D.C.’s signature reworking of funk
column4: and a sound he used frequently early in his career. And once again
column5: the voice of Jerry Seinfeld acts as commentary
column6: stitching the tracks together thematically.  But Wale doesn’t have to rely on audio clips from ""Seinfeld"" anymore: He has Jerry
column7: himself (the two are friends
column8: and Jerry even name-dropped him as one of his ""top five"" in Top Five) providing the sound bites. On ""The Helium Balloon""
column9: one of the more interesting songs on the album
column10: he laments his reception as an artist
column11: adding ""Still know what my core needs/ So fuck who ignores me."" What follows isn’t so much the diligent fan service all this promises
column12: though
column13: so much as a muddied collage of attempts at current trends and a lot of sour disaffection. In other words: a Wale album.

column1: Wale clearly remains frustrated with his inability to ascend to the top tier
column2: and on Nothing he presents himself as a rap-industry antagonist. He burrows into the background of ""The Middle Finger""
column3: revealing his discomfort around other rappers and making a hook out of ""Fuck you
column4: leave me alone."" On ""The Glass Egg""
column5: he opts for cleverness over anger
column6: upending Groove Theory’s ""Tell Me"" and flipping its lyrics (""I’ve been doing my own thing""; ""Tell me if you are for real"") from their original incredulous-about-a-crush context into the cry of an outsider. It works so well that it’s almost surprising no one has done it before.

column1: Nothing is a long album
column2: with one cut coming in over the six-minute mark
column3: and when it is sludgy
column4: it is exhausting. The most unfortunate moment is ""The One Time in Houston""
column5: an amateurish attempt at the city’s signature syrupy screw sound. ""The Girls on Drugs"" cleverly samples Janet Jackson’s house party celebration ""Go Deep""
column6: but isn’t packed with enough of Wale’s dour thoughts to sound like he’s doing anything more than cribbing Drake’s If You’re Reading This
column7: It’s Too Late flow. For someone who spends so much time decrying other rappers’ lifestyles
column8: it’s a wonder why he is pantomiming at all.

column1: Interpolation is one of the constants of Nothing. ""Balloon"" concludes with a pseudo-dancehall coda loosely riffing on Ini Komoze’s crossover ""Here Comes the Hotstepper"". ""The Success"" borrows from the Eurythmics’ ""Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)"". ""The Body"" fully rips ""You Remind Me of Something"" by R. Kelly
column2: who might not be the best guy to pay homage to in 2015
column3: but when you have Jeremih
column4: an heir to the Chicago R&B throne
column5: on the hook
column6: it’s a little easier to take. ""The Body"" is the last of five romantic songs on the album
column7: most of which fail to captivate: Only on his Usher collaboration ""The Matrimony""
column8: and on the tender ""The Bloom (AG3)""
column9: where he reminds us how good he sounds rapping over a live band
column10: does he sound alive.

column1: Wale remains intent on dismantling the public’s sour perception of him
column2: but he doesn’t seem to know how. He wants us to know he’s ""Lil Wayne meets Wayne Perry/ Bad Brains from the go-go"" (""The God Smile"") but he’s loaded his album with the opposite: There are no lyrical acrobatics à la Weezy in his prime
column3: and his reference to Wayne Perry is a head-scratcher because Wale has never purported to be a gangster. He waxes political on the J. Cole-featuring ""The Pessimist"" about the negative perceptions of black America
column4: through the lens of police brutality or ""Love & Hip-Hop""
column5: but is missing the punk fervor of the Bad Brains he namechecks. While there are clear themes throughout the record (love
column6: black experience
column7: a rapper’s malaise)
column8: The Album About Nothing is mostly about fear. Fear of becoming an outsider projecting a false hatred of the inside
column9: fear of pushing musical boundaries to nurture one’s own creativity
column10: fear of being vulnerable and
column11: thusly
column12:
denying his listeners access to himself. If Wale could only shatter those walls and deliver an album where he no longer sounds like a caricature of himself—it’s no wonder he loves ""Seinfeld""—he might finally get back the amnesty he has been so desperately grasping at for the past five years. All he has now is Nothing to lose.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21706/homepage_large.a13c9e47.jpg|The Iron Way|7337.0|T-Pain|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-04-02 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:51.010605|"

T-Pain has always been misunderstood
column2: from the moment he crooned his way onto America’s airwaves with the sweet
column3: surprising ""I’m Sprung"" a decade ago. The misunderstandings may have stemmed from his association with Auto-Tune
column4: a program misunderstood by nearly everyone. Some complained and covered their ears
column5: while helpful rockists pointed out that Peter Frampton had a talking guitar in the '70s. Everyone else—almost literally everyone else
column6: at least on the radio—began sounding like him. Through it all T-Pain remained steadfast—a guy who was singing and rapping before marrying the two was something you had to do to be relevant
column7: and whose primary instrument made him a target. But far from being a doormat
column8: he made the best joke about himself with the Lonely Island
column9: and then made devastating observation that the ""mockery"" of his type of music was nominated for a Grammy
column10: but not his actual music.

column1: And then there was ""D.O.A."" And then there was The-Dream
column2: the Weeknd
column3: and most importantly
column4: Future and a new wave of Atlanta rap. And you know who wasn’t there? Mr. Tallahassee Pain. He disappeared. He started dressing like a steampunk villain around 2011. A few mixtapes a few years ago didn’t move the needle. There was ""Up Down (Do This All Day)""
column5: a fantastic collaboration with B.o.B that appeared and disappeared just as quickly. There was Tiny Desk T-Pain
column6: aka
column7: ""oh he can really sing!"" T-Pain
column8: which despite pandering to the lowest form of pop authenticity-baiting
column9: accomplished the feat of momentarily reminding us: Hey
column10: this is a real human
column11: and this human can sing. It was endearing and impressive. There was sad T-Pain
column12: regaling us with truly heartbreaking stories about his taking all his negative press and industry guff to heart. Finally
column13: there is new T-Pain. T-Pain is back!

column1: For a guy with this career trajectory
column2: the results on The Iron Way
column3: his first slab of new music in a little over two years
column4: are unsurprising. He remains somewhat anonymous in spite of his sound’s ubiquity
column5: and his mixtape is essentially straight down the middle half-killer
column6: half-filler. Where all the weirder
column7: more free-thinking Auto-Tune visionaries in his wake took the sound and spun it into new directions
column8: T-Pain is content to still warble T-Pain songs. The best ones are cavernous slaps about drinking
column9: strip clubs
column10: and heartbreak
column11: and the second best ones are the more upbeat and sprightly slaps about drinking
column12: strip clubs
column13: and heartbreak.

column1: Which is to say: T-Pain is not
column2: and has never really been
column3: a person I want to hear rap. The weakest songs on The Iron Way push that rapping to the forefront
column4: to often-awkward and clumsy results. This includes all the songs with features from Young Cash
column5: Sean Jay
column6: Bun B and Big K.R.I.T.
column7: Yo Gotti and Snootie Wild
column8: OG Maco
column9: Migos and K Camp. There is a song called ""The King""
column10: and it features Bun B and Big K.R.I.T.: Don’t you already know exactly how it sounds?

column1: The best songs on The Iron Way are the ones that establish an appropriate vibe for the subject matter. The sunny weed ode ""Need to Be Smokin""
column2: the straight up power romance ballad ""Heartbeat"". T-Pain soars on ""Let Ya Hair Down""
column3: a seductive track featuring The-Dream
column4: a long-overdue collaboration that is the perfect union between two guys with great voices who love to twist and turn those voices into new shapes. And usually they sing about sex: On ""Booty Butt Ass""
column5: T-Pain manages to quote ""Oh my God Becky"" in a chorus that doesn’t feel corny
column6: and then in the outro
column7: he morphs the mood of the song from ""strip club turn up"" to ""crying in the champagne room."" It’s a mesmerizing two minutes
column8: partly because it’s the most outre moment on a pretty straightforward tape. If everyone else is getting emotional in the club
column9: why not the guy who arguably started the trend over a decade ago?

column1: This isn’t to paint T-Pain into a corner
column2: just to say that maybe the reason he's battled anonymity over his long career is because he gave us everything we needed on ""I’m Sprung"" (and two years later
column3: ""Buy U A Drank""). Other guys took his ""thing"" and made it weirder or sexier or more avant garde. But he’s been content
column4: behind a sheepish smile and many features over the years
column5: to continue to do his thing. The world is currently run by dudes Auto-Tuning their emotions into weird new places. T-Pain did it first. And when he’s playing to his strengths
column6:
he’s arguably doing it better than anyone else.

"|20438.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20438-the-iron-way/|6.1|Matthew Ramirez

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21638/homepage_large.8e9411e1.jpg|Director|32820.0|Yonatan Gat|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Joyful Noise']|2015-04-02 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:51.574780|"

In the much-missed Monotonix
column2: guitarist Yonatan Gat was the anchor
column3: the guy gamely riffing away while his bandmates hoisted themselves aloft in garbage pails or stuffed microphones into their pants. But being the straight man in a band like Monotonix still makes you the wildest guy in most any other room
column4: and Gat's post-Monotonix music is clearly the product of a frenzied
column5: restless spirit. <i>Director
column6: the second record from Gat's eponymous trio
column7: was recorded over three marathon 12-hour sessions with engineer Chris Woodhouse
column8: best known for his work with one-take wonders Thee Oh Sees and Ty Segall. A series of freewheeling jams were eventually whittled down to a lean 29 minutes and change
column9: then mingled with field recordings the well-traveled Gat collected over the years. The results are all over the place in every sense of the phrase
column10: a frequently dazzling display of the trio's impressively far-flung influences.

column1: To listen to Director is to feel yourself barreling forward; riffs don't so much unfurl as fly by and songs seem to vanish almost as soon as they appear. Director's constant motion makes it a particularly tough record to pin down for more than a few seconds at a time; in less than half an hour
column2: Gat and company touch on everything from bossa nova to soukous
column3: Tortoise-style jazz-rock to the head-swimming spazz-outs of Ponytail. Director is conversant not just in many styles
column4: but many languages; centerpiece ""North to South""
column5: for instance
column6: features lyrics in Hebrew
column7: Portuguese
column8: and English. The Israeli-born Gat and Gal Lazer and the Brazilian Sergio Sayeg bring a remarkably vast number of styles to the table here
column9: gleefully recombining them as they go. And you need not know how to suss out a Phyrgian scale or tell your son from your samba to dig into Director; this is a world party
column10: respectful of tradition but unafraid to throw everything in a blender and gulp.

column1: Gat has technical prowess to spare
column2: but he's less concerned about getting things exactly right; there's a seat-of-their-pants feel to the whole of Director
column3: the occasional near-flub a product of their refusal to slow down for any length of time. While Sayeg stays deep in the pocket
column4: Lazer's drums—with cues from Gene Krupa
column5: John Bonham and Tony Allen—and Gat's guitar either tussle like dogs and crackle like flint. Vocals
column6: used sparingly
column7: are often sunk low in the mix. This
column8: combined with Gat's conversational field recordings
column9: gives Director the feel of driving past a bustling street scene with the windows down; you can feel the radiance in the air
column10: even if you're moving just a little too quickly to quite put your finger on it. Despite its sitcom-length runtime
column11: Director manages to feel maybe 10 minutes shorter
column12: so rarely does it pause to fully soak in the scenery.

column1: For all its energy
column2: Director ends not with a bang
column3: but with a floorward collapse. The brief
column4: diffuse ""Underwater Prelude"" seems designed to provide a respite from the calamity that precedes it
column5: but it only ends up sapping the built-up momentum. The skronky ""L'Atlantis"" sounds like the intro to a Sonic Youth song that never fully gets itself off the ground. And closer ""Tanto Que Nem Tem""
column6: with a lovely
column7: mournful vocal turn from Sayeg
column8: is punctuated by bursts of noise that distract where they're meant to disorient. Still
column9:
the wildness of the ride Director takes you on more than makes up for this rocky landing. 

"|20372.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20372-director/|7.0|Paul Thompson

Sweet and Other Distress|1742.0|Godspeed You! Black Emperor|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Constellation']|2015-04-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:52.215053|"

When Godspeed You! Black Emperor returned to record after a long hiatus with Allelujah! Don’t Bend! Ascend! they weren’t quite releasing new music. The album consisted of pieces the Montreal collective had composed during the early 2000s
column3: back when they were at their most prolific
column4: and the album was simply a matter of getting long-performed work down in the studio. <i>Asunder
column5: Sweet and Other Distress contains music of a more recent vintage
column6: which is potentially significant because following Godspeed has always meant grappling with a basic question: When you have one of the most distinctive sonic profiles in music—that trademark quiet/loud mix of soaring guitars
column7: epic strings
column8: and field recordings—how important is it to branch out beyond it? Do we want a Godspeed album that sounds like anything but Godspeed?

column1: Asunder
column2: Sweet and Other Distress
column3: conceived a decade after their initial run
column4: when they defined everything this band is and should be
column5: does not offer a new wrinkle. There is nothing about this album—from the particulars of the recording to the riffs to the arrangements—that would have sounded out of place if they had released it in 2002. Change is not Godspeed’s way
column6: but the other side of that coin is that
column7: despite many imitators
column8: there’s also nothing else out there that sounds quite like them. The shifts on this record involve pivots more than actual movement: At points
column9: guitars are unusually prominent and the music feels a bit heavier. It’s also their shortest album. But beyond a few such tweaks
column10: the album is Godspeed to its core
column11: moving from thin drones to Wagnerian pomp and circumstance and back again over long
column12: patient stretches.

column1: As much as any record they’ve made
column2: the music here is meant to work as one
column3: and sequencing and flow is everything. They’ve been working out this material live for some time now
column4: and fans have taken to calling the whole ""Behemoth""
column5: an appropriate descriptor given its heaviness. Though there are four tracks
column6: the album really happens in three movements. The first and third contain the slowly building refrains and crashing climaxes
column7: and the middle two tracks are more of a single 16-minute piece consisting of drones
column8: gushes of guitar feedback
column9: and fragments of strings. On the vinyl version of the album
column10: the A-side cleverly ends with a locked groove to suggest a sense of continuity
column11: but the CD version finds the two middle pieces flowing one into the next.

column1: Sandwiching the drone section between the two crashing fanfares makes good sense
column2: allowing the album to breathe and suggesting more variety than it might otherwise. Opening track ""Peasantry or ‘Light! Inside of Light!’"" is the album’s highlight
column3: and ranks with Godspeed’s best work. The guitar riff has serious weight and crunch to it
column4: and the piece unfolds with a modal sweep. But the transformation the main line gradually undergoes
column5: where a dramatically beautiful desert vista becomes a setting for a melody that suggests a drunken holiday singalong
column6: shows that there’s still a lot they can do with their basic ingredients.

column1: ""Peasantry"" and the closing ""Piss Crowns Are Trebled"" are so intense and grandiose they skirt self-parody
column2: always a risk with this band. But it's possible to give Godspeed the benefit of the doubt
column3: in part because of how they’ve conducted themselves throughout their career. In 2015
column4: music like this is usually used to sell things
column5: whether it’s a product or a television show. There’s so much feeling in it
column6: huge washes of sound that could easily be regarded as manipulative
column7: and capitalism inevitably strives to pair these kinds of sounds with product. As a listener
column8: to give yourself over to this kind of soaring music
column9: allowing yourself to be carried away
column10: implies a certain amount of trust. Godspeed You! Black Emperor record and play instrumental pieces that exist to move you
column11: using only the force of music
column12: and in a space where sound is the primary context. It's a different kind of transaction. You have to let your guard down
column13:
and Godspeed have to transform feelings into compelling records. They're still on track.
