the Future|32845.0|Jodeci|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Epic']|2015-04-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:52.802644|"

It’s not always fun to watch storied musicians prepare a comeback after years
column4: or even decades
column5: out of the limelight. In the case of Jodeci
column6: the news was more encouraging: more than just a nostalgia act
column7: the groundbreaking '90s R&B group were one of the original purveyors of male ratchet. There would be no Chris Brown or PARTYNEXTDOOR if DeVante Swing
column8: K-Ci
column9: JoJo and Mr. Dalvin hadn’t stomped and writhed all over R&B
column10: opening up a new
column11: sex-positive lane for male rappers and singers. Until Jodeci unlocked the swag
column12: R&B singers were often blazer-and-sweater wearing singers
column13: rarely approaching the energy and aesthetic of a rapper. (The foursome was truly a marquee act on this front—check out this safe sex PSA from 1995.) Twenty years on from their third album The Show
column14: the After Party
column15: the Hotel
column16: Jodeci’s returned to a hip-hop and R&B landscape that’s more sexually liberated than ever before. So
column17: what’s on the agenda for <i>The Past
column18: the Present
column19: the Future?

column1: In some ways
column2: the 'Bad Boys of R&B' tagline was just a foil: Jodeci
column3: led by producer/singer DeVante Swing
column4: remains a group of soul classicists
column5: thematically inspired by the intimacy and lewdness of sex and buttressed by the aesthetic and energy of hip-hop. So
column6: like the second single ""Every Moment"" hinted
column7: this is another record of silky
column8: pro-forma bedroom soul; a classic
column9: if slightly tame Jodeci record
column10: with no real aesthetic challenges or age-inappropriate shifts in style. It’s a fans-first album that certainly won’t be played outside of urban radio formats—but then
column11: it's rare to hear anything as assuredly black as Jodeci’s pristine
column12: four-part harmonies and celestial new jack swing outside those formats anymore anyway.

column1: ""Those Things""
column2: one of The Past’s best tracks
column3: begins in that classic territory before rapid-fire kick drums and snares and a warped synth offer a genius update: New jack swing for a post-trap world
column4: courtesy of former protégé Timbaland
column5: who produces the track as well as ""Incredible"". A wave of sweet oohs breezes through ""Stress Reliever""
column6: paired with thick drums that give the track the airy whimsy of Jai Paul’s ""BTSTU"". Most of the remaining 11 tracks are closer to ""Too Hot""
column7: which lifts the thunderous bass line from Dawn Penn’s classic
column8: <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j_LKYyXFFrU"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""You Don't Love Me (No
column9: No
column10: No"". It’s all ingenious
column11: brawny R&B that celebrates the past
column12: but there’s not much on this album of midtempo ballads that presents a vision of the future. The few guest starts here don't upset the balance: B.o.B (""Nobody Wins"") and Mila J (""Body Parts"")
column13: deliver lukewarm verses and are outperformed by the bombast of the group vocals. Despite the evidence ""Those Things"" puts forward
column14: Jodeci is clearly comfortable living amidst the vaulted synths of their prime
column15: and that doesn’t have to be a bad thing.

column1: In truth
column2: they display a confidence in declining to chase or win over new fans that is exceedingly rare in legacy acts. Missy’s retreading her own trailblazing route by glomming onto Diplo
column3: and even Mary J. Blige had to go to Disclosure to get some play. Jodeci are no longer music’s go-to bad boys. Instead they have an ally in hip-hop’s favorite good boy
column4: Drake
column5: whose commitment to '90s R&B is plastered all over his discography
column6:
making the case for nostalgia over that new-new.

"|20426.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20426-the-past-the-present-the-future/|7.0|Anupa Mistry

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21571/homepage_large.f213a04f.jpg|Sonnet|5012.0|Benoît Pioulard|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kranky']|2015-04-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:53.334525|"

Sonnet feels like a regeneration for Benoît Pioulard
column2: the alias of Seattle-based Michigan transplant Thomas Meluch. The album contains elements of his prior work under the name—particularly its general tone of melancholy and disrepair—but he chooses to zone in on the drifty and (mostly) instrumental side of his music for this album. It’s a subtle shift but not an insignificant one—he sounds more confident and in control than on Hymnal
column3: which veered closer to a grab-bag aesthetic. As is often the case when artists reinvent what they’re doing
column4: Meluch had to go backward to move forward
column5: forgoing digital tools to work in an analog environment. The results are more otherworldly
column6: with tiny drones and banks of noise and blocks of tape hiss all coiling around one another
column7: locked tight in an uneasy embrace that only Meluch can connect or disconnect.

column1: What Sonnet gains over other albums Meluch has made is a more acute sense of direction. The tone varies in shades throughout
column2: sounding like a lost radio broadcast fighting through static
column3: or music humming quietly out of a dysfunctional intercom in a broken down hospital. At some points it reaches such a level of atrophy that it feels like the instruments are disintegrating in Meluch's hands as he records with them. It’s an album that will get slotted into the ambient category
column4: but it’s not ambient in the sense of being something to relax to or to have on in the background. It’s more arresting than that
column5: as ideas crystallize in short
column6: ever-repeating loops.

column1: Meluch's method here is to take field recordings of industrial equipment and nature and attempt to replicate them on guitar. But Sonnet isn’t an album that benefits from being broken down into parts—it’s best consumed whole
column2: in a single sitting
column3: where Meluch’s sense of exploration can truly unfold. At times
column4: he’s knee-deep in sludge
column5: making tar-like guitar lines sound like something you wade through. At others
column6: he’s up in the stratosphere
column7: channeling the mesh between krautrock and shoegaze that Flying Saucer Attack were practicing circa Further.

column1: Vocals come rarely on Sonnet—Meluch removed most of them while paring down the album to its core emotions. When they do appear
column2: they're just another element ghosting into the murk. The result is often reminiscent of the space Leyland Kirby works in when he records as the Caretaker
column3: all haunted mirrors and nearly forgotten memories
column4:
constructed at the very point where those things feel like they’re about to permanently slip into oblivion. Sonnet positions Meluch somewhere beyond the insular place he occupied before. 

"|20304.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20304-sonnet/|7.2|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21637/homepage_large.246ab96f.jpg|Cosmic Troubles|32819.0|Faith Healer|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mint']|2015-04-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:54.012077|"

On 2011’s Brother Loyola
column2: Jessica Jalbert asserted that ""I’m not the records that I own
column3: and I’m not the things I’m good at."" That those points needed making says plenty about the Edmonton songwriter
column4: who’s since refined her '60s-styled indie-pop under the Faith Healer alias. Jalbert
column5: who seems both assured and self-scrutinizing
column6: sidelines in the kind of record-collecting
column7: plainclothes punk bands who covet the Troggs over the Pistols
column8: which frees up her solo work to dive into her daydreamy subconscious. On Cosmic Troubles
column9: her second solo album
column10: she shares private epiphanies and stares at her bedroom ceiling as the universe unravels.

column1: Recorded with longtime collaborator Renny Wilson in his parents’ makeshift basement studio
column2: Cosmic Troubles sounds every bit as excitable and debut-fresh as Brother Loyola. It meanders calmly from in thrall to enthralling
column3: and enjoys the trip—by the chorus of ""Canonized""
column4: Jalbert and Wilson are playfully excavating White Album-era Beatles via the shambling exuberance of the Raincoats
column5: and it sounds fantastic. If there’s little impetus to write great songs that don’t sound like other great songs—usually
column6: it transpires
column7: songs by the Velvet Underground—the references rarely grate; it’s a record that keeps its influences close
column8: like childhood toys under the bed
column9: in a way that’s reassuring rather than cumbersome.

column1: For much of the album Jalbert sings in a calmly vacated tone. Her demeanor is neither ingenuous nor jaded
column2: and she has the dreamy air of somebody who’d spend therapy sessions psychoanalyzing her shrink. Despite the record’s rigorous self-analysis
column3: Jalbert owns her self-consciousness
column4: and applies it on her own terms. Sometimes it becomes a principle ingredient. ""Fools Rush In"" embodies the narrator’s hypercritical subconscious in a taunting Beach Boys harmony: ""I'm so stupid
column5: ba-ba-ba."" ""Again"" taps into the goldmine of whimsy that links neuroses and laundry—""It’s a pain to stretch yourself out after being through the wash""—while ""Angel Eyes""
column6: conventional but no less enchanting
column7: opens its heart with the unrelenting steadiness of Leonard Cohen and Angel Olsen. For all its stylistic play
column8: the record’s tenor is uniformly self-certain.

column1: So it’s all the more alarming when it cracks. The title track
column2: for one
column3: is musically on-point
column4: with haunting echoes of Jefferson Airplane. But its words depict a domestic dispute in stark terms: ""I was out of my mind with my hands around my neck/ You raised yours to slap them off
column5: and I raised mine out to protect."" After the heavenly ""Infinite Return""
column6: ""No Car"" kicks up a heavy riff
column7: before describing a recent breakup from which the partner’s fingers are ""bruised into my flesh.""

column1: In these fragments Jalbert’s songwriting seems to crystallise
column2: her gentle dredging a way to send you fathoms deep into her mind without having to follow all the way. At times it sounds like
column3: having grown out of nihilism
column4: Jalbert is reaching for the nearest tune to get lost in
column5: her stories a psychic sojourn on the route home to oblivion. By the time you return to ""Fools Rush In""
column6: where she slides from lackadaisical soul-searching into idle contemplations of suicide-by-drowning
column7: Cosmic Troubles sounds a sadder
column8: vaster album than before
column9:
but one whose meditations can soothe your bones like an inviting stream.

"|20371.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20371-cosmic-troubles/|7.4|Jazz Monroe

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21695/homepage_large.9f92ceef.jpg|It Follows OST|32864.0|Disasterpeace|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Milan']|2015-04-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:54.554506|"

It Follows is a classic boy-meet-girls story
column2: only the boy is using a fake name
column3: the girl doesn’t know
column4: and after they sleep together it turns out he’s passed more than fluids—specifically
column5: a curse that makes her the target of an unstoppable
column6: unmerciful demon. The demon takes human form; it can’t be seen by anyone but the cursed
column7: and those who’ve previously borne the curse. (It only targets one person at a time.) It doesn’t run—it walks
column8: stopping only when it’s in range for a vicious attack that leaves the victim’s limbs snapped
column9: and their pelvises crushed by coital rage. It can’t open doors
column10: but it knows how to knock. It’s the dark presence behind one of the more gripping horror movies of recent memory
column11: as well as a fantastic argument for abstinence.

column1: The soundtrack is handled by Disasterpeace
column2: aka Rich Vreeland
column3: an electronic artist who’s best known for a series of video game soundtracks. It Follows is his first film score
column4: and he’s worked diligently to build a cohesive world of ominous moods. There are several recurring motifs: a booming percussion that comes like the monster pounding on the door; a shrill klaxon signaling when danger is near; a pattern of corrupted synths chugging into motion like some futuristic train on its way to the junkyard. A window shatters. A cluster of digital hornets buzz and whine. A jet turbine spins into motion
column5: the air supercharging to an agonizing din
column6: only to die down and leave the room sapped of tension. It’s a score that announces when something is about to happen
column7: only to suddenly upend expectations and leave the room on edge.

column1: It Follows wouldn’t exist without John Carpenter’s movies
column2: and neither would the score. ""Title"" sounds like an update of Carpenter’s Halloween theme
column3: as a lonely piano line is slowly enveloped by gothic dread. The melody is echoed on ""Detroit""
column4: the arpeggiated tones brushing up against the sublime as the synthesizers drone from underneath. This is where you’d maybe dock Vreeland and the filmmakers a point for originality
column5: except It Follows comes at a precarious moment for the American horror movie. Everything is either point-of-view or torture porn
column6: and frankly
column7: if someone wants mine a source as fertile as Halloween
column8: they should go right ahead.

column1: Like all OSTs
column2: It Follows makes the most sense when you’ve seen the movie it’s made for—and you should see it
column3: especially if you can watch horror movies in genuine terror of what’s about to happen. But it can work in other contexts
column4: and a quick scan of Vreeland’s work shows he isn’t a one-trick composer leaning on his Casio. I’m most familiar with his score for ""Fez""
column5: a video game that’s ""Super Mario"" meets M.C. Escher
column6: in which a pixellated alien explores a slowly decaying cartoon world. ""Fez"" is a playful
column7: adventurous game in which a sense of whimsy is frequently juxtaposed with the solitude of the unknown. Vreeland’s score conveyed those moods
column8: just as his work for It Follows captures the paranoid fervor aroused by finding your normally comfortable surroundings transformed into a danger zone. Is it your friend you’re looking at
column9:
or the monster? How about now?

"|20427.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20427-it-follows-ost/|7.3|Jeremy Gordon

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21719/homepage_large.dd1f5ecb.jpg|Jenny Death|29614.0|Death Grips|['Rap'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Harvest']|2015-03-31 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:55.196766|"

Keeping up with the Death Grips has increasingly become a headache. Cryptic break-up notes
column3: a tumultuous split with Epic
column4: a realignment with Harvest
column5: cancelled tours (including one with Nine Inch Nails)
column6: no-show gigs: All of these antics were tolerable
column7: sometimes fun
column8: when they came backed up by compelling music. But even that part of the bargain
column9: over the last year
column10: has proved questionable. Last year’s Niggas on the Moon leaned too heavily on Björk samples and flattened their approach
column11: while Fashion Week was an intriguing
column12: if ultimately directionless
column13: collection of instrumentals. Fashion's song titles spelled out JENNYDEATHWHEN
column14: hinting cryptically that their next album would be Jenny Death
column15: the second half of the two-part sequence called The Powers That B. But by Fashion
column16: it was hard to tell if even their hardcore faithful cared about what they would do next.

column1: Jenny
column2: which Death Grips streamed on YouTube last week in advance of its release
column3: is the record they needed to make. It’s not on the level of their artistic and commercial breakthrough The Money Store
column4: but it will absolutely remind you of why you loved them in the first place. In fact
column5: it’s so different from (and better than) Moon that it shouldn’t even be tethered to it. On these ten tracks
column6: they’ve harnessed the unbridled energy of Government Plates into their most fully formed songs since Money
column7: which helps justify their bluster.

column1: Producer Andy ""Flatlander"" Morin brings a lot of the death-disco of Money back into the mix
column2: which broadens their approach without compromising their potency. Nothing here reaches the aggro-pop heights of ""I’ve Seen Footage""
column3: but ""Inanimate Sensation"" comes close; it's clear why it was released as the first single. Over Flatlander’s seasick bass synths
column4: Stefan ""MC Ride"" Burnett jumps through various vocals patterns—his trademark bark
column5: chopped-and-screwed raps
column6: menacing whispers—and ends up with something like a Jock Jams for the underworld. The buildup to MC Ride’s final verse is a staticky
column7: topsy-turvy rush
column8: culminating with the soon-to-be-immortal ""I like my iPod more than fucking!"" Yell that with your headphones on at work.

column1: MC Ride was so sorely missed on Fashion that his presence on Jenny feels like a triumphant comeback. Flatlander may provide the electronics and Hill may bring the percussive energy (and also lent initial critical credibility) to Death Grips
column2: but MC Ride is the unpredictable heart of the group. He was somewhat lost in the madness of Plates and subdued on Moon
column3: but he is in full
column4: raw force here: The title ""I Break Mirrors With My Face in the United States"" brings to mind a sadistic animated .gif enacting the Black Flag Damaged cover
column5: and MC Ride's raging
column6: hypnotic vocal reinforces this impression. He isn’t just a spiral of rage
column7: either—""Pss Pss"" casts him in creep mode
column8: suggesting illicit fantasies in a hushed whisper.

column1: The music on Jenny nods to Death Grips' more conventional rock influences
column2: but it’s in no way trying to pander to a rock audience. Each element they reference is blown up and rebuilt in their own vision. Vaguely surfy dream-pop gets shot into overdrive on ""Centuries of Damn"". ""Beyond Alive"" and ""ON GP"" both contain big rock riffs
column3: the latter approaching metalgaze territory. ""GP"" inflates MC Ride’s discontentment into something massive and anthemic. It’s jaded stadium rock—all it needs is a stadium and an ironclad guarantee they’ll show up.

column1: You hear more of drummer Zach Hill’s acoustic drums on Jenny
column2: too. He continues to unlearn his technical prowess from his Hella days
column3: but he’s electrifying even when going back to basics. Throughout
column4: you can hear them furthering their vision for aggression without borders
column5: swallowing in hip-hop
column6: hardcore
column7: industrial
column8: and the hardest forms of dance music
column9: while not in debt to any one of those elements. Death Grips don’t just imagine a world where rap-rock is redeemed and various forms of heaviness coexist side-by-side
column10: but where those lines are obliterated. That fantasy may not have panned out quite the way it should have
column11: but to deny their ambitions does a disservice to what heavy music can be.

column1: Closer ""Death Grips 2.0"" acknowledges the ongoing ""will they or won’t they"" dynamic that’s long been a point of frustration amongst their critics. The title suggests a rebirth
column2: but the content
column3: a sort of Araabmetalmuzik blast of cut-up industrial beats
column4: could also be a fiery demise. It’s the perfect Death Grips closer
column5: especially with their status in constant question. Right after their alleged ""breakup
column6: there were eulogies for the group
column7: but Death Grips are not the sort of group to be eulogized. Are they calling it quits after this record and tour? Was the breakup even real to begin with? It’s hard to speculate whether Jenny is a redemptive closing chapter
column8: a new beginning
column9: or some other inscrutable part of Death Grips’ master plan
column10: if they even have such a thing. What is evident is that Jenny Death is some of their strongest material in a while
column11:
and may even return a few disillusioned converts to the flock.

"|20451.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20451-jenny-death/|8.1|Andy O'Connor

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21512/homepage_large.6204e584.jpg|Insides|30178.0|Fort Romeau|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ghostly']|2015-03-31 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:55.909957|"

For the four years he’s released music as Fort Romeau
column2: South London’s Michael Greene has poked curiously at house music’s form. On his 2012 debut
column3: Kingdoms
column4: Greene delivered a set of workmanlike deep-house all built around carefully manipulated vocal samples. Spread out over the next couple years
column5: Fort Romeau’s ensuing four EPs documented both his continually improving production abilities and his widening palette. Thanks to moments like the Kosmische-influenced slow burn of 2013’s ""Stay/True"" (from the EP of the same name) or the stuttery tech-house/2-step of ""SW9"" (also from the EP of the same name)
column6: Greene quietly established himself as an intriguing new voice in the genre.

column1: Insides is Fort Romeau’s second full-length record
column2: and although it doesn’t continue on quite the same upward trend of his recent discography in the risk-taking department
column3: it does boast some of his most fully dimensional and impressively produced work yet. While there are barely any vocal samples to be found here
column4: it’s adorned with the kinds of textures and details that had been missing from the wide-eyed Kingdoms. Tonally
column5: it’s a darker and more pensive affair
column6: one that’s less concerned with its vocal centerpieces and more interested in atmosphere
column7: craft and classicism.

column1: Some have framed Insides as a modern throwback record
column2: one that owes its sound to Chicago house more than anything else
column3: and indeed
column4: from the first acidic squiggle in opener ""New Wave""
column5: it’s evident that Greene is studiously and consciously showing his work. Having toured and DJed a fair amount in the time since his last full-length
column6: it seems that he’s come back to the studio with knowledge and reverence to burn
column7: and the galloping pianos and wending atmospherics in the 8-minute long ""All I Want"" and the brooding single-note synth warbles and tech-house flavorings of ""Insides"" bear that out.

column1: But merely painting Insides as an homage to Chicago would be to miss the thing that makes it most interesting. Ultimately
column2: it’s Greene’s willingness to decorate house music’s form with new sounds and reference points that distinguishes him from the scads of Beatport randoms. Insides is inflected with tinges of Kosmische
column3: ambient and microhouse to the extent that some of its best tracks—like the intricate patchwork of bells and percussion of ""Cloche"" or the lonely synth arpeggios of ""IKB""—could barely pass for house at all. Elsewhere
column4: the loping computer music of ""Folle"" and the whirlygigging synth-aided second half of the ten-and-a-half-minute long ""Lately"" recall artists as varied as Ford & Lopatin and Tangerine Dream.

column1: That Fort Romeau was rashly named after an adjacent town while Greene was in France tells you something about his attitude to his music. He may occasionally be trumpeted by classicists as a flag-waver for the old school
column2:
but there’s no actual agenda here beyond his desire to make interesting new sounds. He's getting better at it with every passing release.

"|20244.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20244-fort-romeau-insides/|7.5|Mark Pytlik

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21672/homepage_large.81c98c4a.jpg|Rave Cave EP|11702.0|Andrew Hung|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-03-31 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:56.524828|"

Andrew Hung
column2: one-half of the duo Fuck Buttons
column3: takes a step back on the Rave Cave EP. In place of the intense polish of the duo’s most recent album
column4: Slow Focus
column5: Hung offers a brief look at the way his mind works when faced with a vastly pared-down set of tools—in this case
column6: a Game Boy. (Though as he has said
column7: that choice was simply a convenient solution to the dearth of portable
column8:
easy-to-manipulate gear during Fuck Buttons’ last tour.)

Writing music on an obsolete gaming tool probably seems hopelessly antiquarian to some (especially if you grew up with the DS) but the uninhibited
column9: high-strung music Hung wrings from it feels fresh. There’s nothing here of the magnitude of their massive Tarot Sport centerpiece ""Olympians""
column10: or the protracted leer of Slow Focus. The biggest and brightest moment is the irrepressible glitch-fest ""Korea Town""
column11: a gorgeous tide of bleeps and bloops
column12:
with romantically wafting strings laid on thick on top.

The EP’s other two tracks are harder-edged
column13: built on heavily metronomic beats with just enough swing to stick. They’re also nowhere near as pretty: The propulsive
column14: bull-headed stomp ""The Plane"" is stippled with sharp
column15: abrasive sound effects
column16: pushing the rough equipment to an aggressive extreme. Hung also shows a punkish sense of humor
column17: adding in an almost comically seasick warble partway through ""Fables"". All three songs sound like a loose extension of the unconventional methodology that’s driven Hung and Fuck Buttons bandmate Benjamin John Power’s collaborative jamming.

column1: <div>The EP also benefits from a handmade quality
column2: one that you certainly wouldn’t find on a Fuck Buttons album at this point. Hung and Powers have often worked with cheap equipment
column3: from karaoke machines to children's toys
column4: though they've shown an increasing focus on sound quality as the scale of their work has increased. Here
column5: Hung's unvarnished approach serves to highlight themes that repeatedly creep into his work—an underlying affinity for gear-grinding industrial sounds; a focus on process over a specific end result. In that sense
column6: it's a welcome refresher."|20405.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20405-rave-cave-ep/|7.0|Abigail Garnett

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21656/homepage_large.7e505bb2.jpg|Deep Hits|32831.0|Tufthunter|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-03-31 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:58.191899|"

As a guitarist for Talulah Gosh
column2: Heavenly
column3: and a host of other twee greats
column4: Peter Momtchiloff now has nearly three decades' worth of scrappy indie pop gems to his name. With a catalog that deep
column5: it certainly would've been well-earned if the British-born musician decided to undertake the exercise of compiling a 20th Century Masters collection of his disparate
column6: dusty
column7: and largely under-the-radar recordings. But though the name may suggest otherwise
column8: Deep Hits
column9: his debut release as Tufthunter
column10: is a less self-indulgent affair. Instead
column11: it's a collection of what Momtchiloff does best—guitar-centered pop songs
column12: delightful and charming despite (or maybe because of) their lack of grander ambition. This time around there's an extra spark thanks to a host of guest vocal turns from friends he's accrued over the course of his career.

column1: Even though there's a different voice on each track
column2: Momtchiloff conjures a fairly unified mood. In a recent interview
column3: he acknowledged that the revolving-door concept of Tufthunter owes itself to Stephin Merritt's project the 6ths. But while those records skipped around the world of indie rock
column4: enlisting luminaries like Bob Mould and Lou Barlow
column5: Momtchiloff's guests are mostly confined to the twee world he came up in. Album opener ""Lit Up""'s lyrical focus on partying for ""old times' sake"" is central to the exercise that Momtchiloff is undertaking on Deep Hits. That Lois Maffeo-featuring track
column6: as well as a handful of others
column7: recalls the sunny strumming of his days in Heavenly. But this isn't merely an occasion for the accomplished guitarist to trot out his own familiar lilting lines: He's offering up a twisted and ramshackle take on the whole history of indie pop.

column1: On ""We Fly By Night"" he conjures a compelling vision of Stereolab-indebted krautrock
column2: motoring on the back of a searing organ drone and a couple of brittle and anxious lead lines. He enlists the Magnetic Fields' Claudia Gonson for wry
column3: orchestral backed storytelling on ""How Venus Got Her Name"" and his former bandmate Amelia Fletcher for stripped down K Records joy on ""My Future Band"". It's a difference of shades
column4: sure
column5: but by capably nodding to a whole host of genre touchstones over the course of the record
column6: he demonstrates range in a style more often known for its charm than its technical ability.

column1: Despite the fact that Momtchiloff has resisted the temptation of literally making a compilation of his work
column2: Deep Hits ultimately does something similar anyway
column3: offering the whole spectrum of twee in a tidy 46 minutes
column4: with all the pitfalls that may come with doing so. Even those legendary Sarah Records comps had their down moments. So it's understandable that when he runs the tracks a little longer
column5: as on ""Low Life"" and ""You're All Going to Die""
column6: the allure of the pastiche tends to wear a little thin. But at its highest points
column7: like Gonson's dead-eyed just-so story and the self-doubting straightedge anthem ""The Drink and the Drugs""
column8:
Deep Hits suggests a promise for Tufthunter that goes beyond just capably looking in the rearview mirror.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21653/homepage_large.ceb23985.jpg|Phase IV OST|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Waxwork']|2015-03-31 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:58.763462|"

In the 1950s
column2: as the atomic arms deadlock with the Soviet Union settled into a decades-long deep freeze
column3: American moviegoers began to imagine threats coming from all angles
column4: even from beneath their feet. Warner Brothers’ highest grossing film of 1954 was Them!
column5: about a scourge of atomically enhanced ants. Soon
column6: all everyday bugs were distorted to inspire fear and horror
column7: a trend lasting well into the 1970s
column8: where movies gave us reason to fear fire-starting roaches (1975’s Bug)
column9: African killer bees (1978’s The Swarm) and flesh-eating earthworms (1976’s Squirm).

column1: One of the most profound—albeit neglected—sci-fi horror films to arise from the insect- kingdom subgenre was 1974’s Phase IV. Like Them!
column2: Phase IV scrutinized ants
column3: but instead of being supersized by radiation
column4: these ants had been intellectually enhanced by a cosmic event. The movie holds a special place in the hearts of cinephiles and graphic designers as the lone film made by Saul Bass
column5: an artist who designed the posters for Spartacus and Anatomy of a Murder
column6: and the title sequences for West Side Story
column7: Vertigo
column8: and <i>Goodfellas
column9: among others. Alas
column10: his lone foray behind the camera was a disaster: Phase IV sank without much attention upon its release
column11: and is probably most famous today for being mocked in the very first season of Mystery Science Theater 3000 (and
column12: I suppose
column13: inspiring a Yeasayer video). Perhaps that’s why its soundtrack has never seen release until now
column14: with Waxwork Records paying loving tribute to the film with a special vinyl pressing.

column1: Brian Gascoigne has credits intermittently spanning decades
column2: ranging from The Dark Crystal to Gosford Park to Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
column3: and he’s worked with Scott Walker. He gets the compositional credit on this soundtrack
column4: though the intense analog synthesizer work is contributed by Desmond Briscoe and David Vorhaus. The soundtrack also features Japanese percussionist Stomu Yamash’ta. While many sci-fi and horror films of the '70s are usually brief cues (rare is the John Carpenter track that runs longer than three minutes) what makes Phase IV such a fascinating listen forty years later is that the compositions are broken down into four exploratory
column5: ever-evolving sections
column6: each in the eight-minute range
column7: spanning a wide spectrum of emotion
column8: from fear to pastoral calm
column9: from alien to earthly.

column1: The drones that open ""Phase I"" might be Ligeti-like vocal choirs or bent circuits
column2: but no matter the source
column3: they make the skin prickle with dread. The sinewaves of Briscoe and Vorhaus soon blossom and Yamash’ta’s rumbling tympanum emerge
column4: only to have it all give way to a walking bassline and some sludgy electronics
column5: which threaten to dissolve the piece until a dirge-like theme returns at the end. Flute and strings emerge on ""Phase II"" and carry through most of ""Phase III"" but the analog synthesizers return midway through the piece and carry most of ""Phase IV"". There are traces of sound that might bring to mind the likes of Bitchin Bajas or even Shade Themes from Kairos
column6: but the sound here is pretty much of its own realm. With Phase IV finally back in print (although still missing the original psychedelic ending that Bass imagined for the film)
column7:
it’s cosmic justice of a sort that the accompanying music can now take its rightful place among the 70's strange soundtrack pantheon.

Sufjan Stevens' new album
column2: Carrie & Lowell
column3: is his best. This is a big claim
column4: considering his career: 2003's Michigan
column5: 2004's stripped-down Seven Swans
column6: 2005's Illinois
column7: and 2010's knotty electro-acoustic collection The Age of Adz. He's also had residencies at the Brooklyn Academy of Music
column8: collaborated with rappers and the National
column9: donned wings and paint-splattered dayglo costumes
column10: and released Christmas albums. But none of those side projects were ultimately ever as interesting
column11: or effective
column12: as when Sufjan was just Sufjan
column13: a guy with a guitar or piano
column14: well-detailed lyrics
column15: and a gorgeous whisper that could reach into a heartbreaking falsetto.

column1: Part of what makes Carrie & Lowell so great is that it comes after all of those things—the wings
column2: the orchestras—but it feels like you're hearing him for the first time again
column3: and in his most intimate form. This record is a return to the sparse folk of Seven Swans
column4: but with a decade's worth of honing and exploration packed into it. It already feels like his most classic and pure effort.

column1: By now the album's main narrative is well-known. Carrie & Lowell is titled after Stevens' mother and stepfather. Carrie was bipolar and schizophrenic and suffered from drug addiction and substance abuse. She died of stomach cancer in 2012
column2: but had abandoned Stevens much earlier
column3: first when he was 1
column4: then later
column5: repeatedly (""when I was three
column6: three maybe four
column7: she left us at that video store
column8: he sings on ""Should Have Known Better""). His stepfather
column9: Lowell Brams
column10: was married to Carrie for five years when Sufjan was a child. As a testament to the importance of his role in Stevens' life
column11: Brams currently runs Stevens' label
column12: Asthmatic Kitty
column13: and shows up repeatedly in the record
column14: most poignantly on the title track
column15: where Stevens frames those five years as his ""season of hope.""

column1: Stevens has always written personally
column2: weaving his life story into larger narratives
column3: but here his autobiography
column4: front and center
column5: is itself the grand history. The songs explore childhood
column6: family
column7: grief
column8: depression
column9: loneliness
column10: faith
column11: and rebirth in direct and unflinching language that matches the scaled-back instrumentation. There are Biblical references
column12: and references to mythology
column13: but most of it is squarely about Stevens and his family. A few of the songs (""Carrie & Lowell""
column14: ""Eugene""
column15: ""All of Me Wants All of You"") mention the summer trips to Oregon that Stevens made
column16: between the ages of five and eight
column17: with Carrie
column18: Lowell
column19: and his brother. There are Oregon-specific references to Eugene
column20: the Tillamook Burn forest fires
column21: Spencer Butte
column23: and swimming lessons with a man who calls him Subaru. These were moments when Stevens was closest to his mother
column24: or at least in most constant proximity to her
column25: and he recorded some of Carrie & Lowell's tracks on an iPhone in a hotel in Klamath Falls
column27: as if trying to find a way to recreate those moments one more time.

column1: Other songs focus on an adult Stevens coping with the aftermath of those early years
column2: and the blankness his mother's distance and death left in him. He beats himself up for not trying harder to be closer earlier. On ""Should Have Known Better"" he sings ""I should have wrote a letter/ Explaining what I feel
column3: that empty feeling."" He talks about his own drinking (""Now I'm drunk and afraid/ Wishing the world would go away"") and drug abuse
column4: disconnected relationships (""You checked your text while I masturbated"")
column5: self-loathing
column6: and emptiness (""In a manner of speaking I'm dead""). There are suicidal thoughts (arm cutting
column7: driving a car off a cliff
column8: drowning
column9: and questions like ""Do I care if I survive this?"")
column10: which he pushes away with his faith and by focusing on the wonders around him (""Sea lion caves in the dark
column11: the hysterical light of Eugene
column12: Oregon). There is a lot of blood. Some broken bones. Tears. There is also a constant need to be closer—to his mother
column13: to himself
column14: to the world around him—even when it seems useless: ""What's the point of singing songs/ If they'll never even hear you?"" (""Eugene""). The other main character here is his brother
column15: Marzuki Stevens
column16: and his daughter
column17: Sufjan's niece
column18: who provides the one true moment of joy on the record: ""My brother had a daughter/ The beauty that she brings
column19: illumination"" (""Should Have Known Better"").

column1: As he told Pitchfork
column2: ""With this record
column3: I needed to extract myself out of this environment of make-believe. It’s something that was necessary for me to do in the wake of my mother’s death—to pursue a sense of peace and serenity in spite of suffering. It’s not really trying to say anything new
column4: or prove anything
column5: or innovate. It feels artless
column6: which is a good thing. This is not my art project; this is my life."" On the second to last track
column7: ""No Shade in the Shadow of the Cross""
column8: he sings
column9: in falsetto
column10: ""Fuck me I'm falling apart
column11: and it is maybe the barest
column12: most honest declaration you'll hear on a record this year.

column1: His relationship
column2: or lack thereof
column3: with his mother is complex: He never hates her. He feels her everywhere: She passes through him as an apparition
column4: and everything comes back to her in one way or another. ""I love you more than the world can contain/ In its lonely and ramshackle head
column5: he sings. He doesn't cast blame. ""Fourth of July""
column6: a tender song about her death
column7: is filled with terms of endearment (""my little hawk
column8: ""my firefly"")
column9: and questions about how he can raise her from the dead and then make the most of his own life
column10: before he ends the song by repeating
column11: soberly
column12: ""We're all gonna die.""

column1: The lyrics here are masterful and carefully shorn
column2: and the music is as well. Stevens is joined by Laura Veirs
column3: S. Carey
column4: Thomas Bartlett
column5: and others
column6: but they come off as ghosts in the room around his carefully constructed soundscapes
column7: compositions that tastefully blend acoustic and electronic elements that grow deeper with each listen. There are pianos
column8: organs
column9: starry washes
column10: smears of synthesizers
column11: clicking percussion
column12: unidentifiable pulses
column13: doubled vocals
column14: soaring background harmonies
column15: and quickly picked acoustic guitars that will remind you of Elliott Smith. In the past he'd get showy with multi-part suites or huge arrangements; the writing here is just as ambitious
column16: but never showy. You often forget the music's there
column17: but when you don't
column18: it's catchy
column19: inventive
column20: melodic
column21: seamless. The haunting production

column1: Stevens has been making music for a long time
column2: and Carrie & Lowell shines a light back on the rest of his oeuvre. You realize the story of Michigan's ""Romulus"" is heartbreakingly real
column3: down to its references to Oregon (""Once when our mother called/ She had a voice of last year's cough/ We passed around the phone/ Sharing a word about Oregon"")
column4: and that desperate desire for even one touch: ""Once when we moved away/ She came to Romulus for a day/ Her Chevrolet broke down/ We prayed it'd never be fixed or be found/ We touched her hair."" He loves his mother
column5: and is ashamed of her
column6: and can't stop loving her. It's one example of many
column7: and when you re-listen to the past albums
column8: and songs like ""The Seer's Tower"" and its once mysterious ""Oh
column9: my mother
column10: she betrayed us
column11: but my father loved and bathed us
column12: it acts as a skeleton key to what was once an ineffable sadness. As he put it in ""John Wayne Gacy
column13: Jr."": ""Even in my best behavior I am really just like him/ Look beneath the floorboards for the secrets I have hid."" Here are those secrets laid bare.

column1: There is a photo in the booklet of a young Stevens
column2: at the table
column3: eating a banana. It's one of a few photos in the booklet that seem to depict some of those Oregon summers: a beach spotted with rocks
column4: a small half-painted wooden house near trees and hills. His look is not happy or sad; he's just a kid at a table
column5: eating. But there's something melancholic there
column6: something maybe you add onto it after listening to Carrie & Lowell
column7: but something real nonetheless: His mother is standing beside him. She's not looking at him
column8: but she's there. (She appears in three shots
column9: and in none of them can you see her eyes.) You imagine Lowell took the picture (on the back of the booklet you see his reflection in the mirror of a photo taken of Carrie crocheting). It's a haunting feeling that that little kid
column10: years later
column11: would create a masterpiece so knowing about suffering
column12: sadness
column13: death
column14: and loneliness. In that photo
column15: though
column16: he's still a kid
column17: with all those kid hurts
column18: trying to make sense of the world. And
column19: at least for that moment
column20:
he's close to his mother. And it seems like maybe he's happy.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21626/homepage_large.793011ab.jpg|The Day Is My Enemy|3402.0|The Prodigy|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Cooking Vinyl'
column2:
'Take Me to the Hospital']|2015-03-30 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:12:59.938449|"

Never discount the salubrious effects of lowered expectations. Part of the pleasure to be derived from the Prodigy's sixth studio album comes from the fact that there's really no reason
column4: for the Prodigy still to exist. A quarter-century
column5: after all
column6: is an awfully long time to try to hold a sneer
column7: but that's precisely what they've been doing since Liam Howlett founded the group in 1990 with a couple of dancers
column8: Keith Flint and Leeroy Thornhill. While the U.K. raved under the sign of a giant yellow smiley face
column9: the Prodigy adopted a demonic rictus.

column1: That attitude
column2: paired with Howlett's machine-gun breakbeats
column3: mangled cartoon samples
column4: and acid-metal amalgams
column5: repeatedly took the group to the upper reaches of the British pop charts
column6: and it helped them become one of the first British dance acts to break America when they signed a rumored $5 million contract—with Madonna's Maverick label
column7: no less—for their 1997 album The Fat of the Land
column8: a Trojan Horse for ""electronica"" that also paved the way for a lot of regrettable rap-rock. That record's concussive repercussions can still be felt through all manner of dance music that is loud
column9: aggressive
column10: and in love with its own transgressions: Skrillex
column11: ""Express Yourself""
column12: ""Turn Down for What""
column13: you name it.

column1: But the Prodigy never really seemed to matter in quite the same way again. After a seven-year wait
column2: 2004's <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/6486-always-outnumbered-never-outgunned/""><i>Always Outnumbered
column3: Never Outgunned was a mixed bag of Fat of the Land­-style retreads
column4: and
column5: five years after that
column6: Invaders Must Die sounded like still more rendered Fat drippings rescued from the pan—just beefed up to meet the production standards of the then-ascendant dubstep scene. Perhaps The Day Is My Enemy benefits from the fact that
column7: in the past few years
column8: the zeitgeist has moved on yet again—to hip-hop and R&B
column9: on the one hand
column10: and deeper
column11: moodier shades of dance music on the other—which means that the Prodigy sound increasingly like a genre of one.

column1: The title song
column2: which opens the album
column3: is a malevolent high point. The guitar riff rains down like a buzz bomb and the quarter-note ride cymbal sounds like an anvil; Martina Topley-Bird
column4: of all people
column5: sings a trembling couplet borrowed from Cole Porter's ""All Through the Night"". There's a wild
column6: madcap energy to it—I'm reminded
column7: incongruously enough
column8: of Colourbox's ""Hot Doggie""
column9: from 4AD's Lonely Is an Eyesore compilation—that carries through the rest of the album's best songs. The double-barreled ""Nasty"" rockets ahead on a distorted biwa riff
column10: rolling breakbeats
column11: and call-and-response chants courtesy of longtime vocalists Keith Flint and Maxim
column12: while a woozy Theremin melody taps a winking camp sensibility. ""Destroy"" fuses Belgian rave with skronking baritone sax
column13: while ""Rhythm Bomb"" cribs the chorus of Jomanda's 1988 diva-house tune ""Make My Body Rock (Feel It)"".

column1: The best thing on the album
column2: by far
column3: is ""Ibiza""
column4: a breakbeat fusillade stitched together with rayguns and chintzy Hammond organs; pub philosophers Sleaford Mods spit the withering hook—""Eye-beetha! Eye-beetha!""—and it's such a natural pairing
column5: you wonder why they don't sing on all of the Prodigy's songs. The Prodigy
column6: for all their anger
column7: have never really been about meaning—just see ""Smack My Bitch Up""
column8: or the equally execrable ""Baby's Got a Temper""
column9: an ode to Rohypnol—but the Mods' sudsy expositions actually manage to lend a layer of depth to the music
column10: even if it does just entail shouting ""Transmit! Transmit! What's he fucking doing?"" over and over.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: the lyrics are as corny as ever. In ""Wall of Death""
column3: Maxim and Keith Flint shout
column4: ""You're not ready to visualize/ I'm not here to be sterilized/ Follow me to the wall of death!"" In ""Wild Frontier""
column5: Maxim warns us that we've got to face our fear in the—yeah
column6: you guessed it—wild frontier. And then there's ""Invisible Sun""
column7: a ham-fisted attempt to capture Soundgarden levels of grandeur in trap beats
column8: twangy guitars
column9: and straight-up doggerel: ""Invisible sun
column10: I'm stumbling in the dark/ Invisible sun
column11: a shadow upon the stars/ Invisible sun
column12: shining where there's no path/ Invisible sun
column13: burning out question marks.""

column1: So
column2: yes
column3: there are easily as many misses as hits on the album
column4: and 14 tracks is probably about seven tracks too long. Not to mention that ""Get Your Fight On""—lyrics sadly not written by David Rees—samples Pepe Deluxé's ""Salami Fever""
column5: which the Prodigy already sampled on 2009's ""Take Me to the Hospital"". Then again
column6:
Howlett has been repeating himself in one way or another for some 25 years now; can you blame him for going back to a particularly fertile groove?

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21484/homepage_large.b38c7488.jpg|Primrose Green|32691.0|Ryley Walker|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dead Oceans']|2015-03-30 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:00.822486|"

In his quarter-century
column2: Ryley Walker seems to have made definitive decisions about what qualifies as a worthy influence: Van Morrison records made between 1968 and 1974
column3: Jackson C. Frank
column4: Pentangle
column5: and the recently reissued early works of Mike Cooper are all among the examples. On Primrose Green
column6: he embraces those inspirations without wrestling with them. He lugs their aged weight around as signs of good taste and his self-proclaimed place in a historical lineage. Though Walker comes from a mid-sized city in Illinois
column7: he sings as if he bounced between the British Isles as a kid. Alongside his shoplifted accent
column8: he apes Morrison’s trademark grunts and melismas.

column1: Make no mistake: Walker is a prodigious talent. He’s one of the leading young stylists in a crowded instrumental guitar scene. He possesses the light touch of Bert Jansch
column2: the unbottled energy of Peter Walker
column3: and the musical erudition of John Fahey. And he has a Miles Davis-like capability to surround himself with astounding musicians
column4: from early collaborator Daniel Bachman to the band of Chicago jazz firecrackers who not only support him on Primrose Green but also supply many of its best moments. Walker is versatile
column5: too
column6: with a chameleonic quality that allows him to slip into ragged electric blues and bucolic acoustic reveries with equal ease. Of all the songwriters trying their hand at this revivalist approach during the last decade
column7: including Steve Gunn
column8: Hiss Golden Messenger
column9: and Sharon Van Etten
column10: Walker is the most natural and enviable.

column1: The band he built for Primrose Green is a stirring
column2: captivating ensemble
column3: too
column4: the kind of group that could jam for an uninterrupted hour and never lose an audience’s attention or its own freewheeling focus. During the extended introduction of ""Love Can Be Cruel""
column5: for instance
column6: they delight in the space between folk-rock form and jazz-band freedom. Heavy acoustic strumming
column7: sharp electric guitar and twinkling keyboards dart around a deep rhythm
column8: working into a frenzy until the song approaches the ecstasy of a raga. ""On the Banks of the Old Kishwaukee"" depends upon another stunning groove built by drummer Frank Rosaly and bassist Anton Hatwitch. Walker wires a moaning blues theme into the beat
column9: suggesting the wonderful roots-rock patience of American Beauty-era Grateful Dead. The band sizzles during ""Sweet Satisfaction""
column10: dips and dives during ""Same Minds""
column11: and charges into vibraphone-and-bass bedlam during ""Summer Dress"".

column1: But the trouble comes with Walker—the songwriter and singer
column2: not the instrumentalist. For someone so obsessed with classic troubadours
column3: he has a damning disregard for his own songs. He over-sings almost every part of this record
column4: trying to match his heroes with an inadequate instrument. The screamed lover-boy exhortations of ""Summer Dress"" are counterproductive at best
column5: copycatting at worst. He treats every written syllable of ""Sweet Satisfaction"" like a chance to slur a half-dozen of them
column6: stretching words until it’s easier to ignore them. Walker’s lyrics read like a set of unfinished end-rhyme exercises by a college student who has just discovered the Beats. Smoking grass at night makes him feel ""alright""; leaving his love
column7: however cruel
column8: would make him into a ""fool.""

column1: For a point of contrast
column2: see ""Griffiths Buck Blues""
column3: the one instrumental number on Primrose Green. Over a harmonium drone
column4: Walker musters pure energy and expression with only his guitar. As he starts and stops
column5: slows and sprints
column6: he communicates dread and unease with the conviction his voice lacks.

column1: The extensive biography that accompanies Primrose Green positions it as ""an album of a sort we haven’t seen since the 1970s""—a bit of description perhaps too on the nose
column2: as these 10 songs are acts of pure creative anachronism and affectation. The shape of Walker’s voice and the twists and turns of his band reanimate a specific aesthetic without adding much more than the tools of modern production. While Primrose Green is a great statement for a '70s freak-folk cosplayer
column3:
I just hope it’s not a career-defining one for Walker.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21630/homepage_large.f6bc211f.jpg|III|31306.0|Föllakzoid|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2015-03-30 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:00.977065|"

The Chilean band Föllakzoid specialize in the pillowy sort of rock music designed to shield you from the world for a while. Huge
column2: looping riffs stretch across deeply repetitive percussion
column3: creating an atmosphere somewhere between trance and stupor. The word ""psychedelic"" is never far away when reading descriptions of the band
column4: but three albums into their career
column5: they’ve explored many colors on that particular spectrum. Beginning with outward-facing
column6: Josh Homme-indebted rock on their eponymous debut in 2009
column7: they switched to something closer to krautrock on 2013’s II. Here
column8: they tighten their sound
column9: cutting out the meandering themes and occasionally sloppy riffing. There are only four songs
column10: but extra details emerge slowly on repeat listening.

column1: German producer Uwe Schmidt
column2: better known as Atom™
column3: has been brought in as a collaborator
column4: bringing the discipline of his immersively repetitive electronic music with him. He’s also credited with playing a Korg synth that belonged to Kraftwerk during the 1980s. Föllakzoid can’t let go of their roots entirely—at best
column5: they’re channeling the LSD-laced guitar patterns of Loop and Spacemen 3; at worst
column6: vocalist Juan Pablo Rodrigues leans too hard on foggy vocal effects that recall Brooklyn psych also-rans (and labelmates) Psychic Ills. They’re most effective when working somewhere between their rock instincts and Schmidt’s concise approach. Opener ""Electric"" recalls a more-guitar heavy version of LCD Soundsystem’s ""Get Innocuous!""
column7: where a patient build combines with a subtle layering of elements to deliver the album’s most transcendent moment.

column1: Föllakzoid barely shift course over the 45-minute III. The riff that dominates the closing ""Feuerzeug"" is only a breath away from the one that towers over ""Electric"". ""Piure"" is the best example of that here
column2: mixing up backward-masked electronics
column3: menacing ambient noise
column4: and a guitar churn that sounds like it was played by Can’s Michael Karoli. In general
column5: the album treats its journey as circular
column6: a path of tiny incremental steps that eventually leads us back to where we began.

column1: In 2014 Föllakzoid played a set at Primavera Sound
column2: leaving behind this video memento to mark the occasion. The beginning is marked by the reading of a poem by the Chilean writer Vicente Huidobro
column3: which is heavy on birthing and religious imagery
column4: where each line is so dense in implication it’s easy to just disappear into it for a while. It’s a handy comparison for the type of feeling Föllakzoid try to convey in their music
column5: where their vaguely epic songs—only one track here
column6: the nine-minute “Feuerzeug”
column7: is less than 10 minutes in length—gain an allure by gradually stacking up moments of powerful suggestion. It doesn’t always reach the level of spiritual purity it could
column8: but there’s a touch of steel and a sense of pacing that was missing from Föllakzoid’s prior work
column9:
positioning III as a gateway for a much a deeper dive into altered states.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21645/homepage_large.72829234.jpg|Adventure|32823.0|Madeon|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2015-03-30 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:01.583533|"

Though French producer Madeon has been known in electronic circles for years—he’s been active under the moniker since 2010 and has appeared at Coachella and Ultra—it became increasingly clear last year that the 20-year-old (!) Hugo Pierre Leclercq had bigger conquests in mind. The instrumental ""Imperium""
column2: the first released song from his new Adventure
column3: was first featured on the soundtrack of the globally massive soccer video game ""FIFA 15"". This is a distinction that often breaks big artists to a world audience
column4: and Madeon’s mixture of colorful
column5: sample-heavy EDM and its attending uplifting lilt made for the perfect feel-good vibe directly before the complexity of the new ""FIFA"" made you want to hurl your controller through your brother’s flat screen.

column1: With Adventure
column2: Madeon’s debut LP
column3: the producer presents a strikingly versatile collection. In a landscape filled with hot-on-paper-but-kinda-""eh"" collaborations between big name vocalists and hip producers
column4: Madeon deploys his guests (Passion Pit
column5: R&B singer Kyan
column6: Bastille frontman Dan Smith) with a stirring effectiveness. Album highlight ""Pay No Mind"" weaponizes Passion Pit's bright synth-pop for a stadium anthem
column7: and the warmth of ""La Lune"" recalls a more laidback version of Bastille’s catchy hit ""Pompeii"". On tracks like ""OK""—which features a Charli XCX sample culled from a scrapped collaboration—and ""Pixel Empire""
column8: Madeon pays homage to 8-bit video game soundtracks
column9: reminiscent of Rustie’s Essential Mix and the incomparable (yes
column10: incomparable) ""Donkey Kong Country"" soundtrack all at once. While Adventure carries all the hallmarks of your usual skyscraping EDM release—stomping breakdowns
column11: soaring choruses
column12: maximalism-for-the-sake-of-it—it also straddles a fine balance between being a pop record and being a dance record.

column1: Though not everything is as huge as its banner singles
column2: more inward-looking tracks like the closer ""Home"" are arguably as successful. ""Home"" perhaps best exemplifies Madeon’s range
column3: given that it’s one of the only songs on the album that features Leclercq’s vocals. Over a track that moves from delicate and glimmering to sweeping
column4: Leclercq sings delicately before jumping into the thundering chorus. It’s a sweet note to end on
column5: and marks a signpost for the young producer to follow
column6: if he chooses that direction. The good thing about Adventure is that there are many markers like this; on the path to what feels like something huge
column7:
Madeon’s journey is just beginning.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21692/homepage_large.b2597073.jpg|56 Nights|30068.0|Future|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Free Bandz']|2015-03-27 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:02.326739|"

Future has been on an underrated tear since last October
column2: when his rage-fueled Monster mixtape was dramatically overshadowed by an ill-advised guest appearance on Mike WiLL Made It’s ""Pussy Overrated"" with Wiz Khalifa
column3: which
column4: in the context of his failed romance with R&B singer Ciara
column5: seemed even more crass than it was foolish. The tape itself was vintage Future but also magnificently petty
column6: and it went mostly underappreciated as a result. He continued his strong run with the Zaytoven-produced Beast Mode
column7: which was an equally snappy but less petulant response to his emotional turmoil. After announcing plans earlier this month to keep the ball rolling with a sequel to 2011’s Dirty Sprite on Twitter
column8: Future unexpectedly dropped <i>56 Nights
column9: the latest in what feels like a sustained campaign.

column1: The mixtape's title refers to the amount of time Future’s DJ
column2: Esco
column3: spent in a Dubai jail on a trip to the 2014 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix. It’s officially billed as a DJ Esco tape hosted by Future
column4: the first since 2013’s No Sleep
column5: but unlike that 23-track offering
column6: featuring contributions from Shy Glizzy
column7: Young Scooter and PeeWee Longway
column8: 56 Nights is Future standing alone with no guests. When he raps ""None of this money that matter; all of my niggas
column9: they matter"" on ""Diamonds From Africa""
column10: it feels like an acknowledgement of his DJ’s ordeal.

column1: Future still has other problems
column2: too
column3: and like Beast Mode and Monster before it
column4: 56 Nights hints at the lingering effects from his soured relationship. Where many songs on Beast Mode found Future trying to sort out the pain of estrangement in the embrace of other women
column5: 56 Nights drowns in a potent drug concoction that influences both its sound and his addled
column6: prattling lyrics
column7: which often give way to profound moments of clarity. Casual sex is often written off as tedious
column8: only spurred on by copious drug use (""I didn’t wanna fuck the bitch/ This molly made me fuck her even though she average
column9: on ""March Madness""; ""I pour up again and again/ I said I wasn’t gonna fuck with that bitch then I fucked her again
column10: on ""Never Gon Lose""). The overarching theme is reliance on drugs over women
column11: a preference he spells out on ""Purple Comin In"": ""Fuck a bitch on that shit
column12: I don’t need her"" versus ""Fell in love with that drank and I need it."" Future seems to have developed a codependency on pharmaceuticals
column13: one that fills a void and levels his unease—on ""Trap Niggas"" he raps
column14: ""I’m drinking Activis
column15: the only thing that relax me""—and this continuous state of inebriation allows Future to be remarkably open.

column1: The bulk of the production on 56 Nights is handled by Southside with one song produced by Tarentino. Both are members of 808 Mafia
column2: the in-house production team of Waka Flocka Flame’s Brick Squad Monopoly
column3: and Future follows their unhinged
column4: woozy lead
column5: lining knocking 808s with frenetic flows that fumble into mumbling like on ""No Compadre"".  He occasionally offers brief bits of social commentary and self-reflection: On ""March Madness"" he sings ""All these cops shooting niggas
column6: tragic"" and on ""Trap Niggas""
column7: ""I got a lower case T across my chest/ Your crack house doing numbers then you blessed/ You move your mama to a crib from the 'jects."" The ideas arrive as garbled fragments that
column8: when pieced together
column9: tell his story
column10:
and 56 Nights is an unfiltered look at life through the eyes of a wasted Future.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21643/homepage_large.7af7acd9.jpg|Short Movie|9602.0|Laura Marling|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ribbon Music'
column2:
'Virgin EMI']|2015-03-27 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:02.995355|"

Laura Marling is a particularly standoffish singer/songwriter
column3: reserved in interviews and tauntingly prickly in song; a typical line
column4: from A Creature I Don’t Know standout ""Sophia""
column5: is ""I never did say whatever it was you did that day."" As she’s grown
column6: she’s moved farther in this direction
column7: away from the plain-spoken vulnerability of Alas
column8: I Cannot Swim into vocals that curl words into secretive murmurs
column9: and lyrics that tiptoe up to confessions then stop just short. Mythology and formal allusions swirl around even her candid moments
column10: assuring that any autobiography is lost in the fog.

column1: So it’s a mild shock to hear Marling sing ""We shared an apartment on the Upper West Side"" toward the beginning of her fifth record Short Movie. The lyric is rooted to a specific place
column2: a specific happening in her life. It’s even a precise moment—2012’s post-Hurricane Sandy blackout
column3: which left most of lower Manhattan without power and ""dark
column4: as if no one lives there
column5: as she says on ""False Hope"". In interviews
column6: Marling acknowledges Short Movie is more unguarded
column7: though characteristically only to a point: ""The arm’s distance was getting closer with this record for sure
column8: but then I stopped
column9: she told The Guardian
column10: declining to elaborate.

column1: In part
column2: the new sense of openness comes from the sound. Short Movie is her first album written on electric guitar—specifically
column3: her father’s old Gibson 335. It’s not a drastic change
column4: as Marling’s uptempo tracks have always had muscle
column5: but it’s palpable nevertheless. Marling toured Once I Was an Eagle with longtime cellist Ruth de Turberville (who contributes lovely arrangements on Short Movie) but little else in the way of a band or instrumentation
column6: and on Short Movie
column7: she clutches every guitar fill like it’s a long-lost piece of her identity
column8: luxuriating in space and writing bigger and hazier songs to match.

column1: The arrangement on ""Warrior""
column2: for instance
column3: is stranded atop a canyon of echo and given an arrangement so vast and dusty that Marling almost gets away with the America rip (<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zSAJ0l4OBHM"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">yes
column4: that one). ""Warrior"" is hauntingly serious
column5: but elsewhere you can hear here loosening up: ""Strange
column6: a near-spoken disembowelment of a hapless cheating man
column7: wouldn’t work without the cruelest hitch of a laugh in Marling’s voice as she informs him
column8: ""I don’t love you… I’m pretty sure that you know."" It’s easily the standout: every syllable delivered like acid
column9: and lyrics that continually walk up to the line and cross it—right up to ""No
column10: I do not believe we were born equally.""

column1: Short Movie has been called Marling’s ""quarterlife crisis"" album
column2: but the crises she's grappling here are the same ones she's confronted her entire career: love as a threat to autonomy
column3: suitors as perpetual disappointments
column4: wariness of intimacy but also of the alternatives. Album opener ""Warrior"" is a mythological conceit typical of Marling—men as warriors
column5: women as the steeds they misuse. Marling is the sort of artist to deliver ""I feel your love"" like it’s synonymous with fear
column6: or choking gas; ""Walk Alone"" is the sound of a woman who’s sat with herself long enough to realize
column7: horrified
column8: that what she hears inside is a lonely-morning dirge.

column1: This turns out to be Short Movie’s main
column2: minor downfall: Most of these themes were explored
column3: in more eviscerating detail
column4: in Once I Was an Eagle
column5: and the album meanders in the second half. Without an overarching conceit like <i>Once I Was an Eagle
column6: Short Movie comes off sounding like a transition record
column7: a short movie in the sense that it’s a prelude to something bigger. But Marling’s career is remarkable in part because album after album she not only delivers on those bigger things
column8: but delivers them in her idiosyncratic voice. S<span>he’s spent her entire career dodging comparisons
column9:
but by now she has earned the right to be compared only to herself.
