Ratking’s debut album So It Goes was a Delorean trip through seemingly incongruous corners of New York rap music. Touching on insular Def Jux pessimism and outsized Dipset flair and coated by a shroud of bristly noise
column2: So It Goes seemed to search for an old city
column3: one in danger of being thrust into into the East River by an influx of doe-eyed
column4: affluent young professionals. ""Welcome to New York"" this was not. Their music can feel like a trek through a forbidding city winter
column5: so it’s fitting that the group holed up in December to craft the quick-hit follow up EP 700 Fill. Though it arrives at the tail end of an uncommonly brutal cold season and literally namechecks North Face jacket models and the grade of their goose-down filling on a song (""Steep Tech"")
column6: 700 Fill is a lighter
column7: breezier listen than its predecessor
column8: thanks to the group’s eagerness to toy with its sound and writing process.

column1: Much of 700 Fill was written in just a week by rappers Wiki and Hak over beats that producer Sporting Life pieced together ahead of recording. The lack of an overarching concept gives the new material a freer feel
column2: as Wiki trades grizzled storytelling for battle raps and rhyme acrobatics. Still
column3: there are gems here: ""Arnold Palmer"" kicks a metaphor comparing the titular ice tea and lemonade hybrid to Wiki’s own biracial heritage while pining for a cold Brisk and a fat J on a rooftop in summer
column4: while ""Bethel"" triumphantly renounces So It Goes’ high school graduate career anxiety after a year of good press and extensive touring. 700 Fill cycles between fleshed out cuts and looser lyrical workouts like ""Lenape Lane"" and ""Sticky Trap"" but even the most perfunctory of these exercises are intriguing.

column1: Wiki’s internal rhyme-heavy raps and Hak’s airy hooks were occasionally too divergent to gel on So It Goes
column2: but with 700 Fill
column3: Ratking seems to be figuring out what to do with Hak. The EP confidently cuts him loose on intros
column4: bridges and outros as a confectionary dusting to Wiki’s gruff veneer
column5: although he’s still working out what to do when he’s tossed an entire verse on ""Lenape Lane"" and ""Bethel"". 700 Fill’s not afraid to throw the Wiki-Hak balancing act out the window
column6: though: The two best cuts here are ""Eternal Reveal""
column7: a gossamer Hak reverie with a short Wiki verse stuck in the middle
column8: and ""Flurry""
column9: a spitfire Wiki solo cut. Sporting Life’s taking verses too
column10: and the brusque
column11: unpolished humor of his voice is a reminder that home base for the group is Harlem.

column1: With Ratking’s rapping axis exploring new forms of expression
column2: 700 Fill is really a showcase for Sporting Life. He’s eased off the needling skronk of So It Goes and the group’s debut EP Wiki93 in favor of spacier
column3: more melodic textures. ""American Gods"" and ""Eternal Reveal"" both revisit Sport’s knack for flaying a sample beyond recognition but drop his trademark willful dissonance
column4: the former in service of a soulful sendup of New York’s Just Blaze era and the latter
column5: an idyllic waltz. Otherwise
column6: Sport prefers affixing trap drums to winding
column7: ghostly synth lines to dizzying effect. Imagine Dan the Automator popping in the Mike WiLL era.

column1: 700 Fill is the sound of Ratking pulling its sound apart between albums to feel around for what works and doesn’t. Its off-the-cuff sound and free Bittorrent release strategy suggest a group attempting to sidestep the press and PR machine to sneak around and find itself. ""We’re talking about practice
column2: Wiki sneers in ""Bethel""
column3: quoting a classic press conference from NBA superstar Allen Iverson. ""Not the game!"" If Wiki
column4: Hak and Sport are just in warm-ups here
column5:
the form is still on point.

"|20355.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20355-700-fill-ep/|7.2|Craig Jenkins

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21666/homepage_large.364e9cdf.jpg|Flame Rave EP|4987.0|Clark|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2015-03-27 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:04.800324|"

There’s something a little old fashioned about the music English producer Chris Clark makes
column2: both in its components and in the underlying themes. The fact that he’s now a Warp mainstay is fitting—much of the music on Flame Rave
column3: a four-track EP that follows his excellent Clark LP from last year
column4: mirrors the future vision mapped out in the label’s earliest releases. It doesn’t imagine a world much beyond the first Artificial Intelligence compilation or Polygon Window’s Surfing on Sine Waves
column5: where the future remains all burning chrome and collapsing new buildings. It’s to his credit that Clark can survey such a thoroughly excavated space and scrape out something worthwhile from it
column6: and Flame Rave pushes on the Clark thread of big-theme dystopia until it begins to resemble something like a great dynastic collapse.

column1: Several worlds converge here
column2: merged by Clark's skill and experience. There’s something of the Haxan Cloak’s deliberate hugeness
column3: as well as the sense of techno shifting from a harbinger to a retro-future marker. On ""Silver Sun""
column4: the EP’s lead track but also its weakest
column5: Clark knots up a jungle breakbeat with slow-moving loops
column6: drawing out a subtle sense of conflict that ties into his fascination with technology that throws up error messages everywhere. He never drives his music to the point of total malfunction
column7: instead positioning himself in the gulf between a great night out and a bad one. ""Silver Sun"" even ends with some rave-y whoops and cheers
column8: but it’s thoroughly backgrounded and filtered through heavy distortion
column9: making it feel like a vicarious thrill at best.

column1: The idea of Clark on the outside of club culture looking in is something he’s touched on in interviews. He has the air of an observer at times
column2: while at others he’s deeply engaged
column3: and it’s when he entwines both modes that his music becomes engrossing. ""To Live and Die in Grantham""
column4: its title perhaps a nod to former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher
column5: builds around trance techno patterns that recall the ""pure trance"" version of the KLF’s ""What Time Is Love""
column6: which surely comes from a lifetime of studying the form. But it’s all wrapped up in rushes of warm
column7: emotive electronics
column8: suggesting someone keen to move his audience in both brain and body.

column1: The cover of Flame Rave shows a face split into light and dark. It mirrors the scaly black-and-white picture from the sleeve of Clark
column2: but the juxtaposition of color neatly reflects the progression he’s made from one of his most acclaimed albums to date. Flame Rave finds a little more joy
column3: a little more to celebrate
column4: among the retro-terror his music often evokes. If Clark was the sound of someone scaling an awesome peak
column5: this is the point where he settles in
column6: throws a big party
column7:
and gets caught up in pure emotion.

"|20399.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20399-flame-rave-ep/|6.9|Nick Neyland

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21641/homepage_large.da464808.jpg|Waiting|4234.0|Thursday|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Eyeball'
column2: 'Collect']|2015-03-27 00:00:00|1999|2016-06-11 16:13:05.594623|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".tgrsqtdhq8.1.6:0.1.0.$20375/=1$20375.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div><span style=""font-family: Georgia
column3: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">There will always be a segment of a popular punk band’s fanbase maintaining their debut will never be topped
column4: based on its ""rawness"" and ""honesty."" For Thursday
column5: this cohort<span style=""font-family: Georgia
column6: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> appears to be smaller than most. In fact
column7: the overwhelming consensus is that Waiting is their least potent work
column8: an opinion that’s less uncomfortable to hold knowing that it is also Geoff Rickly’s. But that’s more a reflection on the overall strength of their catalog and how every Thursday record managed to be superlative in its own way: Full Collapse is the most influential; War All the Time the heaviest; A City by the Light Divided remains their most melodic
column9: A Common Existence their most brutal; and No Devolución their most comprehensive. Waiting simply stands as Thursday’s most promising and earnest album.

column1: These are qualities that are granted retroactively
column2: and the slick packaging of this reissue (including their now-iconic dove logo
column3: which didn't actually appear until War All the Time) realigns Waiting as part of Thursday’s arc rather than an outlier. While it’s easy to appreciate because of what it led to
column4: Waiting managed to stand out at the time because of Rickly’s passionate
column5: verbose lyrics and near-frightening intensity. This was by far the most developed aspect of Thursday’s sound in 2000 and would continue to set them apart even as a still-healthy record industry figured out what the hell to do with them.

column1: At the time of Waiting
column2: Thursday didn’t quite know where they stood either. The music itself is agitated
column3: propulsive. ""Porcelain"" was inspired by the suicide of a friend and begins the record expounding on the heartbreaking fragility of life itself
column4: contrasted with Rickly’s anger and resentment towards a society unwilling to take the smallest steps to protect those who might not be able to help themselves. Rickly also advocated for ramped-up suicide prevention measures and tighter background checks for gun buyers in the lyrics sheet.

column1: The same overwhelming frustration courses through ""Dying in New Brunswick""
column2: perhaps the most tortured track Rickly would ever write. As with most of Waiting
column3: it’s drawn from his own experience—his girlfriend at the time moved to the titular city and was raped within a week. Rickly tries to understand her trauma (""In these city streets I hide my face/ I turn away when you look at me/ And every night when I try to sleep/ I can feel your hands all over my body"") as well as cultural mores and legal hurdles that causes the victim to blame themselves (""They say it doesn’t happen that often/ But it’s happening right now""). The only thing the two songs share is a longing for escape
column4: from the city
column5: from everything—death is preferable to the liminal state of dying.

column1: It’s extremely bleak stuff
column2: to the point where a song called ""Ian Curtis"" is one of the least harrowing. Like many
column3: I arrived at Waiting only after discovering Full Collapse
column4: and I heard the chorus of ""Ian Curtis"" as a prescient barb at the Joy Division worshippers that would overrun neighboring New York City years later: ""I heard Ian Curtis hang himself again in your band.""
column5: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">As it turns out
column6: it’s ""in your bed""
column7: and the scene is actually of Rickly and an ex listening to Joy Division in bed together.
column8: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> Given this rueful context
column9: as well as that of ""Porcelain""
column10: the image reflects on the absurdity of romanticizing suicide. ""Ian Curtis"" is followed by an instrumental called ""Introduction""; who wouldn’t want a breather and restart after all of this?

column1: Such is the urgency of Waiting
column2: with Rickly so inspired to just get this weight off him that the band didn’t have time to really figure out what to do besides push. Occasionally
column3: you can hear the sheared
column4: trebly guitars of Texas Is the Reason (whose Norm Brannon heads up Collect Records with Rickly)
column5: Fugazi’s more ruminative moments
column6: or Sunny Day Real Estate’s yearning
column7: exploratory passages. Thursday had too much of a melodic underpinning for ""screamo"" or even ""post-hardcore"" to really stick
column8: but they had yet to figure out how much to commit to pop. On ""Porcelain""
column9: Rickly can barely catch his breath chasing its cyclical melody
column10: unable to fully give the chorus the boost it needs; by Full Collapse
column11: they’d learn to explode on ""Understanding in a Car Crash"" and ""Standing on the Edge of Summer"". At times
column12: it’s the sound of a band throwing songs together rather than crafting them: On ""In Transmission"" the dissonance between Rickly’s melodies and the lead guitar unintentionally serve its central metaphor of communication breakdowns. There are strong moments
column13: but everything that Waiting did well
column14: Full Collapse did better.

column1: But the same could be said of Full Collapse in relation to Thursday’s future works. In fact
column2: Waiting gives hints of how they’d progress even beyond their commercial breakthrough. The violins are a nice touch on ""This Side of Brightness""
column3: but they’re just a touch; on No Devolución’s ""Magnets Caught in a Metal Heart""
column4: Thursday knew how to be orchestral. The social conscience that started to emerge on ""The Circle Ends"" would be fully explored on War All the Time and A Common Existence. And then there’s the last song they ever recorded
column5: ""Stay True""—Rickly’s addressing an up-and-coming punk rock band and giving advice on what it’s like to be young
column6: ambitious
column7: idealistic
column8:
thin-skinned and prone to relying on outside validation. It never sounded patronizing or condescending; anyone who’s heard Waiting knows that Rickly and Thursday have been in that same position.

"|20375.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20375-waiting/|6.5|Ian Cohen

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21580/homepage_large.1c2bb3eb.jpg|The Ark Work|27940.0|Liturgy|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2015-03-26 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:07.440290|"

The first way to experience Liturgy’s The Ark Work is as a confounding mass of sound. The band seems to have designed it that way: Along with the guitars and percussion
column2: there are horns
column3: strings
column4: constantly hammering glockenspiel
column5: even bagpipes
column6: all blaring at once
column7: like 11 open browser tabs autoplaying or a block of car alarms set off by a passing motorcycle. Hunter Hunt-Hendrix
column8: the band’s leading force and The Ark Work’s primary arranger
column9: has talked in interviews about realizing the sound in his head; The Ark Work
column10: he claims
column11: is the closest he’s come to sharing it with us. The sound he's designed here feels purposefully too large
column12: a pressurized force exploding out of confinement. Hearing it feels like watching someone's head split open
column13: which might be an appropriate image for a band so concerned with themes of annihilation and rebirth.

column1: The second way to experience The Ark Work is as a kind of aesthetic gauntlet
column2: hurled with an audible clunk. Liturgy’s previous albums
column3: 2009’s Renihilation and 2011’s Aesthethica
column4: cast Hunt-Hendrix’s imposing ideas—which he has tried to clarify
column5: perhaps comically
column6: in a pair of perfectly inscrutable diagrams included with The Ark Work’s packaging—in songlike forms. The Ark Work is closer
column7: in its 57-minute expanse and grandeur
column8: to a symphony—something long and Germanic
column9: maybe by Bruckner. Long sections of it hang stubbornly in place
column10: pitched between bedlam and boredom
column11: before surging over another exhilarating crag in the music’s development.

column1: Recurring themes pop up
column2: like alpine flowers dotting a mountainside. ""Follow""
column3: the album’s first full track
column4: begins with a chiming contrapuntal figure in the glockenspiels
column5: led by pedal tones in the bass line. It has a fragile
column6: otherworldly quality
column7: which the band snuffs out briskly when it plunges in moments later. The theme resurfaces a few tracks later
column8: on ""Follow II""
column9: played by an organ
column10: on ""Haelegen""
column11: and then again on ""Total War"". Each time
column12: it feels like a welcome space for contemplation amidst the chaos.

column1: These moments provide navigable markers on what can frankly be an imposing
column2: even dismaying listen. The Ark Work is harmonically rich
column3: but very slow; to say that it moves is to point out that glass is technically a liquid. The most awe-inspiring payoffs occur after agonizing liftoff: On ""Follow II""
column4: strings and horns lifts the music up
column5: like pigeons on strings tied to a Mahlerian orchestra. The mass seems to hang an inch or two above ground
column6: groaning and threatening to split open
column7: before the seams burst and Hunt-Hendrix’s little voice spills out.

column1: This sense of watching an impossible bulk lift skyward is the most thrilling sensation The Ark Work provides
column2: and it happens two or three times across the album. In these moments
column3: Hunt-Hendrix’s thrashing ambitions feel justified
column4: and they position Liturgy not as descendants of black metal but of Swans

column16: terror

column1: But Rose made Claustrophobia in a year that

column6: the album is roughly split between techno

column1: Rose certainly hasn't turned his back on dancers; ""Television""
column2: ""PCP""
column3: and ""Black on Black"" are among the heaviest tracks in his catalog. So is the brilliant ""Why You Feel So Low""

column2: rich
column3: enveloping

column5: wind chimes
column6: rubbed wineglass rims
column7: half-heard voices

""All I Think About Is Death"" pairs those tricks with a woman's mournful singing to create an entrancing update of trip-hop. ""Needle Phobia"" starts out as a dead ringer for the drone that opens Aphex Twin's Selected Ambient Works Volume II before morphing into a shuddering tribute to the sound of Autechre's Amber LP. And then there's ""Family Entertainment""—just two-and-a-half minutes of wailing babies and hospital acoustics that swell into a disconcerting fluttering in the ears. As it dissolves into a spray of static
column9: it has the ring of hard-won epiphany.

column5: a roll of the drums
column6: and then
column7: just where you'd expect pyrotechnics
column8: inky silence. And it happens again on ""Black on Black""
column9: the kind of sooty
column10: industrial-tinged banger that Scuba can seemingly turn out in his sleep. It's a clever trick: instead of beating audiences over the head

column1: Scuba's album titles have always tended to read pretty literally: Triangulation suggested his path through dance music's crowded waters
column2: tacking and jibing between techno and dubstep; Personality reflected the swagger of a newfound confidence. But Claustrophobia doesn't seem quite so straightforward. Far from sounding backed into a corner

column4:
Rose seems right at home.

column1: There is nothing new in Malin’s depiction of New York

Chilly Gonzales is one of those musicians you know for his sheer tenacity rather than any breakthrough moment; he's perfected the art of sticking around. His discography is overshadowed by the names he has worked with—Jamie Lidell
column2: Daft Punk
column3: and many musicians from Canada's indie and electro circles
column4: such as Peaches and Feist (he was a key contributor to the Grammy-nominated The Reminder). It's more likely that you own several albums with his name in the credits than one with his name on the cover.

column1: It doesn't help that he's changed his name and style several times. Gonzales' influences encompass classical
column2: jazz
column3: rap
column4: chill-out music and easy-listening pop
column5: and he continually reshuffles them to emphasize one strand or another. Before the '90s were out
column6: he quit the Warner Bros.-signed Canadian alt-rock band Son

column1: In chamber music
column2: he found something like a solid niche. Gonzales' neo-Romantic mode has been his most productive in recent years
column3: with the second of two Solo Piano albums being longlisted for the Polaris Prize. He returns to it on Chambers

column2: ECM or New Amsterdam. Victoire
column3: Nico Muhly
column4: Valgeir Sigurðsson or yMusic
column5: for instance
column6: all sound downright recondite next to Gonzales. He is more interested in where the form has been
column7: and
column8: as he tells us in liner notes and a Vice op-ed
column9: in making us hear it as Schubert was heard in his day—as pop. With Impressionist and minimalist diversions
column10: he plies an extroverted row that ends in the Romantic era
column11: untroubled by dissonance
column12: alternate tonality or complex time. It's as if Schoenberg
column13: Stravinsky and Varèse never happened.

column1: Gonzales has a soft
column2: precise touch on the piano
column3: tastefully decorating nimble progressions with expressive spills through nearby scales. As an admittedly novice string arranger
column4: he favors ranks of staccato pulses and gently fencing legato lines
column5: splicing them effectively on ""Advantage Points"". On ""Prelude to a Feud""
column6: cascading piano arpeggios inspired by Bach and electronic dance music break out into a Tchaikovsky-like courtly dance. ""Cello Gonzales"" fashions the instrument of the title
column7: with its plaintive vocal quality
column8: into a Mendelssohn tribute. ""Sweet Burden"" channels dreamy
column9: pensive French Impressionists; the lush
column10: broad eddies of ""Green Leaves"" summon Vivaldi; ""Solitaire"" and others pine for Schubert.

column2: while ""Switchcraft"" is modeled on Juicy J's asymmetrical flow. You can hear it if you try
column3: but it's unlikely that a casual listener will perceive these as bangers. Gonzales' limited interest in forms and textures beyond pristine
column4: overt beauty level the record out toward soundtrack music
column5: consistent with crowd-pleasers such as Peter Broderick
column6: without many layers to peel back over time. Though enjoyable
column7: it may land in a limbo
column8: too simplistic for fans of great chamber music or its challenging modern variants; too classical—lacking bells
column9: whistles
column10:
samples and beats—to make it more than pleasant dinner party music for people coming from the indie side.

In rap music
column2: the album has become a hurdle. You can count on one hand the rappers who can accomplish the following two feats: getting a label to release an album
column3: and having that album be good enough that fans aren’t imagining the ways in which it could have been more like the artist’s previous—usually more unfettered and pure—work. In the increasingly fraught journey from underground to mainstream
column4: no time is more uncertain than when mixtapes and EPs must finally become an album. You get one or maybe two shots to prove your staying—and earning—power before your resources get shifted to the next dude with a few radio hits or a small but growing fanbase. It is a grim and unfair reality
column5: and on his major label debut album Mr. Wonderful
column6: Queens jester Action Bronson more or less flips his middle finger at it—an admirable response
column7: though ultimately unsuccessful.

column1: Consider that the first time we hear Bronson’s voice
column2: he is singing in an exaggerated off-key warble. The song falls apart twice
column3: with Bronson cursing that he can't get his vocals right. The moment feels like a rejection of the idea that a major-label debut needs to be a no-nonsense statement to be remembered for decades. In theory
column4: this approach would be refreshing
column5: and if any rapper could let the attendant album pressure roll right off his back
column6: it’s Bronson
column7: who inhabits a character whose reality bares little resemblance to his—or our—own. Yet those atonal vocals end up feeling like a warning sign that Bronson is not going to upend the way rappers make their debut albums. Instead
column8: it turns out
column9: he’s just going to derail his own.

column1: Those nagging vocals—the kind of singing you do to momentarily piss off your significant other—not only embody the spirit of the album
column2: but they conveniently highlight exactly when and where Mr. Wonderful falls apart. After an opening handful of tracks that sound reliably like Action Bronson songs—with a few noticeably ritzy
column3: retro-soul productions—the album shifts into a suite introduced by ""THUG LOVE STORY 2017 THE MUSICAL (Interlude)""
column4: a sketch in which an older man sings to Bronson about a lost love who disappeared from the streets.

column1: What follows is a musical of sorts wedged into the gut of the album
column2: with Bronson continuing the story of a runaway girl who has left the protagonist brokenhearted. On ""City Boy Blues""
column3: Bronson fashions himself as a bluesman
column4: singing and mumbling over a jazz-bar instrumental. Next is ""A Light in the Addict""
column5: a maudlin and forgettable song made with longtime collaborator Party Supplies that features an unnecessary multiple-minute piano outro. It’s all wrapped up by ""Baby Blue""
column6: in which Bronson kisses the woman off with those same whining vocals
column7: over a Mark Ronson production that could have fit on an Amy Winehouse album.

column1: This digression is conceptually ambitious
column2: but the execution seems to purposefully undercut the exercise
column3: as if the suite was the result of an argument between a devil on one shoulder and an angel on the other about what the album should accomplish that was won by neither. When Chance the Rapper shows up at the end of ""Baby Blue"" with a verse of playfully inconsequential insults—""I hope every soda you drink already shaken up
column4: ""I hope the zipper on your jacket get stuck""—before admitting he hopes his heartbreaker is still happy
column5: he pulls off in half a minute what Bronson couldn’t in fifteen: using an imagined story to reveal humanity through humor.

column1: Bronson
column2: it should be noted
column3: has hit that note before. ""THUG LOVE STORY 2017 THE MUSICAL (Interlude)"" is a callback to ""Thug Love Story 2012""
column4: a standout from his still-excellent mixtape Blue Chips. That song was connected to the multi-character track ""Hookers at the Point""
column5: inspired by the HBO documentary of the same name
column6: in which Bronson rapped in different voices from the points of view of a pimp
column7: prostitute and john
column8: in the process showing that he could consider and illuminate the world outside of his own head. Those two songs felt almost effortless in their construction
column9: while the suite inside Mr. Wonderful feels at once belabored and half-assed.

column1: From there
column2: the album closes with a whimper. Party Supplies
column3: Bronson’s most reliable partner
column4: is brought back again on ""Only in America""
column5: a track with a classic-rock guitar riff that feels like an inadequate sequel to the duo’s fantastic jukebox rap trifle ""Contemporary Man"". A few tracks later
column6: there is a live recording of a meandering new song called ""The Passage""—if you can figure out the purpose of its inclusion you will have gotten further than me.

column1: Amidst all this are a few tracks—""Terry""
column2: ""Actin Crazy""
column3: ""Galactic Love""—featuring Bronson spitting fantastical bullshit over laidback beats. This is where he is at his most natural
column4: approachable
column5: and likeable
column6: dotting his world-traveling fantasies with the names of gourmet foods. Instead of slicing at convention
column7: Bronson accepts it—bringing himself back to square one
column8: which Mr. Wonderful argues
column9: was a pretty fine place after all.

When Jam City's Jack Latham debuted his Dream a Garden material at Krakow's Unsound festival last fall
column2: he scattered an armload of roses across the stage before strapping on a guitar and stepping behind a laptop and microphone. It was a dramatic way of wiping the slate clean

column6: high-pitched vocals. The album swims in reverb

column1: Ultimately

""New Atlanta

column10: Metro Boomin
column11: the 808 Mafia crew; get a hit on the strip club circuit and local airwaves; collaborate extensively and pump out free projects hosted by the mixtape DJ of favor; maybe sign a 360 deal. The formula works

column13: occasionally cutting-edge rap music.

column1: But it’s not the only way to find success in Atlanta
column2: as Awful Records’ kingpin Father has proved. His effortless-sounding
column3: maddeningly catchy single ""Look at Wrist"" exploded on to the scene last summer
column4: turning dancefloors into cooking dance mosh pits nationwide without so much as a DJ Holiday drop. Along with peers iLoveMakonnen and Key! (conveniently
column5: the single’s two featured artists)
column6: he’s part of the latest iteration of ""New Atlanta
column7: broadly characterized for their DIY ethos and rough-around-the-edges minimalism. And while Makonnen quickly became the scene’s most visible constituent

column11: and a flag planted firmly in the soil of rap’s current epicenter. He reminds us that with good ideas and confidence in your own vision

column1: ""Look at Wrist""
column2: the song that put Awful on the map
column3: came with a hilarious subtext that almost didn’t register because of its hypnotizing repetition. ""Never had to whip a brick
column4: but I get the gist"" felt like meta-commentary on middle American rap fans’ investment in trap lingo with a total remove from the lifestyle. Father wasn’t moralizing—we’re all just trying to have fun here—but this wry
column5: knowing wink consistently informs his work
column6: even in the midst of the turn-up. This is music that’s deceptively simple
column7: that’s deeper than it lets on.

column1: The SoundCloud description of Who’s Gonna Get Fucked First? states its intent plainly: ""32-mins of pure
column2: unfiltered debauchery."" This is party music about girls and drugs and fights
column3: over efficient beats with lots of empty space. The unprintable title might give some initial pause
column4: but it fits. Even more than partying
column5: this is an album about sex—weird
column6: freaky
column7: intoxicated
column8: potentially group sex—but also
column9: consensual
column10: mutually pleasurable
column11: and age-appropriate. Father handles the topic with a maturity and egalitarianism that feels revelatory
column12: resulting in the most sex-positive rap release of the year. On ""Vamp""
column13: in the midst of frothing come-ons
column14: Father reminds his paramour
column15: ""You have a right to all your choices."" ""Morena""
column16: featuring Awful members Stalin Majesty and Abra

column19: hater-baiting flex ""Gurl"".) And on album highlight ""BET Uncut""

column1: Where so much Atlanta rap of the last half decade has been indebted to crunk

column4: finger-snaps
column5: and raucous dance instructionals. The sound requires a rare sort of magnetism

column2: arguably
column3: from this plane of existence) at all: He has always shown a clear debt to Lil B

column11: anime

column15: debauched subtext for adults. It’s the same ethos that turns even the most seemingly straightforward Father tracks slightly askew.

column1: With the exception of the KeithCharles Spacebar contributions
column2: Father handles the production of the album himself. His style is aggressively minimal

column5: casual lyricism is sharp and often loaded with insights

column7: Father sets a hilarious scene with just three simple lines: ""Run up on me
column8: leave you looking like Eddie Winslow/ In that episode when he got his ass beat/ Take my niggas

column10: fights

In Sheila Heti’s 2012 highly autobiographical novel How Should a Person Be?

column2: female fuck-ups in pop culture. The women who get too drunk on the dance floor
column3: who date men who are bad for them
column4: who don’t have their shit together and are unapologetic about it

column1: Chastity Belt haven't traded their raucous party-girl ways for slow-paced sob stories; ""Why Try"" and ""Trapped"" are both shimmy-worthy surf rock jams and ""The Thing"" is a certified head-banger

column4:

column1: While Ocasek’s post-Cars C.V. includes No Doubt

column8: agitated verses leading up to a falsetto whoop in the chorus. Or

It's easy to imagine this sort of thing finding favor with American Anglophiles back when they actually bought CD’s—perhaps an equivalent to a latter-day Supergrass or Ash.

column2: ""Mr. Wrong"") is meant to compensate for  a broken heart. After all

column3: Jimmy Whispers was James Cicero
column4: vocalist and frontman for Chicago-based indie pop ensemble Light Pollution. After that group dissolved some years back
column5: Whispers adopted his childhood nickname—he was a soft-spoken kid—for his solo work. His keyboard demos attracted the attention of fellow lo-fi eccentric Ariel Pink
column6: who invited him to open a few of his shows. Whispers may have appeared as a kindred spirit to Pink
column7: but the Midwestern songwriter approaches his work with far less theatricality and chaos than the volatile L.A. figure. His quick
column8: sweet debut Summer in Pain is pared down to the basics
column9: spelling out heartbreak and frustration with a tried-and-true palette of organs
column10: drum machines
column11: and a world-weary tremble.

column1: While Pink at times seems almost unconscious of the labels people apply to his work
column2: Whispers breaks out the B-word within his album's first 30 seconds. He introduces himself as ""the greatest bedroom popper...in the tri-state area"" before he sings a note. Later in the record
column3: he punctuates songs with interludes in the same register
column4: decrying how he feels like a lost soul in a pre-apocalyptic world. I think he's trying to humanize himself with these gestures

a little insecure.

Those bedroom pop songs about his feelings
column7: though
column8: are worth the corny showmanship that pads them. Like Owen Ashworth of Advance Base (formerly Casiotone for the Painfully Alone)
column9: Whispers can wring heart from a cheap set of keys. The album's middle section shows off his skill at crafting grooves and melodies; ""Heart Don't Know"" strikes a sugar-coated melancholy with its warm chords churning underneath Whispers' ragged voice. On ""Pain in Love""
column10: he laments
column11: ""I wanna change the way I feel tonight/ I wanna love again."" He writes rudimentary lines
column12:
but sometimes the best way to undercut depression and desire is just to spell them out in the plainest terms. Sometimes all you need to feel better is just to ask for it.

""Love is easy when you don't give a shit
column13: Whispers advises on ""Michael
column14: Don't Cry"". ""Life is easy when you want to die."" The only conclusions he manages to reach on Summer in Pain contradict themselves
column15: but they're the best indication of where his head's at. Here's a guy trying to claw his way out of a tangled emotional state by pretending he's surrounded by clean lines. It works when he sticks to the music. The spoken-word framing screams ""look at me
column16: I'm here
column17: I exist""
column18:
when the songs are enough to convince us in the first place.

These are the first words we hear Jon Spencer shout on the new Blues Explosion album and it’s a surprisingly conciliatory statement from a guy who built his reputation on blasphemy. Whether horking up scum-punk phlegm balls like  ""Cunt Tease"" and ""You Look Like a Jew"" with Pussy Galore

column7: provocative

column1: Alas

column7: which sets the thematic tone for a record that essentially functions as the Blues Explosion’s answer to To the 5 Boroughs. Freedom Tower-No Wave Dance Party 2015 is a eulogy for the seedy New York City where Spencer first earned his notoriety—amid the early-'80s triangulation of hardcore

column1: Compared to 2012’s commendable if conventional comeback effort

column4: and destined to usurp the latter as the band’s entrance theme of choice.) And if the No Wave in the album title is a bit of a misnomer—this ode to NYC is more DMC than DNA—they at least get the Dance Partypart right

column10: with heavy

He bemoans the fame of others at one point and decries the luck of other people’s big breaks during another. Never before has Vetiver’s presiding melancholy been so bitter

column7: that nuance is mostly erased

When Christian Holden sang
column2: ""My younger years were something

column4: most listeners had little reason to think that the line was autobiography. By the time Holden arrives to that line on ""Housebroken""
column5: he’s shifted perspectives from a quizzical
column6: concerned narrator to a dog that’s actually a person that’s actually a metaphor for the part of ourselves that legitimizes societal complacency. More importantly

column8: It Never Goes Out

column1: In a literal sense
column2: the Hotelier did not make It Never Goes Out. The Hotel Year did. Moreover
column3: the record was written when the band members were between the age of 16 and 18

column1: Heard again
column2: It Never Goes Out does sound like the product of its environment
column3: and those arriving to this record in 2015 will likely be startled by the youth of its creators—the word ""buttface"" is used in two different songs. Thematically
column4: It Never Goes Out is guided by the most teenaged
column5: punk perspective in existence: rejecting the expectations of middle-class suburbia and realizing the capacity for your own disillusion and disapproval. Holden’s tools are rudimentary here: not just Beatles (""Lonely Hearts Club"") and the Smiths (""Title Track (There is a Light)"") references
column6: but some of the most common ones. Walmart and Hallmark are castigated for co-opting love. Volumes of Nietszche and Thoreau are namechecked. Holden sneers
column7: ""We’re all actors"" and the opener states ""Our Lives Would Make A Sad
column8: Boring Movie"". Earnest
column9: blowtorch-intense convictions like these are something of an occupational hazard for a young punk band

column3: expressive vocals free rein. They have already figured out how group chants and guitar solos can help ""anti-bro"" sentiments play well in a gym

awkward and strident band who labeled their music the work of ""devotional kids"".

The pairing of pop-rock singer-songwriter Andy Kim and Broken Social Scene's Kevin Drew is so obviously peculiar that David Letterman wasted precious intro seconds making an ""Odd Couple"" joke when he presented Kim and Drew's live performance. You can forgive yourself if Kim's name isn't familiar: He was a minor but persistent radio presence during the late '60s and early '70s
column2: and he's most known for co-writing the Archies' novelty hit ""Sugar Sugar"" and for ""Rock Me Gently""
column3: the type of innocuous AM trifles you're most likely in 2015 to hear as comedic relief in a Judd Apatow movie (or in a commercial trading on that same aesthetic). Kim had several lesser
column4: similar hits before going dark for several years
column5: releasing some music as Baron Longfellow
column6: and finally returning under his own name in 2004. (He was coaxed out of retirement by the Barenaked Ladies' Ed Robertson
column7: which suggests that Kim is a much bigger deal in Canada than in the US.)

column1: It's Decided resurrects material from both writers' pasts in addition to new songs
column2: and while the promise of marrying Kim's featherweight pop sensibilities with Drew's glowing orchestration is intriguing
column3: the result mostly scans as ""pleasant rock music"" and nothing more. Kim has a metered
column4: handsome baritone; it's the voice of an old showman
column5: smoothed by singing ""Rock Me Gently"" to moms and grandmoms at innumerable county fairs and casinos. Drew
column6: less excitable here than on BSS records
column7: decorates the tracks with well-pruned horn charts and little keyboard doilies. The whole operation is very mature and artistic—see also Kim's man-in-black routine on the album cover—such that no one could ever confuse Kim with a man who sang some hokey songs many years ago.

column1: Kim and Drew are both artists capable of making you cringe
column2: albeit for wholly different reasons: Kim for his cornball pop instincts and Drew for his bombast. You can hear some of Drew's puerile fascinations in the lyrics to ""Heaven Without a Gun""
column3: just as you can spot Kim's lingering populism in the duo's re-working of ""Shoot 'Em Up Baby""
column4: a doo-wop trifle Kim wrote in 1968. On BSS castoff ""Who Came First""
column5: both Drew and Kim seem less tethered to pop-rock tradition
column6: to more favorable results.  Elsewhere
column7: the results sound something like the National. What it all adds up to is anyone's guess. Is this a reclamation project? No one seems to be suggesting Kim's catalog is buried treasure. For better and for worse
column8:
there is nothing cringe-inducing on It's Decided; the record mostly sounds like I should remember to tip my barista.

but you can’t get into that kind of detail unless you’ve spent enough time staring at someone’s face to recognize tiny changes; they’re the sort of minute physical reactions that happen naturally when you’re tired of trading blows over something that’s ultimately meaningless. Kendrick Lamar’s major-label albums play out like Spike Lee films in miniature. In both artists’ worlds
column4: the stakes are unbearably high

The ""Good and Bad Hair"" musical routine from Lee’s 1988 feature School Daze depicted black women grappling with colorism and exclusionary standards of American beauty. Mookie’s climactic window smash in 1989’s Do the Right Thing plunged its characters into fiery bedlam
column8: quietly prophesying the coming L.A. riots in the process. In these moments

column14: spoken-word style
column15: as if to say
column16: ""This money you crave
column17: it’s blood money."" The album is dotted with surreal grace notes
column18: like a parable: God appears in the guise of a homeless man in ""How Much a Dollar Cost""

column1: The music
column2: meanwhile
column3: follows a long line of genre-busting freakouts (The Roots’ Phrenology
column4: Common’s Electric Circus
column5: Q-Tip’s Kamaal the Abstract
column6: André 3000’s The Love Below) in kicking at the confines of rap music presentation. There’s half a jazz band present at all times; pianist Robert Glasper
column7: producer/sax player Terrace Martin and bass wizard Thundercat give Butterfly a loose
column8: fluid undertow every bit as tempestuous and unpredictable as the army of flows at Kendrick’s disposal. The rapper’s branching out
column9: too
column10: exploding into spastic slam poetry on ""For Free?""
column11: switching from shouty gymnastics to drunken sobs on ""u"" and even effecting the lilt of a caring mother on ""You Ain’t Gotta Lie (Momma Said)"". It turns out Kendrick’s new direction was every direction at once.

column1: Despite all this
column2: he’s still toying with a narrative on the sly: Just beneath the surface lies a messianic yarn about avoiding the wiles of a sultry girl named Lucy who’s secretly a physical manifestation of the devil. Kendrick refuses to dole out blame without accepting any
column3: however
column4: and on the chaotic free jazz excursion ""u"" he turns a mirror on himself
column5: screaming ""Loving you is complicated!"" and suggesting his fame hasn’t helped his loved ones back home. Kendrick’s criticisms
column6: as they did on good kid

column8: self-imposed challenges. As Bilal quips on the chorus to ""Institutionalized"": ""Shit don’t change until you get up and wash your ass
column9: nigga.""

column1: Kendrick’s principle of personal responsibility has treaded dangerously close to respectability politics lately

column3: but To Pimp a Butterfly avoids that trap. (Mostly.) ""Complexion (A Zulu Love)"" is a tender note of appreciation for women of all skin tones with help from North Carolina rapper Rapsody (whose slickly referential guest verse contains a nod to ""Good and Bad Hair""). This is an album about tiny quality of life improvements to be made in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds. It might not be the message we want in a year where systemic police and judicial inequality have cost many the ultimate price
column4: but that doesn’t bankrupt it of value.

for no reason at all.

column5: and the Field—help to frame the record proper. The album's use of short
column6: slack loops echoes Kirby's the Caretaker project: A chorus wobbles on a tilted photograph in ""Feeling the Sun Thru the Earth at Night""
column7: and distant string-like passages crop up in ""Slow Breathing Circuit"" like an amnesiac's memory. Meanwhile
column8: the Field is reflected in the album's liberal use of drum machines
column9: samples and towering
column10: diaphanous chords.

column1: For all of its dreamy moods
column2: Maze of Woods frequently edges toward electronic pop
column3: and is more expansive and dynamic than the debut. ""Escapers""
column4: with a broken beat and dub-echoed voices
column5: wouldn't raise an eyebrow on an Aphex Twin hard-drive purge
column6: the storm clouds of ""Peregrine"" abruptly clear out into a bright Boards of Canada knock
column7: and Orb-like twinkles scatter over big frosty peaks on ""Wolfkids"". Smith's guitar is often recognizable and he provides a variety of delicate effects

column1: The album also makes subtle but widespread use of the kinds of clipped
column2: deformed vocal samples we're used to hearing in electronic music. A length of unintelligible aria twists through ""Springworlds"" like a lost ribbon

so they can be more malleable in pursuing the idea behind a given song.

In ""Avatar""
column2: the twenty-first episode of the third season of ""The X-Files""
column3: actress Janie Woods-Morris portrays a madam named Lorraine Kelleher
column4: who is questioned by Agents Mulder and Scully after the death of one of her prostitutes. (She meets her demise later in the episode.) Within ""The X-Files"" universe
column5: spanning more than two-hundred episodes and nine seasons
column6: Lorraine Kelleher is a minor part
column7: to say the least. But producer Kai Hugo nonetheless chose the name for a track on his second full-length release under the Palmbomen alias. The track
column8: with its canned claps
column9: faux woodblock clops
column10: acid lines and laser pips slowed by cough syrup
column11: is a strange and woozy standout on an odd yet amiable effort.

column1: As Ganz Nackisch
column2: Hugo favored the dusty-stylus distortion and filtered-house thump that was already out of fashion in France in the late '00s. By the time of his 2010 EP Moon Children
column3: he had shifted gears
column4: favoring the slo-mo arpeggios
column5: 2am-hour synth washes and reverbed vocals popularized by the Drive soundtrack. ""Stock""—off his 2013 album Night Flight Europa—embraced the sounds of the continent
column6: from Italo to taser-riddled electro but not much of it stuck. While past productions dabbled in vocals
column7: Palmbomen II does away with them entirely and the album is decidedly more insular and the better for it
column8: sounding like Hugo recorded it all while locked in his bedroom.

column1: If he did so it seems likely he was simultaneously watching every last DVD of ""The X-Files"": Each track on Palmbomen II derives its name from a character on the show
column2: and Hugo's choices
column3: like ""Lorraine Kelleher""
column4: reflect an obsession and peculiarly deep knowledge of every sub-minor and one-off character. There’s no ""Knowle Rohrer"" or ""Marita Covarrubias"" to be found here
column5: much less ""Toothpick Man"" or ""Luis Cardinal""
column6: so even adepts of the show might not glean the connection. Instead
column7: Hugo has a track named for the systems analyst situated near a volcano on Mount Avalon who had a silicone-like tentacle burst through his throat in one early episode (""Peter Tanaka"") as well as a Boards of Canada-esque one-minute interlude named for Mulder’s mother
column8: ""Teena Mulder"".

column1: Taken in one setting
column2: the album could use a bit more movement
column3: BPM-wise
column4: its pacing somewhere between drugged and extremely hungover. ""Gerd Thomas"" feels lethargic
column5: the sluggishness of the 303 and handclaps offset by a sprinkling of marimba. The interlude ""Caitlin Ross"" sounds like it could be from a Ryuichi Sakamoto demo and ""Rebecca Waite"" rides percolating tropical hand drums
column6: distorted thumb piano and a rattle that makes for one of the album’s brighter moments. Tape hiss infuses every number
column7: giving the album a sense of nostalgia
column8: right down to the garbled tape outro of ""Leo Danzinger"". But Hugo seems to be invoking the '90s not as a vague point of reference
column9: but as a very specific point on a timeline. I’d peg it to 1992-1993
column10:
right when Aphex Twin’s own homemade acid compilation Selected Ambient Works 85-92 cuts off and when Chris Carter’s ""The X-Files"" first goes on the air.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21605/homepage_large.eb619f33.jpg|Golem|27851.0|Wand|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['In the Red']|2015-03-19 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:26.557768|"

The heavies of glam and garage rock past loom large over Golem
column2: the second full-length from Los Angeles-based psych-rock quartet Wand. It’s not a nostalgia-driven record
column3: but you can definitely catch a whiff of David Bowie
column4: T. Rex
column5: and eyeliner-era Brian Eno wafting through the band’s heavy riffs and stoned melodies.

column1: However
column2: Wand’s most obvious touchstone is a little more contemporary: Ty Segall. Over the last couple of years
column3: Segall and his close-knit crew—bands like Thee Oh Sees and White Fence— have established a headier and heavier take on dinosaur rock by amping up the tempo and coating familiar-sounding riffs in a layer of lo-fi psychedelic grime. From the double-tracked falsetto vocals to the alien guitar tones
column4: their influence is clear and present on Golem. Wand aren’t sound-alikes
column5: but they also aren’t shy about appropriating moves from the other bands in their scene.

column1: And they’re pretty good at those moves. Evidently there are no hard feelings: Wand has opened for Ty Segall and the band’s singer/guitarist Cory Hanson has also accompanied Segall comrade Mikal Cronin on the road. Wand’s debut album
column2: Ganglion Reef
column3: was released on Segall’s Drag City imprint
column4: GOD? It’s a bit like the Beatles releasing Badfinger on Apple—an act that took heavy inspiration from their more well-known mentor/producers
column5: but also delivered independently memorable material on their own in a similar style.

column1: There are some notable differences
column2: though. Where their peers might ground stoney riffs in personal and real-life inspired subject matter
column3: Wand’s tunes tend to dwell in the wizard candle-lit realms of the fantastic. Some of Hanson’s lyrics (""The forest is soft and the spiders are dead"") sound like they might have first been uttered in the midst of a Dungeons & Dragons campaign. And who knows
column4: maybe they were; the members of Wand have been known to play the game.

column1: Fantastic imagery aside
column2: D&D is not a bad platform for understanding Wand. The game makes use of established ground rules
column3: but the tone and setting can be embellished to suit the tastes and interests of the players. Wand’s foundation lies in the old-school prog/psych sourcebook
column4: but the songs often wander away from the script in a way that is refreshing. Glimpses of pop nostalgia are regularly smeared over with anachronistic synthesizer squiggles or blotted out with heavy rock riffs reminiscent of the Melvins. These are the record's best moments—when a Marc Bolan vocal seamlessly blends into the kind of tape-collage weirdness that might have been at home on a Butthole Surfers LP. Still
column5: listening to Golem—which arrives via Los Angeles garage and weirdo-rock standby In the Red—it’s hard to shake the been-there-done-that feeling. Wand excels at delivering heavy and murky sounds
column6:
but they're a bit late to a conversation that their peers have already dominated.

column1:

Houston’s rap scene—or more specifically
column2: its aesthetic—has been ravaged by outsiders. The biggest appropriators
column3: like Harlem’s A$AP Mob and Miami’s Raider Klan
column4: have repurposed the sounds of DJ Screw and the lingo of UGK into a sort of chopped-and-screwed noir. It’s a haunting take on trill culture that sucks out most of the funk
column5: leaving only distorted vocals and waves of ambience. Houston up-and-comer Maxo Kream is taking heed of the poachers and embracing their renditions of Houston rap and culture. He isn’t interested in reclaiming the city from squatters; in fact
column6: he’s more than willing to play by their rules
column7: and on Maxo 187 he seeks a middle ground between the city’s perception and its reality.

column1: The record is a sinister and visceral portrait of Houston street life that binges heavily on the A$AP brand of trill
column2: even enlisting one of its producers (A$AP P on the Boards). The music is a binary of local Houston and the more panoramic
column3: now global idea of Houston
column4: which spawned the #BEENTRILL movement and the widespread abuse of lean. Kream's sound is far more derivative of the A$AP crew than Z-Ro
column5: but his music is still deeply indebted to Houston gang culture. The music is most menacing when Kream drapes his gangland tales over creeping synth progressions and pulsating bass lines reminiscent of Spaceghostpurrp’s ""Pheel tha Phonk 1990"".

column1: Kream has been completely indoctrinated by gang culture
column2: and on songs like ""Thirteen"" and ""KKK"" his raps are imbued with the rhetoric. At times
column3: it’s borderline propaganda: On ""Paranoia""
column4: which is produced by A$AP P on the Boards
column5: he raps remorselessly about killing civilians and decapitating grandmothers for some sort of greater good (""Fuck your opinion I’m just trying to make a living""). It's chilling
column6: in part because he doesn't even sound like he's trying to convince anyone that what he’s doing is worth it. Maxo 187 doesn’t portray cripping as an escape from the hood but a liberation from ordinary life.

column1: The lyrics are peppered with occasionally complex ideas exposing the corrosive nature of gangs
column2: and Kream softens these ideas with accessible metaphors. When he finds the right balance between the two
column3: his wordplay clicks. ""My boys goin' pop I ain’t talkin' Backstreet/ My guns goin' pop and the bullets in sync
column4: he raps on ""1998""
column5: laying the groundwork for a personal flashback to the year in question. Most of his more engaging rapping takes place when he avoids talk of homicide altogether. The Father-assisted ""Cell Boomin"" and dual-sided ""Trap Mami / Flippin""
column6: both produced by Houston beatsmith Wxlf Gxd
column7: are drug peddler anthems with bouncing flows that explore static thump and a syrupy codeine haze.

column1: A year ago
column2: Maxo Kream told Noisey that he felt the candy-coated Houston sound was dated and that it was time to welcome the city’s new image. His message was clear: The city has changed
column3: so its sound should change with it. However
column4: Kream has tethered himself to the A$AP interpretation of Houston rap and the music he’s making now is heavily shaped by the outside perception of his city
column5: the reappropriation of Screw into something even more ominous. Though Kream maintains his ties to Houston street life
column6:
he continues to find himself in the reflection of those that have been pantomiming H-Town rappers for years now instead of those within the city limits.

Lightning Bolt have been around for close to two decades. In that time
column2: they haven't really changed their basic formula: Brian Chippendale still bashes his drums with chaotic precision and bassist Brian Gibson manages to make four strings sound like many more. From the beginning
column3: their mix of mayhem and heaviness brought to mind Harry Pussy and Black Sabbath playing at the same time. But they somehow showed up in big features in magazines that didn't normally care about noise
column4: and in the record collections of people who felt pretty much the same.

column1: The musical landscape around Lightning Bolt has shifted more than a few times during this period
column2: but the duo continue full-throttle with the kind of triumphant blitz they served up when they first emerged from Providence
column3: R.I. When Lightning Bolt started in 1994
column4: future Black Dice member Hisham Bharoocha handled vocals and guitars for the band
column5: and the difference between the two groups is instructive. Black Dice came out of the same punk/art-school world as Lightning Bolt but they chose a more winding path—from violent punks to noise mongrels to psychedelic noisemakers to gleeful DFA electronic tweakers. LB have remained tunnel-vision focused. The respect for the initial approach suggests an endless possibility in a few gestures
column6: a sensibility that runs counter to the over-stuffed
column7: ADD
column8: and of-the-moment world we live in.

column1: Fantasy Empire is their first LP in five years; it's also the first recorded in a proper studio—Pawtucket's Machines with Magnets—and you can tell. The sound is bigger and more defined; they haven't cleaned things up
column2: exactly
column3: it's just easier to figure out what's leveling you. You can make out deeper textures and striations
column4: and the greater detail lends variety without shifting away from the blown-out repetition. There's also a larger dynamic range—just when you think a song's gotten as big as it possibly can
column5: they pile on more sounds like live loops
column6: synthesizers
column7: tape constructions
column8: and bass overdubs. Rather than serving as a compromise
column9: the shifts that come with higher production values are positive.

column1: Some of Lightning Bolt's mid-period albums grew dull after repeat listens
column2: or made you think about how you'd rather see the music performed live. Wonderful Rainbow from 2003 had an almost pop catchiness to it
column3: and you get that here
column4: too. With a few listens
column5: there's a feeling of anticipation for certain breaks or shifts or
column6: as at the end of ""Over the River and Through the Woods""
column7: head-bangs. And more than any of their records
column8: if you play it loud
column9: and close your eyes
column10: it's very easy to imagine being in the same room as the Brians. (They've been doing some of the songs at their shows since 2010
column11: and the album has a very broken-in feel to it.)

column1: Unexpectedly
column2: Chippendale's vocals have gotten stronger
column3: as he's moved from the early chirps and howls to legit contact-mic crooning. His voice has typically been another strand of noise; here he feels like more of a proper singer
column4: one who can compete with everything going on around him. At the start of ""Over the River and Through the Woods"" he clears his throat like Celtic Frost's Tom G. Warrior
column5: and later in the song
column6: he's a strangulated Ozzy. On ""Horsepower""
column7: he approximates a swaggering demigod on the riff party
column8: while ""Runaway Train"" sees him turn into a metal circus barker. The band's last full-length record
column9: 2009's Earthly Delights
column10: had a metal edge to it
column11: and as the comparisons above suggest
column12: Lightning Bolt go further in that direction on Fantasy. This is noise doom
column13: more or less
column14: the crystalline tone and soloing on ""Dream Genie"" is the stuff of Steve Vai heaven
column15: and ""Horsepower"" brings to mind Geddy Lee howling into a maelstrom kicked up by Sleep. This is also their most flat-out rock'n'roll album to date
column16: and their best since Wonderful Rainbow.

column1: Most of the tracks have an anthemic forward march—these songs are built for speed. That's especially true of the massive 12-minute closer
column2: ""Snow White (& The 7 Dwarves Fans)""
column3: whose tongue-in-cheek title nails the essential Lightning Bolt aesthetic: part punk rock
column4: part adult fairytale. They're still doing what they've always done
column5: but Fantasy Empire is the best they've done it in a long time
column6:
and the new sheen makes everything seem magic again.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21604/homepage_large.398b6f1e.jpg|Trap Genius|31352.0|Tree|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-03-18 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:28.431178|"

Almost from the moment his digitally warped sampling approach
column2: elastic 808 loops
column3: and gruff
column4: elliptical delivery began garnering him critical attention in 2012
column5: Chicago rapper and producer Tree has been attempting to reframe the conversation surrounding his music. Trillin’
column6: the follow-up to his lauded
column7: self-produced Sunday School mixtape
column8: felt like a direct challenge to those pigeonholing him as some kind of ""outsider"" artist: The EP took his home city’s drill music for a spin
column9: featuring regimented
column10: hard-nosed rapping over standard-issue production from a third party. His latest full-length solo release
column11: Trap Genius
column12: is in the same lineage
column13: offering a newly straightforward take on Southern-fried street rap.

column1: Tree has his sights set on lean
column2: ATL-esque club records here but
column3: perhaps despite himself
column4: Trap Genius’ songs always come out in his own highly specific style. His ragged but tuneful baritone recalls Howlin’ Wolf more than Jeezy
column5: and
column6: as always
column7: it lends his songs a weighty
column8: soulful quality. He supersedes and reframes beats better than he rides them
column9: especially when they’re not his own.

column1: The primary ""trap"" signifier is Tree's rigid
column2: triplet-ized flow
column3: which these days is put to use by everyone from unofficial patent owners Migos to trend-hopping chart-toppers like Drake and Big Sean. Tree’s take on it
column4: however
column5: is far from conventional. He's not by nature a nimble rapper—he raps fast
column6: but never treads lightly—and on tracks like ""Betta Than Eva"" and ""Red Yella""
column7: a lengthy set of ""Versace"" triplets creates something of a bull-in-a-china-shop effect. Tree careens across the beat like a heavy projectile
column8: papering over negative space and integrating bluesy inflections
column9: sometimes singing from the gut in a nod to gospel.

column1: The prevailing tone of the songs is celebratory
column2: finding Tree enjoying the spoils of his labor as a rapper; he’s not offering the perspective of a gangbanger
column3: but of an entrepreneur who proudly ""got [money] without ever touching the 'cane."" However
column4: the ghosts of the lifestyle he grew up in—and his friends who are still caught up in it—lurk in the corners of his verses
column5: and in the newscasts
column6: cop radio dialogs
column7: and field recordings of arrests that break up the tape. But these often faceless figures are side characters. For them
column8: the money in which the rap-famous Tree revels (""Money the only thing matters at this point"") is a curse (""All the money in the world couldn’t save a homie"") that clouds judgment. One of the album’s standout images is of a friend ""sitting in county for weeks contained/ Dreaming of being free and broke.""

column1: This best-friend/worst-enemy dichotomy is central to plenty of dope-boy rap
column2: but the picture Tree paints is more complicated and is filled with contradictory perspectives. The cloud-rappy ""New or Leins"" even finds him telling the story of a woman looking for love in all the wrong places
column3: visiting cheating boyfriends in jail. The panoramic approach is inspired
column4: even when the shifts in vantage are abrupt
column5: and the subjects underdeveloped.

column1: Tree tends to linger between the cracks that define and politicize genres
column2: themes
column3: and flows
column4: pitting them against each other in games of his own creation. He hears something that’s popular
column5: figures out what people love about it
column6: and then flips it at market price. The inclination is evidence of an omnivorous love of music
column7: not an interest on cashing in on trends. What inspired him initially is always sublimated into his own sound; it’s ""soul trap"" even without the original beats to which the term usually refers. With no production from Tree
column8: Trap Genius might not seem like a good way to get to know him as an artist
column9: but all of his strengths are here
column10: including his unique sense of rhythm
column11: melody
column12: storytelling
column13:
and economy.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21607/homepage_large.0f842c10.jpg|No News from Home|32749.0|Houndstooth|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['No Quarter']|2015-03-18 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:28.948959|"

""You can’t take it with you when you go"" doesn’t sound very much like a #YOLO cliché when Katie Bernstein sings it on ""Green Light""
column2: a folksily pensive break-up song on Houndstooth’s second album
column3: No News from Home. She delivers the phrase in an eloquently flat voice that suggests an Americanized Nico
column4: perhaps not as intimate but more agile in her phrasing
column5: and she bends that last long ""O"" upwards toward a heaven that may or may not actually be there. She might be talking about death
column6: but in the context of both the album and the song
column7: it’s more likely she’s talking about something potentially worse: touring. You can’t load up the security and comfort of home with the guitars
column8: amps
column9: and drum cases
column10: but there’s always room in the van for anxiety and disappointment. You might leave a friend or lover behind
column11: and only occasionally will you find a bit of peace alongside the side of some highway. ""I found a new love
column12: Bernstein tells her old love
column13: ""a love of the new world and what it would be without you.""

column1: Touring is not the subject of No News from Home. It’s more like the backdrop against which the band’s songs as well as its own story all play out: a necessary rite of passage for any indie act
column2: an inevitable fact of life like taxes and that other thing. The four musicians in Houndstooth all know that life intimately: Before they played their first show together in May 2011
column3: they cut their teeth in such Portland bands as the Parson Red Heads
column4: Inside Voices
column5: and the Threads of Grass. They had developed a local reputation as a dynamic live act skirting the difference between breezy country rock and tightly-coiled krautrock
column6: but when they recorded their first album
column7: 2013’s Ride Out the Dark
column8: they abridged their epic jams into tidy pop songs. It may not have been exactly representative of their onstage attack
column9: but it showcased Bernstein’s distinctive vocals and John Gnorski’s spidery guitar licks and it allowed them to tour well beyond the Pacific Northwest.

column1: That experience obviously informs both the sound and the subject matter of No News from Home. Especially on the slow-burn ""Amelia"" and ""Witching Hour"" (with its sly shout-out to Donnie & Joe Emerson)
column2: the songwriting is sharper and more open-ended
column3: as though the stories they’re telling are still unfolding before them. Furthermore
column4: the band have developed a more confident dynamic
column5: evoking a sense of motion and travel in the clash of guitars and the persistent click of Graeme Gibson’s snare. Album opener ""Bliss Boat"" sounds like a natural show closer
column6: highlighting seemingly everybody in the band. There’s a subdued swing in the rhythm section and scrappy drama in the guitars
column7: as the song builds fluidly into an epic jam that’s part Can
column8: part Byrds.

column1: All that touring and woodshedding has apparently taught them not to waste a note
column2: because the first side of No News from Home has a determined cohesion
column3: sequenced to evoke the choppy rhythms of the road. Almost inevitably they lose some of that focus on side two
column4: whose songs don’t have quite the same sense of purpose or that same sense of movement. Closer ""They’re Racing Tonight""
column5: with its hints of Springsteen mythology
column6: saunters instead of speeds off into the sunset
column7: with so little sense of closure that you can almost hear the words ""To be continued…"" as that last organ chord fades. Hopefully
column8:
their next album will take Houndstooth even further from home. 

"|20340.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20340-no-news-from-home/|6.9|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21632/homepage_large.4f909af5.jpg|Pill EP|28441.0|Pill|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dull Tools']|2015-03-18 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:29.553048|"

Recordings are often free and readily available in 2015
column2: but that doesn't make it any easier to find the good stuff. A young band's stellar new record might be streaming for free on Bandcamp somewhere
column3: but it's easily lost. Finding vital underground music often requires a resourceful middle person—usually
column4: someone who goes to a lot of shows and owns an inordinate number of zines and tapes. It's to Andrew Savage of Parquet Courts' credit
column5: for example
column6: that bands like Beth Israel
column7: Yuppies
column8: and Eaters found an audience online. Each record on his label Dull Tools seems to challenge complacency and subvert expectations.

column1: True to the label's reputation
column2: the Brooklyn band Pill prove slippery to pin down on their debut EP. Post-punk is implied in Veronica Torres' deadpan vocals and Jon Campolo's echoing guitar clack
column3: but Ben Jaffe's saxophone scrambles the signal. Sometimes
column4: his melodies recall Steve Mackay's foundation work on ""Fun House""
column5: and elsewhere
column6: he detours into skronking freakouts à la Pharoah Sanders or Colin Stetson. There are circuit-bent electronics and blasts of noise
column7: dour monotone vocals sung in unison and all-out screams. Across the EP's five tracks
column8: which were produced by Andy Chugg of the art punks Pop. 1280
column9: Pill keep listeners on their toes while navigating their own chaos.

column1: While Jaffe's sax is a fascinating wild card
column2: Torres' lyrics are the heart of this music. She targets seemingly innocuous moments in a relationship
column3: peeling back the facade of domestic bliss and exposing ugly truths in shouted blurts. ""Personality Flaw"" depicts a couple who initially appeared compatible
column4: but now are locked in a war of wills where nobody wants to compromise. ""TV Wedding"" explores how technology glosses over real-life despair. On ""Hotline""
column5: Torres playacts the role of a ""California blonde"" in a one-sided conversation that's clearly predatory in nature. (""Oh
column6: you wanna touch me where?/ Oh no
column7: I'm younger than that!"") The narratives are sometimes abstract and symbolic
column8: but Torres' phrasing has a way of cutting through the haze. On ""Psychic Nipple""
column9: after several lines alluding to entitlement
column10: she delivers the devastating clincher ""Privilege is a warm body that loves you.""

column1: This is where Pill showcase what they're capable of—they are loose with form
column2: they pack in a lot of ideas
column3: and they successfully deliver an emotionally complex narrative where joy is accompanied by an impossible-to-ignore undercurrent of danger. The band's debut outing is enigmatic—a Dull Tools record through and through—but it's also well crafted
column4:
full of stellar performances and unflinching lyrics. Not bad for a band's first recordings.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21592/homepage_large.8f556055.jpg|A Readymade Ceremony|32797.0|Félicia Atkinson|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Shelter Press']|2015-03-18 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:30.223319|"

Intimacy has always been part of Félicia Atkinson’s work. Under her own name and as Je Suis Le Petit Chevalier
column2: the French musician
column3: painter
column4: and writer makes sound art that consistently feels like the articulation of a single
column5: inimitable brain. A Readymade Ceremony might be her most literally intimate effort to date. Often it sounds like she’s sitting right next to you
column6: whispering into your ear with her hand cupped around it. The up-close effect of her voice is matched by her music
column7: whose tones
column8: drones
column9: beats
column10: and samples are so detailed
column11: it’s as if you’re listening through a microscope.

column1: That aura of privacy pervades the album so thoroughly that it seems inappropriate to focus on any individual track. But one piece does serve as the record’s center of gravity
column2: a kind of album-in-miniature capturing the greatness of the whole. The 10-minute ""L’Oeil"" features Atkinson whispering words ""extracted and derived"" from the 1941 Georges Bataille short story ""Madame Edwarda"". Beneath her rolls a bed of wind
column3: static
column4: rumbles
column5: and a plethora of other environment-building sounds.

column1: There’s a tactile feel to that backing
column2: but when placed behind Atkinson’s hypnosis-inducing vocals
column3: it all feels like it’s happening subconsciously. Repeating simple phrases like ""I used to be played more often"" and ""hanged by the shower curtain’s rod
column4: her voice seems to comb across your skin
column5: in a sort of avant-garde version of ASMR. But the point is less about inducing physical response—though ""L’Oeil"" is practically telepathic in that way—than about simultaneously engaging brain
column6: heart
column7: and gut. You feel it because you understand it and vice versa. The words Atkinson intones and the notes she summons are equal parts sound and sense
column8: so the way she says something and what it means become inextricably linked.

column1: The rest of A Readymade Ceremony extends that alchemy
column2: always feeling both tactile and subliminal
column3: literal and abstract. Atkinson’s past work often involved dense
column4: sometimes obscuring layers of echoing sound. But here there’s a new sense of lucidity and spaciousness that feels refreshing
column5: like a sun shining after fog has cleared. By bringing her sounds into sharper focus
column6: Atkinson has sacrificed none of their depth—in fact
column7: getting to see everything makes it more obvious how much is going on.

column1: Despite the higher resolution
column2: A Readymade Ceremony still feels and sounds like a dream. The logic of how she fuses sounds approaches a narrative
column3: but it’s a surreal one—the kind that makes more sense while you’re entranced by it than when you try to explain it to someone later. That’s another quality that has persisted throughout her music
column4: as well as in her flowing poems and naturalistic visual art. It seemed as if it might’ve reached its apex in her career-crowning 2013 double-album Voices/Visions. But it turns out that was just as much a launching point as a peak
column5:
and A Readymade Ceremony is another step up in her fascinating journey.
