Modest Mouse have been working on their new album for longer than many bands have existed. The breadcrumb trail of news reports depicting their progress over the years—they were recording with Krist Novoselic and Big Boi; they were switching producers—gave the worrying impression of a band that maybe didn’t know what the hell they were doing. In 2013
column2: they canceled a tour to hit the studio
column3: and somewhere in there founding bassist Eric Judy quit the band. The process left in its wake some dropped singles and a few different release dates
column4: along with a lingering sense that maybe this venerable indie institution’s creative motor was stuck in neutral.

column1: Strangers to Ourselves finally sees the light of day this week
column2: and to hear Brock tell it
column3: we’re getting another album ""as soon as legally possible."" They are back
column4: in other words
column5: and vigorously making up for lost time. For better and for worse
column6: the album betrays no signs of its troubled birth. They might have spent eight years in the wilderness
column7: but what they have delivered is…a Modest Mouse album
column8: one that sounds like it could have been released five years ago. There are no new directions or tweaks to their approach. ""Lampshades on Fire""
column9: the first single
column10: is a good example. It offers a sort of greatest-hits version of all the sounds Modest Mouse have become known for—""Here’s the hard-swinging backbeat! Here are a few of those eerie-sounding harmonic guitar bends
column11: and  here are some tight
column12: clipped 'bah bah bahs!'"" Still
column13: there’s satisfaction to be had
column14: hearing this band of pros finding and hitting their marks so emphatically. They've been a touring juggernaut for years now
column15: and you can imagine many of these songs exploding live.

column1: Here and there some new flourishes pop up. The glimmering mallet percussion on ""Ansel"" is a nice touch
column2: something we’ve never heard on a Modest Mouse record before. Opener ""Strangers"" is a patient and pretty ballad
column3: featuring drowsy brush work by drummer Jeremiah Green
column4: a prominent cello line
column5: and Brock’s gentle
column6: lilting midrange. The delicately fingerpicked acoustic guitar figure in the beginning of ""Coyotes"" is also lovely
column7: a bit of late-period Beatles. ""The Best Room"" may or may not be inspired by a UFO sighting
column8: as Isaac Brock coyly hinted in a recent interview. But the song is an unruffled and sweet pop-rock number that hits a feeling Modest Mouse never bothered with in their earliest days: It is sunny
column9: optimistic
column10: relaxed. Not even ""Float On""
column11: their massive hit and a teeth-gritted ode to positivity
column12: had this easy sense of goodwill to it.

column1: At times
column2: the record feels labored
column3: like you can hear every studio session that went into its creation. <span id=""docs-internal-guid-334daa5f-2473-43d6-a679-8d55cf26529d"">By the time the metal guitars have crashed into ""Sugar Boats""—and the tubas enter in a moment later
column4: doubling over them—the song has grown both overwhelming and boring. ""Pistol (A. Cunanan
column5: Miami
column7: meanwhile
column8: is an overcooked
column9: clattering mess
column10: a sloppy retread of ""Tiny Cities Made of Ashes"" that might be the worst song Brock has ever recorded. On these moments
column11: you get the sense the band simply recorded for eight years until someone told them to stop.

column1: What’s ultimately missing are new ideas
column2: or a fresh spin on their old ones. The lyrics
column3: which used to be a very good reason to listen to a Modest Mouse record
column4: are no longer the draw. Brock’s voice remains remarkable
column5: an exclamation point he can bend into attention-getting shapes—a Tourette’s-like yelp
column6: a heartburn-belch
column7: a rooster crow. So lines like ""We’re the sexiest of all primates"" (""The Best Room"") are simply awkward
column8: like a party quieting down just as you shout something particularly banal.

column1: Any band that stays together for nearly 20 years
column2: transitioning from indie to major label
column3: losing and gaining members along the way
column4: is going to change. A long time ago
column5: Modest Mouse were known for volatile
column6: destructive behavior and piercing insights
column7: but their last two albums have positioned them as paragons of alt-rock professionalism
column8: a band that takes their fans and their albums seriously and think hard about how to deliver on their expectations. Here they sound like they’ve settled into their status as a reliable indie rock institution. Strangers to Ourselves is a pleasant album
column9:
and one that completes their transition from ""inspired"" to ""sturdy"".

'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Commmons']|2015-03-17 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:33.971773|"

Ryuichi Sakamoto isn’t afraid to look back. Though it’s been decades since the trailblazing techno-pop of solo albums like Thousand Knives and B–2 Unit
column3: he’s continually revisited pieces from throughout his career
column4: including his time in the seminal electronic trio Yellow Magic Orchestra. Sakamoto has released more than a half-dozen studio albums of reconfigured material
column5: making his discography less a straight line than a phylogenetic tree. A song like ""Energy Flow"" might find its first spark of life as a brief commercial jingle
column6: then expand into Japan’s first-ever instrumental chart-topper
column7: then find its way into a modern classical form. ""Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence""
column8: the iconic centerpiece of his soundtrack for the David Bowie vehicle of the same name
column9: has been re-worked repeatedly
column10: including a bit-crushed reduction during recent live performances with German sound sculptor Alva Noto. And 2002’s Century of Reform is itself a set of hypotheses testing the versatility of a single theme. Sakamoto’s great strength throughout his massive oeuvre is his search for new vantage points.

column1: The Japan-only compilation Year Book 2005–2014
column2: collecting rare and unreleased commissioned work
column3: comes at a difficult time for its maker. Last summer
column4: Sakamoto announced that he’d been diagnosed with throat cancer
column5: and would be taking some time away to prioritize treatment. The 63-year-old musician’s output has since consisted of just one album
column6: a live collaboration with Illuha and Taylor Deupree
column7: recorded the year before his hiatus. The past decade has seen Sakamoto’s once panoramic focus narrow to the minute particulars of just a few genres: His collaborative albums with the likes of Noto
column8: Deupree
column9: Fennesz
column10: and Christopher Willits each have their idiosyncrasies
column11: but all deal mostly in cold drones and ambience
column12: while his solo efforts have been mostly focused on piano. Thanks to the wide variety of contexts its 30 pieces were written to serve
column13: Year Book winds up being the most representative—and rewarding—Sakamoto album of its titular period.

column1: The opening invocation
column2: ""Cantus Omnibus Unus""
column3: is a severe Gregorian chant that stakes out new territory for the composer. The brief piece sets the tone for the first disc’s bleak minimalism
column4: where fragments of Debussy keys shimmer gently along a barren digital landscape between pockets of warmth and harmony. These works demonstrate an intuitive grasp of the sounds Sakamoto has continued exploring with his Western collaborators of late
column5: while the fragmentary ""Visionaire"" reminds that these are gestures he discovered for himself on 2002’s spectral Derrida soundtrack.

column1: Breaking from its predecessor’s sustained tone
column2: the second disc bounds in all directions. ""2099"" is a digitized take on free jazz textures
column3: while a 2011 remix of Meredith Monk’s ""Astronaut Anthem"" repurposes the original’s tension to create a drowsy sense of bliss. Two pieces from Sakamoto’s collaborations with Fennesz wind up here: ""Ropa""
column4: whose comforting romanticism is more akin to Leyland Kirby than anything off Cendre or Flumina ; and ""PEACE""
column5: a tortured gale of noise made for an Amnesty International campaign against the death penalty. The three-part ""Dharma"" suite floats somewhere between Sakamoto’s Little Buddha score and his overlooked New Age tendencies
column6: while the arpeggiated ""Meditation"" adds some classic Tangerine Dream to the atmosphere.

column1: Year Book is also an endearing reminder that Sakamoto remains a man of great humor. ""AUDI 2011""—a title that might as well be vaporwave—observes ""the beauty of the Audi car’s streamlined body"" (says the liner notes) through a player-piano experiment not unlike those on Aphex Twin’s recent EP
column2: while ""Otowa"" sounds like a pointed commentary on the sterile pseudo-classical that usually steers luxury car commercials. And the two long ""Nokiartek"" pieces are without a doubt the most alienating creations ever billed to a major cellphone company. There’s a deep amusement in realizing that Sakamoto’s most corporate commissions tend to sound the weirdest and least sociable.

column1: ""Whitescape#2""
column2: a haunted minute of piano and pixelation
column3: takes us up to the weeks before Sakamoto’s diagnosis
column4: and the end of his body of work to date. In his official announcement—still tacked to his website’s front door—he promises a return to music after a full recovery. There is no reason to believe he won’t. But even were he to stop writing music tomorrow
column5:
Year Book 2005–2014 is yet more evidence that Sakamoto’s discography is by now a memory bank so rich and vast you could spend a lifetime in it.

Before even releasing her debut
column2: Laura Welsh underwent a series of transformations. From discarded band names—she has performed as Laura and the Tears as well as Hey Laura—to changes in style
column3: the English singer has done her share of exploration before finally landing on her own name and a strong
column4: confident electro-pop sound for Soft Control. It’s a big record—dramatic crescendos
column5: orchestral arrangements
column6: pounding percussion—for which Welsh enlisted a bevy of big name production and songwriting talent
column7: including Emile Haynie
column8: Dev Hynes
column9: John Legend
column10: and a slew of others.

column1: While Welsh’s voice is undeniably powerful
column2: it’s sometimes hard to differentiate her from her more well-known contemporaries. In a blind taste test
column3: multiple songs here could be B-sides or demos from any of a number of British artists
column4: including Florence Welch and Jessie Ware. Not bad company to be in
column5: for sure
column6: and Welsh is
column7: vocally
column8: on par with both. In fact
column9: it’s more the fault of the sheer volume of collaboration on the album that keeps it from coalescing into a cohesive
column10: forceful whole.

column1: That said
column2: Welsh makes good work of many songs on the album. The John Legend co-write ""Hardest Part""
column3: with its heartbeat thump and minimal synth arrangement
column4: allows Welsh to get her Annie Lennox on
column5: bringing some real heat to an otherwise straightforward R&B ballad. She transitions effortlessly from her power range into a delicate
column6: breathy upper register
column7: and the result is natural and tender. ""Unravel""
column8: produced and co-written by Dev Hynes
column9: is more a showcase for Hynes than Welsh
column10: who performs the song beautifully
column11: but without any particular individuality. It’s more of a Dev Hynes song than anything else
column12: and on a debut where Welsh is clearly trying to define her sound
column13: it’s a loss.

column1: Laura Welsh really shines at extremes. Whether she’s breathless and restrained on ""Hardest Part""
column2: or pushing the boundaries of her voice on ""God Keeps""
column3: Welsh stands out when she’s allowed to plumb the depths of real heartbreak
column4: confusion
column5: and discovery. On ""Still Life""
column6: a gentle
column7: whispery R&B track hidden towards the end of the record
column8: production
column9: writing
column10: and vocals finally gel
column11: with results that skew a little bit Police and a little more Sade.

column1: For an artist who has undergone so many identity experiments before her debut
column2: Soft Control is a promising
column3: if not groundbreaking
column4: beginning. Welsh has staked her claim as a singer who can adapt to the needs of her various producers and co-writers. What’s next
column5: then? To take that claim and carve out the place as one of the electro-pop women of power she is always compared to
column6:
by making an album that is cohesive and entirely her own.

Bronx-bred singer Rahel is currently the lone female artist associated with Camp & Street
column2: a label and collective overseen by New York rapper Le1f. To date
column3: the 27-year-old has guest vocals on songs by Le1f (""Star Me"" and ""Air Max"") and rapper/singer DonChristian’s album
column4: Renzo Piano. While her style is hard to grasp from her limited in-house contributions
column5: on Rahel's recently released debut
column6: Alkali
column7: her approach mirrors that of her early '00s pop-R&B predecessors like Nivea
column8: Ashanti and others: passionate vocals
column9: a surgical focus on relationship disappointment and a sometimes foolish urge to hold on to something that’s gone bad long ago.

column1: What initially stands out most about Alkali is its lush production
column2: which in large part comes from The-Drum’s Jeremiah Meece
column3: who’s also credited as an executive producer. While it could have easily fallen into the one-long-song trap that many do when chasing cohesion
column4: Alkali’s sounds glide into each other
column5: one track after another
column6: their R&B fundamentals enhanced by off-kilter elements like the vocal processing that’s sprinkled throughout the album. The tracks are also distinguished by Rahel’s biggest strength on the record: her charm.

column1: Her lyrics may not mirror the en-vogue
column2: complex masochism of the Weeknd and FKA twigs
column3: but her around-the-way girl sentiment resonates nonetheless. Her plainspoken lyrics
column4: coupled with her conversational delivery
column5: make it easy to zero in on her troubles. At times
column6: Alkali feels like a one-on-one intervention with your friend who’s in need. On ""Bae"" with fellow Camp & Street member DonChristian
column7: Rahel’s patience is running thin with a love interest who’s playing too many games
column8: which perfectly segues into ""Restless"" where she demands complete honesty. It’s also during a distorted monologue in the latter where a giggly but serious Rahel urges
column9: ""Stop frontin’...we grown now."" There’s often a seesaw of angst
column10: playfulness and frustration in young relationships
column11: which Rahel illustrates here quite naturally.

column1: Rahel doesn’t spend the entirety of Alkali losing sleep over her uncooperative lover
column2: though. At the midway point is ""The Break""
column3: where the frustration  finally boils over into an ""I'm through"" proclamation. But
column4: even in her exit
column5: she’s still conflicted and attached: On ""The Current""
column6: she sings a somewhat false-sounding ""we’ll be alright"" and ""I think we gon' make it.""

column1: What’s most interesting about Alkali is how it changes depending on its context. When taken in as a full narrative
column2: the nuances are easy to single out and appreciate
column3: but when removed from context
column4: no track outside of the ones that featured her Camp & Street teammates (""Bae"" and ""Flutter"") stand alone. There’s nothing groundbreaking about the content either. But maybe intricacy isn’t what should matter much for Alkali
column5: an album very much about the heart.

column1: On the album closer ""Easy""
column2: Rahel brings the narrative to a gratifying conclusion
column3: singing ""I feel like keeping what's mine/ 'Cause nothing is worth more than I."" After her agony and ever-changing emotions
column4: the affirmation feels hard-won and honest. Wounded and disappointed
column5: Rahel’s resilience
column6:
self-analyzation and ability to rid herself of baggage feels like a triumph—and it's one you can feel even if you’re just focusing on the music.

In 1996
column2: a Midwesterner named Jason Molina released his debut seven-inch single
column3: cryptically titled Nor Cease Thou Never Now
column4: on Will Oldham’s Palace Records. The most popular story about what happened next goes that some college kids in Indiana heard it and started a record label. Less well-known is the story of a young singer-songwriter halfway around the world: Irish Glen Hansard
column5: then most notable for his role in the 1991 flick The Commitments
column6: heard Cease and became obsessed. He wrote Molina a fan letter and was floored when Molina actually wrote back. The two struck up a friendship that evolved over the years: They toured and even recorded together
column7: including a split seven-inch in 2000.

column1: Molina’s death hit Hansard hard
column2: but he took some solace in his friend’s music
column3: assembling a group of musicians who had played with Molina and jamming. Initially
column4: they had no plans to record
column5: much less release anything
column6: but the sessions went so well that they devised a tribute
column7: and the result of his therapeutic re-immersion is an EP titled It Was Triumph We Once Proposed. Hansard chooses these five tracks as fan more than as a friend
column8: and he wisely gives no thought to comprehensiveness. How could you possibly cover such a productive career in such a short tracklist?

column1: Triumph opens with ""Being in Love""
column2: from Songs: Ohia’s 2000 album The Lioness. The song isn't one of Molina’s best-known compositions
column3: which only makes its inclusion feel like a discovery. The original is slow
column4: quiet
column5: and intense
column6: with Molina singing about the risks of any relationship over a rusty industrial beat
column7: a churchly organ
column8: and sharp stabs of guitar. Hansard gives the song a classic-rock makeover
column9: transforming Molina’s dark musings into a chorus that sounds just shy of hopeful. ""We are proof
column10: he sings
column11: one beat before a guitar crashes through the vocal line
column12: ""that the heart is a risky fuel to burn."" This is what the song might sound like if Magnolia Electric Co. had recorded it
column13: and it works so well you can almost hear Molina singing along.

column1: Nothing else on Triumph surpasses this nervy cover. Rather than radically rethink the other songs
column2: he wraps them around himself like a warm blanket. On ""Hold On Magnolia""
column3: his voice wavers slightly as he sings about Molina’s favorite subjects: the road
column4: the moon
column5: the heart
column6: the job at hand. Likewise
column7: ""Farewell Transmission"" is a sturdy rendition of one of Molina’s most popular songs
column8: with Hansard’s vocals drawing out the measured optimism in the lyrics. Molina is often described as a bleak songwriter
column9: and after his death in 2013
column10: his reputation for facing up to dark truths only intensified. ""The real truth about it is no one gets it right
column11: Hansard sings
column12: but he puts even more emphasis on the next line: ""The real truth about it is that we’re all supposed to try.""

column1: Triumph offers implicit argument that Molina glimpsed the light of morning in the darkest night
column2: and this idea serves as the EP's most powerful tribute. It is also a welcome corrective to the idea that Molina's struggles with addiction and depression can be decoded through his lyrics. Hansard shows us Molina trying to be his best self in his music. The EP builds to an abrupt finale with ""Vanquisher"" and ""White Sulfur""
column3: a pair of songs that barely pass the two-minute mark. Hansard closes the record with the line
column4: ""So then
column5: I have to be going
column6: okay."" At first it sounds like a tearjerker
column7: but Hansard owns the words and directs them toward Molina. It’s powerful not because it reminds us that Molina is gone
column8: but because it makes him feel present once again
column9:
if only for a few minutes.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21422/homepage_large.44e3ab4b.jpg|Goon|32424.0|Tobias Jesso Jr.|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['True Panther']|2015-03-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:36.972401|"

At some point it became clear that one of the themes for the first quarter of 2015 would be The Return of the Male Piano Balladeer. Upcoming records from Father John Misty
column2: Matthew E. White
column3: and new kid/not-kid Tobias Jesso Jr. (he’s 29) would all center on an archetype now associated mostly with the 1970s: the weary dude
column4: wise beyond his years
column5: spinning tales of love and loss from his piano bench before moving over to a barstool. It’s an image that took hold during the '60s hangover
column6: when baby boomers traded youthful dreams and started becoming their parents
column7: a little less certain with each new season that they were
column8: in fact
column9: still crazy after all these years. This highly personal
column10: smaller-scale music was less about The World and more about the geography of a wounded heart. Jesso
column11: Misty and White
column12: in their own ways
column13: are all drawn to a similar directness
column14: a love of the well-written song composed and performed solo.

column1: Hearing Tobias Jesso Jr.’s album
column2: Goon
column3: it turns out he has less in common with his peers than we thought. Father John Misty’s J. Tillman is by far the most literate and complicated of the three songwriters
column4: using a fictional persona to plumb the depths of his own desires and self-loathing. Matthew E. White is more producer and arranger than singer-songwriter
column5: someone who lets the horn arrangements and mic placement do the talking. And Tobias Jesso Jr. is ultimately more of a wide-eyed innocent
column6: a songwriter with a naturally expressive voice who has a McCartney-like propensity for melody and an innate drive toward simplicity.

column1: In the late '60s and early '70s
column2: L.A. singer-songwriters like Randy Newman
column3: Harry Nilsson
column4: and Tom Waits got their start by writing songs for others
column5: playing small clubs on Sunset
column6: and skulking around record label offices. Jesso did try writing for others
column7: but his rise could only happen on the Internet: Some songs posted to YouTube
column8: an exchange with an admired producer (in the case of Jesso
column9: Girls' JR White)
column10: a debut record on a hip label
column11: and a ""The Tonight Show"" appearance before the LP even comes out. This isn’t just luck
column12: of course—Jesso already had some connections from his time living and working in music in Los Angeles and a few famous friends
column13: and his little label is part of the indie juggernaut Beggars Group. But if his quick ascent owes a lot to living in a networked world
column14: his music sounds as natural as breathing. Jesso has a knack for writing songs that you feel like you’ve heard before
column15: even if you can’t quite pin down a precise antecedent. Which is another way of saying he writes songs that sound ""classic"" in the best sense of the word.

column1: The highlights here sound like songs that could be covered and interpreted any number of ways by other vocalists
column2: with a rock-solid melodic and harmonic foundation. ""How Could You Babe"" is among them
column3: moving from slow
column4: halting verses that build tension until the glorious release of the chorus. On the last refrain
column5: Jesso pushes his voice in its upper register to the point where it cracks
column6: a clever suggestion of desperation that speaks to his intuitive sense of phrasing. ""The Wait"" is a two-minute acoustic pop confection featuring Jesso on guitar
column7: a weightless gem that floats by like a freshly blown dandelion seed. A pair of songs
column8: ""Hollywood"" and ""Leaving LA""
column9: hint at Jesso’s background as a journeyman musician in Los Angeles
column10: but the main idea behind virtually every song is the precariousness of love and affection.

column1: Fans of those YouTube demos had to wonder how Jesso’s intimate music might hold up to studio glare
column2: but Jesso’s producers (White handled eight songs
column3: Pat Carney of Black Keys two
column4: and Ariel Rechtshaid one) treat his music with a simplicity that suggests utter confidence in the material. The songwriter’s voice
column5: piano chords
column6: and plucked acoustic are the focus
column7: and bits of light drumming and the odd back-up vocal are often the only augmentation. The approach leads to songs that feel unusually whole. You couldn't imagine taking anything away from these songs
column8: and it's equally hard to imagine adding anything. ""Leaving LA"" is a masterpiece of sonic understatement
column9: moving between solo piano and a blissful interlude of voices and what sounds like harpsichord. ""Bad Words"" finds Jesso’s voice pinched and distant next to a Fender Rhodes and subtle drumming. His vocal line and piano move in unison on ""For You"" as a violin saws away in the background; it all bleeds together until it feels like a single
column10: intricately textured sound.

column1: If Jesso seems to have a Burt Bacharach-like command of how verses

column5: to fit the rhythm and cadence of the tune rather than the other way around. In a couple of places (""Crocodile Tears"" and ""Can We Still Be Friends""
column6: which sounds disconcertingly like the theme song from ""Cheers"") that can lead to rhyme schemes so predictable in their girl/world obviousness as to become a distraction. But these moments are few
column7: and Jesso overcomes them as McCartney did—with the sweetness of his voice. ""There’s a thing called hate/ And a thing called love
column8: too/ Like the love I have for your Mom/ And for you"" reads awkwardly on the page

column4: they could be more likely to have you ruminating about the role music plays in heartbreak instead of the emotional pain itself

column8: Jesso sounds the most like Nilsson

which in this case turns out to be something special.

Florian Fricke's name doesn't often come up in discussions of great minimalist composers. The constraints of genre didn’t really suit him
column2: and his best-known work was with German kosmische legends Popol Vuh
column3: most notably in a series of soundtracks scored for Werner Herzog’s films. Kailash provides an introduction to the spare piano music Fricke worked on throughout his career
column4: which was cut cruelly short by a stroke at age 57 in 2001. It’s been assembled by Soul Jazz
column5: in a loving tribute: The first disc contains a mix of released and previously unreleased piano works
column6: while the second contains a score to a documentary Fricke co-directed with his bandmate Frank Fiedler in the mountains of Tibet. This material edges closer to the metaphysical side of his output with Popol Vuh—a smart move that could hook in fans who haven’t ventured into his lesser-known works. A DVD of the documentary
column7: also titled Kailash
column8: rounds out the comprehensive package.

column1: The piano work here covers a considerable timespan
column2: from 1972 to 1989. During these years
column3: Fricke returned to the piano after years spent wandering various disciplines. According to David Stubbs’ krautrock book
column4: Future Days
column5: Fricke studied classical piano as a child
column6: played jazz-fusion later in life
column7: worked as a film critic
column8: and had something resembling a spiritual epiphany when poring over old Mayan texts (one such text was the inspiration for the name Popol Vuh). Fricke had something of an obsession with purity
column9: both in a sacred and literal sense—the Moog synthesizer that was his trademark for a while was replaced by the piano for
column10: in his words
column11: its more ""human"" and ""direct"" feeling.

column1: If those quotes make Fricke sound like some kind of traditionalist
column2: it was never a feeling conveyed in his otherworldly music. The soundtrack disc in this set contains many of the elements that became hallmarks in his work
column3: including banks of foggy drones
column4: reverberating cymbal splashes
column5: and an air of dark rumination that conjures a decidedly inward-gazing spirituality. Fricke's soundtrack work stands on its own
column6: apart from its visual stimulus
column7: mostly because Fricke has a talent for imbuing his music with a strong sense of journey and place
column8: making sure that contrasting ideas gently cascade into one another. There's a traceable arc from the prickly field recordings in ""The Garden Morya"" and ""Nomads Move"" to the gentle
column9: wave-like structures of ""Last Village"" and the subtly creeping ""Valley of the Gods"". Fricke was clearly keen on reflecting both the light and dark side of his personality—something the Kailash soundtrack fully embodies.

column1: The leap from the Kailash score to the piano work is only a departure in the tools Fricke used. It’s not hard to see how his spare work informed the slightly more full sound of his music under the Popol Vuh name. The suite of three ""Spirit of Peace"" songs build around slowly repeating motifs and moments of near silence as notes gradually fade to grey
column2: which is exactly how the best Popol Vuh tracks work
column3: albeit with different instrumentals. Popol Vuh’s classic Hosianna Mantra (1972) prominently featured Fricke’s piano playing
column4: and much of the material here resembles a version of his ideas from that album with a few layers stripped out. ""The Heart"" is the centerpiece of this set
column5: with Fricke flickering between tranquility and a jagged edge
column6: occasionally letting out an audible sigh
column7: obviously lost in the circular shapes that engulf him in his art.

column1: The piano works make abundantly clear that Fricke was a musician with an exquisite ear for when not to play. He comes close to letting loose on the rippling mid-section of ""Moses""
column2: but holds back
column3: allowing the track its own painfully mournful exit. Both Julian Cope (in Krautrocksampler) and one-time Captain Beefheart sideman Gary Lucas (in a Wire epiphany) compared Fricke to John Cale
column4: and it’s not hard to see why. They share a classically trained background
column5: which they would try to escape from and embrace at various times in their careers. The positively jaunty (by Fricke’s standards) ""Garden of Pythagoras"" even resembles Cale’s piano playing on his and Lou Reed’s elegy for Andy Warhol
column6: Songs for Drella—a record about love and loss and the wonder of formative experiences. Those big concepts are all over this album too
column7:
demonstrating how Fricke could summon them up with the lightest of gestures.

column2: Atlanta rap is just too big to be confined to a singular style. Outsiders might focus on guns
column3: strip clubs

column10: but their lyrical focus is more varied and their energy cooler. They built up an independent buzz
column11: and last year
column12: they signed with Mike WiLL Made It’s Ear Drummer Records. In February

column1: Two-9 don’t hop on each other’s lines or burst halfway through a verse to give a couple bars; they’re organized and reserved. Cross talk is limited to skits that transition between tracks. On highlight ""Money Counter""

column1: Signing with Mike WiLL Made It’s label doesn't appear to have boxed them into his production camp. Gothic trap 808s appear on ""Verified"" and ""Functioning""
column2: but the rest of the tape is far more laidback. Metro Boomin
column3: who has made earth-shaking beats for Future and Young Thug
column4: gives them ""Full House""
column5: which feels perfect for Ty Dolla $ign’s signature cabanas. Opening track ""Gather Round""
column6: from producer Childish Major
column7: is a bit of dusty soul that manages to recall a time in Atlanta rap before ""trap"" became a catchall term. Metro and Childish are transplants to Atlanta
column8: from St. Louis and South Carolina respectively
column9: but Two-9’s vision of their city expands beyond the confines of the I-285 highway loop.

column1: The only thing missing from B4FRVR is any kind of warmth or apparent joy. At the end of ""Full House"" Wiz Khalifa bursts into laughter
column2: and it immediately becomes the most relatable moment on the tape. He’s clearly having a blast recording
column3: where the rest of Two-9's members appear too reserved to even hint at such enthusiasm. B4FRVR reps its city
column4: gives good vibes
column5:
and perhaps next time Two-9 could enjoy their own party.

Denton
column2: Texas’ Pyramids jettison in and out of the fringes of metal. Their self-titled debut from 2008
column3: released on Hydra Head
column4: was a beautiful mess
column5: filled with lush tones that traced jagged musical directions. Sometimes
column6: they were Emperor reconfigured as a dream pop group
column7: other times
column8: they sounded like someone left a drum machine running on a Lovesliescrushing track. Even though black metal and shoegaze were obvious reference points
column9: Pyramids felt alien to both. They were like explorers making up the map as they go. After a series of collaborations with Horseback
column10: Nadja
column11: and Wraiths
column12: Pyramids finally return with their sophomore album
column13: A Northern Meadow. Here
column14: they’ve developed a front-to-back sound that pushes their metal leanings to the forefront
column15: while also upping the enigmatic glow of their debut. This consistency leads to their strongest effort yet.

column1: A lot has transpired in the Pyramids camp between the two records: namely
column2: Hydra Head shut down and Pyramids moved to Profound Lore
column3: Hydra Head’s successor of sorts as a leader in groundbreaking metal. Vocalist and founding member R. Loren concentrated on his label
column4: Handmade Birds
column5: as well as his side projects White Moth and Sailors With Wax Wings
column6: in that period too. Pyramids never really went away
column7: but they hadn’t made a proper album in some time
column8: so it’s no surprise that they’ve changed quite a bit. Meadow commits to layers upon layers of black metal swirls
column9: cascading riffs never ceasing except to leap to another song. They’ve got a better grip on their ambient influences by infusing them into the guitars rather than leaning on electronics. Even their most obviously black metal song
column10: ""The Earth Melts Into Red Gashes Like the Mouths of Whales""
column11: is smoothed into gleaming waves by how the riffs float and the alternating sonorous voices of Loren and M. Craig. ""I Have Four Sons
column12: All Named for Men We Lost to War"" is one of their most aggressive tracks
column13: but sifted through their vision
column14: it’s stripped of chest-beating primitivism. It reinforces that beauty and heaviness are not mutually exclusive.

column1: In ""I Am So Sorry
column2: Goodbye""
column3: some of the self-titled's jagged beauty reappears. It leads off with a chopped riff dripping with melancholy
column4: and towards the end
column5: the melodies break apart and disintegrate like space debris in slow motion. Closer ""Consilience"" also explores this seductive decay
column6: but in a smoother
column7: more gradual fashion. Guitars spiral ever so gracefully into a black hole
column8: dying slowly but not without one last kiss to the audience. This album benefits from one idea being taken to its limits
column9: as opposed to the free-wheeling of their debut.

column1: For Meadow
column2: Pyramids recruited some crucial names in experimental music and underground metal to augment the core lineup. French black metal genius Vindsval
column3: leader of the shape-shifting but always idiosyncratic Blut Aus Nord
column4: takes over drum programming from D. William
column5: who focuses on electronics. Vindsval drives a black metal pulse beneath the guitars' veil
column6: making him a shadowy figure more in control than it seems. (Funnily enough
column7: Loren does a spot-on impression of Vindsval’s vocals on ""The Substance of Grief Is Not Imaginary"".) Colin Marston
column8: an esteemed metal producer who also abstracts metal in Krallice and Gorguts
column9: contributes guitar
column10: and his touches are all over the record. He
column11: with original guitarist M. Dean
column12: steer the bands towards death metal in the main riffs of ""Grief"" and ""Sons""
column13: and processed through Pyramids
column14: it sounds like Portal with prettier vocals. Vindsval and Marston both contributed to remixes that came as a separate disc on the self-titled record
column15: and their familiarity with Pyramids' vision makes them natural allies.

column1: William Fowler Collins rounds out the guest lineup by providing an ambient undercurrent that runs in and out of the record. This heavy roster of powerful names might send expectations soaring
column2: but where Meadow succeeds is that no personality
column3: from the core group or the guests
column4: dominates. They all fall into and become one with the Pyramids aesthetic. This is in contrast to their Nadja collaboration
column5: which
column6: while excellent
column7: had clear lines where both bands came in. Vindsval’s appearance drew a lot of hype from metal fans anticipating this record
column8: but this isn’t a Blut Aus Nord record outsourced to dudes living in a Texas college town. Pyramids are their own unit
column9: and in owning up to their oddities and making them coalesce
column10: not clash
column11:
Meadow becomes their most confident statement.

column7: the 15-minute finale

Winterfylleth and Wolves in the Throne Room and shapes them toward a clear narrative purpose. Setter of Unseen Snares then simply fades into silence—a concept record beautifully and unapologetically finishing what it started.

It’s difficult to take Madonna at face value. She is on her third generation of pop iconhood
column3: after all

column9: the surprise of Rebel Heart

column1: In a way
column2: Rebel Heart fits squarely into a growing canon that also includes Björk’s Vulnicura

column3: but not limited to

column5: orgasmic samples rises in the mix

column7: tender

column1: The good news is that most of the time

column3: and then the 50 Shades of What-the-Actual-Fuck of ""S.E.X.""

column1: The deep production team on Rebel Heart—Ariel Rechtshaid and Diplo in particular—have previously done work referencing classic '80s Madonna

column1: It’s a curious cocktail

column3: refusing it

column6: while some songs never quite make their point

The cringe-inducing ""Body Shop""—wherein Madonna takes a body-as-a-car metaphor into mortifying territory that makes you wish for an Auto Wrecker: ""You can polish the headlights/ You can smooth out the fender."" (Bon Scott is probably spinning in his grave like a rotisserie chicken.) With songs like that sandwiched between unabashed bangers and tenderhearted treacle

column11:
after 30 years of campaigning for our hearts and minds.

column7: sending screaming wisps out onto the track before sinking slowly into a bubbling
column8: steaming pit of sound. It’s pretty macabre except for a hollow dembow
column9: which moves the scary story along at deceivingly pleasant pace.

column1: Heterocetera might not be a happy recording
column2: but that’s what makes the five-track collection so ambitious. This is Lotic’s third release in just over two years—his first for Tri Angle Records—and perhaps the clearest iteration of his phantasmagorical approach to clinical
column3: after-hours techno. There are no overtures to pleasure
column4: no simple hooks
column5: entry points (save for the ""Ha""
column6: if that does it for you) or clear parallels. The closest analogue to Lotic
column7: at least energetically
column8: might be fellow Texan Travi$ Scott
column9: who makes a similar mess of genre—hip-hop
column10: in Scott’s case—and also brings a gothic energy to club music.

column1: So
column2: imagine this: it's 4 a.m.
column3: and you're in a room lit by a single red light bulb in the corner
column4: Lotic’s ""Slay"" lumbering to life on the system. There is no bassline anchoring the warm
column5: atonal synth lines. Instead
column6: patches of distortion rattle around the skeleton of the track
column7: forming an indistinct textural scaffold of percussion. It sounds like something slowly moving closer to you
column8: perhaps crying to itself. Suddenly
column9: everything in the room—the sounds
column10: the people
column11: the red light—feel like they're closing in around you.

column1: This is what Morgan does best: He takes disparate sounds and doesn’t tether so much as nudge them together
column2: in a way that conveys an active mood. It's what so many other producers strive to do but can’t until they are far older than Morgan. A ""Ha"" sample might seem contrived to some
column3: but he knows that
column4: so he hacks away
column5: letting its guts spill formlessly forth. His masterful way with configured elements provides the illusion of a story without dictating the narrative: Here
column6: you decipher the tones and rhythms
column7:
and conjure your own ideas of good and evil.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21568/homepage_large.b5c80823.jpg|Stackin' N Mackin' Vol. 2|32782.0|White Gzus|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-03-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:41.166307|"

Despite a widespread belief that a criminal record is a badge of honor in hip-hop
column2: the logical endpoint of glorifying criminality in music
column3: the truth is that it’s more likely to distract from an artist’s agenda than solidify it. That's apt to be the case for 28-year-old Chicago rapper Gerik ""Gzus Piece"" Raglin
column4: who was pulled over in Ohio on New Year's Day and arrested for allegedly trafficking over $15
column5: 000 in heroin. One-half of the bubbling Chicago duo White Gzus (alongside Marek ""Blanco Caine"" Fortineaux)
column6: Raglin now faces a legal battle which threatens to blunt a promising career before it even achieves lift-off.

column1: Stackin' N Mackin' Vol. 2 is the duo's second release. A follow-up to their locally celebrated 2014 debut
column2: the tape was recorded partially in the wake of Raglin's legal trouble. Possibly as a result
column3: it can feel rushed
column4: as if they ran out of time focusing the camera and just snapped the photo. What's good and at times great about the White Gzus project is that—despite the slight blur on the image—the picture feels fresh and unique.

column1: Their ambitions are disarmingly straightforward. Initially a side project for both of its members—Gzus Piece and Blanco Caine are both a part of the Treated Crew
column2: alongside recent G.O.O.D. Music signee Holt and producer/former Kanye West DJ Million Dollar Mano—they seem as surprised as their audience to have stumbled upon a rewarding recipe with a handful of familiar ingredients. The building blocks are 808s and sumptuous
column3: enveloping grooves
column4: a throwback to the sounds of labels like Suave House and Rap-A-Lot. Perhaps the best example is lead single ""Return of the G""
column5: a twinkling Snapback-produced track which makes the most of its five minutes with an expansive
column6: immersive sound. But a simple formula helps keep all records in bounds. The group's rapping reflects a UGK-like dichotomy: Gzus Piece is the group's refined half
column7: with a casually clever flow that sounds preternaturally unbothered; Blanco is rawer
column8: more blunt. Their silent partner and musical glue is Mr. E
column9: who produces several beats and is responsible for the tape's mixing and mastering.

column1: Mr. E likes to repurpose hip-hop history to his own ends. At first glance
column2: it can seem distracting. Tracks like ""Still Sippin'"" and ""Volume 2"" flip the same samples as hip-hop staples (Three 6 Mafia's ""Sippin on Syrup"" and Raekwon's ""Verbal Intercourse"" respectively) with which White Gzus could never measure up. Yet this baldly tasteless re-purposing of the classics gives White Gzus an edge over other revivalists. Where others might pay slavish devotion
column3: Mr. E simply swipes the originals and gives them a more modern
column4: functionally effective kick.

column1: This method also short-circuits songwriting liabilities for groups like White Gzus
column2: who are under-funded independent artists without A&Rs or access to high-profile collaborators. After all
column3: the ""Verbal Intercourse"" sample is a classic for reason
column4: and SWV's ""Use Your Heart"" flip on ""Cross Town Classic"" is an immediate canvas which draws on the contrast between Blanco's bruising rap style and its breezy '90s effervescence. This is simply clever production
column5: sampling in the old school sense
column6: deriving its creative force as much from economic necessity as anything else. Tracks without familiar samples can be more hit-or-miss; Mic Terror's chorus on ""Return of the G"" is one of the best on the album
column7: and points to how hooks can be an occasional stumbling block elsewhere. ""Count Up"" is a terrific late '90s throwback with Timbaland-style ribbiting noises
column8: but the sung chorus feels like it could use slight pitch correction to snap more tightly into place.

column1: There are missteps and visible seams here and there
column2: but more songs work than don't. The group is just beginning to map out a new and fertile sound
column3: a constellation of styles that manages to thread between the drill and backpack strains of Chicago hip-hop. If the sudden threat to Gzus Piece's freedom has served to frame the group's music with pathos it previously lacked
column4: then so be it. But in an ideal world
column5: he wouldn't have to go through that
column6: and could instead mine this vein for all it's worth
column7:
since White Gzus really is just getting started.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21471/homepage_large.2ca4db86.jpg|Seth Avett & Jessica Lea Mayfield Sing Elliott Smith|11622.0|Jessica Lea Mayfield|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ramseur']|2015-03-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:13:42.952260|"

It’s not an encouraging sign that Seth Avett and Jessica Lea Mayfield open their Elliott Smith covers album with ""Between the Bars"". If it’s not his biggest hit (that would be the Oscar-nominated ""Miss Misery"")
column2: it’s certainly Smith’s most-covered song by a long shot
column3: with jazz interpretations by Madeleine Peyroux and Christopher O’Riley; faithful renditions by Chris Garneau and someone or something called Saucy Monky; live versions by Metric and Agnes Obel; even a strange performance by Madonna
column4: of all people. Millions of YouTubers with a guitar and a digital camera have uploaded a homemade cover
column5: and are probably still doing so as of this writing.

column1: With so many versions out in the world
column2: it’s difficult to put a new signature on the tune
column3: and maybe Avett and Mayfield should get credit for not even trying to make it their own. Instead
column4: they sing it with an almost defiant reverence
column5: as though consciously blurring the line between cover and karaoke. They dutifully preserve the structure and the tone of the original
column6: adding only a few new details
column7: such as the short
column8: descending bass theme in the intro and the gentle stridency in the acoustic strums. Yet
column9: for all their faithfulness
column10: they can’t quite convey the conflicted emotions or the bleak undercurrents of Smith’s lyrics.

column1: Seth Avett & Jessica Lea Mayfield Sing Elliott Smith is a document of two talented musicians trying to figure Smith out. The duo conceived this project in 2011 when the Ohio singer-songwriter toured with the Avett Brothers. On backstage pianos as well as in professional studios
column2: they picked their favorite tunes
column3: devised new arrangements
column4: and worked out new harmonies. Nearly everything on the album
column5: however
column6: will sound immediately familiar to any Smith fan
column7: and any Smith newcomer is advised to check out Either/Or or XO first. That rambunctious piano still storms its way into ""Baby Britain"" at the same time
column8: as though Avett sampled that part from the original. The guitar notes on ""Ballad of Big Nothing"" still bend into the same shapes. At least they punch up a pretty straight reading of ""Somebody That I Used to Know"" with some electric guitars and a rhythm section—a fine interruption of the album’s general solemnity.

column1: But the only real risk they take is on Mayfield’s sped-up
column2: roughed-up reimagining of ""Roman Candle""
column3: off Smith’s 1994 debut. It’s brash and assertive
column4: with Mayfield turning the violent central lyric (""I want to hurt him
column5: I want to cause him pain"") on its head simply by changing the gender of its deliverer. Most of Smith’s songs sound aggressively lonely
column6: as though he could never get out of his own head to connect with other people; having two voices on these songs could potentially transform Smith’s monologues into conversations
column7: presumably between lovers. Especially on ""Baby Britain"" and ""Somebody That I Used to Know""
column8: Avett and Mayfield strike an easy chemistry together
column9: her exquisitely drowsy drawl offsetting his more expressive vocals. Still
column10: they don’t play up the idea of Sings as a duets album
column11: nor do they try to adjust the songs’ points of view or find new implications in the lyrics. Perhaps in the end they are simply too smitten with the idea of Smith as a beautifully doomed artist to create anything beyond a loving
column12: reverent
column13:
and therefore sheepish tribute.

Black metal has a (somewhat deserved) reputation for militant musical conservatism
column2: with any deviation from form
column3: however slight
column4: meeting with derision from elitists. This stereotype persists even though the most visible and critically lauded bands are often the ones who buck conventions
column5: whether the results succeed or not. (The embrace of Nachtmystium’s half-baked psychedelic black metal is a perfect example
column6: as is any given Liturgy press cycle.) Norway’s Enslaved have coasted on that odd critical goodwill for some time now. While Enslaved’s early 2000s work showed how complex and multi-faceted black metal could be
column7: 2008's Vertebrae tread a little too close to alternative rock
column8: pointing to the danger in conflating black metal ""evolution"" with ""accessibility."" Their more recent albums have dug somewhat back into their black metal roots
column9: but their fascination with other
column10: less extreme forms rock never waned
column11: and on In Times
column12: their 13th album
column13: it officially becomes become their crutch.

column1: Enslaved remain capable performers -- the opener “Thurisaz Dreaming” is filled with prime Norwegian blasting and screeches--but the prog-rock sheen on the record
column2: like they only focused on the softer side of Pink Floyd and Kansas
column3: flattens out the fury. As a result
column4: their raging and their simmering happen on the same wavelength. ""Building With Fire"" touches upon the band's more melodic work from Below the Lights and Isa
column5: but other than that
column6: there isn’t a whole lot differentiating one song from another
column7: and many feel longer than they are.

column1: A lot of this falls on Herbrand Larsen
column2: who provides keyboards and clean vocals. His voice has an angelic pleasantness
column3: serving as foil to bassist and lead vocalist Grutle Kjellson’s rasps
column4: and sometimes it feels that’s all he’s there for. He holds back throughout
column5: refusing to go all-out and overdrive the record. Parts that should feel grand
column6: as a result
column7: often feel bogged down and too comfortable. At the end of ""Nauthir Bleeding""
column8: Kjellson and guitarists Arve Isdal and Ivar Bjørnson (who is a founding member along with Kjellson) rapidly intensify in attempting at reaching something glorious. Instead
column9: Larsen neuters the song with soft-rock mewling
column10: driven by some need to make it palatable
column11: like he’s hosting a theoretical corpsepaint-and-cheese party.

column1: Halfway through the title track
column2: there’s a nearly poppy chorus of vocals that feels like it should liven the mood. It’s not a bad part in and of itself
column3: as in the hands of a capable songwriter or producer—Devin Townsend’s pop-metal maximalism comes to mind—it could be incorporated successfully somewhere else. Here
column4: it's just an odd fit among the dour seriousness surrounding it. Times is in need of ""Havenless""
column5: their anthemic song from Lights
column6: or at least something like it. It would break up the monotony here. Times isn’t offensively bad or controversial
column7: and it might have benefitted from being either. Instead
column8: we’ve got some Black Metal Muzak here
column9: competent musically but too timid to go into the depths
column10: emotional
column11: musical or otherwise
column12:
that black metal should strive for.

Fox’s ""Empire"" is many things
column2: all of them absurd. It’s a hip-hop musical (they don’t do well) about a family dynasty (rap has very few) led by a tenacious singing mogul (hmm) and the drug smuggling
column3: songwriting wife who took a fall so that her husband and sons might prosper. It’s a ratings juggernaut
column4: smashing decades-old records for increases in viewership with every episode. It’s a hit on social media thanks to the scathing wrath and inimitable style of Taraji P. Henson’s matriarchal lead
column5: Cookie. Unlike Fox’s last flagship musical serial ""Glee""
column6: however
column7: it is not matching its improbable Nielsen success on the Billboard charts thus far.

column1: This is not for a lack of talent. Empire’s resident musical supervisor is none other than Timbaland (with assistance from sometime collaborator Jim Beanz)
column2: who has supplied show creators Lee Daniels and Danny Strong with polished
column3: radio-ready sounds. Even so
column4: the ripped-from-the-headlines story arcs that make the show so enjoyable for hardcore music fans sometimes hinder its music. The show’s lead performers are feuding brothers Jamal and Hakeem Lyon (played respectively by the pensive Jussie Smollett and the preening Bryshere Gray AKA ""Yazz the Greatest""). Jamal is the Frank Ocean-reminiscent singer
column5: both in his yearning
column6: cerebral songwriting and his quest to find acceptance for his sexuality. Rapper Hakeem is a bad-boy type
column7: a sort of amalgam of Tyga
column8: Chris Brown and Kid Ink. Hakeem’s girlfriend Tiana (Serayah McNeill) is an R&B chanteuse who seems styled after Rihanna. It’s never clear whether ""Empire""’s music is meant to exist in the present mainstream hip-hop landscape or to mirror it as commentary.

column1: It’s frequently suggested on the show that Hakeem values the night life more than his craft
column2: and if the character is intended to be a sendup of pop-rap underachievers
column3: it’s a respectable stroke of withering humor. Unfortunately there’s very little space between the performances on the show depicting Hakeem off his game and the ""good"" Yazz performances included on the soundtrack. The songs that are meant to validate him as a talent are ingratiating aspirational boilerplate. His calling card ""Drip Drop"" made waves online
column4: but the mechanical precision of the performance kills it dead
column5: and ""Empire""’s biggest Hot 100 success is the Jamal-led ""You’re So Beautiful""
column6: anyhow.

column1: Jussie Smollett’s Jamal is the light of the ""Empire"" soundtrack. When his lithe warble cuts through these tracks
column2: you’re not cocking your head to the side to imagine a star; you’re hearing the real thing. He’s flashy on Tim’s sinister horn stomp ""Keep Your Money"" and sufficiently wounded on ""Good Enough"" to distract from striking similarities to Justin Timberlake’s ""What Goes Around… Comes Around"". Smollett nearly upstages Yazz with an unhinged vocal on the chorus of ""No Apologies"" and lends gravitas duetting with Estelle on her recent single ""Conqueror"" that the song lacked as a solo cut. Small wonder Columbia recently signed him to a solo deal in real life. (One hopes a similar windfall awaits Timbaland protege V. Bozeman
column3: who wowed viewers with the rousing ""What Is Love"" in the show’s pilot episode
column4: only to vanish for the majority of the season.)

column1: The soundtrack’s celebrity collaborators
column2: meanwhile
column3: are a mixed bag. Jennifer Hudson stops by to guide the nonmusical elder Lyon brother Andre through a mental health crisis on ""Remember the Music"" (and pops up alongside Juicy J for the carefree ""Whatever Makes You Happy""). J-Hud’s voice is gobstopping as ever here
column4: but ""Remember the Music"" flubs a shot at mining her tear-jerking majesty on a piddling arrangement. Mary J. Blige abets Terrence Howard’s patriarch Lucious Lyon on the stirring piano ballad ""Shake Down""
column5: which succeeds in spite of (or perhaps because of) Howard’s histrionic vocal. The cracked-genius guest spot of the set is Courtney Love
column6: who guests as Elle Dallas
column7: a fallen rock goddess staging a risky comeback. Her weathered torch song ""Walk Out on Me"" suggests she could do Lana Del Rey better than Lana Del Rey if she ever set the guitar down for good.

column1: ""Empire"" is a wonder of absurd tricks and unforeseen turns
column2: but the ultimate goal—rendering its music as something more than just a side platter to gripping TV—proves elusive. Where Jussie Smollett and the growing roster of famous faces lining up for guest appearances are concerned
column3: it’s easy. But it’s still hard to see Yazz as much more than promising and eager for now. The ""Empire"" songwriting apparatus is still coming together
column4: it would seem
column5: but with upwards of ten million pairs of eyes trained on the show week after week
column6: success can’t be far off. They’re warped enough to turn Dire Straits’ ""Money for Nothing"" into swag rap and to feed Courtney Love a gospel choir. There’s nothing they won’t try
column7: and it’s exhilarating: Sooner or later
column8:
they’ll probably strike gold.

For sensitive souls of a certain vintage
column2: Nate Mendel is a hero simply for playing bass on the first two albums by Sunny Day Real Estate
column3: the band that helped elevate emo from mere ""emotional hardcore"" shorthand to a national security threat. Since 1995
column4: however
column5: Mendel has served as bassist for Foo Fighters
column6: trading underground renown for stadium stardom. But while Mendel has been Dave Grohl’s longest-serving foot soldier
column7: he’s also the most unassuming one—he’s neither as iconic as Pat Smear
column8: as flamboyant as Taylor Hawkins
column9: nor as tattooed as Chris Shiflett. Lieutenant represents his first solo bid
column10: and the new alias feels like a sly nod to his deputy ranking in the Foos' megalithic machine. As the outrageously titled but tastefully executed If I Kill This Thing We’re All Going to Eat for a Week makes clear
column11: Mendel is not the sort of guy to celebrate going solo by screaming ""I was always caged and NOW I’M FREEEEEEEEEE!"" Humble and soft-spoken to a fault
column12: he often sounds as if he’s meekly tiptoeing around the shadows of his own spotlight.

column1: Though the album boasts a formidable guest list of fellow alt-rock lifers—Modest Mouse drummer Joe Plummer
column2: Page Hamilton of Helmet
column3: Sunny Day’s Jeremy Enigk
column4: and fellow Foo Shiflett—there are no scene-stealing cameos here; everyone involved respectfully adapts to Mendel’s relaxed
column5: low-key wavelength. In sharp contrast to his day job
column6: Lieutenant favors unwaveringly pleasant
column7: gently swaying sing-alongs that would fit comfortably amid the more rustic end of the 21st-century Sub Pop roster
column8: as a buffer between the Shins and the Head and the Heart (whose Josiah Johnson also appears here). But even with the decibel meter dialed down to accommodate his wounded croon
column9: Mendel struggles to assert himself
column10: flattening out the album’s dynamic variation in the process.

column1: The music bounds from breezy
column2: string-sweetened chamber-folk (""Belle Epoque"") to Weezer-via-Ocasek power-pop (""Rattled"") to brooding power ballads (""Lift the Sheet"")
column3: but Mendel maintains a passive
column4: shoulder-shrugging presence through it all
column5: keeping the album’s heart rate steady
column6: obscuring his lyrical intent
column7: and muting its emotional impact. It’s an issue that’s only compounded when the arrangements get busier
column8: like on the shifty
column9: brass-bolstered ""Sink Sand""
column10: which sounds like a holdover from the Foos’ New Orleans sojourn on Sonic Highways. (By contrast
column11: Mendel’s voice finds its most natural fit on ""Some Remove""
column12: a pretty '70s soft-rock throwback whose gauzy Rhodes organ fuses perfectly with his wistful sigh.) Given the album’s dream-team assembly of players and broad instrumental palette
column13: Mendel clearly has ambitions to create elaborate songs within intimate spaces. But listening to If I Kill This Thing... feels like staring into a terrarium: It's easy to admire the attention to detail and lovingly crafted quaintness
column14:
but hard to get inside.

As a singer in HSY
column2: Anna Mayberry’s ornery snarl usually gets washed into the background. The Toronto noise band's sludge-punk clamor reaches volumes that rival METZ or Cellphone (Toronto has proven in recent years to excel in producing impressively loud acts)
column3: and the cacophony might not always offer the greatest support for a multifaceted voice like Mayberry’s. Her nuanced tone is buried even further under the primal shouts of lead singer
column4: Jude
column5: but if you listen beneath the din
column6:
it's clear that Mayberry actually has an exquisite voice. You can't help but wonder what it would sound like front and center.

Enter her other project ANAMAI
column7: which is
column8: in some respects
column9: the polar opposite of HSY. Originally an outlet for Mayberry’s solo songs
column10: ANAMAI came to fruition when she met electronic artist and producer David Psutka
column11: a.k.a. Egyptrixx
column12: whose background in London dance music places him far outside of Mayberry’s universe. But the two have found a common ground
column13: and Mayberry’s solo project has evolved into a duo. Together
column14: Mayberry and Egyptrixx have taken her ideas and formed songs rich with texture and palpable kinetic power. Their debut full-length
column15: Sallows
column16: is nothing like their main projects
column17:
focusing on an eerie experimental folk that brings a new kind of heaviness to Mayberry’s vocals.

To make way for Mayberry’s rippling voice
column18: songs are kept rather sparse. Fingerpicked electric guitars are given space to swell up with each note
column19: mingling with Mayberry’s echoes into a thick fog. Sometimes
column20: drums and tambourines enter the picture
column21: giving songs like ""Everyone"" and ""Black Crow"" more movement
column22: but ANAMAI have established an inherently deliberate pace. On ""Half""
column23: Mayberry languidly draws out a story of a potential romance over six minutes of a metronomic drone. Intermittently
column24: she replaces choruses with one-liners like ""We kill time
column25: sung with an ominous gravity. Sallows also includes three tracks from ANAMAI’s 2013 self-titled EP—""Mute Flames""
column26: ""Altar Coals"" and ""Black Crow""—and they are the album’s most propulsive moments
column27:
polished and amplified to align with the whole.

With almost every song purposefully crossing the five-minute mark
column28: Psutka's feel for atmosphere comes into play. Mayberry’s dirges come couched in cinematic settings that recall the early-rock'n'roll darkness of Timber Timbre. On ""Mute Flames""
column29: Mayberry’s fragmented phrases are placed beneath a swirling scrim of alien sounds. ANAMAI's ambitions lie in the same vein as Grouper or Julianna Barwick
column30: and while they haven't mastered the mood in one swift endeavor
column31: they haven't deviated too far from the template. ANAMAI may not be as pummelling as a HSY record
column32: but their metaphysical weight makes up for it
column33: producing an even more striking result than Mayberry’s other band."|20312.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20312-sallows/|7.1|Melody Lau

Helsinki speed metal quartet Ranger's 2013 EP Knights of Darkness captured all the classic
column2: leather-clad menace of the pre-thrash early '80s with a demonic grin on its face. Few younger bands capture just how fucking fun heavy metal can be to listen to
column3: but Ranger take riffs and speed very seriously and little else
column4: which appeals to those wanting a rush without the seriousness of other
column5: more extreme genres. On their full-length debut
column6: Where Evil Dwells
column7: they retain much of what made Knights memorable
column8: while tweaking their sound just slightly to accommodate a longer running time.

column1: With two new guitarists
column2: Ville Valtonen and Mikael Haavisto
column3: Ranger throw in some classic NWOBHM licks in addition to the mix of Canadian and German speed metal they’ve cut their teeth on thus far. The melodic leads and anthemic vocals of ""Dead Zone""
column4: for example
column5: could be from Angel Witch or a pre-Bruce Dickinson Iron Maiden cut. Where Knights proved just how relentless they can be
column6: Evil reveals an ear for catchiness too. ""Phantom Soldier"" features some of their most gripping riffs
column7: especially the bridge breakdown. You can easily imagine singer Dimi Pontiac (who also plays bass) whipping a crowd into a fist-pumping frenzy over it.

column1: With a need to make a strong debut statement comes sharper production
column2: and Pontiac’s vocals benefit the most. His voice is much higher in the mix
column3: which greater outlines his snarl. His high screams are still in evidence

column2: serif;"">""I love drums

column7: serif;"">
column8: the British/Mauritian composer has mixed hip-hop
column9: soul and Afro-Caribbean dub with the Sega music of his homeland
column10: resulting in hypnotic
column11: tribal-infused dance grooves. Mo’s music is an acquired taste; beneath the percussive clatter is a rich
column12: minimalistic approach that grows more contagious as it plays.

column2: serif;"">For Mo’s new EP

column5: blending obscure clips into his own jaunty African-themed melodies. He ditches the lo-fi aesthetic of his previous work for a clean mix that maximizes his use of crackling vinyl (""I Find My Eyes"") and woodwind instruments (""On My Way""
column6: ""Sumerian Mother""). In some ways
column7: the new gloss is welcomed: Mo’s music is understated enough

column9: though: He recedes into his music
column10: his words never louder than a mutter as the beat unfolds. He unites disparate tones the same way Paul White does—by taking the most random acts of everyday life—a chant
column11: a mouth click—and creating something clever.

column2: serif;"">There aren’t enough bright moments on How I
column3: which breezes by far too quickly without much impact. Even the bright spots feel underdeveloped and none of the songs ever go anywhere. Take the Deniece Williams-sampled ""How I"" as an example: Here
column4: Mo loops a lyric from ""Silly"" (""How I want you""/ ""How I love you"") and supplants it with layered drums and shakers. The concept works initially
column5: except Mo never builds upon it; instead
column6: he leans on the idea until it expires a short time later. The same goes for ""Sega Chuckle""
column7: which has the best drum work of all the instrumentals
column8: but Mo spoils it with shrieking vocal clips.

column2: serif;"">Mo knows how to make great EPs. 2012's Banana Wine and 2013's Tusk Dance
column3: serif;""> trekked the same spacious path as Drum Talking
column4: but they seemed to stick. I can revisit songs like ""Bomptious"" and ""Biddies"" and feel the same good feelings as when they released. Without a strong anchor
column5: How I finds Mo Kolours adrift
column6:
still searching for the right formula to catapult his sound.

What does the future look like for former members of a joke-rap group? What if things blew apart just as you stopped joking? Das Racist’s career arc was never an obvious one—sometimes it was hard to tell if they were shrugging or lunging at us—and its solo members are now puzzling their way through the aftermath of an ambiguous legacy. Himanshu Suri
column2: aka Heems

column6: he offers vivid images in a halting
column7: tom-roll cadence: ""Your dad mad

column9: why you crying? I thought that we had the spirit of the lion/ He take it out on you

column12: bellowing delivery

column1: Eat Pray Thug isn’t lacking in ideas

column3: and there are long stretches where it’s much harder to connect to Heems’ persona. ""Sometimes""
column4: the opening track
column5: produced by longtime collaborator Gordon Voidwell
column6: is about ""dualities
column7: as the rapper told both NPR and the Times
column8: but here is an example of how that plays out in the song: ""Sometimes I’m like this
column9: sometimes I’m like that/ Sometimes I’m pretty thin
column10: sometimes I’m pretty fat."" Tossed-off lines like these lack the smart-dumb zing of his Das Racist writing or
column11: really
column12: any zing at all. Heems drones the word ""clarity
column13: clarity"" for a few bars on the song
column14: then deadpans: ""Sometimes I write hard
column15: sometimes I’m mad lazy/ I just repeat words like ‘clarity
column16: ’ fucking crazy."" It’s DOA as a punchline

column3: and they feel like unwelcome holdovers from Heems’ previous life. Wordplay like ""The great gats be the TEC-9 and AK"" (from ""Hubba Hubba"") only remind us how good he used to be at this sort of high/low culture switch-up. ""Made enough friends
column4: like I play in the Wrens
column5: he raps on ""Sometimes""
column6: and as one of the people who actually gets that joke

column3: ""Damn
column4: Girl""
column5: and ""Home"" are stabs at accessibility that fail for a more prosaic and difficult-to-circumvent reason: Heems’ voice. Landing somewhere between pained groan and mocking whine

When asked recently to name five records important to him
column2: experimental composer Chris Madak (who often works as Bee Mask) included ""Clutch""
column3: a clattering track by Pearson Sound (aka David Kennedy) that sounds as if someone mapped a drum machine onto a Rubik's Cube. ""I just have a straightforwardly lizard-brained...'whoa…KILLER' reaction to hearing David’s rhythmic chops going off
column4: Madak said
column5: going on to note that watching DJs slip the tune into a set ""was like watching someone execute a really hair-raising parallel parking job in one shot."" Therein lies the thrilling paradox in Kennedy's dance productions: they are inscrutable
column6: bordering on the avant-garde
column7: and yet still provoke primal
column8: dunderheaded glee. We're all still cavemen bashing sticks and rocks together
column9: but one caveman taught himself polyrhythms.

column1: Kennedy has honed his highly rhythmic style over the course of a dozen-plus singles as Pearson Sound
column2: most productively since he dropped his Ramadanman title in 2011. He's done so as one of the UK's most adventurous DJs and as co-head (with Ben UFO and Pangaea) of London's Hessle Audio label
column3: whose sparse release schedule has proved mostly bulletproof. (The label's weekly Thursday broadcast on Rinse FM
column4: largely helmed by Ben UFO
column5: is vital listening for fans of underground electronic music.) But whereas Kennedy's peers have cobbled together styles from house
column6: techno
column7: grime
column8: and the remains of dubstep—and therefore tread in the middle of some Venn diagram or another—Kennedy's work seems to exist at a single nexus point
column9: fully discrete
column10: tangential to his surroundings.

column1: Pearson Sound is the long awaited debut album: nine terse
column2: often brutish rhythm tracks laid out end-to-end
column3: because ambient interludes and extended outros are for mama's boys and DJs
column4: respectively. Kennedy's compositions consist chiefly of drums
column5: most recognizable as such
column6: and so the experience of listening to nine tracks in a row is not unlike having some dental work done under local anaesthetic—there's lots of painless drilling
column7: popping
column8: and clicking
column9: perhaps some tingling. About 40 minutes later
column10: it's over.

column1: Pearson Sound re-calcifies Kennedy's aesthetic after recent releases saw him dip his toes into tonal arpeggios and gummy grime melodies. His tracks are economical and athletic
column2: prizing both strength and dexterity. This is borne out in tracks such as ""Glass Eye""
column3: which doesn't seek to bash but dizzy
column4: and does so with a paucity of elements: just some shivering snares and a liquid string figure.

column1: Kennedy twists his drums just so
column2: playing with dub and house conventions. His snares aren't treated with delay so much as suspended in gelatin
column3: left to quiver
column4: quiver
column5: quiver until finding a state of rest. He's adept at using tonal percussion
column6: crafting melodies from toms and congas the way some producers use pianos. Opener ""Asphalt Sparkle"" features what is either a hi-hat playing 16th notes or a chain being slowly pulled. The track's rhythm doesn't swing; it cranks. There's a natural
column7: but ephemeral
column8: comparison to the ""drum tracks"" that came out of Chicago in the mid- and late-1980s. Drum tracks were tools to help DJs house-ify their sets; Kennedy is composing with rhythm
column9: an outgrowth of Shackleton's early dubwise singles or the nimble grooves of bass explorer Loefah
column10: placing him amongst the small group of producers who learned more from dubstep than how to book DJ gigs.

column1: What's refreshing about Kennedy's tracks—alluded to in Madak's quote above—is the amount of fun he wrangles out of such a sparse and austere template. The melodic elements are bright and whipsmart. The synthesized horn sound that buoys ""Headless"" sounds like it's being played by a sad emoji. ""Swill"" is like the ballroom classic ""The Ha Dance"" reflected in a funhouse mirror. ""Crank Call"" is a disorienting tour de force
column2: featuring a ringing telephone
column3: heavy breathing
column4: and what sounds like a filter sweep being performed on a pack of laughing hyenas.

column1: Perhaps unsurprisingly coming from an artist who mostly bangs on cans
column2: the nine tracks on Pearson Sound don't represent any kind of narrative or linear progression. Even for a dance album—a notoriously tricky medium—it can feel disassociated
column3: so just as you'll never doubt you're listening to Pearson Sound
column4: you may forget you're listening to Pearson Sound. Another quibble: The harsher
column5: craggier sound palette used here—the product of analog gear
column6: reading the press junket tea leaves—strips these tracks
column7: subtly

column9: in addition to ""REM"" and ""Untitled""). Still
column10: Pearson Sound tracks are lessons in how to push boundaries without sacrificing dance music's primeval instincts
column11:
and Pearson Sound contains nine such lessons. Bang some things together in celebration.

For over a decade
column2: the Late Night Tales mix series has found extended life by providing artists—mostly European

Essentially just natural runoff from the glut of afterparty compilations that overstuffed the ""various"" placards in dance music sections in record stores everywhere for most of the early 2000s

column5: the beach house)

column1: Thanks to appearances from the likes of Air

column1: In between those three pillars sits an equitable spread of current electronic (Holy Other
column2: Teebs

column4: folk music (Alela Diane
column5: Songs of Green Pheasant) and indie rock (School of Seven Bells
column6: HEALTH

even if you do get the feeling Hopkins prefers to spend his late nights alone.

""Paying""
column2: the centerpiece of Sarah Bethe Nelson’s debut album
